superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter d d
The eighth letter of the alphabet: called daAlN. It is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, not with the breath only]; and of the letters termed niTaEiyRap [pronounced by pressing the tip of the tongue against the upper gums and suddenly withdrawing it], like T and t. (TA.) It is substituted, agreeably with general usage, for the t of the form AifotaEala and its variations, when the first radical letter is z, as in AizodaAda [for AizotaAda]; or c, as in AidRakara [for Aicodakara, originally Aicotakara]; or d, as in AidRaraOa [for AidodaraOa, originally AidotaraOa]: and sometimes after j, as in AijodamaEuwA, a dial. var. of AijotamaEuwA: also, sometimes, for the pronominal affix t after d, as in jaladRu for jaladotu; and after z, as in juzodu for juzotu: it is also substituted for the t of tawolajN, contr. to analogy: and it occurs substituted for T, contr. to general usage, as in maradaI for maraTaI. (MF.) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Four.]

R. Q. 1 daOodaOa c
R. Q. 1. daOodaOa, inf. n. daOodaOapN and diYodaMCN, He (a camel, S) ran (EadaA) most vehemently, (S, M, K, TA,) going a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN [q. v.]: (TA:) or hastened, or sped, and ran, or rose in his running; syn. OasoraEa wa OaHoDara: (K:) accord. to AA, daOodaMCN↓ is [a subst., or quasiinf. n., signifying] a quick pace or manner of going: and [the inf. n.] daOodaOapN is syn. with UiHoDaArN: and in the Nawádir [app. of Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee] it is said that dawodaOa (inf. n. dawodaOapN) and tawodaOa (inf. n. tawodaOapN) and kawodaOa (inf. n. kawodaOapN) are syn. with EadaA; and that daOodaOapN and diYodaMCN signify a camel's proceeding with short steps, at a rate quicker than that of the pace termed HafadN [q. v.]: accord. to the Kf, these two words signify the going a pace quicker than that termed xababN [q. v.], not so quick as that termed rabaEapN [q. v.]. (TA.) You say, daOodaOati AldRaAbRapu The beast ran a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN. (M.) And daOodaOa fiI Uivorihi He followed him, having him near before him. (M, * K, * TA.) And hence, daOodaOa minohu He ran (OaHoDara) to escape from him, being followed by him, and being near before him; as also tadaOodaOa↓. (M.) ＝ -A2- He put a thing in motion. (M, K.) ― -b2- And, contr., He rendered a thing, still, or motionless. (M, K.)

R. Q. 2 tadaOodaOa c
R. Q. 2. tadaOodaOa: see above. ― -b2- Also It (a stone, TA) rolled; or rolled along or down: (K, TA:) it (anything) rolled, or rolled along or down, before one, (M, TA,) and went away: IAth says that it may be from tadahodaha. (TA.) ― -b3- It became, or was put, in motion. (TA.) ― -b4- And, contr., It became, or was rendered, still, or motionless. (TA.)

daOodaON c
daOodaON: see daOodaMCN, in three places.

daOodaOapN c
daOodaOapN inf. n. of R. Q. 1 [q. v.]. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Also The hasty replying of a foolish, or stupid, person. (T, TA.) ― -b3- The sound of the falling (T, M, K) of stones in a torrent, (T,) or of a stone upon the bed of a torrent: (M, K:) or the falling of stones in the bed of a torrent. (Lth, IKtt, O.) ― -b4- And The sound of one's moving, or putting in motion, [or rocking,] a child in the cradle (K, TA) in order that it may sleep. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

daOodaMCN c
daOodaMCN (AA, T, S, M, K) and diYodaMCN↓ (AA, S, M, K) and duWoduwoCN↓, (M, K,) all with medd, (TA,) The last (of the days, T) of the [lunar] month; (AA, T, S, M, K;) as also daOodaOu↓: (M:) or the day of doubt; yawomu AlXRakRi [generally meaning the day of which one doubts whether it be the last of Shaabán or the first of Ramadán; but here app. relating to any month]: (TA:) or daOodaON↓ signifies the day, (M,) or night, (TA,) of which one doubts whether it be the last of one month or the first of the next month: (M, TA:) so says Kr: (M:) or the first word and the second (M, K) and the third (K) signify the twenty-fifth, and the twenty-sixth, and the twentyseventh, night: (M, K:) or the twenty-eighth night, and the twenty-ninth: or each of these two is called daOodOapN↓; and the two together, AldRaMdiYu: (Th, M:) or [each of] three nights of the end of the month; (K, TA;) which are [also] called layaAliI AlmuHaAqi: (TA:) pl. daMdiYu, (M, K,) and, by poetic license, daMdK: (M:) or the daMdiY are three nights of the latter part of the month, before those called lyAlI AlmHAq: (T, S:) thus says A 'Obeyd; and IAar says the like: or they are the three nights that are after the mHAq; and are so called because the moon hastens therein to become invisible; from the phrase daOodaOapu AlbaEiyri: As says that three of the nights of the month are called the mHAq; and three, the dMdY; and these latter are the last; and AHeyth says the like. (T.) AldRiYodaMCu↓ signifies also The last part of the night. (Kr, M.) And layolapN daOodaON↓ and daOodaOapN↓ and daOodaMCN and daOodaMCapN↓, (M, K, TA,) of which the first two are the most common, mean A dark night: (TA:) or a very dark night: (M, K:) because of the concealment of the moon therein. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also R. Q. 1.

layolapN daOodaMCapN c
layolapN daOodaMCapN: see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.

duWoduwoCN c
duWoduwoCN: see daOodaMCN.

diYodaMCN c
diYodaMCN: see daOodaMCN, in two places.

1 daOaba c
1. daOaba, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
daAa^a
, (T, M, A, K,) inf. n. daOobN (T, S, M, A, K) and daOabN (T, M, A, K) and duWuwbN, (T, S, M, A, K,) He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself; (T, S, A, K;) and wearied himself, or became wearied; (S, A, K;) in his work, (S, A, K,) or in a thing, (T,) and in a journey or journeying; (T, A;) in which last case, daOabato is said of a she-camel, (T,) or of a daAbRap [or horse or the like]: (A:) or he held on, or continued, (M, and Bd in viii. 54,) in his work, and his way. (Bd ibid.) See also 4. Hence, AllRayolu waAlnRahaAru yadoOabaAni fiI QEotiqaAbihimaA (tropical:) [The night and the day hold on their course in their alternating]. (A.) ― -b2- daOobN (K) and duWuwbN (TA) also signify The act of driving vehemently; and i. q. TarodN [the act of driving away, hunting, &c.]. (K, TA.)

4 AdOb c
4. AdOb, (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. UidoMbN, (T,) He made another, (S, A, K,) his hired man, and his beast, (A,) to strive, labour, toil, or exert himself; (S, A, K;) he fatigued, or wearied, (T, S, A, K,) another, (S, K,) his hired man, (A,) and his beast: (T, A:) or he made another, and anything, to hold on, of continue: and AdObhu also signifies OaHowajapu UilaI AldRuWuwbi [he made him to be in need of striving, &c.; or of holding on, or continuing]: (M:) and OadabuwA is used by a rájiz, but not necessarily by poetic license, for OadoOabuwA. (IAar, M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AdOb AlsRayora [He pursued the journey laboriously, or with energy; or he held on, or continued, the journey]: (S, M, L, K, in art. msd; and M and L in art. sOd:) and [in like manner] you say, sayoranaA daOabonaA↓ [for
fiI sayorinaA, or perhaps fI is omitted by inadvertence]. (TA in art. nHb.)

daOobN c
daOobN (T, S, M, A, K) and daOabN↓ (S, M, K) [both originally inf. ns. of 1: and hence,] (tropical:) A custom, manner, habit, or wont: (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K:) an affair, a business, or a concern: (Zj, T, S, A, K:) and a case, state, or condition: (Zj, * T, * S, * M, A, * K: *) and a deed, or work. (A.) You say, hecaA daOobuka (tropical:) This is [thy custom, &c.:] thy affair, business, or concern: or thy case, state, or condition: and thy deed, or work. (A.) Zj says that kadaOobi Mli firoEawona [in the Kur iii. 9 &c.] means, accord. to the lexicologists, (assumed tropical:) Like the case of the people of Pharaoh: but in his opinion, like the striving, labouring, or toiling, of the people of Pharaoh in their unbelief, and their leaguing together and aiding one another against Moses. (T.)

daOaba c
daOaba: see the next preceding paragraph.

daYibN c
daYibN: see daAYibN.

rajulN daWuwbN EalaI XaIoCK c
rajulN daWuwbN EalaI XaIoCK [A man who strives, labours, toils, or exerts himself, and wearies himself, or who holds on, or continues, with energy, to do a thing]. (M.)

daAYibN c
daAYibN (TA, and so in a copy of the S,) and daYibN↓ (TA, and so in two copies of the S,) Striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself, and wearying himself, in his work [&c.: or holding on, or continuing, therein: see the verb]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] layolapN daAYibapN [A hard, fatiguing, or continuous, night-journey]. (M and K in art. mrs.) ― -b3- And AldRaAYibaAni (tropical:) The night and the day; (S, A, K;) which [are so called because they] hold on their course (yadoOabaAni) in their alternating. (TA.)

1 daOala c
1. daOala, aor.
daAa^a
, inf. n. daOolN (S, M, K) and daOalN (K [perhaps a mistake for the next, which is well known but not mentioned in the K, but see caOala,]) and daOalaAnN (S, M) and daOalaI, (M, K,) He walked, or went, in a weak manner, (M, K,) and with haste: (M:) or he ran with short steps: (M, K:) or he walked, or went, in a brisk, or sprightly, manner: (K:) or he walked, or went, as though labouring in his gait, by reason of briskness, or sprightliness: (M:) [or he went along by little and little, stealthily, lest he should make a sound to be heard: for] daOolN is syn. with xatolN: or, accord. to AZ, it signifies the walking, or going, in a manner resembling that which is termed xatolN; and in the manner of him who is heavily burdened, or overburdened: and As, in describing the manner in which horses go, explains daOalaAnN as signifying the walking, or going, with short steps, and in an unusual manner, as though heavily burdened, or overburdened. (S.) [See also caOala.] ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] daOala lahu, aor. as above, inf. n. daOolN and daOalaAnN, He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; syn. xatalahu: (M, K:) [and daAOalahu↓ signifies the same: or he practised with him mutual deceit, delusion, &c.: for] mudaAOalapN is syn. with muxaAtalapN; and sometimes it is with a quick pace: (AA, T, K:) you say, daOalotu lahu and daAOalotuhu: (AA, T, TA:) and AlcRiYobu badoOalu lilogazaAli liyaOokulahu i. e. yaxotuluhu [The wolf deceives, &c., the gazelle, or young gazelle, that he may eat him]. (AZ, T, TA.)

3 daARa^a
3: see the last sentence of the paragraph above.

daOolN c
daOolN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

duWulN c
duWulN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

duYilN c
duYilN, and sometimes it is pronounced duWulN↓, The jackal; as also daOalaAnN↓ and daOolN↓: and the wolf: and a certain small animal resembling what is called Aibonu EirosK [the weasel]: (K accord. to the TA: [accord. to the CK, and app. most MS. copies of the K, daOolN↓ has the last two significations, and not the first signification: but this is inconsistent with what follows the last signification in the K, as it would require us to read that AldRaOolu, instead of AldRuYilu, which is well known as the correct form, is the name of the father of a certain tribe:]) duYilN has the last of these significations: (T, S:) or it signifies a certain small animal resembling the fox; and this is well known: and accord. to Kr. duWulN↓ signifies a certain small animal; but this is not known: and accord. to him also, daOalaAnN↓, with fet-h to the C, signifies the wolf; (M;) as also caOalaAnN; (TA;) or so daOolaAnN↓ and caOolaAnN; and also the jackal. (Lth in art. cOl.) duYilN is the only instance of the measure fuEilN (S, K) known to Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, (S,) i. e. Th: (TA:) but there are several other instances: (MF, TA:) [one of these is ruYimN, or AlrRuYimu.]

daOolaAnN c
daOolaAnN and daOalaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

duWoluwlN c
duWoluwlN A calamity, or misfortune: (S, M, O, K:) pl. daMliylu. (S.) And Confusion. (K.) You say, waqaEa Alqawomu fiI duWoluwlK The people, or party, fell into confusion in respect of their case or affairs. (S.)

daWuwlN c
daWuwlN [That runs in the manner termed daOalaAnN, inf. n. of 1,] is [an epithet] from AldAlAn [i. e. AldRaOalaAnu], which signifies a kind of running, as also daOAlyn↓ and dAAlyl↓ [i. e. daMliynu and daMlylu, pls. of daOalaAnN; the latter irreg., like caMliylu pl. of daOalaAnN, q. v.]. (Ham p. 458.) [See also caWuwlN.]

daMliylu dMlyl
daMliylu and daMliynu: see what next precedes.

1 daOaA c
1. daOaA, first pers. daOawotu, aor. yadoOaI, inf. n. daOowN: see 1 in the next art.

1 daOaI c
1. daOaI, and daOaA, aor. yadoOaI, (T, M, K,) inf. n. daOoIN, (T, M,) of the former verb, (M,) and daOowN, (T, K,) of the latter verb, (K,) said of a wolf, (M, K,) [and of a man, as shown below,] He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him. (T, M, K.) You say, daOayotu lahu, (S, K,) aor. OadoOaIo lahu, inf. n. daOoIN, I deceived, deluded, &c., it, namely, a thing, (S, K,) or him, namely, a man; (so in one of my copies of the S;) and so daOawotu lahu. (S, M.) And AlcRiYobu yadoOaI lilogazaAli The wolf deceives, deludes, &c., the gazelle, or the young gazelle: (S, M:) or walks, or goes, in the manner of him who deceives, deludes, &c., to the gazelle, or the young gazelle. (T.)

daOoIN c
daOoIN and diYiIRN↓ and duYiIRN↓, (M, K,) the last said by IB, on the authority of As, to be pl. of [the n. un.] daOoyapN↓, of the measure fuEuwlN, [originally duWuwIN,] (TA,) The vertebræ of the kaAhil [or withers (app. of a camel)] and of the back: or the cartilages of the breast: or the ribs thereof, where it meets the side: (M, K:) or AldRaOayaAtu↓ signifies the ribs of [i. e. within] the shoulderblade, three on either side; (IAar, M, K;) sing. daOoyapN↓: (M:) or daOoyapN↓, (T,) or daOoIN, (S,) signifies the part of the camel against which lies the [piece of wood called] Zalifap of the saddle, and which is [often] galled thereby: (T, S:) or daOoIN is the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of daOoyapN↓, and signifies the vertebræ of the withers, in the part between the two shoulder-blades, of the camel, peculiarly; (Lth, T;) and the pl. [of daOoyapN] is daOayaAtN↓: (Lth, T, S:) or the dOyAt are the vertebræ of the neck: or the vertebræ of the spine: (AO, T:) or the two ribs next to the waAhinataAni are called the daOoyataAni: AZ says that the Arabs knew not the term dOyAt in relation to the neck, but they knew it in relation to the ribs, as signifying six [ribs] next to the stabbing-place of the camel, three on either side; and this is correct: (T:) [and it is said in the L, in art. jnH, that daOoIN signifies the ribs of the back, of a man, which are called the jawaAniH, pl. of jaAniHapN, six in number, three on the right and three on the left:] the pl. of daOoIN [or rather the quasi-pl. n.] is daYiIRN, like as DaYiynN is of DaOonN, and maEiyzN of maEozN: (S:) and, accord. to IB, duYiIRN is a pl. of daOoyapN↓, as mentioned above, meaning the vertebræ of the neck. (TA.)

daOoyapN c
daOoyapN; and its pls. daOayaAtN and duYiIRN: see the next preceding paragraph, in seven places. ― -b2- Hence, (S,) Aibonu daOoyapa The guraAb [or crow]: (S, M, K:) so called because it alights upon, and pecks, the dOyp of the camel that has galls, or sores. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also The part, of a bow, upon which the arrow lies: there are two parts of which each is thus called, next to the part of the stave that is held by the hand, above and below. (M.) ＝ -A3- daAyapN [without C, from the Pers. daAyaho,] A child's nurse; a woman who has the charge of a child, who takes care of him, and rears, or nourishes, him; (TA in art. HDn;) i. q. ZiYorN; both of which words are said by IJ to be chaste Arabic: pl. daAyaAtN. (M and TA in art. dwI.)

daYiIRN c
daYiIRN and daYiyRapN: see daMCN (in the latter part of the paragraph), in art. dwO.

duYiIRN c
duYiIRN and diYiIRN: see daOoIN.

dayoOaI c
dayoOaI, of the measure fayoEalN; and its fem; with p: see daMCN (in the latter part of the paragraph), in art. dwO.

1 dabRa db
1. dabRa aor.
dabiba
, inf. n. dabiybN (T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and dabRN (M, K,) and madabRN, (S, K,) [and perhaps dababN also, q. v.,] It, or he, (the ant, T, M, and any animal, M, and in like manner a party moving towards the enemy, T, or an army, and a child, Msb,) [crept; crawled; or] went, or walked, leisurely, or gently, (T, M, Msb, K,) without haste, (T,) EalaI AlOaroDi [upon the ground]: (S:) and [simply] he walked: (IAar, T:) he (an old man) [crept along; or] walked leisurely, softly, or gently: (S:) and dbRb↓, also, he walked leisurely, by slow degrees. (TA.) Hence, Oakocabu mano dabRa wadaraja The most lying of those who have walked and died, or passed away, or perished: (T:) i. e., of the living and the dead. (T, S, K.) And yadibRu maEa AlquraAdi [He creeps about with ticks]; said of a man who brings a small worn-out skin containing ticks, and ties it to the tail of a camel; in consequence of which, when one of the ticks bites it, the camel runs away, and the other camels run away with it; and thereupon he steals one of them: whence it is said of a thief, or stealer of cattle &c. (TA.) And huwa yadibRu bayonanaA biAlnRamaAYimi (tropical:) [He creeps among us with calumnies, or slanders]. (A, TA.) And dabRato EaqaArabuhu [lit. His scorpions crept along]; meaning (tropical:) his calumnies, or slanders, and mischief, (M, A, K,) crept along; syn. sarato. (M, K [See also art. Eqrb.]) And the same phrase is also used to signify (tropical:) His downy hair crept [along his cheeks]. (MF in art. Eqrb.) And dabRa qamoluhu [lit. His lice crept]; meaning (tropical:) he became fat: said of a man. (Ham. p. 633.) And dabRa Aljadowalu (tropical:) [The rivulet, or streamlet for irrigation, crept along]. (A.) And dabRa fiyhi (tropical:) It crept in, or into, it, or him; syn. saraI; (M, A, K;) namely, wine, or beverage, (T, M, A, K,) in, or into, the body, (M, K,) or in, or into, a man, (T,) and into a vessel; (M;) and a disease, or malady, (M, A, K,) in, or into, the body, (M, K,) or fiI Euruwqihi [in his veins]; (A;) and wear in a garment, or piece of cloth; (M, K;) and the dawn in the darkness of the latter part of the night. (M.) ― -b2- dibRiI Hajalo (in the CK Hajalu) is the name of A certain game of the Arabs: (K, TA:) the l is quiescent. (TA.) ― -b3- dubRa used as a noun: see below. ＝ -A2- dabRa [second pers. dabibota,] aor. yadabRu, inf. n. dababN, He (a camel) was, or became, such as is termed OadabRu; (IAar, T, TA;) i. e., had much hair, or much fur (wabar), or much fur upon the face. (TA.)

2 dabRaRa
2: see 1, first sentence.

4 Oadobabotuhu c
4. Oadobabotuhu [third pers. OadabRa] I made him (namely, a child, S) [to creep, or crawl, or] to go, or walk, leisurely, or gently. (S, K. [For the correct explanation, Hamalotuhu EalaI AldRabiybi, Golius seems to have found Hmlth ElI AldRaAbRapi.]) ― -b2- AdbR AlbilaAda (assumed tropical:) He filled the country, or provinces, with justice, so that the inhabitants thereof walked at leisure (dabRa OaholuhaA [whence Golius has supposed dabRa to signify “ juste se habuit populus ”] M, K, TA) by reason of the security and abundance and prosperity that they enjoyed. (M, TA.)

R. Q. 1 dabodaba dbdb
R. Q. 1. dabodaba, [inf. n. dabodabapN,] He (a man) raised cries, shouts, noises, or a clamour. (AA, T.) ― -b2- And He beat a drum. (AA, T.)

dabRN db
dabRN: see dababN.

dubRa db
dubRa and XubRa are used as nouns, by the introduction of mino before them, though originally verbs. (S and K * and TA in art. Xb.) One says, OaEoyayotaniI mino XubRa UilaI dubRa, (M, K, *) by way of imitation [of a verbal phrase], (M,) and mn XubRK AlI dubRK, Thou hast wearied me from the time of thy becoming a youth until thy walking gently, [or creeping along, resting] upon a staff: (M, K, * TA:) a prov.: (M, TA:) said alike to a man and to a woman. (TA in art. Xb.) And faEalota kacaA mino XubRa UilaI dubRa and mn XubRK AlI dubRK Thou hast done thus from youth until thy walking gently, [or creeping along, resting] upon the staff. (S.) ＝ -A2- dubRN: see dubRapN, in two places. ＝ -A3- Also [The bear;] a certain beast of prey, (S, M, K,) well known; (K;) a certain foul, or noxious, animal: (Msb:) a genuine Arabic word: (M:) fem. with p: pl. [of mult.] dibabapN (S, M, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OadobaAbN. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AldRubRu (assumed tropical:) The constellation of the Greater Bear: and, accord. to some, that of the Lesser Bear: the former, for distinction, being called AldRubRu AlOakobaru; and the latter, AldRubRu AlOaSogaru. (M, K.)

dabRapN db dbh dbp
dabRapN A single act [of creeping, or crawling, or] of going, or walking, leisurely, or gently: pl. dibaAbN. (K.) ＝ -A2- A hill, or heap, or gibbous hill, syn. kaviyb, (IAar, T, S, M, K,) of sand: (S, K:) and (in some copies of the K “ or ”) a tract of red sand: or an even tract of sand: (K:) or, as in some copies of the K, an even tract of land: (TA:) and a place abounding in sand: (T, L:) pl. as above. (TA.) Hence the prov., waqaEa fulaAnN fiI dabRapF mina AlrRamoli [lit. Such a one fell into, or upon, a place abounding in sand]; meaning, (tropical:) into difficulty, or misfortune; for the camel in such a place suffers fatigue. (T.) ＝ -A3- A certain thing for oil, or ointment; (S;) a receptacle for seeds (bizor) and olive-oil: (M, K:) pl. as above. (Sb, M.) A kind of bottle, or pot, (baTRapN,) peculiarly of glass. (K.) [Form the Pers. dabRaho.] ― -b2- See also dubRaMCN. ＝ -A4- And see dababN, in three places.

dubRapN db dbh dbp
dubRapN A way, or road. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A state, or condition: (M, K:) and (tropical:) a way, mode, or manner, of acting &c.; (IAar, T, S, M, A, K;) whether good or evil: (IAar, T:) as also dubRN↓, (M, A, K,) in both these senses: (M:) and (assumed tropical:) a natural disposition, temper, quality, or property. (S:) You say, rakibotu dubRatahu, and dubRahu↓ (M, A) (tropical:) I kept to his state, or condition, and his way, mode, or manner, of acting &c.; and did as he did. (M.) And daEoniI wadubRatiI (assumed tropical:) Leave thou me and my way, mode, or manner, of acting &c.; and my natural disposition, &c. (S.)

dibRapN db dbh dbp
dibRapN A mode, or manner, [of creeping, or crawling, or] of going, or walking, leisurely, or gently. (M, K. *) You say, huwa xafiIRu AldRibRapi [He has a soft, or stealthy, mode, or manner, of creeping along, &c.]. (M, K:) And dababotu dibRapF xafiyRapF [I crept along in a soft, or stealthy, mode, or manner, of creeping]. (T, S.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. dabiybN↓ [as meaning Anything that creeps, or crawls, upon the earth; and used as a coll. gen. n.]. (K.) One says, maA Oakovara dibRapF hecaA Albaladi [How many are the creeping, or crawling, things of this country, or town!]. (TA.)

dababN dbb
dababN A certain pace, between that termed AlnRaSobu and that termed AlEanaqu: (TA voce naSaba, as on the authority of En-Nadr:) or this is termed dabiybN↓. (TA voce wasaja, as on the authority of En-Nadr and As.) ＝ -A2- Also Down; syn. zagabN; (M, K;) and so dababaAnN↓, (K,) and dabRapN↓: (Kr. M:) or down (T, S) of the face, (S,) or upon the face; (T;) and so dabRapN↓, (K,) of which the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is dabRN↓; (M, K;) accord. to Kr, who assigns to it the former meaning, and says that dabRapN↓ is syn. with zagabN, not that it is syn. with zagabapN: (M:) or dababN signifies hair upon the face of a woman: (TA:) or, as also dababaAnN↓, much hair (M, K) and wabar [or camel's fur]: (M:) or both these words signify hair upon the jabiyn [or part above the temple] of a woman. ('Eyn, TT.) ＝ -A3- Also The young one, when just born, of the [wild] cow: (K:) or when a [wild] bull is a year old, and weaned, he is thus called; and the female, dababapN, and dbAn. (TA in art. Xb. [But for “ and dbAn, ” I think it evident that we should read “ and the pl. is dubRaAnN, ” or “ dibRaAnN, ” like as jucoEaAnN and jicoEaAnN are pls. of jacaEN. See also XababN.])

dabibapN db dbb dbbh dbbp
dabibapN: see OadabRu.

dababAnN dbbAn
dababAnN: see dababN, in two places.

dabaAbi dbAb
dabaAbi [an imperative verbal n.,] a call to a female hyena, signifying dibRiI [i. e. Creep along; or crawl; or go leisurely]: (Sb, T, K:) like nazaAli and HacaAri. (Sb, T.)

dabaAbN dbAb
dabaAbN The pace, or motion, of a she-camel that can scarcely walk, by reason of the abundance of her flesh, and only creeps along, or walks slowly. (T, * TA.)

dabuwbN dbwb
dabuwbN A she-camel that can scarcely walk, by reason of the abundance of her flesh, and that only creeps along, or walks slowly: (S:) pl. dububN. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Fat; (T, M, K;) as an epithet applied to a she-camel, (T,) or to any thing [or animal]. (M, K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) One who creeps about with calumny, or slander; as also dayobuwbN↓: (T, K: *) or the latter signifies (assumed tropical:) one who calumniates, or slanders, much, or habitually; as though he crept about with calumnies, or slanders: (M:) or (assumed tropical:) one who brings men and women
together; (T, M, K;) because he creeps about between them, and hides himself: (T:) i. q. dayRuwvN. (M, in TA, art. dyv.) ― -b4- jiraAHapN dabuwbN (assumed tropical:) A wound that flows with blood. (K.) And TaEonapN dabuwbN (assumed tropical:) A thrust, or stab, that makes the blood to flow. (K.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) A deep cave, or cavern. (K.)

dabiybN dbyb
dabiybN inf. n. of dabRa [q. v.]. (T, S, M, &c.) See also dababN. ＝ -A2- And see also daAbRapN, and dibRapN.

dubRaMCN dbMC
dubRaMCN and dabRapN↓ The gourd: (M, K:) or round gourd: or dry gourd: but this is said by Ibn- Hajar to be a mistake of En-Nawawee; and he asserts it to be i. q. yaqoTiynN [q. v.]: or it is the fruit of the yqTyn: (TA:) n. un. of the former with p. (M, K.) Accord. to F [and ISd] and several others, this is the proper art. of the former word, the C being considered by them augmentative: accord. to Z and others, its proper art. is dbI: and some also allow its being written and pronounced dubRFI: this is mentioned by Kz and 'Iyád as a dial. var. of dubRaMC. (TA.) [See an ex. voce riXaMCN, in art. rXw.]

maA biAldRaAri dubRiIRN and dibRiIRN There is not in the house any one: (S, M, * K:) dubRiIRN being from dababotu; i. e. mano yadibRu; and it is not used in any but a negative phrase. (Ks, S.) [See also dibRiyjN and dibRiyHN.]

dubRaMCapN dbMCh dbMCp
dubRaMCapN A locust while smooth and bare, before its wings have grown. (Mentioned in the TA in this art., but not there said to belong to it. [See art. dbI.]) ― -b2- [See also dubRaMCN, of which it is the n. un.]

dabRaAbN dbAb
dabRaAbN An animal that is weak, and creeps along, or walks slowly: fem. with p. (TA from a trad.)

dabRaAbapN dbAb dbAbh dbAbp
dabRaAbapN fem. of dabRaAbN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also, as a subst., The musculus, or testudo;] a machine (M, * Mgh, * K, TA) made of skins and wood, (TA,) used in war; (M, Mgh, K, TA;) men entering into [or beneath] it, (Mgh, TA,) it is propelled to the lower part of a fortress, and they make a breach therein (M, Mgh, K, TA) while within the machine, (M, K, TA,) which defends them from what is thrown upon them from above: (TA:) it is also called DaborN. (Mgh.)

dabodabN dbdb
dabodabN The walk of the long-legged ant. (M, K.) In the T it is said that dabodabapN↓ signifies The long-legged ant [itself: but this is perhaps a mistranscription]. (TA.)

dabodabapN dbdb dbdbh dbdbp
dabodabapN [inf. n. of R. Q. 1, q. v.] ― -b2- Any quick motion, or pace, performed with short steps: (M:) and any sound like that of solid hoofs falling upon hard ground: (M, K:) a certain kind of sound [like the tramp of horses, as is indicated by an ex.]: (S:) or cries, shouts, noises, or clamour: (A:) and dabaAdibu [is its pl., and] signifies a sound like dubo dubo; an onomatopœia. (T.) ＝ -A2- [A kind of drum;] a thing resembling a Tabol: pl. dabaAdibu. (Mgh, Msb. [See also dabodaAbN.]) ＝ -A3- Milk such as is termed raAYib, upon which fresh is milked: or the thickest of milk; as also dabodabaI↓. (K.) ＝ -A4- See also dabodabN.

dabodabaI dbdbI dbdby
dabodabaI: see the next preceding paragraph.

dabodaAbN dbdAb
dabodaAbN A drum; syn. TabolN. (M, K. [See also dabodabapN.])

dubaAdibN dbAdb
dubaAdibN Very clamorous; (IAar, T, K;) as also jubaAjibN: (IAar, T:) or both signify very evil, or mischievous, and clamorous. (Az, in TA, art. jb.) ― -b2- And A bulky, or corpulent, man. (K.)

daAbRapN dAbh dAbp
daAbRapN [originally a fem. part. n.], for nafosN daAbRapN, (M,) [or the p is added lilnRaqoli, i. e. for the purpose of transferring the word from the category of epithets to that of substs.,] Anything that walks [or creeps or crawls] upon the earth; as also dabiybN↓: (S: see dibRapN:) an animal that walks or creeps or crawls (yadibRu); (M, A, K;) discriminating and not discriminating: (M:) any animal upon the earth: (Msb:) it is said in the Kur [xxiv. 44], waQllRehu xalaqa kulRa daAbRapK mino maMCK faminohumo mano yamoXiI EalaI baTonihi waminohumo mano yamoXiI EalaI rijolayoni waminohumo mano yamoXiI EalaI OarobaEK [And God hath created every dAbRp of water (meaning of the seminal fluid); and of them is he that goeth upon his belly, and of them is he that goeth upon two legs, and of them is he that goeth upon four]: here, as dAbRp applies to a rational and an irrational creature, the expression fmnhm is used; for which, if it applied only to an irrational creature, faminohaA or faminohunRa would be used: moreover, the expression mn ymXI is used, though dAbRp applies originally to an irrational creature, [or rather a beast, and a reptile,] because the different classes of beings are spoken of collectively: (M:) and this passage of the Kur refutes the assertion of him who excludes the bird from the significations of this word: (Msb:) in the last verse but one of ch. xxxv. of the Kur, it is said to relate to mankind and the jinn (or genii) and every rational being; or to have a general signification: (M:) its predominant signification is a beast that is ridden: (S, M, A, K:) especially a beast of the equine kind; i. e. a horse, a mule, and an ass: (Kull:) or particularly a birocawon [meaning hackney, or horse for ordinary use and for journeying: (M:) but as particularly applied, when used absolutely, to a horse and a mule, it is an adventitious conventional term: (Msb:) it is applied to a male and a female: (M, A, Msb, K:) and is properly an epithet: (M:) pl. dawaAbRu. (Msb, TA.) The dim. [signifying Any small animal that walks or creeps or crawls upon the earth, a small beast, a small reptile or creeping thing, a creeping insect, and any insect, and also a mollusk, a shell-fish (as in an instance cited voce maHaArapN in art. Hwr) and the like,] is duwayobRapN↓, (Zj, T, Msb,) in which the I is quiescent, but pronounced with UiXomaAm [i. e. a slight approximation to the sound of kesr], as it is in every similar case, in a dim. n., when followed by a doubled letter: (Zj, T:) and duwaAbRapN↓ also has been heard, with the I changed into A anomalously. (Msb; and L in art. hd, on the authority of ISd.) ― -b2- daAbRapu AlOaroDi [The Beast of the Earth] is an appellation of one of the signs of the time of the resurrection: (S, M, K:) or the first of those signs. (K.) It is said to be a beast sixty cubits in length, or height, with legs, and with fur (wabar), and to be diverse in form, resembling a number of different animals. (TA.) It will come forth in Tihámeh, or between Es-Safà and ElMarweh, (M,) or at Mekkeh, from Jebel Es- Safà, which will rend open for its egress, during one of the nights when people are going to Minè; or from the district of Et-Táïf; (K) or from three places, three several times. (M, K.) It will make, upon the face of the unbeliever, a black mark; and upon the face of the believer, a white mark: the unbeliever's mark will spread until his whole face becomes black; and the believer's, until his whole face becomes white: then they will assemble at the table, and the believer will be known from the unbeliever. (M.) It is also said that it will have with it the rod of Moses and the seal of Solomon: with the former it will strike the believer; and with the latter it will stamp the face of the unbeliever, impressing upon it “ This is an unbeliever. ” (K.) ― -b3- See also OaraDapN.

dayobuwbN dybwb
dayobuwbN: see dabuwbN.

duwaAbRapN: dims. of daAbRapN, q. v.

duwayobRapN dwybh dwybp
duwayobRapN: dims. of daAbRapN, q. v.

OadabRN c
OadabRN Having down (K, TA) upon the face: (TA:) or having much hair: (M, K:) and having much wabar [or fur]: (M:) it is applied to a man: (M:) and to a camel, (M, K,) in the second of these senses, (K, TA,) or in the third sense, or as meaning having much fur upon the face; (TA;) or i. q. OazabRu: (M:) and occurs in a trad. written Oadobab, (M, K,) to assimilate it in measure to a preceding word, namely, HawoCab: (M:) the fem. is dabRaMCu; with which dabibapN↓ is syn.; (M, K;) signifying a woman having hair upon her face: (TA:) or having much hair upon the jabiyn [or part above the temple]. (M, TA.)

madibRN mdb
madibRN and madabRN The track, or course, of a torrent, (S, M, K, *) and of ants: (S, K:) pl. madaAbRu. (TA.) One says, of a sword, lahu OavorN kaOanRahu madabRu AlnRamoli and madaAbRu AlcRarRi [It has diversified wavy marks like the track of ants and the tracks of little ants]. (TA.) The subst. is with kesr; and the inf. n., with fet-h; accord. to a rule constantly obtaining, (S, * K, * TA,) except in some anomalous instances, (TA,) when the verb is of the measure faEala (S, K, TA) or faEila, (TA,) and its aor. is of the measure yafoEilu. (S, K, TA.) [Here it should be observed that majorFI, given as the explanation of madibRN and madabRN in the K, is both an inf. n. and a n. of place and of time: but J clearly explains both these words as above; and F seems, in the K, to assign to them both the same signification.]

OaroDN madabRapN c
OaroDN madabRapN A land abounding with dibabap [or bears]. (T, S, M. *)

mudabRabN mdbb
mudabRabN, like muEaZRamN, (TA,) or midobabN, (so in a
copy of the T, according to the TT,) an epithet applied to a camel, (T, TA,) signifying AlcI ymXI dbAdb (TA) [app. dabaAdiba, and if so it seems to mean That walks quickly, with short steps: or that makes a sound with his feet, like dubo dubo: see dabodabapN: but in the TT it is written dabAo dabAo; perhaps correctly dabRFA dabRFA, creeping and creeping].

1. dabaja, aor.
dabuja
[or
dabija
, as will be shown below], (L,) inf. n. dabojN, (L, K,) [not dabajN and dabajapN as in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag,] He variegated, decorated, embellished, adorned, or ornamented: (L, K: *) [and so dbRj↓, inf. n. tadobiyjN, occurring in the TA in art. nmX; but app. in an intensive sense.] And [hence,] dabaja AlOaroDa, (A, L, Msb,) aor.
dabuja
(L, A) or
dabija
, (Msb,) inf. n. as above; (A, L, Msb;) and dabRajahaA↓ [but app. in an intensive sense]; (A;) (tropical:) It adorned the land with meadows, or gardens: (A, L:) or it watered the land, and produced various flowers. (Msb.) It is a Pers. word, arabicized: (L:) or derived from diybaAjN. (Msb.)

2 dabRaja
2: see above, in two places. [Accord. to Golius, (for III. is inadvertently put in his Lex. for II.,) as on the authority of the S and K, in neither of which is the verb mentioned, “ Veste dybAj alium ornavit. ”]

maA biAldRaAri dibRiyjN mA bAldAr dbyj
maA biAldRaAri dibRiyjN, (ISk, S, A,) or fiI AldRaAri, (K,) (tropical:) There is not in the house any one: (ISk, S, A, K:) dibRiyjN is not used otherwise than in a negative phrase: IJ derives it from diybaAjN; because men adorn the earth: (TA:) [Z says,] it is from dabaja, like sikRiytN from sakata; because men adorn houses: (A:) Abu-l-'Abbás says that dibRiyHN is more chaste than dibRiyjN: (TA:) [ISk says, or J, for the passage is ambiguous,] A'Obeyd doubted respecting the j and the H; and I asked respecting this word, in the desert, a company of the Arabs thereof, and they said, maA fiI AldRaAri dibRiIRN, and nothing more; but I have found in the handwriting of Aboo-Moosà El- Hámid, mA fI AldAr dibRiyjN, with j, on the authority of Th: (S:) AM says that the j in dibRiyNj is substituted for the [latter] I in dibRiIRN, in like manner as they say murRiIRN and murRijRN &c. (TA.)

dubayobiyjN dbybyj
dubayobiyjN: see the next paragraph, near the end.

diybaAjN dybAj
diybaAjN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) or dayobaAjN, (Th,) or both, (IAar, A'Obeyd,) the latter having been sometimes heard, (IAar,) or the latter is post-classical, (A'Obeyd,) or wrong, (AZ,) a word of well-known meaning, (K,) [Silk brocade;] a certain kind of cloth, or garment, made of Uiboriysam [i. e. silk, or raw silk]: (TA:) a kind of cloth, or garment, of which the warp and woof are both of Abrysm: and particularly a name for that which is variegated, decorated, or embellished: (Mgh, Msb:) a kind of woven stuff, variegated, or diversified, with colours: (Lb, TA:) [accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the S and K, in neither of which is the word explained at all, “ vestis serica: imprimis picta, pec. Attalica, auro intexta:] derived from dabaja: (Ks:) or it is a Pers. word, (Kr, S, A,) arabicized; (Kr, S, A, Msb, K;) so some say, and from it dabaja is derived; (Msb;) originally diybaAIo, or diybaA; (Kr;) [or rather diybaAho, for the change of the final h into j in arabicized words from the Pers. is very common;] or diywo baAfo, i. e. “ the weaving of the deevs, or jinn, or genii: ” (Shifá el-Ghaleel:) pl. dayaAbiyju and dabaAbiyju; (S, Msb, K;) the latter being from the supposed original form of the sing., i. e. dibRaAjN; (S, Msb;) like danaAniyru [pl. of diynaArN, which is supposed to be originally dinRaArN]: and in like manner is formed the dim. [duyayobiyjN↓ and dubayobiyjN↓]. (S.) ― -b2- diybaAju AlquroMni is a title given by Ibn-Mes'ood to The chapters of the Kur-án called AlHawaAmiymu [the fortieth and six following chapters; each of which begins with the letters HemL]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also the paragraph next following, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A young she-camel; one in the prime of life. (IAar, K.)

diybaAjapN dybAj dybAjh dybAjp
diybaAjapN (tropical:) [A proem, an introduction, or a preface, to a poem or a book; and especially one that is embellished, or composed in an ornate style]. lihecihi AlqaSiydapi diybaAjapN HasanapN (tropical:) [To this ode is a beautiful proem] is said of a qSydp when it is embellished (muHabRarap) [in its commencement]. (A.) And one says, maA OaHosana diybaAjaAti AlbuHoturiIRi (tropical:) [How beautiful are the proems of l-Boh- turee!]. (A.) ― -b2- diybaAjapu Alwajohi, and Alwjh diybaAju↓, (assumed tropical:) Beauty of the skin of the face. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- And AldRiybaAjapu (tropical:) The face [itself]; as also AldRiybaAju↓, and AldRiybaAjataAni: (Har pp. 15 and 476:) or the last signifies the two cheeks: (S, A, Msb:) or the two sides of the neck, beneath the ears; syn. AllRiytaAni. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN yaSuwnu diybaAjatayohi, i. e. (tropical:) [Such a one preserves from disgrace] his cheeks; (A;) or diybaAjatahu his face: and yaboculu diyabaAjatahu [uses his face for mean service, by begging]. (Har p. 15. [See also 4 in art. xlq; and 1 (near the end) in the same art.; where similar exs. are given.]) ― -b4- [Golius, after mentioning the signification of “ the two cheeks, ” adds, as on the authority of the K, in which even the word itself is not mentioned, “ et quibusdam quoque Nates. ”] ― -b5- diybaAjapu AlsRayofi I. q. Oavoruhu, q. v. (AZ, T in art. Avr.)

duyayobiyjN dyybyj
duyayobiyjN: see diybaAjN, near the end of the paragraph.

mudabRajN mdbj
mudabRajN Ornamented with diybaAj. (K.) You say TayolasaAnN mudabRajN A TylsAn [q. v.] of which the ends, edges, or borders, are so ornamented. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- OaroDN mudabajapN (tropical:) Land adorned with meadows, or gardens. (A.) ― -b3- mudabRajN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A species of the haAm [or owl]. (T, K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A species of aquatic bird, (T, K,) of ugly appearance, called Oagoyaru mudabRajN, with puffedout feathers, and ugly head, found in water with the [bird called] nuHaAm. (T.) ― -b5- And, applied to a man, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) Having an ugly head and make (K, TA) and face. (TA.)

2 dbRH dbH
2. dbRH, inf. n. tadobiyHN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,). said of a man, (S, Msb, &c.,) He stretched out his back, and lowered his head, (As, S, Msb, * K,) so that his head was lower than his posteriors; (As, S, Msb; *) as also AndbH↓; (K;) and so dbRx, [q. v.,] with x: (Msb:) the doing thus in inclining the body in prayer, like as the ass does [when he is mounted], is forbidden in a trad.: (S, Msb:) i. e. he lowered his head in inclining his body in prayer so that it was lower than his back: (A'Obeyd, Msb:) or he lowered his head, and raised his posteriors, in prayer: (TA:) or [simply] he lowered his head; (IAar, T, TA;) as also dbRx [q. v.]: (T, TA:) or he did so in walking: (TA:) or he bent his back; (Lh, T, Msb, TA;) as also dbRx; with which As says that dnRx, with n and x, is syn.: (Msb:) and dbRH Zahorahu signifies he (a man) bent his back, raising the middle of it as though it were a camel's hump: erroneously related by Lth with c. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also He (a boy, in play,) lowered his back in order that another might come running from a distance and mount upon him. (Aboo- 'Adnán, TA.) And one says, dabRiHo liI HatRaI Oarokabaka, meaning Stoop for me in order that I may mount upon thee. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, said of an ass having a sore back, He relaxed his legs, and lowered his back and rump, by reason of pain, on being mounted. (L.) ― -b4- And He was, or became, low, base, abject, or ignominious. (IAar, K.) [And so danRaHa and danRaHa.] ― -b5- dbRHt AlkamoOapu [The truffles pushed up the ground above them, or] the ground swelled up from the truffles, without their appearing (K) as yet. (TA.) ― -b6- dbRH fiI bayotihi He kept in his house, or tent; not going forth. (K.)

, inf. n. dubuwrN, He followed behind his back; he followed his back; (M, TA;) he followed him, with respect to place, and also with respect to time, and also (assumed tropical:) with respect to rank or station. (TA.) You say, jaMCa yadoburuhumo He came following them. (M, TA.) And dabaraniI fulaAnN Such a one came after me, behind me, (T, A,) or following me nearly. (A.) And dabarahu, inf. n. daborN, He succeeded him, and remained after him. (TA.) And qabaHa QllRehu maA qabala minohu wa maA dabara [May God curse the beginning of it and the end].
