, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. dubuwrN (S, M, Msb, K) and daborN, (M, K,) It passed forth from the butt: (S, Msb:) or passed beyond the butt, (M, A, K,) and fell behind it. (M, A.) ― -b4- dabara bihi He, or it, went away with it; took it away; carried it off; or caused it to go away, pass away, or cease. (S, K.) ― -b5- dabara Alqawomu, aor.
dabuxa
, (M, TA,) inf. n. dabaArN, (As, S, M, K,) like damaArN, (As, S,) [and dabaArapN, like damaArapN (q. v.), and app. dabaraI↓, (see AlxayobaraI,) or dabraI may be a simple subst.,] The people, or company of men, perished; (As, * S, * M, K * TA;) went away, turning the back, and did not return. (TA. [And Adbr (q. v.) has a similar, or the same, meaning.]) Hence, Ealayohi AldRabaAru Perdition befall him; may he go away, turning the back, and not return. (M, TA.) ― -b6- And dabara (tropical:) He became an old man. (S, A, K.) Hence, as some say, the expression in the Kur [lxxiv. 36], waQllRayolu UicaA dabara (tropical:) [And the night when it groweth old]. (TA. [See also 4.]) ― -b7- dabarati AlrRiyHu, (S, M, A, K,) aor.
dabuxa
, inf. n. dubuwrN, (M,) The wind blew in the direction of that wind which is termed dabuwr [i. e. west, &c., which is regarded as the hinder quarter]: (M, A:) or changed, and came in that direction. (S, K.) [Hence,] dabarato lahu AlrRiyHu baEoda maA Oaqobalato [lit. The wind became west to him after it had been east: meaning (tropical:) his fortune became evil after it had been good]: and dabara baEoda UiqobaAlK [(tropical:) which means the same: see dabuwrN; and see also 4 in this art., and in art. qbl]. (A.) ― -b8- And dubira, (S, K,) a verb of which the agent is not named, (S,) He, (K,) a man, (TA,) or it, a people, (S, M,) was smitten, or affected, by the wind called AldRabuwr. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- dabara AlHadiyva Eanohu: see 2. ＝ -A3- qabalotu AlHabola wadabarotuhu: see dabiyrN. ＝ -A4- dabara, aor.
dabuxa
, inf. n. daborN, signifies, accord. to Kr, He wrote a writing or letter or book: but none other says so; and the known word is cabara. (M.) [The inf. n. is explained in the K as syn. with AikotitaAbN.] ＝ -A5- dabira, (S, M, Mgh, K,) aor.
dabaxa
, (K,) inf. n. dabarN, (M, Mgh,) He (a horse or the like, M, K, and a camel, S, M, Mgh) had galls, or sores, on his back, (M, Mgh, K, * TA,) produced by the saddle and the like; (Mgh;) as also Adbr↓. (K. [But the corresponding passage in the M shows that this is probably a mistake for Oadobaru a syn. of dabirN.])

2 dbRr AlOamora c
2. dbRr AlOamora, (T, M, A,) or fiI AlOamori (S,) inf. n. tadobiyrN, (T, S, K,) He considered, or forecast, the issues, or results, of the affair, or event, or case; (TA;) and so tdbRrhu↓: (Mgh:) or its end, issue, or result; (T, M, K;) as also tdbRrhu↓: (T, M, Msb, K:) or he looked to what would, or might, be its result: and fiyhi tdbRr↓ he thought, or meditated, upon it; (S;) [as also tdbRrhu↓:] Aktham Ibn-Seyfee said to his sons, OaEojaAza yaAbaniIRa laA tatadabRaruwA↓ OumuwrK qado walRato SuduwruhaA [O my sons, think not upon the ends of things whereof the beginnings have passed]: (T: [see EajuzN:]) and in the Kur [iv. 84] it is said, AlquroMna OafalaA yatadabRaruwna↓ Will they, then, not consider the meanings of the Kur-án, and endeavour to obtain a clear knowledge of what is in it? (Bd:) and again, in the Kur [xxiii. 70], Alqawola Oafalamo yadRabRaruwA↓ Have they, then, not thought upon, (TA,) and endeavoured to understand, (yatafahRamuwA, K,) what has been said to them in the Kur-án? for tadabRurN↓ signifies the thinking, or meditating, upon [a thing], and endeavouring to understand [it]; syn. tafakRurN and tafahRumN: (TA:) and tdbRrhu↓ he looked into it, considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, in order to know it, or until he knew it. (Msb in art. Aml.) dbRr OamorFA, inf. n. as above, signifies [also] He did, performed, or executed, a thing, or an affair, with thought, or consideration. (Msb.) [And He devised, planned, or plotted, a thing, EalaI gayorihi against another. And hence, He managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated, an affair; because the doing so requires consideration of the issues, or results, of the affair. You say, dbRr Oumuwra AlbilaAdi, and, elliptically, dbRr AlbilaAda, He managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated, the affairs of the provinces, or country: and in like manner, the affairs of a house. tadobiyrN is also attributed to irrational animals; as, for ex., to horses; meaning their conducting the affair of victory: and to inanimate things; as, for ex., to stars; meaning their regulating the alternations of seasons &c.: see Bd in lxxix. 5. And dbRr alone signifies He acted with consideration of the issues, or results, of affairs, or events, or cases; acted with, or exercised, forecast, or forethought; or acted with policy.] ― -b2- dbRr Eabodahu, (M, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He made his slave to be free after his own death, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) saying to him, Thou art free after my death: (T, TA:) he made the emancipation of his slave to depend upon his own death. (TA.) ― -b3- dbRr AlHadiyva, (inf. n. as above, K,) He related the tradition, narrative, or story, having received it, or heard it, from another person: (As, T, S, K: *) and huwa yudabRiru Hadiyva fulaAnK He relates the tradition, &c., of, or received from, or heard from, such a one: (As, S:) and dbRr AlHadiyva Eanohu; (M;) or Eanohu dabarahu↓, (S, K,) aor.
dabuxa
; (TA;) He related the tradition, &c., having received it, or heard it, from him, (S, M, K,) after his death: (S, K:) Sh says that dbRr AlHadiyva is unknown; but so the phrase is related on the authority of A'Obeyd: Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà [i. e. Th] disallows yudabRiruhu as meaning he relates it; and says that it is yacoburuhu, with c, meaning “he knows it, or learns it, well, soundly, or thoroughly;” syn. yutoqinuhu. (T.)

3 dAbrhu dAbr dAbrh dAbrp
3. dAbrhu, (S, A, *) inf. n. mudaAbarapN and dibaArN, (K,) [He turned his back upon him: see 6. ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) He severed himself from him, and avoided him, or shunned him; (TA;) became at variance with him; (A;) regarded him, or treated him, with enmity, or hostility. (S, A, K.) And dAbr raHimahu (assumed tropical:) He cut, or severed, the ties, or bonds, of his relationship; disunited himself from his relations. (A.) ― -b3- daAbarotuhaA I made a slit such as is termed UidobaArap in her (a ewe's or goat's or camel's) ear. (As, S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 4.

4 Adbr Odbr Adbr dbr
4. Adbr, (M, K, and Bd in ix. 25,) inf. n. UidobaArN (S, M) and duborN↓, accord. to Kr, but correctly the latter is a simple subst. [or quasi-inf. n.]; (M;) and dabara↓, (IAar, S, K,) inf. n. daborN (TA) and dubuwrN; (TK;) He went, turning his back; turned back; went back; took a backward course; retreated; retired; retrograded; declined; syn. walRaIi (S, M, K) and taOaxRara (IAar) and cahaba UilaI xalofK; (Bd ubi suprà, and S and K in art. qbl;) contr. of Oaqobala. (S, Bd.) And Adbr bihi [He went back, or backward, with it, or him; removed, or turned, it, or him, backward]. (S, K.) You say, yudobiru biAldRalowi UilaI AlHawoDi [He goes back with the bucket to the watering-trough]: opposed to the phrase yuqobilu bihaA UilaI biYori. (A.) See also dabiyrN, first sentence. And Adbr Eanohu [He went back, &c., from it, or him]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He feigned himself negligent of, or inattentive to, the want of his friend; (K;) as though he turned back from him. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] Adbr signifies (assumed tropical:) It went backward, to a bad state; said of the affair, or case, of a people. (M, TA.) You say also, OamorN fulaAnK UilaI UiqobaAlK and [in the contr. sense] AlI UidobaArN (assumed tropical:) [The affair, or case, of such a one is inclining to advance, and to go backward, to a bad state]. (A.) [UidobaArN often signifies The retiring, or declining, of good fortune; opposed to UiqobaAlN: see also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.] And Adbr Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The case of the people took a backward course, and there remained none of them. (TA.) And Adbr AlnRahaAri and dabara↓ (inf. n. of the latter dubuwrN, A) signify the same; (Fr, T, S, M;) i. e. The day went, or departed; (M, A;) and so AlSRayofu [the summer, or the spring]: and in like manner one says [in the contr. sense] Oaqobala and qabala: so says Fr, and he adds, but you say of a man, Aqbl AlrRaAkibu and Adbr only, with A, though [Az says] it seems to me that the two forms are applicable in the same manner to men as they are to times. (T.) Some read, in the Kur [lxxiv. 36], waQllRayoli UicaA dabara↓, (T, S,) which, accord. to some, means And the night when it cometh after the day; (T;) or when it followeth the day: (S: [for another rendering, see 1:]) others, (T, S,) the greater number, (T,) read AcA Oadobara, (T, S,) meaning when it retreateth to depart. (T.) [Hence,] Adbrt AlSRalaApu (assumed tropical:) The prayer ended. (Bd in l. 39.) And waUidobaAra AlsRujuwdi: and waUidobaAra AlnRujuwmi: see duburN. And Adbr (assumed tropical:) He died; (K;) as also dAbr↓.
(Lh, M, K. [See also dabara Alqawomu, in the first paragraph.]) ― -b4- maA Oaqobala mina Aljabali wamaA Oadobara and maA qabala minohu wamaA dabara↓ signify the same [i. e. What is in front, of the mountain; and what is behind]. (JK.) ＝ -A2- Adbr also signifies He made a man to be behind him. (M.) ＝ -A3- And It, (the saddle, S, K, or a burden, M, TA,) and he, (a man, S, Mgh,) caused a camel, (S, M, Mgh,) or a horse or the like, (K,) to have galls, or sores, on the back; galled the back. (M, Mgh, K. *) ― -b2- And His camel became galled in the back. (S, K.) ― -b3- See also 1, last signification. ＝ -A4- It is also said [app., of a man, as meaning He slit the ear of a she-camel in a particular manner, i. e.,] when (T) the fatolap [or twisted slip formed by slitting (see UidobaArapN)] of the ear of a she-camel, (T, K,) it being slit, (T, [but for AcA nHrt in the TT and TA, from which this is taken, I read UicaA buHirato, an emendation evidently required,]) turns towards the back of the neck: (IAar, T, TT, K, * TA:) and Oaqobala is said in like manner when this ftlp is turned towards the face. (IAar, T, TT, TA. [See also 3.]) ＝ -A5- It signifies also Earafa dabiyrahu mino qabiylihi, (IAar,) or Earafa qabiylahu mino dabiyrihi; (K;) said of a man. (IAar. [See dabiyrN.]) ＝ -A6- Also He, (K,) a man, (TA,) or it, a company of men, (S, M,) entered upon [a time in which blew] the wind called AldRabuwr. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A7- And He journeyed on the day called dubaAr, i. e. Wednesday. (K, TA.) ＝ -A8- And He became possessed of much property or wealth, or of many camels or the like. (Msb, * K.)

5 tadabRaxa
5: see 2, in nine places. ― -b2- Earafa AlOamora tadabRurFA means He knew the thing at the last, (M, Mgh,) after it had past. (Mgh.) Jereer says, (M,)
walaA tatRaquwna AlXRarRa HatRaIyuSiybakumo
walaA taEorifuwna AlOamora UilRaA tadabRuraA
[And ye fear not evil until it befalleth you, and ye know not the thing save at the last, when it has past]. (M, Mgh. *) [See also 10.] And in like manner, tadabRara AlkalaAma [meaning He postponed the saying] is said of one who has sworn after doing a thing. (Mgh.)

6 tdAbrwA tdAbr tdAbrwA
6. tdAbrwA They turned their backs, one upon another. (A'Obeyd, T.) ― -b2- And hence, (A'Obeyd, T,) (assumed tropical:) They severed themselves, one from another, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) and avoided, or shunned, one another; (A'Obeyd, T;) became at variance, one with another; (A;) regarded, or treated, one another with enmity, or hostility: (M, A:) or it is only said of the sons of one father, or ancestor. (M.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) They spoke [evil], one of another, behind the other's back. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) They abstained from, or neglected, aiding, or assisting, one another. (TA in art. xcl.)

10 Astdbrhu Ostdbrh Astdbrh Astdbrp Qstdbr Qstdbrh
10. Astdbrhu contr. of Astqblhu. (S, * Msb, K. *) [As such it signifies He turned his back towards him, or it.] You say, Astdbr Alqibolapa He turned his back towards the kibleh. (MA.) ― -b2- [As such also,] He came behind him. (TA.) You say, Astdbrhu faramaAhu (A, TA) He came behind him and cast, or shot, at him. (TA.) ― -b3- [As such also, He saw it behind him: he looked back to it: he saw it, or knew it, afterwards:] he saw, (M, K,) or knew, (TA,) at the end of it, namely, an affair, or a case, what he did not see, (M, K,) or know, (TA,) at the beginning of it: (M, K:) [or rather] he knew it at the end of an affair, or a case; namely, a thing that he did not know at the beginning of it. (T, A.) You say, Aisotadobara mino Oamorihi maAlamo yasotaqobilo He knew at the end of his affair, or case, what he did not know at the beginning of it. (A.) And UinRa fulaAnFA lawi Qsotaqobala mino Oamorihi maA Qsotadobarahu lahudiIa liwijohapi Oamorihi Verily such a one, had he known at the beginning of his affair, or case, what he knew at the end thereof, had been directed to the right way of executing his affair. (T.) [See also 5.] ― -b4- Astdbrhu EalaI gayorihi He appropriated it to himself exclusively, in preference to others: (AO, K:) because he who does so turns his back upon others, and retires from them. (TA.) El-Aashà says, describing wine,
EalaI AlXRarobi Oawo munokirK maA Eulimo
tamazRarotuhaAgayora musotadobirK
i. e. [I sipped it] not appropriating [it] to myself exclusively [in preference to the other drinkers, nor denying what was known]. (AO, TA.)

daborN dbr
daborN The location, or quarter, that is behind a thing. (K. [In the CK, for xalof is put xalaf.]) Hence the saying, (TA,) jaEalotu kalaAmahu dabora OucuniI (assumed tropical:) I turned away from his speech, and feigned myself deaf to it: (T, S:) I did not listen to his speech, nor care for it, or regard it. (M, K, * TA.) You say also, Oucunihi jaEalahu daAbira↓ (tropical:) He turned away from him, avoided him, or shunned him. (T, * A.) ― -b2- See also dabariIRN. ― -b3- Also, [like UidobaArN, inf. n. of 4,] (assumed tropical:) Death. (K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Constant sleep: (M, K:) it is like tasobiyxN. (M.) ＝ -A2- I. q. dibaArN↓; these two words being pls. [or rather coll. gen. ns.] whereof the sings. [or ns. un.] are daborapN↓ and dibaArapN↓; which signify A maXaArap [explained in the TA as meaning a channel of water; but it seems to be here used as meaning a portion of ground separated from the adjacent parts, for sowing or planting, being surrounded by dams, or by ridges of earth, which retain the water for irrigation, as explained in art. Xwr, and as is indicated by its Persian equivalent here following,] in, (S,) or of, (K,) land that is sown or for sowing; (S, K;) called in Persian kurod: (S:) and dibaArN signifies small channels for irrigation between tracts of seedproduce; (K;) and its sing. is daborapN: (TA:) [Mtr says,] daborapN is syn. with maXaArapN; in Persian karodah [app. a mistranscription for kurod as above]; and the pl. is daborN and dibaArN: (Mgh:) [ISd says,] daborapN signifies a small channel for irrigation between tracts of land sown or for sowing: or, as some say, i. q. maXaArapN: and the pl. is dibaArN: it is also said that dibaArN signifies i. q. kurodapN; and its n. un. is dibaArapN: and dibaAraAtN signifies rivulets that flow through land of seed-produce; and its sing. is daborapN: but I know not how this is, unless daborapN have dibaArN for its pl., and this have p added to it, as in fiHaAlapN, and so dbArAt be a pl. pl., i. e. perfect pl. of dibaArapN: AHn says that daborapN signifies a patch of ground that is sown; [as is also said in the K;] and the pl. is dibaArN. (M.) ― -b2- Also A piece of rugged ground in a baHorN [i. e. sea or large river], like an island, which the water overflows [at times] and from which [at times] it recedes. (M, K.) ― -b3- And A mountain; (T, K;) in the Abyssinian language: (TA: [Az says, “I know not whether it be Arabic or not:”]) whence the saying of the King of Abyssinia, (T, * K, * TA,) maA OuHibRu OanRa liI daborFA cahabFA waOanRiIMcayotu rajulFA mina Almusolimiyna [I would not that I had a mountain of gold and that I had harmed a man of the Muslims]: (T, K:) but [SM says that] this is a confounding of two readings; which are, daborFA mino cahabK and Oano yakuwna daborN liI cahabFA: (TA:) another reading is caborFA mino cahabK. (TA in art. cbr.) ― -b4- See also diborN. ― -b5- Also, (S, M, K, &c.,) and diborN↓, (AHn, M, K,) A swarm of bees: and hornets, or large wasps; syn. zanaAbiyru: (S, M, K:) and the like thereof, having stings in their hinder parts: (B:) it has no sing., or n. un.: (As, M:) or the n. un. is daborapN↓ or diborapN↓; of which the dim. dubayorapN↓ occurs in a trad.: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OadoburN (K) and [of mult.] dubuwrN: (As, S, K:) and dabuwrN↓, with fet-h to the first letter, signifies bees; and has no proper sing. (M.) 'Ásim Ibn-Thábit El-Ansáree was called HamiIRu AldRabori [The protected of hornets, or bees], because his corpse was protected from his enemies by large hornets, (S,) or by a swarm of bees. (M, Mgh * in art. HmI.) ― -b6- daborN also signifies The young ones of locusts; (AHn, K;) and so diborN↓. (AHn, M, K.)

duborN dbr
duborN: see duburN: and dabariIRN; the latter in two places. ＝ -A2- See also 4, first sentence.

diborN dbr
diborN: see daborN, last sentence but two, and last sentence. ― -b2- Also, (S, M, K,) and daborN↓, (M, K,) Much property or wealth; or many camels or the like; (S, M, K;) such as cannot be computed, or calculated: (M:) the sing. [and dual] and pl. are alike: you say [using it as an epithet] maAlN diborN and maAlaAni diborN and OamowaAlN diborN: (S, M:) this mode of usage is best known; but sometimes dubuwrN is used as its pl.: (M:) in like manner you say maAlN davorN: and you say also rajulN cuw diborK, (S, TA,) and rjl dbr, [unless this be a mistake for the phrase immediately preceding,] (Fr, TA,) meaning a man having large possessions in land or houses or other property. (Fr, S, TA.)

dabarN dbr
dabarN [app. signifies A tract of the western sky at sunset: for] the Arabs said, UicaA raOayota AlvRurayRaA bidabaro faXahorN nitaAjo waXahorN maTaro waUicaA raOayota AlXRiEoraI biqabalo famajodu fatFI waHimolu jamalo, meaning When thou seest the Pleiades near to setting with sunset, then [is a month which] is a time of breeding of camels, and [a month which is] a time of rain: and when thou seest Sirius [near to rising] with sunset, [then is the glory of the generous man, and the time for the burden of the full-grown hecamel; for] then is the most intense degree of cold, when none but the generous and noble and
ingenuous man will patiently persevere in the exercise of hospitality and beneficence, and when the heavy burden is not laid save upon the strong full-grown he-camel, because then the camels become lean and the pasturage is scanty. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also, and so is OadobaArN, a pl. [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n.] of dabarapN↓, (S, M, K,) which signifies A gall, or sore, on the back (M, * Mgh, K, * TA) of a horse or the like (M, K, TA) and of a camel, (M, Mgh,) produced by the saddle and the like; (Mgh;) and also on the kirokirap [or callous projection on the breast] of a camel. (S and K in art. sr.) They used to say, in the Time of Ignorance, UicaA baraOa AldRabaru waEafaA AlOavaru, explained as meaning [When] the galls on the back of the beast or upon the foot of the camel [shall heal, and the footstep, or mark, become obliterated]. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A3- Also inf. n. of dabira. (M, Mgh.)

dabirN dbr
dabirN (M, K) and Oadobaru↓ (M) A horse or the like, (M, K,) and a camel, (M,) having galls, or sores, (M, K,) on his back (TA) [produced by the saddle and the like; having his back galled: see dabarN]: fem. [of the former] dabirapN and [of the latter] daboraMCu↓: and pl. [of either] daboraI. (M, TA.) [Hence the prov.,] haAna EalaI AlOamolasi maA laAqaI AldRabiru [What he that had galls on his back experienced was a light matter to him that had a sound back]: applied to one who has an ill concern for his companion. (K.) ― -b2- In the phrase rajulN xasirN wadabirN [app. meaning A man erring and perishing], Lh says that dabirN is an imitative sequent to xasirN: but [ISd says,] I think that xasirN is a verbal epithet, and that dabirN is a possessive epithet. (M in art. dmr.) You say also OaHomaqN daAmirN xaAsirN daAbirN↓: (T in art. bt: [see art. xsr:]) and daAbirN is said to be an imitative sequent to xaAsirN. (TA.)

duburN dbr
duburN and duborN↓, (the latter a contraction of the former, Msb, [and not so commonly used, like as UibolN is not so commonly used as UibilN,]) The back; syn. ZahorN: (S, A, B, K;) the first signification given in the [S and] A and B: pl. OadobaArN. (TA.) You say, walRaI duburahu [lit., He turned his back; and tropically,] (tropical:) he was put to flight. (A.) And walRaAhu duburahu [lit., He turned his back to him; and tropically,] the same as the phrase immediately preceding. (Mgh, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [liv. 45], wayuwalRuwna AldRubura [And they shall turn the back, in flight]: where Aldbr is used in a collective sense, agreeably with another passage in the Kur [xiv. 44], laA yarotadRu Uilayohimo Tarofuhumo. (S, B.) You also say, walRawoA daborapF↓ (tropical:) They turned back in flight, or being routed. (A, TA.) ― -b2- The back, or hinder part, contr. of qubulN, (S, A, Msb, K,) of anything: (Msb:) as, for instance, of a shirt. (Kur xii. 25, 27, and 28.) You say, waqaEa AlsRahomu bidubori Alhadafi The arrow fell behind the butt. (TA in art. qbl.) ― -b3- The backside; posteriors; buttocks; rump; or podex: and the anus: syn. AisotN. (K.) [It has the former of these two significations in many instances; and the latter of them in many other instances: in the S and K in art. jEr, it is given as a syn. of majoEarN, which has the latter signification in the present day. This latter signification may also be intended in the S, M, A, Msb, and K, by the explanation “ contr. of qubulN, ” as well as the “ back, or hinder part, ” of anything: for qubulN very often signifies the “ anterior pudendum ” of a man or woman, and is so explained. The anus is also called Haloqapu AldRuburi and HitaAru AldRuburi and Xaraju AldRuburi.] Its pl. OadobaArN is also applied to the part which comprises the Aisot [or anus] and the HayaMC [or vulva, i. e., external portion of the female organs of generation,] of a solid-hoofed animal, and of a cloven-hoofed animal, and of that which has claws, or talons: or, as some say, of a camel, or an animal having feet like those of the camel: and the sing., to the HayaMC [or vulva] alone, of any such animal. (M, TT.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The latter, or last, part, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) of a thing, an affair, or an event, (T, S, Msb,) or of anything: (M, K:) pl. OadobaArN (M) [and dibaArN: see dabariIRN]. [See also daAbirN.] One says, jiYotuka duburi AlXRahori, and fiI duburihi, and EalaI duburihi, and OadobaAra AlXRahori, and fiI OadobaArihi, (tropical:) I came to thee in the latter, or last, part or parts, of the month. (M, K.) And OadoEuw laka fiI OadobaAri AlSRalawaAti (assumed tropical:) [I will petition for thee in the latter, or last, parts, or the conclusions, of the prayers]. (A.) See also dabariIRN. In the Kur [I. xxxix.], waOadobaAra AlsRujuwdi signifies (assumed tropical:) And in the latter parts, or the ends, of the prayers: and AlsRujuwdi waUidobaAra↓ [virtually] signifies the same [i. e. and in the ending of prostration], and is another reading of the text: Ks and Th adopt the former reading, because every single prostration has its latter part: or, accord. to the T, the meaning is, and in the two rek'ahs (AlrRakoEataAni) after sunset; as is related on the authority of 'Alee the son of Aboo-Tálib. (TA.) The similar expression in the Kur [lii. last verse] waOadobaAra AlnRujuwmi is explained by the lexicologists as signifying (assumed tropical:) And during the consecution of the stars, and their taking towards the west, to set: but [ISd says,] I know not how this is, since OaxocN, by which they explain it, is an inf. n., and OadobaAr is a pl. of a subst.: AlnRujuwmi waUidobaAra↓, which is another reading of the text, signifies and during the setting of the stars: and Ks and Th adopt this latter reading: (M:) or, accord. to the T, both mean and in the two rek'ahs before daybreak. (TA.) ― -b5- Also The hinder part, (M,) and angle, (zaAwiyap,) of a house or chamber or tent. (M, K.) ― -b6- Eitoqa AlEabodi Eano duburK (S, K) means The emancipation of the slave after the death of his owner. (S, Mgh, * Msb. * [See 2.]) ― -b7- [See also dabiyrN, of which, and of dibaArN, duburN is said in the TA in art. qbl to be a pl.].

daborapN dbr dbrh dbrp
daborapN: see duburN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A turn of evil fortune; an unfavourable turn of fortune: or a turn to be vanquished; contr. of dawolapN: (As, M, K:) dawolapN relates to good; and daborapN, to evil: one says, jaEala QllRehu Ealayohi AldRaborapa (assumed tropical:) [May God make the turn of evil fortune to be against him]: (As, T, M:) this [says ISd] is the best explanation that I have seen of daborapN: (M:) or (so accord. to the M, but in the K “ and ”) it signifies (assumed tropical:) the issue, or result, of a thing or an affair or a case; (M, K;) as in the saying of Aboo-Jahl to Ibn-Mes'ood, when he [the former] lay prostrate, wounded, limani AldRaborapu (assumed tropical:) In whose favour is the issue, or result? and was answered, “ In favour of God and his apostle, O enemy of God: ” (T, TA:) also (tropical:) defeat in fight; (S, A, Mgh, K;) a subst. from AlUidobaAru, as also dabarapN↓, (S,) and daAbirapN↓: (IAar, A, K:) you say, kaAnati AldRaborapu lahu, meaning (tropical:) His adversary was defeated; and Ealayohi meaning (tropical:) He was himself defeated: (A:) and limani AldRaborapu, meaning (assumed tropical:) Who is the defeater? and EalaImani AldRaborapu (assumed tropical:) Who is the defeated? the pl. of daborapN in the last sense is dibaArN: (TA:) which also signifies conflicts and defeats; (K;) as in the saying, OawoqaEa QllRehu bihimu AldRibaAra God caused, or may God cause, to befall them conflicts and defeats. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also daborN, in two places.

diborapN dbr dbrh dbrp
diborapN The direction, or point, towards which one turns his back; contr. of qibolapN. (S, K.) One says, maA lahu qibolapN walaA diborapN, meaning (tropical:) He has no way of applying himself rightly to his affair. (S, K, TA.) And layosa lihecaA AlOamori qibolapN walaA diborapN (tropical:) The right way of executing this affair is not known. (S, A.) ― -b2- See also UidobaArapN. ＝ -A2- And see daborN, near the end.

dabarapN dbr dbrh dbrp
dabarapN: see daborapN: ＝ -A2- and see also dabarN.

dabaraI dbr dbrI dbry dbryy
dabaraI: see 1.

daboriIRN dbr dbrI dbry dbryy
daboriIRN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

dabariIRN dbr dbrI dbry dbryy
dabariIRN [Backward: and hence, (tropical:) late]. You say, AlEilomu qabaliIRNwalayosa biAldRabariIRi (assumed tropical:) [True learning is prompt, and is not backward]: i. e., the man of sound learning answers thee quickly; but the backward says, I must consider it. (Th, T.) And tabiEotu SaAHibiI dabariyRFA (assumed tropical:) I followed my companion, fearing that he would escape me, after having been with him, and having fallen back from him. (M.) And XarRu AlrRaOoIi AldRabariIRu (T, S, A, K *) (tropical:) The worst opinion, or counsel, is that which occurs [to one] late, when the want [of it] is past; (T, S, K, * TA;) i. e., when the affair is past: or raOoIN dabariIRN signifies an opinion, or a counsel, not deeply looked into; and in like manner, jawaAbN, an answer, or a reply. (M.) And fulaAnN laA yuSalRiI AlSRalaApa UilRaA dabariyRFA (AZ, S, M, A, K) and daboriyRFA↓, (AHeyth, K,) and the relaters of traditions say duburiyRFA↓, (S,) which is said in the K to be a corruption, but it may have been heard from a good authority, and with respect to the rules of the language is chaste, for, accord. to IAth, dabariIRN is a rel. n. irregularly formed from duburN, (TA,) (tropical:) Such a one performs not prayer save in the last part of its time. (AZ, S, K *) It is said in
a trad., laA yaOotiI AlSRalaApi UilRaA dabariyRFA; and in another, AlRA duborFA↓ or daborFA↓, accord. to different relations; (tropical:) He will not come to prayer save at the last, or late: and in another, OataI AlSRalaApa dibaArFA↓ (tropical:) He came to prayer at the latest of the times thereof; (IAar, TA;) or after the time had gone: (S:) dibaArN↓ being a pl. of duburN↓ and duborN↓ meaning the last of the times of prayer &c. (IAar, TA.) One says also, jaMCa fulaAnN daboriyRFA↓ (tropical:) Such a one came last, or latest. (A, * TA.) dbryRFA is in the accus. case as an adv. n. of time [like duborFA and daborFA and dibaArFA], or as a denotative of state with respect to the agent of the verb. (TA.) In the passage in the K [where it is said that dabariIRN signifies Prayer in the last of its time, &c.], there is a looseness. (TA.)

duburiIRN dbr dbrI dbry dbryy
duburiIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

AldRabaraAnu AldbrAn dbr
AldRabaraAnu [The Hyades: or the five chief stars of the Hyades: or the brightest star among them, a of Taurus:] five stars of Taurus, said to be his hump; (S;) one of the Mansions of the Moon; [namely, the Fourth;] a certain star, or asterism, between AlvRurayRaA [or the Pleiades] and AljawozaMCu [or Orion], also called AltRaAbiEu and AltRuwayobiEu; (T;) it follows AlvryRA, (T, M,) and therefore is thus named. (T.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl: and see AlmijodaHu, in art. jdH.]

dubaArN dbAr
dubaArN, (S, M, K, [in the M, accord. to the TT, written dubaAru, and it occurs in poetry imperfectly decl., but there is no reason for its being so in prose,]) and dibaArN↓, (K,) Wednesday; the fourth day of the week; (S, K;) an ancient name thereof: (S, M, * TA:) or, accord. to the 'Eyn, (K,) the night of [i. e. preceding the day of] Wednesday: (M, K:) which latter explanation is preferred by some authorities. (TA.) Wednesday is a day of ill luck: Mujáhid, being asked respecting the day of ill luck, answered, “ The Wednesday that does not come round [again, i. e. the last Wednesday,] in the month. ” (TA.)

dibaArN dbAr
dibaArN: see dabariIRN, in two places. ― -b2- You say also, fulaAnN maA yadoriI qibaAla AlOamori mino dibaArihi Such a one does not know the first part of the affair from the last thereof. (TA.) And maA yaEorifu qibaAlFA: mino dibaArK: see dabiyrN. And maA Oanota lahumo fiI qibaAlK walaA dibaArK (assumed tropical:) Thou art not one for whom they care. (TA in art. qbl.) ＝ -A2- See also daborN: ＝ -A3- and dubaArN.

dabuwrN dbwr
dabuwrN, used as a subst. and as an epithet, [of the fem. gender,] so that one says either riyHu AldRabuwri or riyHN dabuwrN and simply dabuwrN, but more commonly used as an epithet, (M,) [The west wind: or a westerly wind: the west being regarded as the hinder quarter:] the wind that is opposite to that called AlSRabaA (S, L, Msb, K) and Alqabuwlu, (L,) blowing from the direction of the place of sunset: (L, Msb:) or the wind that comes from [the direction of] the back, or hinder part, of the Kaabeh, going towards the place of sunrise: (M:) but IAth rejects this explanation: (TA:) or the wind that comes from the quarter behind a person when he is standing at the kibleh: [but this is a most strange explanation:] or, accord. to IAar, the wind that blows from the tract extending from the place where En-Nesr et-Táïr [or Aquila] sets [i. e. about W. 10° N. in Central Arabia] to the place where Suheyl [or Canopus] rises [about S. 29° E. in Central Arabia]: (M:) or that comes from the direction of the south (Aljanuwb), going towards the place of sunrise: (Msb:) it is the worst of winds: it is said that it does not fecundate trees, nor raise clouds: (Meyd, TA:) and in a trad. it is said that the tribe of 'Ád was destroyed by it: (T, TA:) it blows only in the hot season, and is very thirsty: (TA voce nakobaMCu:) pl. duburN and dabaAYiru. (M.) [Hence the saying,] EaSafato dabuwruhu wasaqaTato Eabuwruhu [lit. His west wind, or westerly wind, blew violently, and his Sirius set: meaning (tropical:) his evil fortune prevailed, and his good fortune departed: for the dbwr is the worst of winds, as observed above, and Sirius sets aurorally in the beginning of winter, when provisions become scarce]. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also daborN, last sentence but two.

dabiyrN dbyr
dabiyrN A twist which a woman turns backward (bihi maA Oadobarato↓), in twisting it: (S, K:) or what one turns backward from his chest [in rolling it against the front of his body]: (Yaakoob, S, A, K:) and qabiylN signifies “ what one turns forward (maA Oaqobala bihi) towards his chest: ” (Yaakoob, S, A:) or the former, what the twister turns backward towards his knee [in rolling it against his thigh; against which, or against the front of the body, the spindle is commonly rolled, except when it is twirled only with the hand while hanging loosely]: and the latter, “ what he turns forward towards his flank or waist: ” (As, T:) [whence the saying,] qabalotu OuxoraI AlHabolu marRapF wa dabarotuhu↓ [I turned the rope, or cord, forward, or toward me, in twisting it, one time, and turned it backward, or from me, another time]: (TA in art. qbl:) or dabiyrN signifies the twisting of flax and wool: and qabiylN, the “ twisting of cotton. ” (Lth, T.) One says, Earafa qabiylahu mino dabiyrihi, meaning (tropical:) He knew, or distinguished, his obedience from his disobedience; (K,) TA;) or dabiyrahu mino qabiylihi his disobedience from his obedience. (Aboo-' Amr Esh-Sheybánee, IAar, T.) And fulaAnN maA yaEorifu qabiylFA mino dabiyrK (S, A) or qabiylahu mn dabiyrihi (TA) (tropical:) [Such a one knows not &c.]: or maA yaEorifu qabiylFA mino dabiyrK and qibaAlFA mino dibaArK↓ he knows not the ewe, or she-goat, that is termed muqaAbalap from that which is termed mudaAbarap: or him who advances towards him from him who goes back from him: or the parentage of his mother from that of his father: (K in art. qbl:) or that of his father from that of his mother: so says IDrd in explaining the former phrase: or a qubul from a dubur: or a thing when advancing from a thing when going back: and the pls. of each are qubulN and duburN. (TA in that art.) Accord. to El-Mufaddal, dabiyrN signifies An arrow's losing in a game of chance [such as Almayosir]; and qabiylN, its “ winning therein. ” (T, TA.) [See qabiylN, in art. qbl.] ― -b2- Also The upper [because it is the hinder] part of the ear of a camel: the lower part is called the qabiyl. (TA in art. qbl.)

dibaArapN dbArh dbArp
dibaArapN: see daborN.

dubayorapN dbyrh dbyrp
dubayorapN: see daborN.

daAbirN dAbr
daAbirN act. part. n. of dabara, Following (S, K, TA) behind the back; following the back; following, with respect to place, and also with respect to time, and also (assumed tropical:) with respect to rank or station. (TA.) [Hence,] daAbiru qawomK The last that remains of a people or party; he who comes at the end of a people or party; as also daAbiratuhumo↓; which likewise signifies those who remain after them: and daAbirapN↓ [so in the TA, but accord. to the T daAbirN, which I think the right reading,] signifies one who comes after; or follows, another. (TA.) And AldRalowu bayona qaAbilK wadaAbirK The bucket is between one who advances with it to the well and one who goes back, or returns, with it to the wateringtrough. (A.) And jaEalahu daAbira Oucunihi: see daborN. And Oamosi AldRaAbiru and Almudobiru↓ Yesterday that is past: (S, M, K:) the epithet being here a corroborative. (S, * M.) You say, SaAruwA kaOamosi AldRaAbiri [They became like yesterday that is past]. (A.) And hayohaAta cahaba kamaA cahaba Oamosi AldRaAbiru [Far distant is he, or it! He, or it, hath gone like as hath gone yesterday that is past]. (S.) ― -b2- Also An arrow that passes forth from the butt, (S, Msb, K,) [or passes beyond it, (see 1,)] and falls behind it: (TA:) you say sahomN daAbirN, and sihaAmN daAbirapN and dawaAbiru. (Msb.) ― -b3- An arrow that does not win [in the game called Almayosir]; (K, TA;) contr. of qaAbilN. (S, TA.) ― -b4- The last arrow remaining in the quiver. (A.) ― -b5- The last of anything; (Ibn-Buzurj, T, M, K;) and so daAbirapN↓: (M:) [see also duburN:] and (accord. to As and others, TA) the root, stock, race, or the like; syn. OaSolN. (K.) One says, qaTaEa QllRehu daAbirahumo May God cut off the last that remain of them. (S.) And qaTaEa QllRehu daAbirahu May God cut off the last of him, or it: (A:) or may God extirpate him. (As, T.) And in the Kur [vi. 45] it is said, faquTiEa daAbiru Alqawomi And the last of the people were extirpated. (M, TA.) And in a trad., yuqoTaEu bihi daAbiruhumo All of them shall be cut off thereby, not one remaining. (TA.) ― -b6- See also dabirN, last sentence. ― -b7- As an epithet applied to a camel: see gudRapN.

daAbirapN dAbr dAbrh dAbrp
daAbirapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) The end of a tract of sand: (Esh-Sheybánee, S, A, * K:) pl. dawaAbiru. (A.) ― -b3- Of a solid hoof, The hinder part: (T, TA:) or the part that corresponds to the hinder part of the pastern: (S, K:) or the part that is next after the hinder part of the pastern: (M, TA:) pl. as above. (T, TA.) ― -b4- Of a bird, The back toe: it is with this that the hawk strikes: (M, TA:) or a thing like a toe, in the inner side of the foot, with which the bird strikes: (S:) that of a cook is beneath his SiySiyap [or spur]; and with it he treads: (M, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b5- See also daborapN. ― -b6- Also A mode of XagozabiyRap [or throwing down by a trick] (S, K) in wrestling. (S.)

Oadobaru c
Oadobaru; and its fem. daboraMhu: see dabirN.

UidobaArN OdbAr UdbAr AdbAr dbr
UidobaArN [originally inf. n. of 4]: see the next paragraph, in two places.

UidobaArapN OdbArh UdbAr UdbArh AdbArh AdbArp dbr
UidobaArapN A slit in the ear [of a ewe or she-goat or she-camel], which being made, that thing [thus made, meaning the pendulous strip,] is twisted, and turned backward: if turned forward, it is termed UiqobaAlapN: and the hanging piece of skin of the ear is termed UidobaArapN [in the former case] and UiqobaAlapN [in the latter case]; as though it were a zanamap [q. v.]; (As, S, M, * K;) and, respectively, UidobaArN↓ and UiqobaAlN, and diborapo↓ and qibolapN. (TA in art. qbl.) The ewe or she-goat [to which this has been done] is termed mudaAbarapN↓ [in the former case] and muqaAbalapN [in the latter]: and you say of yourself [when you have performed the operation, in these two cases respectively], daAbarotuhaA and qaAbalotuhaA: and the she-camel is termed caAtu UidobaArap and caAtu UiqobaAlapN; (As, S, K;) and so is the ewe or she-goat; (As, T;) and the she-camel, caAtu UidobaArK↓ and caAtN UiqobaAlK. (TA in art. qbl.)

OudaAbirN c
OudaAbirN A man who cuts, or severs, the ties, or bonds, of his relationship; who disunites himself from his relations; (S, K;) like OubaAtirN: (S:) one who does not accept what any one says, (AO, [who mentions OubaAtirN therewith as having the former signification,] T, S, M, K,) nor regard anything: (AO, T, S, M:) one who will not receive admonition. (IKtt.) [See OuxaAyilN.]

mudobirN mdbr
mudobirN [Going, turning his back; turning back; &c.: see its verb, 4]. You say, maA lahumo mino muqobilK walaA mudobirK They have not one that goes forward nor one that goes back. (A.) In the phrase in the Kur [ix. 25], vumRa walRayotumo mudobiriyna [Then ye turned back retreating], the last word is a corroborative denotative of state; for with every tawoliyap is UidobaAr. (M.) See also daAbirN. ― -b2- naAbN mudobirN is said to signify (assumed tropical:) An aged she-camel whose goodness has gone. (TA.) ― -b3- OaroDN mdbrpN [app. mudobirapN] (assumed tropical:) A land upon which rain has fallen partially, not generally, or not universally. (TA in art. qbl. [This explanation is there given as though applying also to ArD mqblp, app. muqobilapN; but I think that there is an omission, and that the latter phrase has the contr. meaning.])

madobarapN mdbr mdbrh mdbrp
madobarapN i. q. UidobaArN [inf. n. of 4, q. v.]. (M.)

mudabRarN mdbr
mudabRarN A slave made to be free after his owner's death; (S;) to whom his owner has said, “ Thou art free after my death; ” whose emancipation has been made to depend upon his owner's death. (TA.)

mudabRirN mdbr
mudabRirN [is extensively and variously applied as meaning One who manages, conducts, orders, or regulates, affairs of any kind, but generally affairs of importance]. faQlomadabRiraAti OamorFA, in the Kur [lxxix. 5], signifies [accord. to most of the Expositors] And those angels who are charged with the managing, conducting, ordering, or regulating, of affairs. (TA. [See also Bd.])

madobuwrN mdbwr
madobuwrN, (TA,) and madobuwruwna, (S,) A man, (TA,) and people, (S,) smitten, or affected, by the [westerly] wind called AldRabuwr. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, the former, Wounded: (K:) or galled in the back. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And Possessing much property or wealth, or many camels or the like. (K.)

mudaAbarN mdAbr
mudaAbarN applied to a place of abode, Contr. of muqaAbalN. (M.) You say, hecaA jaAriI muqaAbaliI and mudaAbariI [This is my neighbour in front of me and in rear of me]. (TA in art. qbl.) ― -b2- mudaAbarapN applied to a ewe or she-goat: see UidobaArapN: so applied, Having a portion of the hinder part of her ear cut, and left hanging down, not separated: and also when it is separated: and muqaAbalapN is applied in like manner to one having a portion of the extremity [or fore part] of the ear so cut: (As, T:) and the former, applied to a she-camel, having her ear slit in the part next the back of the neck: or having a piece cut off from that part of her ear: and in like manner applied to a ewe or she-goat: also an ear cut, or slit, in the hinder part. (M.) [It seems that a she-camel had her ear thus cut if of generous race. And hence,] naAqapN muqaAbalapN mudaAbarapN (tropical:) A she-camel of generous race by sire and dam. (T, TA.) And fulaAnN muqaAbalN wa mudaAbarN (tropical:) Such a one is of pure race, (S, K,) or of generous, or noble, race, (A,) by both parents: (S, A, K:) accord. to As, (S,) from AlUiqobaAlapu and AlUidobaArapu. (S, K.)

mudaAbirN mdAbr
mudaAbirN [act. part. n. of 3, q. v.:] (assumed tropical:) One who turns back, or away, from his companion; who avoids, or shuns, him. (As.) ― -b2- Also A man whose arrow does not win [in the game called Almayosir]: (S, K:) or one who is overcome in the game called Almysr: or one who has been overcome [therein] time after time, and returns in order that he may overcome: or, accord. to A'Obeyd, he who turns about, or shuffles, the arrows in the ribaAbap in that game. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. xD.]

fulaAnN musotadobirN Almajodi musotaqobiluhu flAn mstdbr Almjd mstqblh flAn mstdbr Almjd mstqblp
fulaAnN musotadobirN Almajodi musotaqobiluhu (tropical:) Such a one is [as though he had behind him and before him honour or dignity or nobility; meaning that he is] generous, or noble, in respect of his first and his last acquisition of honour or dignity. (TA. [But it is there without any syll. signs; and with mstqbl in the place of musotaqobiluhu.])

4 Adbst AlOaroDu c
4. Adbst AlOaroDu The land showed its plants or herbage: (K:) or began to show the blackness of its plants or herbage. (AHn, M, S.)

9 AdbsR Adbs
9. AdbsR, inf. n. AidobisaAsN; (S, K;) or AdbAsR↓; (M;) He (a horse, S, M, K, and a sheep, or goat, M, and a bird, S) became black: (K:) or [brown; i. e.] of a colour between black and red; (S;) or black tinged, or intermixed, with redness. (M, TA.) [See dubosapN and Oadobasu.]

11 UidobaAosRa
11: see 9. AdbAsRt AlOaroDu The blackness of the land became mixed with redness. (M, TA.)

dabosN dbs
dabosN Anything black. (Lth, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] Much people; as also dibosN↓: (IAar, K:) the former is also common to other things; (M, * TA;) so that you say maAlN dabosN, meaning much property. (TA.)

dubosN dbs
dubosN: see the next paragraph.

dibosN dbs
dibosN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and dubosN↓ (M) and dibisN↓ (K) The expressed juice of fresh ripe dates; (A, Mgh, Msb;) what flows from fresh ripe dates; (S;) the honey of dates; [i. e. the sweet, thick, or inspissated, juice thereof;] (M, K;) the expressed juice of dates, (M,) or of fresh ripe dates not cooked: (AHn, M:) what is called SaqorN in the dial. of the people of ElMedeeneh: said by some to be the honey of fresh ripe dates: by some, what flows, or exudes, from raisins and from fresh grapes: and by some, what flows from the baskets of dates: (TA:) [see also rubRN, in an explanation of which the inspissated juice of any fruit is termed its dibos:] also the honey of bees, Easalu AlnRaHolu: so in the copies of the K and in [some of the copies of] the A; a signification not known; but [AHn] EdDeenawaree mentions the word dabaAsaAtN, and explains it as signifying “ domestic bee-hives; ” and by this it is seen that the application of dbs to what bees eject may be correct: or the true reading may be Easalu AlnRaxoli, with x, as in some copies of the A; and it may be meant as explaining what precedes, meaning the expressed juice of the fruit of the palm-tree, by a kind of trope; though, as such, a useless repetition: but it is said in the O, on the authority of IDrd, that bees' honey is called dibisN↓: (TA:) the vulgar apply the word to [the inspissated juice of fresh ripe grapes, which resembles thick honey: and sometimes to] the honey of raisins. (MF.) ＝ -A2- See also dabosN.

dibisN dbs
dibisN: see dibosN, in two places.

dubosapN dbs dbsh dbsp
dubosapN A colour in animals that have hair; (Msb;) [brownness;] or redness tinged, or intermixed, with blackness: (M, Msb:) it is in sheep, or goats, and in horses; (M;) [and in birds: see 9:] accord. to Hoseyn Ibn-' Abd-Allah El-Isbahánee, in his book on strange pigeons, greenness, or a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, in which are redness and blackness. (TA.) [See also Oadobasu.]

dubosiIRN dbs dbsI dbsy

(TA.) You say also layolN dajuwjiIRN Dark night: (S, A, K:) or intensely dark night; and so dajuwjN↓ and dujaAjiIRN↓ (TA:) and layolapN dayojuwjN↓ (S, K) and dajodaAjapN↓ (K) a dark night: S, K:) the pl. of dayojuwjN↓ is dayaAjiyjN and dayaAjRN the latter a contraction of the former. daAjRN dAj dAjy
daAjRN [part. n. of 1]. You say jamaAEapN daAjRapN A party, or company, creeping along; i. e., going, or walking, leisurely, softly, or gently: (ISk, S:) or doing so with short steps: or coming and going. (TA.) And Oaqobala AlHaAjRu wa AldRaAjRu (S, * K, * TA) The [company of pilgrims to Mekkeh, and of the] letters-out of camels &c., and the servants, or assistants, (S, K,) and the like attendants of the pilgrims, came: (TA:) the two words HAjR and dAjR, though sings., are used in the pl. sense: (TA:) or AldAjR signifies also the merchants; (K;) or the merchants and others who go leisurely, or creep along, after the pilgrims. (TA.) AldAjR has the same meaning in the words of a trad., heWulaMCi AldRaAjRu walayosuwA biAljaAjRi [These are the lettersout of camels &c., and they are not the pilgrims]: (S, K:) said by Ibn-' Omar, of a people whom he saw among the pilgrims, whose appearance he disliked: or it means, accord. to A 'Obeyd, those who are with the pilgrims, such as the hired men, and the camel-drivers, and the servants, and the like; and Ibn-' Omar meant that these were not pilgrims in the proper sense, but merely persons journeying and creeping along. (TA.) In the words of another trad., maA tarakotu mino HaAjapK walaA daAjapK UilRaA Oatayotu, the word dAjp is without teshdeed, and is an imitative sequent to HAjp: (S:) [see art. dwj:] but accord. to one relation, it is mA trkt HaAjRapN walaA daAjRapN, meaning, accord. to El-Khattábee, [I left not a company of] pilgrims to Mekkeh, nor those returning. (TA.) One says also, OamaA waHawaAjRi bayoti QllRehi wa dawaAjRihi laOafoEalanRa kacaA wakacaA [Nay, by the pilgrims to the House of God, and those who journey thither for mercantile purposes, I will assuredly do such and such things]. (TA.)

(S, O.) You say, daxalotu madoxalFA HasanFA [like duxuwlFA HasanFA I entered with a good entering]. (S.) And daxalotu Albayota (S) or AldRaAra, i. e. [I entered the house, or] I became within the house, and the like, (Msb,) correctly meaning UilaI Albayoti [&c., or fiI Albayoti &c., i. e. I entered into the house, &c.], the prep. being suppressed, and the noun put in the accus. case after the manner of an objective complement: for nouns of place are of two kinds, vague and definite; the vague being such as the six relative locations, xalofN, and qudRaAmN, and yamiynN, and XimaAlN, and fawoqN, and taHotN, and the like, such as OamaAmN, and waraMCN, and OaEolaI, and Oasofalu, and Einoda, and laduno, and wasoTN in the sense of bayonN, and qubaAlapN, all which, and similar nouns of place, may become adverbs, because indefinite; for dost thou not see that what is xalof to thee may be qudRaAm to another? but that which is definite, having make, and corporeal substance, and tracts that comprehend it, as a mountain and a valley and a market and a house and a mosque, the noun signifying such a thing cannot become an adverb; for you may not say, qaEadotu AldRaAra, nor SalRayotu Almasojida, nor nimotu Aljabala, nor qumotu AlwaAdiIa; the phrases of this kind that occur being instances of the suppression of a prep.; as daxalotu Albayota, and nazalotu AlwaAdiIa, and SaEidotu Aljabala. (S, O, TA.) You say also, daxalotu EalaI zayodK AldRaAra, meaning I entered the house after Zeyd, he being in it. (Msb.) [And simply daxala Ealayohi He came in upon him: and also he came upon him; i. e. invaded him.] And daxala biQmoraOatihi, (Msb, TA,) and EalayohaA, (MA,) inf. n. duxuwlN, (Mgh, Msb,) [like daxala biOaholihi, and EalayohaA, (see OaholN,) i. e. AlwaToC, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) whether it be such as is allowed by the law or such as is forbidden, (Mgh,) generally such as is lawful. (Msb, TA. [See what is said in explanation of the term xalowapN in the first paragraph of art. xlw.]) And daxala baEoDuhu fiI baEoDK i. q. tadaAxala [q. v.]. (TA in art. qSr, &c.) [For ex.,] you say, daxala baEoDu AlnRujuwmi fiI baEoDK [The stars became confused together]. (Mgh and TA in art. Xbk: in the former coupled with AixotalaTato.) And daxala fiyhimo [He entered among them, so as to become a member of their community, confraternity, party, sect, or the like;] said of a stranger. (K.) [And daxala fiI TaAEatihi: see TaAYiEN, in art. TwE.] When daxala is said of income, or revenue, [meaning It came in, accrued, or was received,] the aor. is as above, and the inf. n. daxolN: (Msb:) and you say, yadoxulu EalaI AlUinosaAni [It comes in, or accrues, to the man]. (Msb, K. *) daxala bihi [lit. He entered with him, or it]: see 4. ― -b2- [Hence, daxala fiyhi meaning (assumed tropical:) It became included, comprehended, or comprised, in it. And hence,] daxala fiI diyni AlUisolaAmi (assumed tropical:) [He entered within the pale of the religion of ElIslám; he entered the communion of that religion; he entered into, embraced, or became a proselyte to, that religion]. (Msb in art. slm, &c. [See Kur cx. 2.]) And daxala fiI AlOamori, inf. n. duxuwlN, (assumed tropical:) He entered upon, began, or commenced, the affair. (Msb.) [And daxala fiI Oamori gayorihi, and Oumuwri gayorihi, and tdxRl↓, and tdAxl↓ (assumed tropical:) He entered into, or mixed himself in, another's affair, and another's affairs.] ― -b3- [Hence also, daxala Ealayohi said of night, &c., It came upon him, or invaded him. And said of a word, such as a prep. &c., It was, or became, prefixed to it, preposed to it, or put before it.] ― -b4- [daxalaniI minohu seems (from an instance in art. bDE in the K) to mean (assumed tropical:) An evil opinion of him entered my mind; from daxolN as signifying “ a thing that induces doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion. ”] ＝ -A2- duxila, (S, K,) like EuniIa; (K;) and daxila, aor.
daxala
; inf. n. [of the former] daxolN and [of the latter] daxalN; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He had an unsoundness (daxalN, S, K, i. e. fasaAdN, K) in his intel-lect, (S, K,) or in his body, (K,) or in his grounds of pretension to respect. (TA in explanation of the former verb.) And daxila Oamoruhu, aor.
daxala
, (K,) inf. n. daxalN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) His affair, or case, or state, was, or became, intrinsically bad or corrupt or unsound. (K.) ― -b2- duxila AlTRaEaAmu The corn, or food, became eaten by worms or the like. (JK.) ― -b3- duxila Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) He was led into a mistake, or an error, respecting a thing, without knowing it, by his having preconceived it. (Msb.)

2 dxRl dxl
2. dxRl, inf. n. tadoxiylN, He put dates into a dawoxalRap [q. v.]. (TA.) [In the present day, dxRlhu is used in the first of the senses assigned below to Oadoxalahu; but for this I have not found any classical authority.]

3 mudaAxalapN mdAxlh mdAxlp mdxl
3. mudaAxalapN [inf. n. of dAxl] signifies The entering [with another] into a place: or (assumed tropical:) into an affair. (KL.) You say, dAxlhu fiI Oumuwrihi (assumed tropical:) [He entered with him into, or mixed with him in, his affairs]. (JK, S.) And daAxalahumo [alone (assumed tropical:) He entered with them into, or mixed with them in, their affairs: he mixed with them in familiar, or social, intercourse: he conversed with them; or was, or became, intimate with them]. (Lh, TA in the present art. and in art. xlT. [See 3 in art. xlT.]) And daAxalahu fasaAdN fiI EaqolK Oawo jisomK (assumed tropical:) [Unsoundness in intellect, or body, infected him, as though commingling with him; like xaAlaTahu]. (K.) dixaAlN [also is an inf. n. of dAxl]: see 6, in two places. ― -b2- [See also dixaAlN below.]

4 Adxlhu Odxl Odxlh Adxlh Adxlp dxl
4. Adxlhu, inf. n. UidoxaAlN and mudoxalN, (S, K,) He made, or caused, him, or it, to enter; or to go, come, pass, or get, in; he put in, inserted, brought in, or introduced, him, or it; as also bihi daxala↓ [lit. he entered with him, or it], (K, TA,) inf. n. duxuwlN. (TA.) You say, Oadoxalotu
zayodFA AldRaAra, [for fiIAldRaAri, I made, or caused, Zeyd to enter the house, or I brought, or introduced, Zeyd into the house,] inf. n. mudoxalN. (Msb.) Hence, in the Kur [xvii. 82], rabRi OadoxaloniI mudoxala SidoqK (S, * TA) O my Lord, cause me to enter El-Medeeneh in a good, or an agreeable, manner: (Jel: [see also various similar explanations in Bd:]) [or mudoxal↓ may be here a n. of place, or of time: see, in art. xrj, what is said of the words of the Kur that follow, OaxorijoniI maxoraja SidoqK.] One says also, Oadoxalotu AlxufRa fiI rijoliI and Alqalanosuwapa fiI raOosiI [for Oadoxalotu rijoliI fiI AlxufRi and raOosiI fiI Alqalanosuwapi I put, or inserted, my leg, or foot, into the boot and my head into the cap]. (Ham p. 43.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, yudoxilu EalaI qawomihi makoruwhFA yaloTaxuhumo bihi [He brings against his people an abominable, or evil, charge, aspersing them with it]. (S in art. Er.)

5 tadaxRala
5: see 1, first sentence: and again in the latter half of the paragraph.

6 tdAxl dAxl tdAxl
6. tdAxl signifies daxala baEoDuhu fiI baEoDK [One part of it entered into another, or parts of it into others; meaning it became intermixed, intermingled, commixed, or commingled; it intermixed; it became confused: and hence it often means it became compact, or contracted]. (TA in art. qSr.) [Hence,] tadaAxalN signifies The entering of joints one into another; (M;) as also dixaAlN↓ (JK, M, K) and daxiylN↓; (K;) but this last is not in the M [nor in the JK], and requires consideration: (TA:) [perhaps the joints (mafaASil) here mentioned are those of a coat of mail; for it is said immediately before in the JK that dixaAlN in coats of mail signifies firmness, or compactness, of make. Hence also,] tadaAxulu AllRugaAti [The intermixture, or commixture, of dialects]. (Mz 17th nwE.) And tadaAxulu AlOumuwri (assumed tropical:) The dubiousness and confusedness of affairs; as also AlOumuwri dixaAlu↓. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- [It is also trans.] You say, tadaAxalani minohu XaIoCN [Something thereof, or therefrom, crept into me, i. e., into my mind]. (S, TA. [In the former, this meaning seems to be indicated by what there immediately precedes.]) And tadaAxalaniI mino hecaA AlOamori ramaDN (assumed tropical:) [Distress and disquietude, or grief, crept into me from, or in consequence of, this thing]. (A and TA in art. rmD.)

7 Uinodaxala
7: see 1, first sentence.

8 UidRaxala Odxl Adxl dxl
8. UidRaxala: see 1, first sentence. AdRxl EalaIRa [app. He encroached upon me]. (TA in art. hyD: see 1 in that art.)

10 Astdxl Astdxl
10. Astdxl He wished, desired, asked, or begged, to enter. (KL.) ― -b2- And He entered a xamar [or covert of trees &c., or some other place of concealment]: said of one lurking to shoot, or cast, at objects of the chase. (TA.)

daxolN dxl
daxolN Income, or revenue, or profit, that comes in, or accrues, to a man from his immovable property, such as land and houses and palm-trees &c., (T, Msb, K,) and from his merchandise; (Msb;) contr. of xarojN; (S;) as also madoxuwlN↓ [for madoxuwlN bihi]: (TA:) the former is originally an inf. n., of which the verb is daxala, aor.
daxula
. (Msb.) You say, daxoluhu Oakovaru mino xarojihi [His income is more than his outgoings, or expenditure]. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also duxolapN. ― -b2- A disease; (K;) as also daxalN↓: (K, TA; but not decisively shown to have this meaning in the CK:) a vice, fault, defect, or blemish; (S, K;) and particularly in one's grounds of pretension to respect, (Az, TA,) as also, thus restricted, daxalN↓: (K, TA:) and a thing that induces doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion; as also daxalN↓ [app. in all the senses explained in this sentence: each originally an inf. n.: see duxila and daxila]. (S, K.) Hence the saying, (S, TA,) of
daxula
Athmeh Bint-Matrood, (TA,)
wamaA yudoriyka biAldRaxoli
taraI AlfitoyaAna kaAlnRaxoli
[Thou seest the youths, or young men, like palmtrees; but what will acquaint thee with the vice, &c., that is, or may be, in them]: (S, O, TA:) applied in relation to him who is of pleasing aspect, but devoid of good. (O, TA. [See also another reading of this verse voce raqolapN.]) ＝ -A3- See also dixaAlN: ＝ -A4- and daxilN.

duxolN dxl
duxolN [A species of millet;] i. q. jaAwarosN; as also duxonN. (TA.)

dixolN dxl
dixolN: see duxolapN.

daxalN dxl
daxalN primarily signifies A thing that enters into another thing and is not of it. (Bd in xvi. 94.) See daxolN, in three places. Also Badness, corruptness, or unsoundness; or a bad, a corrupt, or an unsound, state or quality; (S in art. dgl, and K;) in intellect or in body [&c.]. (K.) You say, fiI Eaqolihi daxalN [In his intellect is an unsoundness]. (S, K.) And hecaAAlOamoru fiyhi daxalN and dagalN [This affair, or case, in it is an unsoundness]: both signify the same. (S.) ― -b2- Rottenness in a palm-tree. (TA.) ― -b3- Leanness, or emaciation. (TA.) ― -b4- Perfidiousness, faithlessness, or treachery: (K and TA; but not in the CK:) deceit, guile, or circumvention. (S, K.) Hence, in the Kur [xvi. 96], walaA tatRaxicuwA OayomaAnakumo daxalFA bayonakumo [And make ye not your oaths to be a means of] deceit, or guile, or circumvention, between you. (S, TA. [And in the same sense it is used in verse 94 of the same ch.]) ＝ -A2- Also People, or persons, who assert their relationship to those of whom they are not: (K:) in this sense thought by ISd to be a quasi-pl. n. [app. of daxiylN (q. v.), like as XarafN is of XariyfN]. (TA.) You say, humo daxalN fiI baniI fulaAnK They are, among the sons of such a one, persons who assert their relationship to them not being of them. (S, K.) [But Freytag asserts, though without naming any authority, evidently taking it from the TK, in which I find it, that one says, hm dxl lhm, and also hw; thus applying it to a single person (which is questionable) as well as to a plurality.] ― -b2- And Tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees; (K;) as also dagalN. (TA.)

daxilN dxl
daxilN Intrinsically bad or corrupt or unsound: and daxolN↓ occurs in the same sense at the end of a verse: this may be a contraction of the former, or it may be for cuw daxolK. (TA.)

daxolapN dxl dxlh dxlp
daxolapN A place in which bees, (K,) or wild bees, (AA, TA,) deposit their honey. (AA, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

duxolapN dxl dxlh dxlp
duxolapN The night of the ceremony of conducting a bride to her husband. (TA.) [In the present day, this night is commonly called layolapuAldRuxolapi; vulgarly layolap AaldRuxolaho.] ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) The inward, or intrinsic, state, or circumstances, of a man; as also daAxilapN↓: (S:) or, as also dixolapN↓ and daxolapN↓ and daxiylapN↓ and daxiylN↓ and duxolulN↓ and duxolalN↓ and duxayolaMCu↓ and daAxilapN↓ and duxRalN↓ and dixaAlN↓, (K,) or, accord. to Lth, duxaAlN↓, (TA,) and duxRayolaI↓ and dixolN↓ and daxolN↓ (assumed tropical:) a man's intention: his way of acting, or his opinion: his whole case or circumstances: his mind, or heart: and his secret. (K.) You say, huwa EaAlimN biduxolatihi (assumed tropical:) He is acquainted with his inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances. (S.) And every one of the foregoing fourteen syn. words is prefixed to the word Oamor, so that you say, Earafotu duxolapa Oamorihi &c., meaning (assumed tropical:) I knew the whole [of the inward, or intrinsic, circumstances] of his case. (TA.) faraXotuhu dixolapa↓ OamoriI, or faraXotu lahu dixolapa OamoriI, is a post-classical prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) I laid open to him the inward, or intrinsic, and true, or real, state of my case. (Har p. 306.) One says also, huwa HasanRu AldRixolapi↓ and Almadoxali↓ (tropical:) He is good in his way of acting in his affairs: (K, TA:) and fulaAnN Hasanu Almadoxali↓ waAlmaxoraji (assumed tropical:) Such a one is good, and laudable, in his way of acting, or conduct. (TA.)

dixolapN dxl dxlh dxlp
dixolapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places: ― -b2- and see duxolulN. ― -b3- Also A mixture of colours in a colour. (T, M, K.)

duxolalN dxll
duxolalN: see duxRalN. ＝ -A2- and see also duxolapN: ― -b2- and the paragraph here next following.

duxolulN dxll
duxolulN (assumed tropical:) A companion, [such as is] a confidant, and special friend; as also daxiylN↓ (KL) and daxiylapN↓ [app. for SaAHibu daxiylapK] (K * and TA voce waliyjapN) and dixolapN↓ [app. for SaAHibu dixolap]: (L voce waliyjapN:) [the pl.] duxoluluwna signifies special, or particular, and choice, or select, friends: (Az, TA:) or duxolulN signifies, as also dixolalN↓ and daxiylN↓ and mudaAxilN↓, one who enters with another into the affairs of the latter: (K, TA:) [i. e.] AlrRajuli daxiylu↓ and duxoluluhu signify the man's particular, or special, intimate, who enters with him into his affairs. (S.) You say, bayonahumaA duxolulN and dixolalN↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) Between them two is a particular, or special, intimate, who enters with them into their affairs: so says Lh: but ISd says, I know not what it is: accord. to the T, on the authority of AO, the meaning is, between them is brotherhood, or fraternization, and love, or affection: and accord. to ISd and the K,
AlHubRi duxolalN↓ and duxoluluhu [the latter not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K] and daAxiluhu↓ signify (assumed tropical:) purity of inward love. (TA.) ― -b2- duxoluluwna signifies also Persons of the lower, or lowest, sort, who enter among a people, or party, of whom they are not: thus having two contr. meanings. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- Aldxll [app. AldRuxolulu] and AldRuxRaAlu↓ [thus in the TA] and AldRaAxilu↓, accord. to IAar, all signify The same as AlOucuni daxRaAli↓ [an appellation now applied to the ear-wig; in the K, art. Eqrb, said to be the EuqorubaAn, but not as meaning the Eaqorab or the male Eaqorab]: accord. to AZ, it is the hrnSAn [i. e. hironiSaAn or hirinoSaAn, a kind of worm, the species of which is doubtful]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also dixRalN. ＝ -A2- And see duxolapN.

dixolalN dxll
dixolalN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

dixolilN dxll
dixolilN A portion of flesh (in some copies of the K of fat, TA) in the midst of flesh. (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

duxaAlN dxAl
duxaAlN: see dixaAlN: ＝ -A2- and see also duxolapN.

dixaAlN dxAl
dixaAlN [an inf. n. of 3, q. v.]. ― -b2- In watering, (S, K,) it is The putting in a camel, that has drunk, between two camels that have not drunk, (K,) or the bringing back a camel, that has drunk, from the resting-place by the water, to the watering-trough, and putting him in between two thirsty camels, (S,) in order that he may drink what, may-be, he has not drunk: (S, K:) in like manner it is explained in the T, on the authority of As, who adds that this is done only when the water is scanty: (TA:) or the putting in a weak or sick camel [that has already drunk] with those that are drinking, and then, after that, with those that are returning to the water, so that he drinks three times: (Skr:) or the driving of camels to the watering-trough a second time, in order that they may complete their drinking, after they have already been watered drove by drove: (JK, TA:) so says Lth; but the approved explanation is that of As: (TA:) or the driving of camels to the watering-trough at once, all together; as also daxolN↓. (JK.) ＝ -A2- The forelocks of a horse; (K;) because of their entering, one into another; (TA;) as also duxaAlN↓: (K:) so in the M. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also duxolapN.

daxiylN dxyl
daxiylN A guest. (M, TA.) Hence the saying of the vulgar, OanaA daxiylu fulaAnK [I am the guest of such a one; generally meaning I am under his protection]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also duxolulN, in three places. ― -b3- [An adventive abider among a people.] You say, fulaAnN daxiylN bayona Alqawomi Such a one is a person abiding among the people, not related to them. (Msb.) And huwa daxiylN fiyhimo He is a stranger to them (M, K) who has entered, (M,) or who enters, (K,) among them: (M, K:) applied also to a female. (TA.) [See daxalN, which is app. a quasi-pl. n. of daxiylN in this sense.] ― -b4- Hence, A subject of discourse introduced by way of digression, or as having some relation to the class, or category, of the proper subjects treated of, but not included therein. (Msb.) ― -b5- And A word that is adventitious, not indigenous, to the language of the Arabs; that is introduced into that language, and does not belong to it. (K.) There are many such words in the Jemharah of Ibn-Dureyd. (TA.) ― -b6- And A horse that is introduced between two other horses in a race for a wager. (JK, O, TA.) [See muHalRilN.] See also daxiyliIRu. ― -b7- And see duxolapN: ― -b8- and daAxilN. ＝ -A2- It is also said in the K to be syn. with dixaAlN in a sense explained above: see 6.

daxiylapN dxyl dxylh dxylp
daxiylapN: see duxolapN: ― -b2- and duxolulN.

duxayolaMCu dxylMC
duxayolaMCu: see duxolapN.

daxiyliIRN dxyl dxylI dxyly dxylyy
daxiyliIRN A gazelle [and any animal] brought up in, or near, the house or tent, and there fed, syn. rabiybN, (IAar, K, TA,) like OaholiIRN, (TA,) upon the neck of which are hung cowries. (IAar, TA.) And A horse that is fed only with fodder: so accord. to Aboo-Nasr and others: a meaning erroneously assigned in the K to daxiylN↓. (TA.) Accord. to Skr, A horse of a race called banaAtu daxiylK. (TA.)

duxayoliyaMCu dxylyMC
duxayoliyaMCu [in the CK with p in the place of the C] A certain game of the Arabs. (JK, O, K, TA.)

duxRalN dxl
duxRalN Herbage that enters among the stems of trees, (S, K,) or among the lower parts of the branches of trees, (M, TA,) or among the branches of trees, and cannot be depastured by reason of its tangled state; also termed EuwRacN. (T, TA.) ― -b2- The feathers, or portions of feathers, that enter between the ZuhoraAn and buTonaAn [here app. meaning the outermost and innermost portions]: (K:) they are the best thereof, because the sun does not strike upon them. (TA.) ― -b3- A portion, or portions, of flesh, or of muscle, lying within sinews: (M, K:) or flesh whereof one portion is intermixed with another: (TA:) or duxRalu AllRaHomi means flesh that cleaves to the bone; and such is the best of flesh. (T, TA.) ― -b4- Applied to a man, (TA,) Thick, and compact, or contracted, in body; (K, * TA;) lit, having one portion thereof inserted into another. (TA.) ― -b5- A certain bird, (S, K,) of small size, (S, TA,) dust-coloured, (K, TA,) that alights upon palm-trees and other trees, and enters among them; (TA;) also called duxolalN↓ and duxolulN↓: (K:) n. un. duxRalapN: ISd says that it is an intrusive bird, smaller than the sparrow, found in El-Hijáz: accord. to the T, it is a kind of small bird, like the sparrow, that has its abode in caves and in dense trees: AHát says, in “the Book of Birds,” that the duxRalap is a certain bird that is found in caves, and enters houses or tents, and is caught by children: when winter comes, the birds of this kind disperse; and some of them become of a dusky colour, and of a dark and somewhat reddish colour, and gray (zaroqaMC); and some, variegated with blackness and redness, and with whiteness: they are of the size of the lark, but the latter is larger than they are in the head; neither short nor long in the tail; but short in the legs, which are like the legs of the lark: (TA:) the pl. is daxaAxiylu, (S, M, K,) which is anomalous in respect of the insertion of the I: (M:) in the T, dxAlyl [which is app. a mistranscription]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also duxolapN.

duxRalapN dxl dxlh dxlp
duxRalapN Any compact portion of flesh. (Sgh, K.) ― -b2- Also n. un. of duxRalN [q. v.]. (TA.)

daxRaAlN dxAl
daxRaAlN That enters [into anything] much, or often; wont to enter. (TA.) [See dasRaAsN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] daxRaAlu AlOucuni: see duxolulN.

AldRuxRaAlu AldxAl
AldRuxRaAlu: see duxolulN.

duxRayolaI dxyl dxylI dxyly dxylyy
duxRayolaI: see duxolapN.

daAxilN dAxl
daAxilN [act. part. n. of 1, Entering, &c. Hence,] AldRaAxilu as meaning daxRaAlu AlOucuni: see duxolulN. ― -b2- It is [also] applied as an epithet to a disease, and to love; [as meaning Internal, or inward;] and so daxiylN↓, in the same sense. (K.) ― -b3- [Also, as a subst.,] The interior of anything; (M, Msb, * TA;) contr. of xaArijN. (Msb.) Sb says that it is not used adverbially unless with a particle; [so that you may not say daAxilFA as meaning Within; but you say fiI daAxilK; and in like manner you say UilaI daAxilK meaning In, or inwards; and mino daAxilK meaning From within;] i. e. it is only a subst.; because it has a special signification, like yadN and rijolN. (TA.) ― -b4- daAxilu AlHubRi: see duxolulN.

daAxilapu AlUizaAri dAxlp AlAzAr
daAxilapu AlUizaAri The part of the AzAr [or waist-wrapper] that is next the body; (Mgh;) the extremity of the AzAr that is next the body, (S, K,) next the right side (K, TA) of a man when he puts it on; being the inner extremity in that case: and the part of the body which is the place thereof; not of the AzAr: IAmb says that, accord. to some, it is a metonymical term for the macaAkiyr [meaning the penis with what is around it]: or, accord. to some, the hip, or haunch. (TA.) ― -b2- daAxilapu AlOaroDi The part of the ground that may serve as a place for concealment, and that is low, or depressed: pl. dawaAxilu. (T, K.) One says, maA fiI OaroDihimo daAxilapN mino xamarK [There is not in their land a place for concealment such as a hollow or a covert of trees]. (TA.) ― -b3- [In the K and TA in art. jwz, the term daAxilap is applied to Bad pieces of money intermixed and concealed among good pieces; as is there indicated in the K, and plainly shown in the TA.] ― -b4- AldRawaAxilu in the phrase AldRawaAxilu waAlxawaAriju has been explained in art xrj. (Msb. See xaArijapN.) ― -b5- See also duxolapN, in two places.

dawoxalRapN dwxlh dwxlp
dawoxalRapN and dawoxalapN, with and without teshdeed, A thing [or receptacle] made of palm-leaves woven together, (ISk, S, K,) in which fresh ripe dates are put, (ISk, S,) or in which dates are put: (K:) pl. dawaAxiylu, occurring in poetry, [the I being app. inserted by poetic license,] (TA,) and dawaAxilu. (K in art. lhv.)

madoxalN mdxl
madoxalN An entrance, i. e. a place of entrance, or ingress, (S, Msb,) of a house [or the like; and any inlet]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A way of act-
ing. (K, TA: see duxolapN, last sentence, in two places.) [And madoxalu xayorK (assumed tropical:) A means of attaining, or doing, good.] ― -b3- [Also A time of entrance.]

mudoxalN mdxl
mudoxalN is syn. with UidoxaAlN: and is also the pass. part. n. of Oadoxalahu: (S:) [and a n. of place: and of time:] see 4. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Base, base-born, or ignoble; of suspected origin or lineage, or adopted, or who claims for his father one who is not: (K, * TA:) because he is introduced among a people [to whom he is not related]. (TA.)

midoxalN mdxl
[midoxalN An instrument by means of which one enters: mentioned by Golius as meaning a key; on the authority of Ibn-Seenà (Avicenna).]

mudRaxalFA mdxl mdxlA

(TA.) ― -b6- [Hence, also,] one says to a man, when he seeks a thing, and begs for it importunately, OadirRahaA wa Uino Oabato, meaning, [lit.,] Ply her, though she refuse, until she yield her milk abundantly. (TA in art. Hlb.) ― -b9- And bayona Eayonayohi EiroqN yudirRuhu AlgaDabu (said in a trad., TA) (tropical:) Between his eyes was a vein which anger caused to flow; (S; *) or to fill with blood; (A;) or to become thick and full: (TA:) or which anger put in motion: (S:) for (TA) OadarRa AlXRaIoCa signifies he put the thing in motion. (K, TA.) ― -b10- AdrRt Almigozala (tropical:) She twisted the spindle vehemently, (A, K,) so that it seemed to be still in consequence of its vehement twirling. (K, * TA.) ― -b11- And AdrR AlsRahoma (assumed tropical:) He made the arrow to turn round well upon the nail (AHn, K *) of his left thumb, turning it with the thumb and fore finger of his right hand. Hence the saying of a certain Arab, to whom El-Asma'ee had come, OatayotaniI wa OanaA Oudarodiru [Thou camest to me when I was a child mumbling with toothless gums: or it may mean thou hast come to me when I am old, mumbling &c.: see durodurN]. darRN dr
darRN an inf. n. used as a subst., (Msb,) Milk; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also dirRapN↓. (K.) Hence, cawaAtu AldRarRi, and AldRarRu alone, Milch-animals. (TA.) And OumRahaAtu AldRarRi The teats of a camel or clovenfooted animal. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence also the saying, lilRehi darRuka (tropical:) To God be attributed the good that hath proceeded from thee! or thy good deed! (TA:) or thy deed: (A:) or thy gift! and what is received from thee! [and thy flow of eloquence! and the like: when said to an eloquent speaker or poet, it may be rendered divinely art thou gifted!] a man's gift [or the like] was originally thus likened to the milk of a camel; and then this phrase became so common as to be used as expressive of admiration of anything: (Aboo-Bekr, TA:) it was first said by a man who saw another milking camels, and wondered at the abundance of their milk: (ISd, TA:) the thing alluded to therein is attributed to God to indicate that none other could be its author. (TA.) You say also, lilRehi darRuhu (tropical:) To God be attributed his deed! (S, K:) or his knowledge! or his good! or bounty! or beneficence! (Har p. 418:) [&c.:] meaning praise. (S.) Accord. to IAar, darRN signifies (tropical:) A deed, whether good or evil. (TA.) Ibn-Ahmar says, lilRehi darRiI [To God be attributed what hath brought me to this state!] wondering at himself. (TA.) One also says, lilRehi darRuka mino rajulK, which is likewise an expression of praise, (S,) meaning (tropical:) To God be attributed the goodness, or good action, of thee, as a man! [i. e., of such a man as thou!] (TA.) And lilRehi darRuhu faArisFA (tropical:) [To God be attributed his excellence as a horseman!]. (Msb.) And, in dispraise, (S,) darRuhu laA darRa↓ May his good, or wealth, not be, or become, much, or abundant! (S, A, TA:) or may his work not thrive! (K.) El-Mutanakhkhil says,
laA darRa darRiIa Uino OaToEamotu naAzilahumo
qirofa AlHatRiIi waEinodiI AlburRu makonuwzu
[May my wealth not become abundant, or may my work not thrive, if I feed him among them who is a guest with the rind of HatiIR (q. v.) when I have wheat stored up]: this verse is cited by Fr, who also mentions the phrase, darRa darRu fulaAnK [May the wealth of such a one become abundant! or may his work thrive!]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The soul; syn. nafosN. (K.) One says rajulN sariIRN AldRarRi A man of generous and manly soul. (TK.) And dafaEa QllRehu Eano darRihi May God defend his soul. (Lh.)

(Msb.) Hence the prov., laA Mtiyka maAQxotalafati AldRirRapu waAljirRapu I will not come to thee as long as the flow of milk and the cud go [the former] downwards and [the latter] upwards. (TA. [See also musotadirRN.]) ― -b6- dirRapN also signifies (tropical:) Blood [as being likened to milk]. (K.) A poet cited by Th likens war and the blood thereof to a [raging] she-camel and her dirRap. (TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) The means of subsistence [as being likened to milk]. (TA in art. gr. [See an ex. voce girRapN.]) ― -b8- And A mode, or manner, of flowing, or streaming, of milk. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain thing with which one beats, or flogs; (Kr, S, A, K, TA;) i. e. the dirRap of the Sultán: (TA:) a whip: (Msb:) [app. a whip for flogging criminals; as seems to be implied in the TA: I have not found any Arab who can describe it in the present day: it seems to have been a kind of whip, or scourge, of twisted cords or thongs, used for punishment and in sport, such as is now called firoqilRap: or a whip made of a strip, or broad strip, (see 1 in art. xfq,) of thick and tough hide, or the like: it is described by Golius and Freytag (by the latter as from the S and K, in neither of which is any such explanation found,) as “ strophium ex fune aliave re contortum, aut nervus taurinus, similisve res, quibus percuti solet: ”] an Arabic word, well known: (TA:) [or an arabicized word, from the Pers. durRaho:] pl. dirarN. (A, Msb.)

durodurN drdr
durodurN The part of the gums where the teeth grow: (TA:) or the part where the teeth grow of a child: (S, K, TA:) or the part where the teeth grow both before they grow and after they have fallen out: (K, TA:) pl. daraAdiru.
