1 daraOahu c
1. daraOahu, aor.
daraAa
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. daroCN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and daroOapN; (K;) and drROhu↓; (M, TA; [or this latter has probably an intensive signification;]) He pushed it, or thrust it; or pushed it, or thrust it, away, or back; repelled
it; or averted it; syn. dafaEahu; (S, * M, Mgh, * Msb, K;) namely, a thing. (Msb.) Hence, kaAna bayona Eumara wamuEaAci boni EaforaMCa daroCN There was, between 'Omar and Mo'ádh Ibn-'Afrà, a contending, and a mutual pushing or thrusting, &c. (Mgh.) And daraOa Eanohumo He repelled from them, or defended them; as also daraha, which is formed by substitution from the former, like haraAqa from OaraAqa. (S in art. drh.) And daraOa Eanohu AlHadRa He averted (dafaEa) from him the prescribed castigation: (M, Mgh:) or he deferred his prescribed castigation: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to other things. (AZ, T.) It is said in a trad., AidoraWuwA AlHuduwda biAlXRubuhaAti [Avert ye, or defer ye, the prescribed castigations on account of dubious circumstances]. (ISk, M, TA.) And AidoraWuwA AlHuduwda maA QsotaTaEotumo [Avert ye, or defer ye, the prescribed castigations as long as ye are able]. (S, form a trad.) ― -b2- See also 5. ― -b3- daraOa Eani AlbaEiyri AlHaqaba is explained by Sh as meaning He pushed back the kind girth of the camel: but AM says that the correct meaning is, he spread the kind girth upon the ground, and made the camel to lie down upon it [in order that he might gird him]. (TA.) [For] daraOa signifies also He spread, or laid flat, (K, TA,) a thing upon the ground. (TA.) ― -b4- daraOa AlXRaIoCa biAlXRaIoCa He supported the thing by the thing; made the. thing to be a support to the thing. (TA.) [Hence,] daraOa AlHaAYiTa bibinaMCK He conjoined the wall with a structure [so as to support the former by the latter]. (TA.) ― -b5- daraOa biHajarK He cast a stone; like radaOa. (TA.) You say, daraOahu biHajar and radaOahu bihi He cast a stone at him. (M in art. rdO.) ― -b6- daraOa said of a torrent, (K,) inf. n. daroCN, (TA,) (tropical:) It rushed, or poured forth with vehemence; as also AndrO↓. (K.) And daraOa AlwaAdiI biAlsRayoli (assumed tropical:) The valley poured along the torrent. (TA.) [See also daroCN, below.] ― -b7- daraOa, (K,) inf. n. duruwoCN, (TA,) is syn. with TaraOa [He came from a place, or from a distant place, unexpectedly; &c.]. (K.) And you say, daraOa EalayonaA fulaAnN, (T, S, K, * TA,) inf. n. duruwoCN (S, TA) and daroCN; (TA;) and AndrO↓ (S, TA) and tdrRO↓; (TA;) Such a one came, or came forth, upon us unexpectedly, (T, S, K, * TA,) or whence we knew not; as also TaraOa, (T,) and daraha. (IAar, TA in art. drh.) And Ealayohi biXarRK AndrO↓, vulg. AndrI, He came upon him suddenly with evil, or mischief. (TA.) ― -b8- Hence, i. e. from daraOa signifying “ he came, or came forth, unexpectedly, ” (T, S, TA,) daraOa, inf. n. duruwoCN, said of a star, meaning (tropical:) It shone, or glistened, (S, K, TA,) intensely, (S, TA,) and its light spread: (TA:) or, as some say, it rose. (T.) [Hence also,] daraOati AlnRaAru (assumed tropical:) The fire gave light, shone, was bright, or shone brightly. (Sh, K.) ＝ -A2- daraOa, (T, S, K,) aor.
daraAa
, (T,) inf. n. duruwoCN, (T, S,) He (a camel) had what is termed the gudRap, (S, K,) i. e. the plague, or pestilence, (TaAEuwn,) of camels, (T,) and had therewith a tumour in his back, (S, K,) or in his naHor [or stabbing-place, in the uppermost part of the breast]: but in a female, it is in the udder: (TA:) or had a tumour in his naHor. (IAar, T.) The epithet applied to the male is daAriYN↓: and so, accord. to ISk, to the female, (T, S,) meaning Attacked by the gudRap in her maraAq, (T, and so in a copy of the S,) thus, without teshdeed to the q, signifying the part, of her throat, which is the place of passage of the water, (T, TA,) or in her maraAqR [or thin and soft parts of the belly], (so in one of my copies of the S,) so that the protuberance of the gudRap [or pestilential tumour] is apparent: which protuberance is termed daroCN↓. (T, S.)

3 mudaAraOapN c
3. mudaAraOapN, primarily, (TA,) signifies The act of opposing; and repelling, or striving to repel: (S, TA:) or treating in an evil, or adverse, manner; and opposing: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or the putting one off in the matter of a right or due, by promising to render it time after time; and treating in an evil, or adverse, and a contrary, manner. (Mgh in arts. drI and XrI.) One says, daraOotuhu I repelled him, or strove to repel him. (T, Msb, K.) And fulaAnN laA yudaAriYu wa laA yumaAriI, (S, TA,) i. e. Such a one does not act in an evil, or adverse, manner, nor oppose, [nor does he wrangle, or dispute obstinately:] and lA yudaAriI, meaning, accord. to Sgh, if for lA yudaAriYu, does not repel, or strive to repel, him who has a right from his right. (TA.) ― -b2- Accord. to El-Ahmar, in [the exercise of] good disposition, (T, S,) and in social intercourse, (S,) it is with and without C; (T, S;) contr. to the assertion of A 'Obeyd, who says that in this case it is without C. (T.) [F says,] daAraOotuhu is syn. with daArayotuhu and daAfaEotuhu and laAyanotuhu [the second of which has a meaning explained above; the first and last meaning I treated him with gentleness or blandishment, soothed him, coaxed him, or wheedled him; &c.]; thus bearing two contr. significations: (K:) [or] daraOotuhu and daArayotuhu both signify I was fearful, or cautious, of him; and treated him with gentleness or blandishment, or soothed him, coaxed him, wheedled him, or cajoled him: (S:) [but Az says,] I say that the verb with C means I was fearful, or cautious, of him, as says AZ; or of his evil, or mischief: and daArayotu signifies “ I deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted; ” as also darayotu. (T.)

4. OadoraOato biDaroEihaA, (AZ, T, S,) inf. n. UidoraMCN, (AZ, T,) [as also AcrOt, with c,] She (a camel) excerned (Oanozalato) the milk, (AZ, T, S,) and relaxed her udder, on the occasion of bringing forth. (AZ, S.) The epithet applied to the she-camel so doing is mudoriYN↓. (AZ, T, S, K.)

(TA.) ― -b3- tdrRWwA, (M, K, TA,) and AidRaraWuwA↓ dariyoYapF, (TA,) They concealed themselves from a thing in order to beguile it, or circumvent it: (M, K, TA:) or they made use of a cariyEap [or dariyoYap] for hunting and spearing or thrusting [or shooting objects of the chase]: (TA:) and AdRrOtu↓ lilSRayodi, (S,) or AlSRayodi, (K,) I prepared for myself a dariyYap for the chase: (S, K:) and daraOa↓ AldRariyoYapa lilSRayodi, aor.

6. tdArWwA They repelled, or strove to repel, one another (M, Msb, K) in contention, or altercation, (M, K,) and the like; and disagreed. (M.) AidRaAraOotumo is originally tadaAraOotumo, (S, K,) the t being incorporated into the d, (S, TA,) because they have the same place of utterance, (TA,) and the A being added to commence the word: (S, TA:) the meaning is, Ye disagreed; and repelled, or strove to repel, one another. (S.) faQdRaAraOotumo fiyhaA, in the Kur ii. 67, means And ye contended together respecting it; because those who contend repel one another: or ye repelled, or strove to repel, one another, by each of you casting the slaughter upon his fellow. daroCN drC
daroCN and inf. n. of 1 in senses pointed out above. (S, M, &c.) So of that verb said of a torrent. (TA.) [Hence,] jaMYa AlsRayolu daroCFA and duroCFA↓ The torrent rushed, or poured forth with vehemence, [or came rushing, &c.,] from a place, (M, K,) or from a distant place, (TA,) unknown: (M, K, TA:) or the latter signifies the torrent came from a distant land or tract. (S.) And jaMCa AlwaAdiI duroCFA↓ The valley flowed with the rain of another valley: if with its own rain, you say, saAla ZahorFA: (IAar, M; and the like is said in the TA in the present art. and in art. darobN drb
darobN is not a word of Arabic origin: (Msb:) AldRarobN is [the Arabic name of the ancient Derbe, near the Cilician Gates, which were the chief mountain-pass, from the direction of the countries occupied by the Arabs, into the territory of the Greek Empire: these “ Gates ” are mentioned by El-Idreesee as fortified, and guarded by troops who watched the persons going and coming:] a well-known place in AlrRuwm [or the territory of the Greek Empire], mentioned by Imra-el-Keys, [as El-Idreesee also says,] in the words,
bakaI SaAHibiI lamRaA raOaI AldRaroba Hawolahu
[My companion wept when he saw the drb around him; knowing himself to be in the power of the Greeks]. (MF, TA.) [Hence,] Any place of entrance, (Kh, T, M, A, Mgh [in my copy of which it is written darab in all its senses], K,) or a narrow pass, (Mgh,) to [the territory of] AlrRuwm: (Kh, T, M, A, Mgh, K:) or such as is not open at both ends: such as is open at both ends being called darabN↓: (K:) or a place of entrance between two mountains: (Msb:) or a narrow pass in mountains: and hence it has another meaning well known: (S:) [i. e.] the gate of a sikRap [here meaning street: misunderstood by Golius, who has consequently explained darobN as having, for one of its meaning, “ porta
ingressusve palmeti ”]; used in this sense by the Arabs because it [i. e. the drb properly so called] is like a gate, or entrance, to that whereto it leads: (Msb:) or the gate of a wide sikRap: (T:) or a wide gate of a sikRap; and the largest gate; (M, K;) both of which explanations mean the same: (M:) and also a wide sikRap itself: so in the phrase, zuqaAqN Oawo darobN gayoru naAficK [a narrow street or a wide street not being a thoroughfare]: (Mgh: [in my copy of which, darabN is put for darobN:]) [but in the present day, and as used by El-Makreezee and others, a by-street, whether wide or narrow, branching off from a great street, or passing through a HaArap (or quarter), open, or having a gate, at each end:] pl. duruwbN (Kh, T, M, Mgh, TA) and diraAbN. (Sb, K. [The former pl., the only one commonly known, is not mentioned in the K.]) ― -b2- Also A place in which dates are put to dry. (M, K.)

, He rose in grade, degree, rank, condition, or station. (K, TA.) ― -b2- He kept to the plain and manifest way in religion or in speech. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also (i. e. darija) He continued to eat the kind of bird called durRaAj. (K.) ＝ -A4- daraja as a trans. v.: see 4, in two places.

meaning [The creaking of the large sheaves of pulleys] which the pivots made to go [round] slowly (SayRaratohaA UilaI Oano tadoruja). (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2, in two places. ― -b3- [Also] He caused him to ascend, and to descend, by degrees. (Bd in vii. 181.) ― -b4- And hence, He (God) drew him near to destruction by little and little: (Bd ibid:) He brought him near to punishment by degrees, by means of respite, and the continuance of health, and the increase of favour: (Idem in lxviii. 44:) He (God) took him (a man) so that he did not reckon upon it; [as though by degrees;] bestowing upon him enjoyments in which he delighted, and on which he placed his reliance, and with which he became familiar so as not to be mindful of death, and then taking him in his most heedless state: such is said to be the meaning in the Kur vii. 181 and lxviii. 44: (TA:) or He bestowed upon him new favours as often as he committed new wrong actions, and caused him to forget to ask for forgiveness [thus leading him by degrees to perdition]: and [or as some say, TA] He took him by little and little; [or by degrees;] not suddenly: (K:) or Aisotadorajahumo signifies He took them by little and little; [one, or a few, at a time;] not [all of them together,] suddenly. (L.) And He, or it, called for, demanded, or required, his destruction: from daraja “ he died. ” (A, TA.) ― -b5- It (another's speech, Aboo-Sa'eed, TA) disquieted him so as to make him creep along, or go slowly or softly, upon the ground. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K.) ― -b6- He deceived him, or beguiled him, (AHeyth, K, TA,) so as to induce him to proceed in an affair from which he had refrained. (AHeyth, TA.) ― -b7- Astdrj AlnRaAqapa He invited the she-camel's young one to follow after she had cast it forth from her belly: so accord. to the K: [in the CK, for AlnRaAqapa and waladahaA, we find AlnRAqpu and waladuhA:] but accord, to the L and other lexicons, Astdrjt AlnRaAqapu waladahaA, i. e. the she-camel invited her young one to follow [her] after she had cast it forth from her belly. (TA.) ― -b8- Astdrjt AlrRiyHu AlHaSaA The wind [blew so violently that it] made the pebbles to be as though they were going along of themselves (K, TA) upon the surface of the ground, without its raising them in the air. (TA.) [See also 1.]) ― -b9- AisotidoraAjN also signifies The drawing forth (in Pers. byrwn Awrdn) speech, or words, from the mouth. (KL.) ― -b10- And The rejecting a letter, such as the w in yaEidu for yawoEidu. (Msb in art. wEd.)

darojN: see darajN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, and darajN↓, A thing in, or upon, which one writes; (S, K;) [a scroll, or long paper, or the like, generally composed of several pieces joined together, which is folded or rolled up:] and mudorajN↓, [used as a subst.,] a writing folded or rolled up; pl. madaAriju: (Har p. 254:) and mdrjp [app. mudorajapN↓, from Oadoraja “ he folded ” or “ rolled up, ” with p added to transfer it from the predicament of part. ns. to that of substs.,] signifies [in like manner] a paper upon which one writes a risaAlap [or message, &c.], and which one folds, or rolls up; pl. madaAriju. (Har p. 246.) ― -b2- fiI daroji AlkitaAbi signifies fiI TayRihi [lit. Within the folding of the writing; meaning infolded, or included, in the writing]; (S, A, TA;) and fiI vinoyihi [which means the same]; (A;) and fiI daAxilihi [an explicative adjunct, meaning in the inside of the writing]. (TA.) You say, Oanofacotuhu fiI daroji AlkitaAbi [I transmitted it in the inside of the writing]. (S, TA.) And jaEalahu fiI daroji AlkitaAbi [He put it in the inside of the writing]. (A, L, TA.) And fiI daroji AlkitaAbi kacaA wa kacaA [In the inside of the writing are such and such things; or in the writing are enclosed, or included, or written, or mentioned, such and such things; this being commonly meant by the phrase fiI TaIRi AlkitaAbi kcA wkcA]. (TA.)

[of mult.] is dirajapN and [of pauc.] OadoraAjN. (K.)

darajN drj
darajN A way, road, or path; (S, L, K;) as also darojN↓: (L:) and madorajapN↓ (S, A) and madorajN↓ (A, K) signify [the same; or] a way by, or through, which one goes or passes; a way which one pursues; a course, or route; syn. macohabN (S) and masolakN (S, K) and mamarRN; (A;) and particularly the way along which a boy and the wind &c. go; as also darajN; respecting which last, in relation to the wind, see daruwjN: (L:) or madorajN↓ signifies a road; or a cross-road; or a bending road; and its pl. is madaArijN: (Msb:) and madorajapN↓ is explained by Er-Rághib as signifying a beaten way or road: and it signifies also the course by which things pass, on a road &c.: and the main part of a road: and a rugged [road such as is termed] vaniyRap, between mountains: (TA:) the pl. of darajN (S, L) and of darojN↓ (L) is OadoraAjN (S, L) and diraAjN, which occurs in a prov. cited below: (Meyd:) and the pl. of madorajapN is madaArijN↓: (S, TA:) OakamapK madaAriju↓ signifies the roads that lie across a hill such as is termed Akmp. (TA.) You say OadoraAjaka meaning Go thy way, as thou camest. (TA from a trad.) And rajaEa darajahu (TA) and rajaEa OadoraAjahu (Sb, S, K) and UidoraAjahu↓ (K) or EalaI UidoraAjihi (IAar) He returned by the way by which he had come. (S, K, TA.) And rajaEa darajahu He returned to the thing, or affair, that he had left. (TA.) And rajaEa EalaI OadoraAjihi and rajaEa darajahu AlOawRala He returned without having been able to accomplish what he desired. (IAar.) And AisotamarRa darajahu and OadoraAjahu [He kept on his way; persevered in his course]. (TA.) And huwa EalaI daraji kacaA He is on the way of, or to, such a thing. (TA.) And AitRaxacuwA daArahu madorajapF↓ and madorajFA↓ They made his house a way through which to pass. (A.) And lihecaA hecaA AlOamoru madorajapN↓ (assumed tropical:) This thing, or affair, is a way that leads to
this. (TA.) And AlHaqRi AimoXa fiI madaAriji↓ (tropical:) Walk thou in the ways of truth. (TA.) And cahaba damuhu OadoraAja AlrRiyaAHi (tropical:) His blood went for nothing; [lit., in the ways of the winds; meaning] so that no account was taken of it, and it was not avenged. (S, A, * K.) And xalR daraja AlDRabRi Leave thou the way of the DbR [a species of lizard], (S, Meyd,) and oppose not thyself to him, (TA,) lest he pass between thy feet, and thou become angry (fatanotafixa): (S, Meyd:) a prov., applied in the case of demanding security from evil. (Meyd. [See another reading, and explanations thereof, in Har p. 220, or in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 437.]) And mano yarudRu AlfuraAta Eano diraAjihi or OadoraAjihi, accord. to different readings, with two different pls. of darajN; i. e. Who will turn back Euphrates from its course? a prov. applied to an impossible affair. (Meyd.) And mano yarudRu AlsRayola EalaI OadoraAjihi Who will turn back the torrent to its channels? another prov. so applied. (Meyd.) daraju sayolK and sayolK madoraju↓ signify The way by which a torrent descends in the bendings of valleys. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps, as denoting a way, or means,] (assumed tropical:) A mediator between two persons for the purpose of effecting a reconciliation. (K.) ― -b3- OanaAa daraju yadayoka means (tropical:) [I am submissive, or obedient, to thee;] I will not disobey thee: (A, TA: *) and drj used in this sense does not assume a dual nor a pl. form: [therefore] you say also, humo daraju yadika (tropical:) They are submissive, or obedient, to thee. (TA.) ― -b4- daraju AlrRamoli and AlmaMCi signify [The ripples of sand and of water;] what are seen upon sand, and upon water, when moved by the wind. (Az and TA in art. Hbk.) See daruwjN. ― -b5- See also darajapN, in two places. ＝ -A2- And see darojN.

durojapN drj drjh drjp
durojapN A thing which is rolled up, and inserted into a she-camel's vulva, and then [taken forth, whereupon] she smells it, and, thinking it to be her young one, inclines to it [and yields her milk]: (S:) or, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilá- bee, (S,) a thing (T, S, K) consisting of rags, (T,) or of tow and rags (S, M) and other things, (M,) which is rolled up, (T, K,) and stuffed into a she-camel's vulva, (T, S, M, K,) and into her tuel, (K,) and bound, (TA,) when they desire her to incline to the young one of another, (T, S,) having first bound her nose and her eyes: (S:) they leave her thus, (S, K,) with her eyes and nose bound, (K,) for some days, (S,) and she in consequence suffers distress like that occasioned by labour: then they loose the bandage [of her vulva] from her, and this thing comes forth from her, (S, K,) and she thinks it to be a young one; and when she has dropped it, they unbind her eyes, having prepared for her a young camel, which they bring near to her, and she thinks it to be her own young one, and inclines to it: (S:) or with the thing that comes forth from her they besmear the young one of another she-camel, and she thinks it to be her own young one, and inclines to it: (K:) the thing thus rolled up is called durojapN (T, S) and jazomN and waviyqapN; (T;) and the thing with which her eyes are bound, gimaAmapN; and that with which her nose is bound, SiqaAEN: (S:) the pl. [of mult.] is durajN (S, TA) and [of pauc.] OadoraAjN: (TA:) or it signifies [or signifies also] a piece of rag containing medicine, which is put into a she-camel's vulva when she has a complaint thereof: pl. durajN. (L, K.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A piece of rag stuffed with cotton, which a woman in the time of the menses puts into her vulva, (K, TA,) to see if there be any remains of the blood: (MF:) likened to the drjp of a she-camel. (K.) It is said in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, kunRa yaboEavona biAAldRarajapi fiyhaA Alkurosufu [They (women) used to send the drjp, with cotton therein]: (IAth, K, * TA:) but accord. to one reading it is dirajap, (IAth, K,) pl. of durojN [explained above], meaning “ a thing like a small safaT, in which a woman puts her light articles and her perfumes: ” (IAth:) El-Bájee read darajap, which seems to be a mistake. (K.) ― -b3- See also 4, last sentence. ＝ -A2- And see what here next follows.

darajapN A single stair, or step, of a series of stairs or of a ladder; one of the daraj of a sulRam: (Mgh:) and hence, by a synecdoche, (Mgh,) a series of stairs, or a ladder, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) constructed of wood or of clay [&c.] against a wall or the like, (Mgh,) by which one ascends to the roof of a house; (TA;) as also durajapN↓ (S, K) and durojapN↓ and durajRapN↓ and OadorujRapN↓: (K:) the pl. of the first is darajN↓, (S,) or [rather] darajapN [has for its proper pl. darajaAtN, and] is n. un. of darajN like as qaSabapN is of qaSabN. (Msb.) darajN↓ and darajaAtN also signify Stages upwards: opposed to darakN and darakaAtN: and hence darajaAtN is used in relation to Paradise; and darakaAtN, in relation to Hell. (B voce darakN, q. v.) ― -b2- A degree in progress and the like: you say darajapF darajapF By degrees; gradually. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A degree, grade, or order, of rank or dignity: (S, A, K: *) degree, grade, rank, condition, or station: and exalted, or high, grade &c.: (TA:) pl. darajaAtN. (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- [A degree of a circle:] a thirtieth part of a sign of the Zodiac: (TA:) [pl. darajaAtN.] ― -b5- [A degree, i. e. four minutes, of time: pl. darajaAtN.]

, (S,) inf. n. daradN, (S, * M, Mgh, L, K, *) He was, or became, toothless; (S, L;) he lost his teeth. (M, Mgh, L, K.) I kept to the use of the toothstick until I feared that it would deprive me of my teeth, or render me toothless]: (L:) or, accord. to another relation, xaXiytu Oano Oudorida↓ OasonaAniI [I feared that I should make my teeth to fall out]; but this [verb, Mtr says,] I have not heard. , (TA,) inf. n. darosN (M, K) and diraAsN, (S, A, Msb, K,) (tropical:) He trod, or thrashed, the wheat, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and the like: (Msb:) [because he who does so passes repeatedly over it:] of the dial. of El-Yemen: (M, TA:) or diraAsN in the sense here indicated is of the dial. of Syria. , (K,) inf. n. darosN and diraAsapN (S, M, K) and daraAsapN and diraAsN, (TA,) (tropical:) He read the book; (M, K;) as though he opposed it until it became easy for him to remember it: (M:) or he read it repeatedly, [or studied it,] in order to remember it: (A:) or he made it easy to remember, by much reading: (TA:) or he read and learned it: (Bd in vi. 105:) and daArasahu↓, inf. n. mudaArasapN and diraAsN, signifies the same: (M:) and so darasRahu↓, and Oadorasahu↓: (K:) or the former of the last two has an intensive signification: the latter of them is mentioned by IJ: (TA:) [but accord. to the M, it is said by IJ that both of these are doubly trans., and have a different signification, which is also indicated in the A as that of the former of them: see 2:] Alkutuba daArasato↓, and tadaArasotuhaA↓, and AidRaArasotuhaA↓, signify the same as darasotuhaA [I read the books, or read them repeatedly, &c.]: (S, TA:) and AlquroMna tadaArasa↓ signifies He read the Kur-án, and returned to it time after time, in order that he might not forget it. , inf. n. darosN and diraAsapN, (tropical:) I read science. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [vi. 105], accord. to different reading, waliyaquwluwA darasota, and daArasota↓, (tropical:) [And to the end that they may say, Thou hast read, &c.:] but some say that the former means Thou hast read the books of the people of the Scriptures: and the latter, Thou hast consulted, or conferred, with them; expl. by caAkarotuhumo: (M:) or the former means Thou hast learned: (Abu-l-'Abbás:) and the latter, Thou hast read, or studied, under the Jews as thy teachers, and they have read, or studied, under thee as their teacher: (I'Ab, Mujáhid, K:) and another reading is daArasa↓;
i. e. daArasa AlnRabiIRu Alyahuwda [he prophet hath read, or studied, with the Jews]: and another, daArasato↓, which may be rendered in two ways: The Jews have read, or studied, or consulted, or conferred, with (daArasato) Mohammad: and The signs (MyaAt) have vied in length of time [or antiquity] with those of other scriptures so that every one of them has for the most part become obliterated: (TA:) and another reading is darasato; and another, darusato; both meaning, They (these stories, or histories,) have become obliterated: (M:) or they are things which have long since passed: (Abu-l-' Abbás:) but the latter of these two verbs has a more intensive signification: and it is also said to signify They have been dissipated. OadoraEu, applied to a horse, and to a sheep or goat, Having a black head, the rest being white: (S, Msb, * K:) or, as some say, having a black head and neck, (Msb, TA,) the rest being white: (TA:) or having a white head and neck, the rest being black: (TA:) fem. daroEaMCu: (S, Msb:) pl. duroEN: (S:) or daroEaMCu signifies having what is termed daraEN [q. v.]; applied to a sheep or goat, (K,) and to a mare: (TA:) or a sheep or goat black in the body, and white in the head: or black in the neck and head, the rest of her being white: or, accord. to AZ, a ewe having a black neck: or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, sheep or goats differing in colour: or, accord. to ISh, black except in having the neck white: and red [or brown], but having the neck white: and also, having the head with the neck white: accord. to Az, the right explanation is that given by AZ, meaning having the fore part black; being likened to the nights termed duraEN; or the latter are likened to the former: and hence, (TA,) ― -b2- layolapN daroEaMCu (tropical:) A night of which the moon rises at the dawn, (K,) or at the commencement of the dawn; the rest thereof being black, and dark. (TA.) And layaAlK duraEN↓, (S, K,) said by AHát to have been heard by him only on the authority of AO, but so accord. to As and A 'Obeyd and AHeyth, (TA,) and duroEN; (K;) the former contr. to rule, for by rule it should be duroEN, its sing. being daroEaMCu; (A 'Obeyd, S;) or, accord. to AHeyth, you say valaAvN duraEN wavalaAvN ZulamN, and duraEN and ZulamN are pls. of duroEapN↓ and ZulomapN, not of daroEaMCu and ZalomaMCu; and Az says that this is correct and regular; but IB says that daroEaMCu has duraEN for its pl. for the purpose of assimilation to ZulamN in the saying valaAvN ZulamN wavalaAvN duraEN, and that no other instance had been heard by him of a word of the measure faEolaMCu having a pl. of the measure fuEalN; (TA;) (tropical:) Three nights of the month which follow those called AlbiyDu; (As, S, K; *) namely, the sixteenth and seventeenth and eighteenth nights; (TA;) because of the blackness of their first parts, and the whiteness of the rest thereof: (S, K:) there is no difference in what As and AZ and ISh say respecting them: but some say that they are the thirteenth and fourteenth and fifteenth; because part of them is black and part of them white: [this, however, seems to have originated from a misunderstanding of an explanation running thus; three nights of the month which follow those called AlbiyD, which, meaning the latter, are the thirteenth &c.; for the thirteenth and fourteenth and fifteenth are all white:] or, accord. to AO, AllRayaAliI AldRuraEu signifies the nights of which the fore parts are black and the latter parts white, of the end of the month; and those of which the fore parts are white and the latter parts black, of the commencement of the month. (TA.) ― -b3- OadoraEu also signifies (assumed tropical:) One whose father is free, or an Arab, and whose mother is a slave; syn. hajiynN; (K;) as also muEalohajN. (TA.) 4. Adrkhu, (S Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. UidoraAkN (S, Msb) and mudorakN, (Msb,) He, or it, attained, reached, overtook, or came up with, him, or it: (S, K, TA:) or sought, or pursued, and attained, reached, &c., him, or it: (Msb:) [dArkhu, also, signifies the same, as shown above:] and tdArkhu↓, likewise, [of which AidRarAakahu is a variation,] is syn. with Adrkhu; (Jel in lxviii. 49, and KL, * and TA; *) and so is AidRarakahu↓. (TA.) You say, Oadorakotu AlrRajula and AidRarakotuhu↓ [I attained, reached, overtook, or came up with, the man]. (IJ, TA.) And maXayotu HatRaI Oadorakotuhu I walked, or went on foot, until I overtook him, or came up with him. (S, TA.) And EiXotu HatRaI Oadorakotu zamaAnahu I lived until I attained, or reached, his time. (S, TA.) And Oadorakotu AlfaAYita [I attained, &c., that which was passing away]. (Mgh.) And Adrkhu bimakoruwhK [He overtook him, or visited him, with some displeasing, or abominable, or evil, action]. (M and K in art. wtr. See also 6, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places: and see 10, first sentence.) And OadorakaniI Aljahodu [Difficulty, or distress, &c., overtook me, ensued to me, or came upon me]; a phrase similar to balaganiI Alkibaru in the Kur [iii. 35]: and so Oadorakotu Aljahoda [I came to experience difficulty, &c.]; like balagotu mina Alkibari EutiyFA in the Kur [xix. 9]. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. blg.) ― -b2- [Hence, He attained, obtained, or acquired, it; and so tdArkhu↓, as is shown in the KL; so too Adrk bihi, for one says,] Adrk bidamihi [He obtained revenge, or retaliation, for his blood]. (S in art. wtr.) ― -b3- [Hence also, He perceived it; attained a knowledge of it by any of the senses.] You say, Oadorakotuhu bibaSariI [I perceived it by my sight;] I saw it. (S, TA.) laA tudorikuhu AlOaboSaAru, in the Kur [vi. 103], means, accord. to some, The eyes [perceive him not]: accord. to others, the mental perception comprehendeth not [or attaineth not the knowledge of] the real nature of his hallowed essence. (TA.) You say also, Adrk EilomiI, meaning My knowledge comprehended that such a thing was a fact. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence likewise, as an intrans. v., or a trans. v. of which the objective complement is understood,] Adrk also signifies [He attained a knowledge of the uttermost of a thing; or] his knowledge attained the uttermost of a thing. (TA.) See also 6, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b5- Also It (a thing) attained its proper time: (Msb, K:) it attained its final time or state, or its utmost point or degree. (K.) [He (a boy, and a beast,) attained his perfect, ripe, or mature, state; and in like manner Adrkt is said of a girl: or it is like Adrk as meaning] he (a boy) attained to puberty, (S, Msb,) or to the utmost term of youth. (TA.) It (fruit) attained to ripeness, or maturity; became ripe, or mature; (S Msb;) attained its time, and its utmost degree of ripeness or maturity. (T, TA.) And Adrkt Alqidoru The cooking-pot attained its proper time [for the cooking of its contents]. (TA.) And Adrkt Alxamoru [The wine became mature]. (Msb and K in art. xmr.) And Adrk maMCu AlrRakiyRapi The water of the well reached its darak, i. e. its bottom (Aboo-' Adnán, TA.) ― -b6- Also It passed away and came to an end; came to nought; became exhausted; or failed entirely: (S, K:) said in this sense of flour, or meal: (S:) and thus it has been explained as used in the Kur [xxvii. 68], where it is said, [accord. to one reading,] balo Oadoraka Eilomuhumo fiI AlMxirapi [Nay, their knowledge hath entirely failed respecting the world to come]. (TA. [See also 6.]) Sh mentions this signification as heard by him on no other authority than that of Lth; and Az asserts it to be incorrect: but it has been authorized by more than one of the leading lexicologists, and the language of the Arabs does not forbid it; for it is said of flour, or meal, and in this case can only mean it came to its end, and entirely failed, or became exhausted; and fruits, when they are ripe (UicaA Oadorakoto) are exposed to coming to nought, and so is everything that has attained to its extreme term; so that the signification of “ coming to nought ” is one of the necessary adjuncts of the meaning of UidoraAkN. (TA.) [In like manner,] AidRaraka↓ signifies It (a thing) continued uninterruptedly and then come to nought: (IJ, TA:) and agreeably with this signification is explained the saying in the Kur [xxvi. 61], UinRaA lamudRarikuwna [Verily we are coming to nought, by those who read thus instead of lamudorakuwna being overtaken]. (TA.) ― -b7- You say also, Adrk AlvRamanu AlmuXotariIa, meaning [The payment of] the price was, or became, obligatory on the purchaser: this is an ideal reaching, or overtaking. (Msb.)

6 tdRArkwA dArk tdArk tdArkwA
6. tdRArkwA i. q. tlAHqwA (S) [i. e.] They attained, reached, overtook, or came up with, one another; as also AidRaArakuwA, and AidRarakuwA↓; (Sh, TA;) [or] the last of them attained, reached, overtook, or came up with, the first of them. (S Msb, K, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [vii. 36], (S,) HatRaI UicaA QdRaArakuwA fiyhaA jamiyEFA [Until, when they have overtaken one another, or have successively arrived, therein, all together]: originally tadaArakuwA. (S, K. *) And tdArk AlvRariyaAna [The two moistures reached each other; (like AilotaqaI AlvRarayaAni;) meaning] the moisture of the rain reached the moisture of the earth. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence] tdArk signifies [It continued, or was carried on, uninterruptedly; it was closely consecutive in its parts, or portions;] one part, or portion, of it, followed, or was made to follow, another uninterruptedly; said of anything. (TA.) You say, tdArk AlsRayoru [The course, or pace, or journeying, continued uninterruptedly]. (S and TA in art. Hfd, &c.) And tdArkt AlOaxobaAru The tidings followed one another closely. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, when said of knowledge, meaning, accord. to Fr, It continued unbroken in its sequence or concatenation.] bali QdRaraAka Eilomuhumo fiI AlMxirapi (K, TA,) in the Kur [xxvii. 68], (TA,) [virtually] means Nay, they have no knowledge respecting the world to come: (K, TA:) or, as IJ says, their knowledge is hasty, and slight, and not on a sure footing, &c.: Az says that AA read balo Oadoraka [of which an explanation has been given above (see 4)]: that I'Ab is related to have read balaIMOadoraka↓ [&c., i. e. Yea, hath their knowledge reached its end &c.?], as interrogatory, and without tesh-deed: and that, accord. to the reading bl AdRrAk Fr says that the proper meaning is, [Nay,] hath their knowledge continued unbroken so as to extend to the knowledge of the world to come, whether it will be or not be? wherefore is added, balo humo fiI XakRK minohaA balo humo minohaA Eamuwna: he says also that Ubeí read, Oamo tadaAraka; and that the Arabs substitute balo for Oamo, and Oamo for balo, when a passage begins with an interrogation: but this explanation of Fr is not clear; the meaning is [said to be] their knowledge shall be unbroken and concurrent [respecting the world to come] when the resurrection shall have become a manifest event, and they shall have found themselves
to be losers; and the truth of that wherewith they have been threatened shall appear to them when their knowledge thereof will not profit them: accord. to Aboo-Mo'ádh the Grammarian, the readings balo Oadoraka↓ &c. and bali QdRaAraka &c. mean the same; i. e. they shall know in the world to come; like the saying in the Kur [xix. 39], OasomiEo bihimo waOaboSiro, &c.: and Es-Suddee says of both these readings that the meaning is, their knowledge shall agree, or be in unison, in the world to come; i. e. they shall know in the world to come that that wherewith they have been threatened is true: or, accord. to Mujáhid, the meaning of bali QdRaAraka Eilomuhumo &c. is said to be, is their knowledge concurrent respecting the world to come? bl being here used in the sense of Oam: (TA:) or it may mean their knowledge hath gone on uninterruptedly until it hath become cut short; from the phrase tdArk banuw fulaAnK meaning The sons of such a one went on uninterruptedly into destruction. (Bd.) ＝ -A2- tdArkhu: see 4, in two places. It is used in the [primary] sense of Oadorakahu in the saying in the Kur [lxviii. 49], lawo laA Oano tadArakahu niEomapN mino rabRihi lanubica biQloEaraMCi [Had not favour (meaning mercy, Jel) from his Lord reached him, or overtaken him, he had certainly been cast upon the bare land]. (Jel.) ― -b2- [Hence, elliptically, He overtook him, or visited him, with good, or with evil.] El-Mutanebbee says,
Oana fiI OumRapK tadaArakahaA QllRe
hu gariybN kaSaAliHK fiI vamuwdi
[I am among a people (may God visit them with favour and save them from their meanness, or visit them with destruction so that I may be safe from them,) a stranger, like Sálih among Thamood]: tdArkhA AllReh is a prayer for the people, meaning AllReh wnjRAhm mn lwmhm AdrkhA↓ [i. e. luWomihimo]: or it may be an imprecation against them, i. e. AllReh bAlAhlAk liOanojuwa mnhm Adrkhm↓: [each meaning as explained above:] and IJ says that because of this verse the poet was named AlmtnbRI. (W p. 35. [The verse there commences with OanaA; but Oana is required by the metre, and is more approved in every case except the case of a pause.]) It is mostly used in relation to aid, or relief, and benefaction: [so that it signifies He aided, or relieved, him; he benefited him; he repaired his, or its, condition; he repaired, amended, corrected, or rectified, it:] whence the saying of a poet,
tadaArakaniI mino Eavorapi AldRahori qaAsimN
bimaA XaMCa mino maEoruwfihi AlmutadAriki
[Kásim relieved me, or has relieved me, from the slip of fortune with what he pleased of his relieving, or continuous, beneficence]. (TA.) [See also, in the first paragraph of art. dq, another example, in a verse of Zuheyr, which is cited in that art. and the present in the TA: and see the syn. talaAfaAhu. Hence,] tadaArakotu maA faAta i. q. Astdrkthu, q. v. (S, Msb, TA.)

8 AidRaraka OdAr Odr OdrI Odrk Adrk dAr drI drk
8. AidRaraka: see 4, first and second sentences: ― -b2- and near the end of the paragraph: ― -b3- and see also 6, first sentence.

10 Astdrk AlXRaIoCa biAlXRaICi c
10. Astdrk AlXRaIoCa biAlXRaICi [properly] signifies bihi HaAwala UidoraAkahu↓ [i. e. He sought, or endeavoured, to follow up the thing with the thing]: (K:) as, for instance, AlxaTaOa biAlSRawaAbi [the mistake with what was right]. (TK.) [Hence,] you say, Aisotadorakotu maAfaAta [I repaired, amended, corrected, or rectified, what had passed neglected by me, or by another; and I supplied what had so passed, or what had escaped me, or another, through inadvertence]; and tadaArakotuhu↓ signifies the same [in relation to language and to other things; whereas the former verb is generally restricted to relation to language or to a writer or speaker]. (S, Msb.) You say also, Astdrk Ealayohi qawolahu He corrected, or rectified, what was wrong, or erroneous, in his saying: [but more commonly, he supplied what he had omitted in his saying; generally meaning, what he had omitted through inadvertence: and Aisotadorakotuhu Ealayoh I subjoined it, or appended it, to what he had written, or said, by way of emendation; or, more commonly, as a supplement, i. e., to supply what had escaped him, or what he had neglected:] and hence, EalaI AlbuxaAriIRi Almusotadoraku↓ [The Supplement to ElBukháree; a work supplying omissions of ElBukháree;] by El-Hákim. (TA.) [Thus] AisotidoraAkN signifies The annulling a presumption, or surmise, originating from what has been before said, [by correcting an error, or errors, or by supplying a defect, or defects,] in a manner resembling the making an exception. (Kull.) [Hence Harofu QsotidoraAkK, meaning A particle of emendation, applied to balo, and to lekinRa or lekino.]

darokN dr drk
darokN: see the next paragraph, in eight places.

darakN dr drk
darakN The act of attaining, reaching, or overtaking; syn. laHaAqN; (K, TA; [in the CK, AllRiHAqu is erroneously put for AllRaHaAqu;]) [properly an inf. n. of the unused verb daraka (q. v.), but, having no used verb, said to be] a noun from AlUidoraAku [with which it is syn.], (TA,) or a noun from Oadorakotu AlXRaIoCa; as also darokN↓: and hence DamaAnN AldRaraki [which see in what follows]. (Msb.) [Hence,] laA taxaAfu darakFA, in the Kur [xx. 80.], means Thou shalt not fear Pharaoh's overtaking thee. (TA.) One says also AlTRarydapi farasN daroku↓, meaning A horse that overtakes what is hunted; like as they said farasN qayodu AlOawaAbidi. (TA.) ― -b2- ― -b3- Also The attainment, or acquisition, of an object of want: and the seeking the attainment or acquisition thereof: as in the saying, bakRiro fafiyhi darakN [Be thou early; for therein is attainment, &c.]: and darokN↓ signifies the same. (Lth, TA.) [Hence, perhaps,] yawomu AldRarika: this was [a day of contest] between El-Ows and El-Khazraj: (K:) thought to be so by IDrd. (TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. tabiEapN [i. e. A consequence; generally meaning an evil consequence: and perhaps it also means here a claim which one seeks to obtain for an injury]: as also darokN↓. (S, K.) One says, maA laHiqaka mino darakK faEalaIRi xalaASuhu (S, TA) and mn darokK↓ [i. e. Whatever evil consequence ensue to thee, on me be the compensation thereof]: in the A, mA Oadorakahu mn darakK fElIR xlASh i. e. maA yaloHaquhu mino tabiEapK [Whatever evil consequence ensue to it, &c.; relating to a thing sold]. (TA.) And hence DamaAnu AldRaraki in the case of a claim for indemnification for a fault of a defect or an imperfection in a thing sold [meaning either Responsibility, or indemnification, (see DamaAnN,) for evil consequence]: (TA in the present art:) or this means [indemnification for evil consequence in a sale; i. e., virtually,] the returning of the price to the purchaser on the occasion of requirement by the thing sold: the vulgar say incorrectly [DamaAn darak, and still more incorrectly] DumaAn darak [generally meaning thereby I sell this, or I purchase this, on the condition of responsibility, or indemnification, for any fault or defect or imperfection that may be found in it]: (TA in art. Dmn:) [and in this manner DamaAnu AldRaraki may be correctly rendered; for] darakN also signifies a fault or a defect or an imperfection [in a thing sold]; for instance, in a slave that is sold. (TA in art. Ehd.) [In the KT, AldRaraku is also explained as signifying The purchaser's taking from the seller a pledge for the price that he has given him, in fear that the thing sold may require it: but this seems to be an explanation of the case in which the word is used; not of the word itself.] ＝ -A2- Also A rope, (M, K,) or a piece of rope, (S,) that is tied upon the [lower] extremity of the main rope (S, M, K) of a well, to the cross pieces of wood of the bucket, (S,) so as to be that which is next the water, (S, M, K,) in order that the main rope may not rot (S, M) in the drawing of water: (M:) or a doubled rope that is tied to the cross pieces of wood of the bucket, and then to the main wellrope: (Az, TA:) and darokN↓ signifies the same. (K. [But only darakN is authorized by the TA in this sense.]) [See also karabN.] ― -b2- Also, and darokN↓, The bottom, or lowest depth, (Sh, T, S, M, K,) of a thing, (T, M, K,) as of the sea and the like, (T,) or of anything deep, as a well and the like: (Sh:) pl. OadoraAkN, (K,) a pl. of both, of a form frequent and analogous with respect to the former, but extr. with respect to the latter; and darakaAtN also. (TA.) And A stage of Hell: (IAar:) a stage downwards: (MA:) or stages downwards; like darakaAtN: (B:) opposed to darajN (MA, B) and darajaAtN, (B,) which are upwards: wherefore, (MA, B,) the abodes of Hell, or the stages thereof, are termed darakaAtN; (AO, S, MA, K, B;) [Golius and Freytag give darakapN as its sing.; the former as from the S, and the latter as from the K, in neither of which it is found;] and those of Paradise, darajaAtN. (S, MA, B.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 144], UinRa QlomunaAfiqiyna fiIQldRaraki QloOasofali mina QlnRaAri [Verily the hypocrites shall be in the lowest stage of the fire of Hell]: here the Koofees, except two, read fI AldRaroki↓. (TA.) ― -b3- [Golius gives another signification, “ Pars terræ, ” as on the authority of the S and K, in neither of which it is found.]

dirokapN drk drkh drkp
dirokapN The ring of the bow-string, (K, TA,) that
falls into the notch of the bow. (TA.) ― -b2- And A thong that is joined to the string of the bow, (K,) of the Arabian bow. (TA.) ― -b3- And A piece that is joined to the girdle when it is too short, (Lh, K,) and in like manner, to a rope, or cord, when it is too short. (Lh, TA.)

daraAki drAk drI
daraAki an imperative verbal noun, (S,) meaning Oadoriko [Attain thou, reach thou, overtake thou, &c.]: (K:) form the unused verb daraka: (IB:) like taraAki [from taraka], meaning Outoruko. (TA.)

diraAkN drAk drI
diraAkN [an inf. n. of 3, used in the sense of the part. n. mutadaArikN↓]. You say, TaEanahu TaEonFA diraAkFA He thrust him, or pierced him, with an uninterrupted thrusting or piercing: and Xariba XurobFA diraAkFA He drank with an uninterrupted drinking: and DarobN diraAkN An uninterrupted beating or striking. (TA.)

diraAkapN drAk drAkh drAkp
diraAkapN: see madorakN.

dariykapN drykh drykp
dariykapN i. q. TariydapN [as meaning An animal that is hunted]. (S, K.)

darRaAkN drAk drI
darRaAkN an epithet from Oadoraka, (S, Kudot;,) applied to a man, (K,) and signifying kaviyru AlUidoraAki [i. e. One who attains, reaches, or overtakes, &c., much, or often: and also having much, or great, or strong, perception: as will be seen from what follows]: (S, TA:) and so mudorikN↓ [expressly said in the TA to signify kvyr AlAdrAk, though why it should have this signification as well as that (which it certainly has) of simply attaining &c., I cannot see,] and mudorikapN↓: (K, TA:) the last explained by Lh as signifying sariyEu AlUidoraAki [i. e. quick in attaining, &c.]. (TA.) Keys Ibn-Rifá'ah says,
waSaAHibu Alwitori layosa AldRahora mudorikahu↓
EinodiI waUinRiI ladarRaAkN biOawotaAri
[And he who has a claim for blood-revenge is not ever an attainer of it with (meaning from) me; but verily I am one who often attains bloodrevenges]. (IB.) Seldom does faERaAlN come from OafoEala; but they sometimes said HasRaAsN darRaAkN [i. e. Having much, or great, or strong, perception]; it being [in this instance] a dialectal syn. [of HsRAs], or thus for conformity: (S:) it is said to be the only instance of faERaAlN from OafoEala except jabRaArN and saORLrN; [and some other instances might be added; but all of them require consideration:] accord. to IB, drRAk is from the unused verb daraka. (TA.)

madorakN mdr mdrk
madorakN: see mudorakN ― -b2- lahu madorakN [if not a mistranscription for mudorikN or mudorakN] means He has a sense in excess; [app. a preternatural perception, or a second sight;] and so diraAkapN↓. (TA.)

mudorakN mdr mdrk
mudorakN A place, and a time, of UidoraAkN [i. e. attaining, reaching, overtaking, &c.]. (Msb.) Hence madaAriku AlXRaroEi; (Mgh, Msb;) among which is included investigation of the law by means of reason and comparison; (Mgh;) i. e. The sources from which are sought the ordinances of the law; where one seeks for guidance by means of texts [of the Kur-án or the Sunneh] and by means of investigation by reason and comparison: (Msb:) the lawyers make the sing. to be madorakN↓; (Mgh, * Msb;) but there is no way of resolving this: (Msb:) correctly, by rule, it is mudorakN; because the meaning intended is a place of UidoraAk. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Also pass. part. n. of 4. ― -b3- And hence, Perceived by means of any of the senses; like maHosuwsN: and perceived by the intellect; thus opposed to maHosuwsN.]

mudorikN mdr mdrk
mudorikN: see darRaAkN, in two places. ― -b2- [AlquwRapu Almudorikapu, and simply Almudorikapu, as a subst., The perceptive faculty of the mind. See also what next follows.]

mudorikapN mdrk mdrkh mdrkp
mudorikapN: see darRaAkN. ― -b2- [See also mudorikN.] ― -b3- AlmudorikaAtu Alxamosu and AlmadaAriku Alxamosu signify The five senses. (TA.) [See also madorakN.] ＝ -A2- Also The Hajomap [a word I do not find in any other instance, app. a mistranscription for maHojamap (which when written with the article differs very little from the former word) i. e. the place to which the cupping-vessel is applied, for this is often] between the two shoulder-blades: (K:) so says Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

mudaArikapN mdArk mdArkh mdArkp
mudaArikapN A woman (TA) that will not be satiated with coitus; (K, TA;) as though her fits of appetency were consecutive. (TA.)

mutadaArikN mtdArk
mutadaArikN Uninterrupted; or closely consecutive in its parts, or portions: differing from mutawaAtirN, which is applied to a thing in the case of which there are small intervals. (Lh.) See also diraAkN. ― -b2- Applied to a rhyme, (Lth, M, K,) and to a word, (Lth, TA,) Having two movent letters followed by a quiescent letter; as faEuwo and the like: (Lth, TA:) or having two movent letters between two quiescent letters; as mutafaAEiluno, (M, K,) and musotafoEiluno, and mafaAEiluno, (M, TA,) and faEuwluno faEalo, (M, K,) i. e. as faEalo when immemediately following a quiescent letter, (M, TA,) and faEuwlu fulo, (M, K,) i. e. as fulo with a movent letter immediately followed by it: (M, TA:) as though the vowel-sounds overtook one another without an obstacle between the two movent letters. (M, K.) ― -b3- [AlmutadaAriku is also the name of The sixteenth metre of verse; the measure of which consists of faAEiluno eight times.]

musotadorakN mstdrk
musotadorakN [A supplement]: see 10. ― -b2- [In the TA and some other similar works, it is often used as signifying Superfluous, or redundant.]

1 darina dAr drn drnn
1. darina, aor.
darana
, inf. n. daranN; (T, * S, * M, Msb, K; *) and Adrn↓; (T, M, K;) It (a garment, S, M, &c.) was, or became, dirty, or filthy: (S, M, Msb, K:) or was, or became, defiled, polluted, or smeared, with dirt, or filth. (T, K.) And darinato yaduhu biAlXRaIoCi His hand was, or became, defiled, polluted, or smeared, with the thing. (K.)

4 Adrn OdAr Odrn Odrnn Adrn drn
4. Adrn: see 1. ＝ -A2- Also He rendered a garment dirty, or filthy: (S, K:) or he defiled, polluted, or smeared, a garment with dirt, or filth. (K.) ＝ -A3- Oadoranati AlUibilu The camels fed upon what is termed dariyn: (M, K:) thus they do in the case of drought, or sterility. (M.)

daranN dAr drn drnn
daranN Dirtiness, or filthiness; or dirt, or filth: (S, M, K:) or defilement, or pollution, with dirt or filth: (T, K:) and accord. to the K, AlUidorawonN↓ also is syn. with AldRaranu; but ISd says that this is not known. (So in the TA. [In the text of the M, however, as given in the TT, in the place of AldRaranu in this case I find AlradiIL (for AlrRadiIoCu, i. e. the bad, &c.); and another passage in the M, respecting a signification of UidorawonN, (which see below,) suggests that the explanation of AlUidorawonu as meaning AldRaranu may have been taken from this passage in consequence of an oversight.]) maAkaAna UilRaA kadaranK bikafRiI, meaning It was no otherwise than like dirt in my hand, which I therefore wiped with the other hand, is a prov. applied in the case of a thing done in haste. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] OumRu daranK means (assumed tropical:) The present world, or the present state of existence. (Z, K.) ― -b3- daranN is also used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Vileness, ignominy, or abjectness. (Har p. 509.)

darinN dAr drn drnn
darinN (S, M, Msb, K) and Oadoranu↓, (M, TA,) applied to a garment, Dirty, or filthy: (S, M, Msb, K:) or defiled, polluted, or smeared, with dirt, or filth. (K.) ― -b2- And, so applied, Old and worn out; as also dariynN↓. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence,] yadaAhu daranaAtN biAlxayori (tropical:) [in the CK mina Alxayori, His hands are worn out by beneficence; meaning, much used therein]: and Oayodiyhimo diraAnN (tropical:) [Their hands are worn out thereby]: and huwa darinu Alyadayoni (tropical:) [He is worn out in respect of the hands thereby]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- darinapN applied to a she-camel means Mangy, or scabby. (TA.)

daranN dAr drn drnn
daranN, like saHaAbN, (K,) or darRaAnN↓, (so accord. to the TT as from the M,) The fox. (M, K.)

dariynN drI dryn
dariynN: see darinN. ― -b2- Also, (S, M, K,) and duraAnapN↓, (M, K,) Dry herbage: (M:) and whatever is broken in pieces, of [plants of the kind termed] HamoD, or of trees, or of herbs, or leguminous plants, (M, K,) of such as are eaten without being cooked, or are slender and succulent or soft or sweet, and such as are hard and thick, or thick and inclining to bitterness, or thick and rough, when old (M) and dry: (M, K:) or dariynN signifies what is broken in pieces, of herbage, when it is old (S, TA) and withered, or wasted, and black; (so in a copy of the S;) i. e. withered, or wasted, herbage; such as is seldom made use of by the camels: (S, TA:) or herbage that has become a year old, and then dried up: (Th, M:) dry herbage a year old: (Lth, T:) or dry and old herbage. (Ham p. 527.) ― -b3- [Hence,] OumRu dariynK (assumed tropical:) Sterile, or unfruitful, land. (S, K.) A poet says,
taEaAla nusamRiTo HubRa daEodK wanagotadiI
sawaMCayoni waAlmaroEaI biOumRi dariyni
[Come thou, let us keep to our love of Daad (a woman's name), and we will go forth early in the morning, both alike, though the pasturing be in sterile land]: he means, we will keep to our
love, though the means of subsistence be strait. (S.)

duraAnapN drAnh drAnp

dirohamN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the measure fiEolalN, (Msb, MF,) of which it has been said that there are only three other instances, but there are many more; (MF;) an arabicized word, (S, Msb,) from the Pers. [diramo]; (S;) also pronounced dirohimN↓, (S, Msb, K,) but this is of rare occurrence; (TA;) and dirohaAmN↓, (S, K,) which is more rare; (TA;) A certain silver coin; (Mgh, Msb;) like as diynaArN signifies a certain gold coin: (Mgh:) [and the weight thereof; i. e. a drachm, or dram:] its weight is six dawaAniyq [or dániks]; (Msb, and K in art. mk;) i. e., the weight of the diroham UisolaAmiIR: but in the Time of Ignorance, some dirhems were light, being four dwAnyq; and these were called TabariyRapN: and some were heavy, being eight dwAnyq; and these were called EabodiyRapN, or bagoliyRapN: and of these two they made two that were equal; so that each drhm was six dwAnyq: this is said to have been done by 'Omar: or, accord. to another account, some dirhems were of the weight of twenty carats, and were called the weight of ten [i. e. of ten dániks]; and some were of the weight of ten [carats], and were called the weight of five; and some were of the weight of twelve [carats], and were called the weight of six; and they put the three weights together, and called the third part thereof the weight of seven: and one of the weights of the drhm before El-Islám was twelve carats, which is six dwAnyq: but the drhm AslAmIR is sixteen carats; the dAnq of this being a carat and two thirds: (Msb:) or dirhems should be fourteen carats [i. e. seven dániks]; ten being of the weight of seven mavaAqiyl [or mithkáls]: in the Time of Ignorance, some were heavy, [equal to] mvAqyl; and some were light, [called] TabariyRapN; and when they were coined in the age of El-Islám, they made of the heavy and the light two dirhems, so that ten became equal to seven mvAqyl: A 'Obeyd says that this was done in the time [of the dynasty] of the sons of Umeiyeh: (El-Karkhee, cited in the Mgh:) [see also De Sacy's “ Chrest. Arabe, ” sec. ed., vol. ii. p. 110 of the Arabic text, and p. 282 of the transl.; where it is further stated, on the authority of Ibn-Khaldoon, that the diroham magoribiIR was three dwAnyq; and the yamaniIR, one dAnq; and, as is said in the Msb, that 'Omar adopted the mean between the bglIR and the TbrIR, making the drhm to be six:] the pl. (of drhm, S) is daraAhimu and (of drhAm, S) daraAhiymu. (S, K.) [The former of these pls. is often used as signifying Money, cash, or coin, in an absolute sense.] The dim. is durayohimN↓ and durayohiymN↓: the latter held by Sb to be anomalous; for he says that it is as though it were formed from dirohaAmN, though this was not used by them. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, [i. e., to the coin thus called,] (TA,) dirohamN signifies also (assumed tropical:) A Hadiyqap [app. as meaning a round piece of land surrounded by a fence or the like, or by elevated land; for this is one of the significations of HadiyqapN]. (K.) [It is said that] this is taken from
the saying of 'Antarah, [describing shower of copious rain,]
fatarakona kulRa HadiyqapK kaAldRirohami
[So that they left every ridged-round spot of ground like the drhm]. (TA.) [But accord. to one reading, he said, kulRa qaraArapK; meaning, as is said in the EM, p. 227, “ every round hollow; ” and likening such a hollow to the drhm because of its roundness, and the clearness and whiteness of its water.]

1. daraI AlXRaIoCa He knew the thing; syn. Ealimahu; (M;) [and so daraI biAlXRaIoCi; for] you say, darayotuhu (S, Msb, K) and darayotu bihi, (S, K,) aor. OadoriI, (Msb, K,) inf. n. daroIN (S, M, Msb, K) and diroIN (Lh, M, K) and diroyapN (S, M, Msb, K) and daroyapN, (M, * K,) which last is said by Sb to be not used as an inf. n. of un., but as denoting a state, or condition, (M,) and, accord. to some copies of the S, duroyapN, (TA, [so in one of my copies of the S,]) and diraAyapN (S, M, Msb, K) and darayaAnN and diroyaAnN (M, K) and duriIRN, (TS, K,) I knew it; (S, Msb, K;) syn. Ealimotuhu (Msb, K) or Ealimotu bihi: (S:) or it has a more special meaning than Ealimotuhu: it is said to signify I knew it after doubting: so says Aboo-'Alee: (TA:) or I knew it by a sort of artifice, or cunning, or skill; (K, TA;) or with painstaking, and artifice or cunning or skill; (Har p. 24;) and therefore daraI is not said of God: (TA:) a rájiz says, (S, * TA,) but this is an instance of the rude speech of the Arabs of the desert, (TA,)
laA humRa laA OadoriI waOanota AldRaAriI↓
[O God, I know not, but Thou art the knowing]: (S, TA: [in Har, p. 24, it is cited as commencing with AalRehumRa, and therefore as a prose-saying, ascribed to Mohammad, and as adduced by some to show that AldRaAriI is allowable as an epithet applied to God:]) or, as some relate it, laA Oadori, (S,) in which the I is elided in consequence of the frequent usage of the phrase; (S, M;) like the phrases lamo Oubalo and lamo yaku; (S;) and like laA yaOolu in the saying Oaqobala biDarobahK laA yaOolu [q. v. in art. Alw]. (M.) [The saying laA darayotu walaA QYotalyota or Oalayota &c. is explained in the latter part of the first paragraph of art. Alw.] One says, maA OadoriI OaIRu AlnRaAsi huwa [I know not who of mankind he is]. (The Lexicons passim.) And IAar mentions the saying maA tadoriI maA diroyotuhaA, (M,) or durayotuhaA, (TA,) as meaning Thou knowest not (maA taEolamu [which may also be rendered she knows not]) what is her knowledge. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- daraI, (T, M, K,) aor. yadoriI, (T, S,) inf. n. daroIN, (T, M, K,) He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, (ISk, T, S, M, K,) a man, (ISk, T,) and an object of the chase; as also AidRaraI↓ and tdrRI↓: (T, S, M, K: [AdorAhu in the CK is a mistake for AdRrAhu:]) he hid, or concealed, himself, and deceived, deluded, &c. (S.) A rájiz says,
kayofa taraAniIOacRariI waOadRariI↓
girariI girRaAti jumolK watadarRaI↓

How seest thou me winnowing the dust of the mine and deceiving Juml by looking at her while she is inadvertent, (T, S,) she also deceiving me [by looking at me while I am inadvertent]: tadarRaI being for tatadarRaI. (S.) See also 3. ＝ -A3- daraI raOosahu, (K,) aor. yadoriI, inf. n. daroIN, (TA,) He scratched his head with the midoraI: (K:) or raOosahu drRI↓ he combed his head with the midoraI: (M: [see Ham p. 159, line 11: and see also carRaIa:]) and tadarRato↓ she (a woman, S) loosed and let down, or loosed and separated, or combed, her hair (S, K, TA) with the midoraAp. It is also said in the Kur [xci. 9 and 10], qado OafolaHa mano zakRaAhaA waqado xaAba mano dasRaAhaA↓, (M, K, *) in which dsRAhA is for dasRasahaA↓, like taZanRayotu for taZanRanotu, (K,) because the niggardly conceals his place of sojourning and his property, but the liberal makes his place of sojourning upon an open and elevated spot that he may not be concealed from guests and those who desire to come to him: (Fr, Zj, K: *) or the meaning is, He is successful who maketh it (namely his soul) pure and believing, and he is unsuccessful who introduceth it among the good when he is not of them: (IAar, Th, M, K: *) or [he is successful who maketh it to increase in grace by good works,] and he is unsuccessful who maketh it vile and little by evil works: (M:) or the latter clause means, and he is unsuccessful who hideth it, and maketh it obscure and of no reputation, by the neglect of almsgiving and of obedience [to God in other matters]: (TA:) or the soul is unsuccessful that God rendereth obscure [so I render, here, dsRAhA]. dasRaAsN That enters much, or often; wont to enter; syn. daxRaAlN: so in the saying, AlEiroqu dasRaAsN [The natural disposition is wont to enter and actuate him in whom it is engendered: generally applied to him who has some fault derived from his mother, or the like; as is said in a marginal note in my copy of the TA: see EiroqN]. (TA.)

daAsuwsN dAsws
daAsuwsN: see dasiysN.

madosuwsN mdsws
madosuwsN, applied to a camel: part. n. of dusRa [q. v.]. (S.)

dasotN dAs ds dsI dst
dasotN i. q. daXotN, (K,) A [desert, or such as is termed] SaHoraMC: an arabicized word [from the Pers. daXoto]: (Msb, K:) or it is either a dial. var. of dXt or an arabicized word from this latter. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The upper end of a chamber, which is the most honourable place therein: (A, K, TA:) in this sense an arabicized word [from the Pers. dasoto]. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, [A place, or seat, of honour: a seat of office: used in these senses in the present day:] used by the later writers to signify a court, or council; syn. diywaAnN: and the court, or council, (majolis,) of a wezeer or governor. (TA.) ― -b3- A thing against, or upon, which one leans, or stays himself: (Har p. 261:) a pillow, or cushion. (Id. p. 276.) ＝ -A3- Headship, rule, dominion, government, or superiority. (MF.) ＝ -A4- A game; a single act of a game or play: pl. dusuwtN. (TA.) You say, AldRasotu liI The game is mine: and AldRasotu EalaIRa The game is against me. (Har p. 130.) And tamRa Ealayohi AldRasotu [The game ended, or has ended, against him]: this is said of one who is overcome: the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance used to say so when a man's arrow [in the game called Almayosir] was unsuccessful, and he did not attain his desire. (TA.) [In the contrary case, one says, tamRa lahu AldRasotu The game ended, or has ended, in his favour.] fulaAnN Hasanu AldRasoti [Such a one is a good player] is said of a skilful chess-player. (A.) And a poet says,
tafarozanu fiI OuxoraI AldRusuwti AlbayaAciqu
[The pawns become queens in the ends of the games: tafarozana being for tatafarozana]. (TA.) ― -b2- [It is also used in the present day to signify A trick of cards.] ― -b3- And An evasion, a shift, a wile, or an artifice; or art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill: (MF, and Har p. 130:) and deceit, delusion, guile, or circumvention. (Har ibid.) ＝ -A5- Also, (TA,) or dasotN mina AlvRiyaAbi, (Msb, K, TA,) as also daXotN mn AlvyAb, (TA in art. dXt,) [A suit, or complete set, of clothes;] the clothes which a man wears and which suffice him for his going to and fro in the transaction of his affairs: pl. as above: (Msb:) in this sense, also, an arabicized word [from the Pers. dasoto]. (K.) El-Hareeree has mentioned together instances of this word in three different senses, in the 23rd Makámeh, where he says, naAXad tRuka QllReha Oalasota AlRaciI OaEaArahu AldRasoto faqulotu laA waAlRaciI Oajolasaka fiI hecaA AldRasoto maA OanaA biSaAHibi celika AldRasoto balo Oanota AlRaciI tamRa Ealayohi AldRasoto I conjure thee by God [to tell me], art thou not he who lent him the suit of clothes? And I said, No, by Him who seated thee in this place of honour, I am not the owner of that suit of clothes: but thou art he against whom the game hath ended. (TA.) ― -b2- And dasotN mina Alwaraqi, (K,) as also daXotN mn Alwrq, (TA in art. dXt,) [A quire, or twenty-five sheets folded together, of paper: still used in this sense: pl. as above:] in this sense, also, an arabicized word [from the Pers. dasoto]. (K.) ― -b3- [dasotN is also used in the present day in a similar, but more extensive, sense; as signifying A lot, or parcel, of things: of some things, ten; of others, twelve; &c.] ＝ -A6- Also an appellation applied, as mentioned by El-Khafájee in the “ Shifá el-Ghaleel, ” by the common people of Egypt and of other countries of the East, to A copper cooking-pot: (MF:) [it is still used in this sense; applied in Egypt to a copper cookingpot wide at the bottom, contracted at the mouth, and more contracted a little below the mouth. And dasotu xaXabK is applied to A shallow wooden tub.]

AldRasotabanodu Aldstbnd
AldRasotabanodu [from the Pers. dasobanodo] A certain
game of the Magians, which they thus call; i. q. AldRaEokasapu: (S and K in art. dEks:) they turn round [in a circle, as though imitating the revolutions of the “ host of heaven ”], having taken one another by the hand, [in a manner] like dancing. (K in that art.) [Hence probably originated the similar performances of certain Muslim darweeshes in celebrating what they term a cikor, described in the works of several travellers, and in my own work on the Modern Egyptians.]

dusotuwrN dstwr
dusotuwrN, an arabicized word, (K,) [from the Persian dasotuwro,] by some of the Arabs, [and in the present day generally,] pronounced dasotuwrN, which is not absolutely erroneous, as it is the original form of the word before its being arabicized, (MF,) The copy, or original, [of the register, as will be seen from what follows,] which is made for the several classes [of the officers and servants of the government], from which their transcription is made, (expl. by AlnRusoxapu AlmaEomuwlapu lilojamaAEaAti QltRaIi minohaA taHoriyruhaA, K,) and in which are collected the rules and ordinances of the King; (TA;) the register (dafotar) in which are collected the rules of the realm: (Kull p. 186:) pl. dasaAtiyru. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) The great wezeer (waziyr) to whom recourse is had [by the King] with respect to what he may prescribe concerning the circumstances of the people, because he is the possessor of the register so called: (Mefáteeh el-'Uloom by Ibn-Kemál-Páshà, in TA; and Kull ubi suprà:) the officer who manages, conducts, orders, or regulates, the affairs of the King. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also, in the conventional language of astronomy, (tropical:) An almanac.] ― -b4- Also, vulgarly, Permission; leave. (TA.) [For instance, it is used in this sense by a man entering a house, or approaching an apartment, in which he supposes that there may be some woman whom he should not see unveiled, in order that she may veil herself or retire: on such an occasion, he repeats the word dstwr several times as he advances.]

, (S, M,) inf. n. dasorN, (S, M, K,) He, or it, pushed, thrust, drove, impelled, propelled, or repelled, him, or it. (S, M, A, K.) dasura
and

duwaAsiriIRRN: see dawosarN.

, (S, TA,) inf. n. dasoEN (S, Mgh, K) and dasiyEapN, (S, TA,) He impelled it, pushed it, thrust it, or drove it; and particularly so as to remove it from its place; propelled it, repelled it; pushed it, thrust it, or drove it, away, or back. dasaEa
, (TA,) inf. n. dasoEN (Z, TA) and dusuwEN, (TA,) The camel propelled his cud so as to make it pass forth from his inside to his mouth; (S, TA;) drew it forth from his stomach and cast it into his mouth. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, also, (as appears from an explanation of dasiyEapN, q. v. infrà,)] dasaEa, aor.
dasaEa
, (S, TA,) inf. n. dasoEN, (K,) (tropical:) He gave a large gift. (S, K, TA.) It is said in a trad., (S, TA,) that God will ask the son of Adam on the day of resurrection, (TA,) Oalamo OajoEaloka tarobaEu wa tadosaEu Did I not make thee to take the fourth part of the spoil, and to give largely? (S:) and on his answering “ Yes, ” that God will ask, “ Then where is [thy] gratitude for that? ” for the doing thus is the act of the chief. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- Natural disposition: (S, K:) or, as some say, generosity of action: or, as some say, make; or natural constitution. (TA.) ― -b4- The pl. is dasaAYiEu. (TA.)

dasokarapN A building like a qaSor [q. v.], surrounded by houses, or chambers, (Lth, Mgh, Msb, K,) and places of abode for the servants and household, (TA,) and pertaining to kings: (Lth, Mgh, Msb:) Heraclius is related, in trads., to have received the great men of the Greeks in a dskrp belonging to him: (TA:) or a building like a qaSor, which is surrounded by houses, or chambers, and in which the vitious, or immoral, (XuTRaAr,) assemble: (Har p. 140:) or houses of the foreigners (OaEaAjim), in which are wine and instruments of music or the like: (K:) thought by Az to be an arabicized word; (Msb;) not genuine Arabic: (TA:) [from the Persian dasokaraho, or dasotokaraho:] pl. dasaAkiru. (K.) ― -b2- Also A Christian's cloister, or cell; syn. SawomaEapN. (AA, K.) ― -b3- And A town, or village; syn. qaroyapN. (Az, Msb, K.) ― -b4- And A plain, or level, land. (Kz, K.)

(K.) ― -b2- And dasima, (inf. n. dasamN, TK,) He, or it, was, or became, of the colour termed dusomap, i. e., dust-colour inclining to blackness. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- dasama, (Z, K, and so in some copies of the S,) [aor., app.,
dasima
,] inf. n. dasomN; (TA;) or dsRm↓; (so in some copies of the S;) said of rain, It moistened the earth (S, Z, K) a little, (K,) not much, (S,) or so as not to reach the moist soil. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- And dasama, aor.

, (K,) inf. n. dasomN, (TA,) He smeared a camel with tar. (K.) ― -b3- Also, (S, M, K,) aor.

, (S, K, *) or

Tasama, [in some copies of the K, and in the TA, Tamasa, which signifies the same, i. e. It became effaced, or obliterated,] said of a relic, trace, mark, or the like. (S, K.)

2. tadosiymN, (S,) inf. n. of dsRm, (Msb,) signifies The smearing (S, Msb) a thing, (S,) or a morsel, or mouthful, (Msb,) [or seasoning it, imbuing it, or soaking it,] with dasam [i. e. grease, or gravy, or dripping]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- dasRimuwA nuwnatahu, (Mgh, K,) said by 'Othmán respecting a beautiful boy, (Mgh,) means Blacken ye his dimple in the chin, in order that the evil eye may not have effect upon it. (Mgh, K. *) [Accord. to another explanation, mentioned in the TA, the blackness denoted by this phrase is behind the ear: but this is evidently a mistake.] ― -b3- See also 1.

dasomN Odsm dsm
dasomN: see dasamN. ＝ -A2- OanaA EalaI dasomi AlOamori means ElI TarafK minohu [app. I am beside, or out of, the case, or affair]. (K.)

dasamN Odsm dsm
dasamN a word of well-known meaning; (S;) i. q. wadakN; (M, K;) both signifying Grease, or gravy; i. e. the dripping that exudes from flesh-meat and from fat; (Msb in art. wdk;) the wadak of flesh-meat and of fat: (Mgh: [in the CK, Alwaraku is erroneously put for Alwadaku:]) or, accord. to the T, anything that has wadak, of flesh-meat and of fat: (TA:) and dirt, or filth: (M, K:) and dasomN↓ signifies the same as dasamN, accord. to El-Kurtubee; but El-Welee El-'Irákee says, I have not seen this on the authority of any other lexicologist. (TA.) You say, yaduhu mina AldRasami saliTapN [app. meaning, if correctly transcribed, His hand is hard by reason of dirt adhering to it: in my MS. copy of the K, the last word is written saTilapN; a word which I do not find in any sense: in the TK, sTlp: this Freytag thinks to be the right reading, though I know of no such word; and he renders the phrase, “ manus ejus propter sordes inhaerentes catinus est; ” evidently assuming that sTlp is a dial. var. of saTolN]. (K.) [It seems that you say also, maA fiyhi dasamN meaning (assumed tropical:) There is not in him, or it, any profit, or good: a sense assigned in the TA to the phrase mA fyh dysm dsm; in which I think it evident that the transcriber has written dysm by mistake, and forgotten to erase it after adding dsm.) ― -b2- Also The bowels, or intestines. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Accord. to IAar, it means also kaviyru AlcRikori [Praising, or glorifying, God, much]; a sense in which it is incorrectly said in the K to be dasiymN↓, like OamiyrN: (TA:) and hence the trad., of weak authority, laA yacokuruwna QllReha UilRaA dasamFA: (K:) or, accord. to Z, this is from dasama said of rain: and, as related by Abu-d-Dardà, the words are OaraDiytumo Uino XabiEotumo EaAmFA OalRaA tacokuruwna QllReha UilRaA dasamFA, meaning [Do ye approve, if ye be satisfied in your stomachs throughout a year,] that ye should not praise, or glorify, God, save a little? (TA:) or it may denote commendation; so that the meaning of lA yckrwn AllReh AlRA dsmFA is, that praise, or glorification, is the stuffing of their hearts and of their mouths: and it may denote discommendation; as meaning that they praise, or glorify, little; from tadosiymu nuwnapi AlSRabiIRi; (K, TA;) the blackness denoted by this phrase being small in quantity: or, as some say, the meaning is, that they do not praise, or glorify, God for anything but eating, and the grease, or gravy, in their insides. (TA.)

(TA.) And viyaAbN dusomN, Dirty, or filthy, garments. (S, TA.) And dasima AlvRawobi, applied to a man, [Dirty in the garment: and hence, going on foot;] not riding; as also Oadosamu↓ AlvRawobi. (TA.) [Hence also,] (assumed tropical:) Defiled by culpable dispositions. (TA.) A rájiz says,
laAhumRa UinRa EaAmira bona jahomi
Oawocama HajRFA fiI viyaAbK dusomi
meaning (assumed tropical:) [O God, verily 'Ámir Ibn-Jahm] hath imposed upon himself, (S in art. wcm,) or hath performed, (M,) pilgrimage being defiled by sins. (S in art. wcm, and M.) ― -b2- EimaAmapN dasimapN signifies A black turban; (TA;) as also EmAmp dasomaMCu↓. (Az, Mgh, TA.) And dasimN occurs in a trad. as meaning (assumed tropical:) Strict, or pious, [though] black, (Oasowadu, [or this may here mean a genuine Arab, as opposed to OaHomaru meaning a foreigner,]) and religious. (TA.)

[Freytag erroneously assigns the meaning “ vilis ” to Oadosamu.]) One says, maA Oanota UilRaA dusomapN (tropical:) Thou art none other than one in whom is no good. (TA.)

dayosamapN dysm dysmh dysmp

OadosamN, and its fem. dasomaMCu: see dasimN. ― -b2- dasomaMCu also signifies A kind of milking-vessel; i. q. EulobapN and janobapN and samoraMCu. (T and TA in art. (K.) ― -b2- [Freytag assigns to it also the significations “ Multum pinguis ” and “ Oleo conspurcatus; ” both as on the authority of the K, in which I do not find either of them: also that of “ Vilis, ” as applied to a man; a signification belonging to dusomapN.]
