(TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] daEaA bihi, said of anything in the earth, means It needed it; or required it: [and so daEaA Uilayohi: one says of a wall, daEaA UilaI UiSolaAHihi It needed, or required, its being repaired: (see 10 in art. rm:) and] one says to him whose clothes have become old and worn out, qado daEato viyaAbuka [Thy clothes have become such as to need thy putting on others; or] thou hast become in need of putting on other clothes. (Aboo-'Adnán, TA.) [See also 10.] ― -b5- daEawotuhu, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb,) and daEawotu bihi, (MA, [and of frequent occurrence,]) inf. n. [duEaMCN and] daEowN, (TA, [but the former is more common,]) also signify I called him, called out to him, or summoned him, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb,) syn. naAdayotuhu, (Mgh, Msb,) or AldRuEaMCu is to the near and AlnRidaMCu is to the distant, (Kull p. 184,) and desired him to come, to come forward, or to advance; (Msb;) and AisotadoEayotuhu↓ signifies the same, (S, MA,) [i. e.] I called him to myself. (MA.) One says, daEaA AlmuWacRinu AlnRaAsa UilaI AlSRalaApi [The mWcRn called the people to prayer]. (Msb.) And the saying of En-Nahdee kunRaA nadoEuw wanadaEu means We used to call, or invite, them to ElIslám at one time, and to leave doing so at another time. (Mgh.) And daEawotu AlnRaAsa, (Msb,) inf. n. duEaMCN and daEowapN, (S,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and madoEaApN, (S, [app. there mentioned as an inf. n., agreeably with many other instances,]) means also I invited people to eat with me, or at my abode. (Msb.) ― -b6- [Hence,] maA daEaAka UilaI hecaA AlOamori What drew, led, induced, or caused, and constrained, or drove, thee to do this thing? (TA.) And daEaAnaA gayovN waqaEa bibaladK qado OamoraEa, i. e. [Rain that fell in a region which had become abundant in herbage invited us thither, or] was the cause of our seeking its herbage. (TA.) And yadoEuwmaA baEodahu, (S, Mgh, K, *) or yadoEuwmaA waraMCahu mina AllRabani, (Nh, TA,) [It draws, or attracts, what is to come after it, of the milk,] said of some milk left in the udder. (S, Nh, Mgh, K, TA.) And daEaAhu UilaI AlOamiyri He drove him, or urged him to go, [but more commonly meaning he summoned him,] to the prince, or commander. (K, * TA. [In the TK, AlI AlOamori to the thing, or affair.]) ― -b7- [Hence likewise,] AldRuEaMCu signifies also The calling to one's aid: thus, [in the Kur ii. 21,] waQdoEuwA XuhadaMCakumo means And call ye to your aid [your helpers]. (TA.) ― -b8- And daEaA AlmayRita He called upon the dead, praising him, and saying, Alas for such a one! or he wailed for, wept for, or deplored the loss of, the dead, and enumerated his good qualities and actions; as though he called him. (TA. [See also 5.]) ― -b9- And daEawotuhu zayodFA and bizayodK (tropical:) I called him, i. e. named him, Zeyd. (Msb, K, TA.) And daEawotuhu biQboni zayodK (assumed tropical:) I called him, i. e. asserted him to be, the son of Zeyd. (Msb.) ― -b10- daEaAhu QllRehu (assumed tropical:) God destroyed him: [as though He called him away:] whence tadoEuw mano Oadobara watawalRaI, in the Kur lxx. 17, [describing the fire of Hell,] (assumed tropical:) It shall destroy him who shall have gone back from the truth and turned away from obedience: or this means (tropical:) it shall draw, and bring, &c.: or it refers to the zabaAniyap of Hell [i. e. the tormentors of the damned]: (Bd:) or it means (assumed tropical:) it will do to them hateful deeds. (TA.) [Also] God punished him, or tormented him. (TA.) And daEaAhu QllRehu bimakoruwhK (tropical:) God caused an evil, or abominable, event to befall him. (ISd, Z, K.) ― -b11- daEaA fiI AlDRaroEi (tropical:) He left some milk, such as is termed daAEiyap, in the udder. (M, K, TA.) Accord. to IAth, daAEiyapN is an inf. n., like EaAqibapN and EaAfiyapN. (TA.)

3 mudaAEaApN dEymyS
3. mudaAEaApN signifies (tropical:) The proposing an enigma or enigmas to a person; or the contending with another in doing so; syn. muHaAjaApN. (S, K, TA.) You say, daAEayotuhu (tropical:) I proposed to him an enigma or enigmas; &c. (TA.) A poet says,
OudaAEiyka maA musotaSoHabaAtN maEa AlsRuraI
HisaAnN wamaA MvaAruhaA biHisaAni
[(assumed tropical:) I propose to thee an enigma: What are things that are taken as companions in night-journeying, good, and the effects whereof are not good?]: meaning swords. (S.) ― -b2- And The asking a thing of one much, so as to weary; as also muHaAjaApN. (K.) ― -b3- daAEayonaA AlHaAYiTa Ealayohimo (tropical:) We pulled down, or demolished, the wall upon them, from the sides [or foundations] thereof. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- [Golius assigns other significations to daAEaI, for which I find no authority: namely, “ Convocavit ad Deum propheta, præco sacer, ” followed by an accus.: and “ Contendit contra alium: Provocavit: pecul. rem vindicans sibi vel arrogans. ”]

4 OadoEaAhu c
4. OadoEaAhu [so in some copies of the K; in other copies AidRaEaAhu↓; the former of which I regard as the right reading;] He made him to assert his relationship as a son [for yudoEaI, in my copies of the K, I read yadRaEiI↓, syn. with yaEotaziI,] to one who was not his father. (K.) [SM, who appears to have read AidRaEaAhu↓, says that it is like AisotaloHaqahu and AisotalaATahu.]

5 AltRadaERiI AltdEI AltdEy
5. AltRadaERiI [inf. n. of tadaERato] signifies The taToriyb [or singing, or quavering or trilling and prolonging of the voice, or prolonging and modulating of the voice,] of a woman wailing for the dead. (TA. [See daEaA AlmayRita, above.])

6 AltRadaAEiI AltdAEI AltdAEy tdAEy
6. AltRadaAEiI signifies The calling, summoning, or convoking, one another. (Mgh.) You say, tadaAEawo liloHarobi [They called, summoned, or convoked, one another for war: and hence,] (assumed tropical:) they prepared themselves for war. (TA.) And tadaAEawoA Ealayohi, (Msb, K,) or EalaI baniI fulaAnK, (T, M,) They collected themselves together, (K,) or called one another so that they assembled together, (M,) or leagued together, and called one another to mutual aid, (T, Msb, *) against him, (Msb, K,) or against the sons of such a one. (T, M.) And
tadaAEaI Ealayohi AlEaduwRu mino kulRi jaAnibK (assumed tropical:) The enemy advanced against him from every side. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tadaAEati AlsRaHaAbapu biAlbaroqi waAlrRaEodi mino kulRi jaAnibK (assumed tropical:) The cloud lightened and thundered from every quarter. (TA.) And tadaAEaI AlbunoyaAnu, (Mgh, Msb,) or AlbinaMCu, (TA,) (tropical:) The building cracked in its sides, (Msb,) or became much broken, (TA,) and gave notice of falling to ruin: (Msb, TA:) or cracked in several places, without falling; and in like manner, tadaAEati AlHiyTaAnu, (Mgh,) the walls cracked in several places, without falling: (Mgh, K: *) and tadaAEati AlHiyTaAnu liloxaraAbi the walls fell to ruin by degrees; syn. tahaAdamat: (S:) [but Mtr says,] tadaAEato UilaI AlxaraAbi is a vulgar phrase; not [genuine] Arabic. (Mgh.) And tdAEI said of a sand-hill, (assumed tropical:) It, being put in notion, or shaken in its lower part, poured down. (Msb.) And [hence,] tadaAEato Uibilu baniI fulaAnK (tropical:) (tropical:) The camels of such a one became broken by emaciation. (TA.) ― -b3- tadaAEawo biAlOaloqaAbi They called one another by surnames, or nicknames. (Msb.) ― -b4- AltRadaAEiI also signifies (assumed tropical:) The trying one another with an enigma or enigmas; or contending, one with another, in proposing an enigma or enigmas; syn. AltRaHaAjiI. (TA in art. Hjw.) You say, bayonahumo OudoEiyRapN yatadaAEuwona bihaA (assumed tropical:) [Between them is an enigma with which they try one another; or by proposing which they contend, one with another]. (S, K. *) ― -b5- yatadaAEawona faSola AlxiTaAbi (assumed tropical:) They compete, one with another, [as though each one challenged the others,] in discoursing of the science of chasteness of speech, and eloquence. (Har p. 446.) ― -b6- See also 8, in two places. ＝ -A2- [It is also used transitively:] you say, tadaAEawuA Alqawoma They [together] called the people. (Mgh in art. nqD. [See 6 in that art.])

7 AndEI AndEI AndEy
7. AndEI i. q. OajaAba. (K.) Akh heard one or more of the Arabs say, lawodaEawonaA laQnodaEayonaA, meaning laOajubonaA [i. e. Had they called us, &c., we had certainly answered, or replied, or assented, or consented]. (S.)

8 AidRaEaI OdEI OdEy AdEI AdEy dEA QdEI
8. AidRaEaI He asserted a thing to be his, or to belong to him, or to be due to him, either truly or falsely: (K, * TA:) he claimed a thing; laid claim to it; or demanded it for himself: and he desired a thing; or wished for it. (Msb.) And AidRaEawuA AlXRaIoCa and AlXIC tadaAEawuA↓ signify the same [i. e. They claimed the thing, every one of them for himself]. (Mgh.) You say, AidRaEayotu EalaI fulaAnK kacaA [I asserted myself to have a claim upon such a one for such a thing; preferred a claim against such a one for such a thing; or claimed of such a one such a thing]. (S.) And AidRaEaI zayodN EalaI Eamorw maAlFA [Zeyd asserted himself to have a claim upon 'Amr for property; or preferred a claim against 'Amr &c.]. (Mgh.) And AidRaEayota EalaIRa maA lamo OafoEalo [Thou hast asserted against me, or charged against me, or accused me of, that which I have not done]. (S and K in art. Xrb, and S in art. Akl.) hecaA QlRaciI kunotumo bihi tadRaEuwna, in the Kur [lxvii. 27], means This is that on account of which ye used to assert vain and false things: or which ye used to deny, or disbelieve: or, accord. to Fr, the latter verb may here be used in the sense of tadoEuwna; and the meaning may be, this is that which ye desired to hasten, and for which ye prayed to God in the words of the Kur [viii. 32], “ O God, if this be the truth from Thee, then rain Thou upon us stones from Heaven, or bring upon us some [other] painful punishment: ” it may be from AldRuEaMCu: and it may be from AldRaEowaI: (TA:) [i. e.] it means this is that which ye used to demand, and desire to hasten; from AldRuEaMCu: or that which ye used to assert, [namely,] that there will be no raising to life; from AldRaEowaI. (Bd.) And walahumo maA yadRaEuwna, in the Kur [xxxvi. 57], is explained as meaning And they shall have what they desire, or wish for; which is referrible to the meaning of AldRuEaMCu. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, AidRaEaI gayora Oabiyhi [He asserted the relationship of father to him of one who was not his father; or claimed as his father one who was not his father]. (T, Mgh, Msb.) And yadRaEiI UilaI gayori Oabiyhi [He asserts his relationship as a son, or claims the relationship of a son, to one who is not his father]. (T, Msb. See 4, in three places.) And yadRaEiyhi gayoru Oabiyhi [One who is not his father asserts him to be his son; or claims him as his son]. (T, Msb.) AlAidRiEaMCu in war signifies The asserting one's relationship; syn. AlAiEotizaMCu; (S, TA;) as also AltRadaAEiI↓; (TA;) i. e. the saying “ I am such a one the son of such a one. ” (S.) And [hence] sometimes it includes the meaning of Informing, or telling; and therefore bi may be prefixed to its objective complement; so that one says, fulaAnN yadRaEiI bikarami fiEaAlihi, i. e. Such a one informs of the generosity of his deeds. (Msb.)

10 UisotadoEawa
10: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence, AstdEI signifies also It called for, demanded, required, or invited, a thing. See also daEaAbihi.]

daEowapN dE dEA dEwh dEwp wdE
daEowapN [as an inf. n. of un.] signifies A single time or act (S, Msb) [of prayer and of imprecation, as is indicated in the S, and also, though less plainly, in the TA]. See duEaMCN. ― -b2- [Also, as such, A call.] You say, huwaminRiI daEowapu AlrRajula (K, TA) and Alkalobi, and daEowapa AlrRajuli and Alkalobi, in the former case dEwp being used as a simple subst., and in the latter case as an adv. n., (TA,) meaning qadoru maA bayoniI wabayonahu caAka [i. e. He, or it, is distant from me the space of the call of the man and of the dog]. (K, TA.) And lahumu AldRaEowapu EalaI gayorihimo The call is to them before the others of them: (K, TA: [yabodaOu in the CK is a mistake for yubodaOu:]) accord. to the T and the Nh, in the case of gifts, or pay, or salary. (TA.) ― -b3- The call to prayer: whence, in a trad., AldRaEuwapu fiI AlHabaXapi [meaning The office of calling to prayer rests among the Abyssinians]; (JM, TA;) said by the Prophet in preference of his muWacRin Bilál. (JM.) ― -b4- A call, or an invitation, to El-Islám. (Mgh.) You say, OadoEuwka bidaEowapi AlUisolaAmi and AlslAm diEaAyapi↓ and AlAslAm daAEiyapi↓, meaning I call thee, or invite thee, by the declaration of the faith whereby the people of false religions are called: daAEiyapN being an inf. n. syn. with daEowapN, like EaAfiyapN and EaAqibapN: (JM:) daEowapu AlUisolaAmi and daEAyatuhu↓ and daAEiyatuhu↓ signify the same: and daEowapu AlHaqRi [in like manner] means the declaration that there is no deity but God. (TA.) ― -b5- An invitation to food, (S, M, Msb, K, TA,) and to beverage; or, accord. to Lh, specially a repast, feast, or banquet, on the occasion of a wedding or the like: (TA:) thus pronounced by most of the Arabs, except 'Adee of Er-Rabáb, who pronounce it, in this sense, diEowapN↓: (A 'Obeyd, S, M, Msb:) it is an inf. n. in this sense, (S,) or a simple subst.: (Msb:) and duEowapN↓ signifies the same; (K;) or, as some say, this, which is given as on the authority of Ktr, is a mistake: (TA:) and so does madoEaApN↓ [app. an inf. n.]. (S, Msb, K.) You say, kunRaAfiI daEowapi fulaAnK and madoEaAtihi↓, meaning [We were included in] the invitation (duEaMC [see 1]) of such a one to food: (S, Msb: [but in the latter, naHonu, in the place of kunRaA:]) [or we were at the repast, or feast, or banquet, of such a one; for] you say [also] daEaAhu UilaI AldRaEowapi and AlI AlmadoEaApi↓ [He invited him to the repast, or feast, or banquet: and in this sense daEowap is commonly used in the present day]. (MA.) ― -b6- See also diEowapN: ― -b7- and daEowaI. ― -b8- Also i. q. HalifN or HalofN (accord. to different copies of the K) [both in the sense of Confederation to aid or assist]: (K, TA:) [whence] one says, daEowapN fulaAnK fiI baniI fulaAnK [meaning The confederation of such a one is with the sons of such a one]. (TA.)

duEowapN dE dEA dEwh dEwp wdE
duEowapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

diEowapN dE dEA dEwh dEwp wdE
diEowapN respects relationship, (S, Msb,) like daEowaI↓ or daEowaI fiI AlnRasabi; (S;) meaning A claim in respect of relationship; (K;) [i. e.] one's claiming as his father a person who is not his father; (Az, Mgh, Msb;) [in other words,] one's claiming the relationship of a son to a person who is not his father: or one's being claimed as a son by a person who is not his father: (Az, Msb:) thus pronounced by most of the Arabs, except 'Adee of Er-Rabáb, who pronounce it, in this sense, daEowapN↓. (S, Msb.) See also daEowaI. ― -b2- Also Kindred, or relationship, and brotherhood: so in the saying, liI fiIAlqawomi diEowapN [I have in, or among, the people, or company of men, kindred, or relationship, and brotherhood]. (Ks, Msb.) ― -b3- See also daEowapN.

daEowaI dEwI dEwy
daEowaI: see duEaMCN, in five places. ― -b2- Also a subst. from 8; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, TA;) omitted in the K, though better known than the sun; (TA;) and so daEaAwapN↓ (M, Msb, K) and diEaAwapN↓ and diEowapN↓, (M, K,) accord. to the general pronunciation, (M, TA,) and daEowapN↓, (M, K,) accord. to the pronunciation of 'Adee of Er-Rabáb, (M, TA,) and daAEiyapN↓; (TA, there said to be syn. with daEowaI;) [meaning An assertion that a thing belongs to one, or is due to one; a claim; as is indicated in the S and Mgh and K &c.;] a demand; a suit; (Yz, Az, Msb;) whether true
or false: (Mgh, K, TA:) the pl. of daEowaI is daEaAwK and daEaAwaI; the former of which is preferable accord. to some, being, as IJ says, the original form; but some say that the latter is preferable: (Msb:) [the latter only is mentioned in the Mgh:] the alif in the sing. [written I] is a sign of the fem. gender; and therefore the word is without tenween. (Mgh.) Yz mentions the sayings, liI fiI hecaA AlOamori daEowaI I have, in respect of this thing, [a claim or] a demand, and daEaAwaI or daEaAwK [claims or] demands, as written in different copies. (Az, Msb.) And lawo OuEoTiIa AlnRaAsu bidaEaAwiyhimo [If men were given according to their claims, or demands,] occurs in a trad. (Msb.) ― -b3- See also diEowapN.

duEowiIRN dEwI dEwy
duEowiIRN is a word used only in negative sentences: (S:) you say, maA biAldRaAri duEowiIRN There is not in the house any one: (S, K: *) Ks says that it is from daEawotu, and [properly] means layosa fiyhaA mano yadoEuw [there is not in it one who calls, &c.]. (S.)

duEaMCN dEMC
duEaMCN is an inf. n. of 1; (Msb, K;) as also daEowaI↓: (K:) the former is originally duEaAwN: (S:) [both, used as simple substs., signify A prayer, or supplication, to God:] and the pl. of the former is OadoEiyapN. (S.) IF says that some of the Arabs, for daEowapN↓, say daEowaI↓, with the fem. alif [written I]. (Msb, TA.) One says, AallRehumRa Almusolimiyna OaXorikonaA fiI daEowaI↓, meaning [O God, make us to share] in the prayer (duEaMC) of the Muslims. (TA.) And hence, in the Kur [x. 10], fiyhaA suboHaAnak QllRehumRa daEowaAhumo↓ [Their prayer in it shall be sbHAnk AllRehmR]. (TA.) [duEaMCN followed by li signifies An invocation of good, a blessing, or a benediction: followed by EalaI, an imprecation of evil, a curse, or a malediction.] suwrahu AldRuEaMCi is a title of The first chapter of the Kur-án. (Bd.) ― -b2- [Hence,] duEaMCN signifies also Adoration, worship, or religious service. (TA.) ― -b3- And i. q. UiymaAnN [i. e. Belief; particularly in God, and in his word and apostles &c.: faith: &c.]: a meaning mentioned by the Expositors of El-Bukháree. (TA.) ― -b4- [Also A call, or cry; and so daEowaI↓, as in the Kur vii. 4 (where the latter is explained by Bd as syn. with the former) and xxi. 15.] ― -b5- And [particularly] A calling, or crying, for aid or succour. (TA.)

daEiIRN dEA dEI dEy wdE
daEiIRN One invited to a repast: pl. duEawaMCu; as in the saying Einodahu duEawaMCu [With him, or at his abode, are guests invited to a repast]. (TA.) ― -b2- One who makes a claim in respect of relationship; (S;) [i. e.] one who claims as his father a person who is not his father; (Az, Mgh, Msb;) [in other words,] one who claims the relationship of a son to a person who is not his father: or one who is claimed as a son by a person who is not his father; (Az, Msb;) an adopted son: (S, K:) pl. OadoYiyaMCu, (S,) which is anomalous; (Bd in xxxiii. 4;) occurring in the Kur [in the verse just referred to], where it is said, wamaAjaEala OadoYiyaACakumo OabonaMCakumo (S) Nor hath He made your adopted sons to be your sons in reality. (Jel.) ― -b3- And One whose origin, or lineage, or parentage, is suspected; (K, TA;) as also madoEiIRN↓: pl. of the former as in the next preceding sentence. (TA.)

daEaAwapN dEAwh dEAwp
daEaAwapN and diEaAwapN: see daEowaI.

diEaAyapN dEAyh dEAyp
diEaAyapN: see daEowapN, in two places.

daERaMCN dEMC
daERaMCN One who prays, or supplicates God, or who calls, &c., much, or often. (TA.)

AldRaERaMCapu AldEMCh AldEMCp
AldRaERaMCapu [an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates;] The sabRaAbap [or fore finger]; (K;) i. e. the finger with which one calls [or beckons]. [TA.)

daAEK dAE dAEy
daAEK [Praying, or supplicating God:] calling, or summoning: (Mgh:) [inviting:] and particularly, [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] one who calls, or summons, or invites, to obey a right or a wrong religion: (TA:) pl. duEaApN (Mgh, Msb, TA) and daAEuwna. (Msb, TA.) [Hence,] daAEiI QllRehi [God's summoner, or inviter; i. e.] the prophet: (K:) and also, (Msb, K,) or simply AldRaAEiI, (TA,) The muWacRin [or summoner to prayer]. (Msb, K, TA.) [Hence also, daAEiI AlmanaAyaA The summoner of death, lit. of deaths; like TaAriqu AlmanaAyaA] ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places. ― -b3- Also A punisher. (TA.)

daAEiyapN dAEy dAEyh dAEyp
daAEiyapN: see daEowapN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also daEowaI. ― -b3- daAEiyRapN AllRabani The remainder of the milk, (K,) or what is left, of the milk, in the udder, (S, Mgh,) that draws, or attracts, (K,) or in order that it may draw, or attract, (S, Mgh,) what is to come after it; (S, Mgh, K; *) as also AllRabani daAEiI↓, occurring in a trad., where it is said, daEo daAEiIa AllRabani [Leave thou the remainder of the milk, in the udder, that is to draw, or attract, what is to come after it]; (S, Mgh;) i. e. do not exhaust it entirely. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Hence, daAEiyapN is metaphorically applied to signify (tropical:) A mean, or means; a cause; or a motive; (Har p. 306;) [as also daAEK↓, often used in these senses in the present day;] and so, in an intensive sense, madoEaApN↓ [properly signifying a cause of drawing, attracting, or inducing, &c., originally madoEawapN, being a noun of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN]: (Idem p. 86:) [the pl. of the first is dawaAEK.] ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) The cry of horsemen in battle; (K;) as being a call to him who will aid, or succour. (TA.) ― -b6- dawaAEiI AlSRadori (assumed tropical:) The anxiety [or rather anxieties] of the bosom. (Ham p. 509.) ― -b7- dawaAEiI AldRahori (tropical:) The vicissitudes of fortune: (K, TA:) sing. daAEiyapN. (TA.)

OudoEuwRapN c
OudoEuwRapN: see what next follows.

OudoEiyRapN c
OudoEiyRapN (S, K) and OudoEuwRapN↓ (K) An enigma; a riddle; (S, K; *) like OuHojiyRapN [and OuHojuwRapN]; and including such as is in verse, like that quoted above, in the second paragraph of this article. (S.)

madoEaApN mdEAh mdEAp
madoEaApN: see daEowapN, latter part, in three places: ― -b2- and see also daAEiyapN: [pl. madaAEK. ― -b3- Hence the saying,] lahu masaAEK wamadaAEK, i. e. (tropical:) [He possesses means of attaining honour and elevation, and] causes of glorying, or memorable and generous qualities, especially in war. (TA.)

madoEuwRN mdEw mdEy
[madoEuwRN pass. part. n. of 1; as also madoEiIRN↓.]

madoEiIRN mdEI mdEy mdEyy
madoEiIRN: see what next precedes: ― -b2- and see also daEiIRN, last sentence.

mudRaEFI mdEI mdEy mdEyy
mudRaEFI Claimed property [&c.]: mudRaEFI bihi is nought. (Mgh.) ― -b2- mudRaEFI Ealayohi One upon whom a claim is made for property [&c.]. (Mgh.) [A defendant in a law-suit.]

mudRaEK mdE mdEy
mudRaEK Claiming property [&c.]; a claimant. (Mgh.) [A plaintiff in a law-suit.]

1 daEayotu dEA dEyt

Perseus transcribers were unclear about the final character of line 1 and the initial character of line 2. means And as though she were shrinking from the quarter of her off side, bi being here used in the sense of Eano, from a creature that cries for food at supper-time; meaning a cat, of ugly form and big head, fearing to be scratched by it: as J says, [in art. wHX,] she shrinks with her off side because the rider's whip is in his right hand: (EM p. 233:) [or the meaning is, as though she were shrinking with the outside of her off side; lit, with the side of her off side; for, accord. to ISd,] this is an instance of the prefixing of a noun to another identical therewith [in signification]. dafaYiIRN, (T, S, M, K,) also termed davaYiIRN, (As, IAar, S, K,) but this latter is not of established authority, and is not mentioned in the M nor in the O., (TA in art. dvO,) The rain that falls after the heat has acquired strength; (M, K in art. dvO, TA;) when the earth has put (lit. vomited) forth the kamoOap [or truffles, which, accord. to Kzw, are found in Nejd (Central Arabia) at the period of the auroral setting of the Tenth Mansion of the Moon, (which happened, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, in that part, on the 11th of February O. S.,) when the sharpness of winter is broken, and the trees put forth their leaves: see also 1 in art. ntj]: (Lth, IAar, Th, M:) or the rain that is after [that called] the rabiyE[q.v.], before, (qabol, as in one copy of the S, in another qbl without any syll. signs,) or in the first part of, (qubul, as in the TA,) [that called] the Sayof[q. v., see also nawoCN], when the kamoOap disappear entirely from the earth: (S, O, TA:) AZ says that the beginning of the dafaYiIR is wuquwEu Aljabohapi and the end is AlSRrofapu [i. e. the period extends from the auroral setting of the Tenth Mansion of the Moon (about the 11th of February O. S. as explained above, when the sun in Arabia has begun to have much power,) to about the 9th of March O. S.: see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl; and see also another statement voce nawoCN]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And the term dafaYiyRapN↓ [used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, for miyrapN dafaYiyRapN,] is applied to The miyrap [or provision of corn &c.], (AZ, T, S, M, K,) whatever it be, that is brought (AZ, T, S) before, (qbl, written without any syll. signs in a copy of the S, and qbla in the CK,) or in the first part of, (qubul, as in the M and TA and in a copy of the S and in one of the K, [and this appears to be the right reading,] in a copy of the T qibl,) the Sayof [here meaning spring]: (AZ, T, S, M, K:) this is the third myrp; [see this word for an explanation of the statement here given;] the first being that called the riboEiyRap[q. v.]; and the second, that called the SayofiyRap[q. v.]: then comes the dfYyRp; and then, the ramaDiyRap, which comes when the earth becomes burnt [by the sun]. (M.) ― -b3- And in like manner also, (AZ, S,) i. e., by the term dafaYiIRN is also meant, (M,) The nitaAj [or offspring] (AZ, S, M) of sheep or goats [brought forth at that period, as is implied in the S, or] in the end of winter: or, as some say, at any time. (M.)

daforN (T, S, M, A, Msb, K) and dafarN↓, (IAar, M, A, K,) the former a simple subst., and the latter an inf. n., (Msb,) or both inf. ns., (A,) and daforapN↓, (Msb,) Stink; stench: (IAar, T, S, M, A, Msb, K:) never used to signify a sweet smell: (M:) accord. to Aboo- ” Alee El-Kálee, dafarN↓ has the above-mentioned signification; but daforN signifies pungency of odour, whether stinking or sweet: other authorities, however, assert, accord. to what is transmitted from them, that the word signifying intense pungency of odour, whether sweet or bad, is cafarN, with c, and with two fet-hahs, whence misokN Oacofaru: I Aar says that cafarN↓ signifies stink, or stench; and caforN, baseness, or vileness; but this is not known on any other authority. (T, S.) ― -b4- Hence, too, AldRaforu, (TA,) and OumRu daforK, (S, K,) (assumed tropical:) Calamity, or misfortune. (S, K, TA.) ― -b5- And OumRu daforK, (T, S, A, K,) written by Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee OumRu dafarK↓, but this is wrong, (R,) and OumRu daforapa↓, (IAar,) and dafaAri↓, and OumRu dafaAri, (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) The present world; (T, S, M, A, K;) because of its calamities, or misfortunes. 1. dafaEahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
dafaEa
, (K,) inf. n. dafoEN (Msb, K) and dafaAEN (TA) and madofaEN, (K,) [He impelled it, pushed it, thrust it, or drove it; and particularly, so as to remove it from its place; he propelled it; he repelled, or repulsed, it; he pushed it, thrust it, or drove it, away, or back;] he put it away, or removed it from its place, (Msb, TA,) by, or with, force, or strength: (TA:) or dafoEN signifies the putting away or removing or turning back a thing before the coming or arriving [of that thing]; like as rafoEN signifies the “ putting away or removing or turning back ” a thing “ after the coming or arriving ” thereof. (Kull p. 185.) Hence the saying in the Kur [ii. 252, and xxii. 41], walawo laA dafoEu QllRehi AlnRaAsa [And were it not for God's repelling men]; where some read difaAEu↓ [which means the same, as will be seen in the course of what follows, though bearing also another interpretation, likewise to be seen in what follows]. (TA.) You say, dafaEotu AlrRajula [I impelled, pushed, &c., the man]. (S.) And dAfEhu↓, inf. n. difaAEN [and mudaAfaEapN]; and dfREhu↓; (TA;) [both, app., accord. to the TA, signifying the same; but the latter more properly relates to several objects together, or signifies he impelled it, pushed it, &c., much, or vehemently, or often; whereas] mudaAfaEapN (K, TA) and difaAEN (TA) are [often exactly] syn. with dafoEN. (K, TA.) Thus, (TA,) you say, as meaning the same, Eanohu dAfE↓ and dafaEa [He repelled from him; whence another explanation of these two phrases, which see in what follows]. (S, TA.) And hence, dafaEa QllRehu Eanoka Almakoruwha, inf. n. dafoEN, (tropical:) [May God repel, or avert, from thee what is disliked, or hated, or evil]: (TA:) and QllRehu Eanoka AlsRuwoCa daAfaEa↓, inf. n. difaAEN, (tropical:) [May God repel, or avert, from thee evil]. (S, TA.) And dafaEotu Eanohu AlOacaI (tropical:) [I repelled, or averted, from him what was hurtful, or annoying; as also daAfaEotu↓]. (Msb, K, TA.) Sb mentions, as a saying of the Arabs, AidofaEi AlXRarRa walawo UiSobaEFA (tropical:) [Repel thou, or avert thou, evil, or mischief, though but with a finger: the last word being in the accus. case by reason of the subaudition of the prep. b; the meaning being biUiSobaEK]. (TA.) [See also an ex. voce dafuwEN.] When dafoEN is made trans. by means of Eano, [and has a single objective complement, a second objective complement is understood, and in general] it has the meaning or the act of (assumed tropical:) Defending; as in the Kur [xxii. 39], UinRa QllReha yadofaEu Eano QlRaciyna MmanuwA (assumed tropical:) [Verily God defendeth those who have believed; i. e. repelleth from them aggression and the like]; (B;) and yudaAfiEu↓, in the same, (K, TA,) accord. to another reading, signifies the same; (K, TA;) or this latter signifies (assumed tropical:) defendeth energetically, with the energy of him who contendeth for superiority in so doing. (Bd.) And Eanohu daAfaEotu↓ signifies [also] (assumed tropical:) I pleaded, or contended in arguments, in defence of him. (Msb.) [Exceptions to the statement cited above form the B will be found in what follows in this paragraph; and another exception, voce mudafRaEN.] ― -b2- [In the exs. which follow, the verb is used in senses little differing, essentially, from those assigned to it in the first sentence of this art.] ― -b3- dafaEotu mina AlUinaMCi dafoaEapF [I poured forth from the vessel a single pouring]: the last word, which is with fet-h, is an inf. n. [of un.]. (Msb.) ― -b4- dafaEati AllRibaOafiI DaroEihaA qubayola AlnRitaAji (tropical:) [She (a ewe, or goat, S, or a camel, S, K) infused the first milk into her udder, i. e. secreted it therein, a little before bringing forth]. (S, K.) And dafaEati AllRabani EalaI raOosi waladihaA likavoratihi (tropical:) [She (a ewe or goat, or a camel, TA) secreted the milk in her udder when about to produce her young, by reason of its abundance]; for the milk becomes abundant in her udder only when she is about to bring forth: the inf. n. [app. the inf. n. of un.] is dafoEapN. (TA.) And dafaEato alone, said of a ewe or goat, signifies (assumed tropical:) She secreted milk in her udder when about to produce the young; expl. by OaDoraEato EalaI raOosi Alwaladi [which see in art. DrE]. (S, TA.) Accord. to En-Nadr, one says dafaEato bilabinihaA, and biAllRabani, when her young is in her belly; but when she has brought forth, one does not say dafaEato. (TA.) ― -b5- In the saying, gaXiyitonaA saHaAbapN fadafaEonaAhaA UilaI gayorinaA [lit. A cloud overspread us, and we drove it away to other persons], meaning (tropical:) it departed from us to other persons, dfEnAhA is for dafaEatonaA, which means dufiEato EanRaA [lit. it was driven away from us]. (TA.) ― -b6- dafaEahu biHujRapK (assumed tropical:) [He refelled him, or refuted him, by an argument or the like]. (MF in art. kfH.) ― -b7- dafaEotu Alqawola (assumed tropical:) I rebutted the saying; repelled it by an argument, an allegation, or a proof. (Msb.) ― -b8- AidofaEo hecaA (tropical:) Leave thou this, sparing him. (As, TA.) [See mudafRaEN.] ― -b9- [In several exs. here following, the verb resembles AndfE; nafosahu, or the like, being understood after it.] ― -b10- dafaEa AlmaMCu [The water poured out, or forth, as though it impelled, or propelled, itself]: (TA: [where it is followed by waQnoSabRa, as an explicative adjunct:]) and so AlsRayolu [the
torrent]. (ISh.) [See also 6.] And dafaEa AlwaAdiI biAlmaMCi [The valley poured with water]. (TA in art. HXk.) ― -b11- dafaEa fiI Eadowihi (assumed tropical:) [He pushed, or pressed, on, or forward, as though he impelled himself, in his running]. (S in art. gwr; &c.) [See also 7.] ― -b12- dafaEa Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The people, or company of men, came at once. (Msb.) ― -b13- dafaEa UilaI AlmakaAni, (TA,) and dufiEa Uilayohi, (Msb, TA,) in the pass. form, (Msb,) (tropical:) He reached, or came to, the place. (Msb, TA.) You say also, hecaA TariyqN yadofaEu UilaI makaAni kacaA (tropical:) This is a road which reaches to such a place. (TA.) ― -b14- dafaEa mino EarafaAtK (assumed tropical:) He commenced the journey from 'Arafát, and impelled and removed himself thence, or impelled his she-camel, and urged her to go. (TA, from a trad.) And dafaEotu Eani AlmawoDiEi (assumed tropical:) I removed, went, went away, or journeyed, from the place. (Msb.) [See again 7.] ― -b15- dafaEa also signifies (assumed tropical:) He returned. (MF.) ― -b16- When dafoEN is made trans. by means of UilaI, it [generally, but not always, as has been shown above,] has the meaning of the act of Giving, or delivering; as in the Kur [iv. 5], faQdofaEuwA Uilayohimo OamowaAlahumo [Then give ye, or deliver ye, to them their property]. (B.) You say, dafaEotu UilaII fulaAnK XayoYFA [I gave, or delivered, to such a one a thing]. (S, K. *) And dafaEotu AlwadiyEapa UilaI SaAHibihaA I restored the deposit to its owner. (Msb.) And dafaEotu lahu qiToEapF mina AlmaAli [I gave him a part, or portion, of the property]. (S in art. zEb; and the like is said in that art. in the K.) And dafaEahu [alone] He gave it; syn. OaEoTaAhu. (Er-Rághib, MF.)

2 dafRaEa
2: see 1; fourth sentence. ― -b2- dfREhu UilaI kacaA (tropical:) He drove him, compelled him, or necessitated him, to do, or to have recourse to, such a thing. (TA.) ― -b3- dfREhu also signifies He rendered him abject and contemptible, or poor; as though deserving to be repelled. (Ibn-Maaroof, as cited by Golius.) [See the pass. part. n., below.] ― -b4- dfRE qawosahu (assumed tropical:) He made his bow even. (AHn, TA.)

3 mudaAfaEapN mdAfE mdAfEh mdAfEp mdfE
3. mudaAfaEapN [in its primary acceptation] signifies The contending, or striving, with another, to push him, or repel him; or the pushing, or repelling, another, being pushed, or repelled, by him; or the pushing against another; syn. muzaAHamapN. (TA.) [Hence, yudaAfiEu AlOaxobavayoni He is striving to suppress the urine and ordure: see Oaxobavu. And mudaAfaEapu AlEayoXi The striving to retain life: see 2 in art. zlj. ― -b2- But it is often used in the same sense as dafoEN:] see the verb and its two inf. ns. in seven places in the former half of the first paragraph of this article. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) i. q. mumaATalapN: (S, K, TA:) in some of the copies of the S, muTaAwalapN. (TA.) You say, daAfaEotuhu biHaqRihi, (Jm, TA,) or Eano HaqRihi, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) I deferred with him, delayed with him, or put him off, in the matter of his right, or due, by promising time after time to render it to him; [and so repelled him, or strove to repel him, from it;] syn. maATalotuhu. (Jm, Msb, TA.) And dAfE biHaAjatihi (assumed tropical:) He deferred, delayed, postponed, or put off, his (another's) needful affair. (L in art. rvd.) ― -b4- dAfE AlrRajulu Oamora kacaA (assumed tropical:) The man attached, or devoted, himself to such an affair, and exerted himself, and persisted, or persevered, in it. (TA.)

5 tadafRaEa
5: see 6, and 7.

6 tdAfEwA dAfE tdAfE tdAfEwA
6. tdAfEwA [They contended, or strove, together, to push, or repel, one another; or] they pushed, or repelled, one another; or pushed against one another. (Msb.) You say, tdAfEwA fiI AlHarobi They pushed, thrust, or repelled, one another in war, or battle. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tdAfE AlkalaAmaAni (assumed tropical:) The two sayings, or sentences, opposed, or contradicted, each other; conflicted; were mutually repugnant. (Msb in art. nqD.) ― -b3- tdAfE AlsRayolu (tropical:) The torrent was impelled, driven, or propelled, in its several parts, or portions, by the impetus of one part, or portion, acting upon another; and in like manner, [or as signifying it became impelled, driven, or propelled,] AndfE↓, and [in an intensive sense] tdfRE↓. (TA.) [See also dafaEa. AlsRayolu.] ― -b4- tdAfE jaroIu Alfarasi [in like manner signifies (assumed tropical:) The running of the horse continued by successive impulses, his force of motion in each part of his course impelling him through the next]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 7. ＝ -A2- [It is also trans.] You say, tdAfEwA AlXRaIoCa They repelled the thing, every one of them from himself. (TA.) And DayofN yatadAfaEuhu AlHaIRu [A guest whom the tribe repel, or repulse, every one of them from himself]. (IDrd, K.)

7 AndfE OndfE AndfE QndfE
7. AndfE is quasi-pass. of dafaEahu; (S, K, TA;) and tdfRE↓ is quasi-pass. of dfREhu; and tdAfE↓ is quasi-pass. of dAfEhu: but all three are used in the same sense: see 6: (TA:) [the first, however, primarily signifies He, or it, became impelled, pushed, thrust, or driven; and particularly, so as to be removed from his, or its, place; became propelled; became repelled; became impelled, pushed, thrust, or driven, away, or back, or onwards; became put away, or removed from its place; as is implied in the S and K and TA: whereas the second, properly, has an intensive signification: and the third properly denotes the acting of two or more persons or things, or of several parts or portions of a thing, against, or upon, one another; as is shown by exs. and explanations above: though the second and third are often used in the primary sense of the first.] ― -b2- [Hence,] AndfE also signifies (assumed tropical:) He went away into the country, or land, in any manner: (Lth:) or, said of a horse [&c.], (tropical:) he [or it] went quickly or swiftly (S, K, TA) [as though impelled or propelled; pressed, or pushed, on, or forward; rushed; launched, or broke, forth; it poured forth with vehemence, as though impelled: see 1, which has a similar meaning, particularly in the phrases dafaEa AlmaMCu, and AlsRayolu, and dafaEa fiI Eadowihi, &c.]. ― -b3- AndfE fiI, AlHadiyvi, (S, K, TA,) and fiI AlUinoXaAdi, (TA,) (tropical:) He pushed on, or pressed on, in discourse, and in reciting poetry; or entered thereinto; or launched forth, or out, thereinto; or was large, or copious, or profuse, therein; or dilated therein; or began it, commenced it, or entered upon it; syn. OafaADa fiyhi. (K, TA.) And AndfE fiI AlDRaHiki [He broke forth into laughing]. (JK in art. bwq.) ― -b4- [AndfE fiI AlTRaEaAmi (assumed tropical:) He fell to eating of the food; or applied himself eagerly to it.] ― -b5- AndfE fiIAlOamori (tropical:) He acted with penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in the affair; syn. maDaI fiyhi. (A, TA.)

10 AisotadofaEotu QllReha AlOasowaMCa c
10. AisotadofaEotu QllReha AlOasowaMCa (tropical:) I asked, or begged, God to repel from me evils. (S, K.)

dafoEN dfE
dafoEN [see 1. Used as a simple subst., it signifies Impulsion; or the act of pushing, thrusting, or driving; and particularly, so as to remove a thing from its place; propulsion; repulsion; &c.].

dafoEapN dfE dfEh dfEp
dafoEapN A single impulsion; a push, a thrust, or single act of driving; and particularly, so as to remove a thing from its place; a single propulsion; a single repulsion: (S, * Msb, K, * TA:) [it is an inf. n. of un. of 1 in all its senses; and thus,] it signifies also a single act of pouring: [&c.:] pl. dafaEaAtN. (Msb.) You say, dafaEahu dafoEapF, i. e. [He impelled, &c., him, or it,] once [or with a single impulsion, &c.]. (TK.) And dafaEotu mina AlUinaMCi dafoEapF, i. e. [I poured forth from the vessel] a single pouring. (Msb.) ― -b2- [As an inf. n. of un. of 1,] it also signifies (assumed tropical:) A coming of the collective body of a people, or party of men, to a place at once. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also (assumed tropical:) A heat, a single course, or one unintermitted act, of running, or the like.]

dufoEapN dfE dfEh dfEp
dufoEapN A quantity that pours forth, or out, at once, from a skin, or vessel: (Lth, K:) a quantity poured forth, or out, at once, (Msb,) [or with vehemence, being] syn. with dufoqapN. (IF, S, Msb, K, [in the CK with E in the place of the q,]) of rain, [i. e. a shower, fall, or storm, as meaning the quantity that falls without intermission,] (IF, S, Msb, K,) and [a gush] of blood, (IF, Msb,) &c.: (IF, S, Msb:) it is also [used as signifying the tide] of a valley, (K in art. THm,) and [the tide, or rush,] of a torrent, (S and K in that art.,) and [the rush, or irruption,] of a troop of horses or horsemen, (S and K in art. dlq, &c.,) and [the irruption, or invasion,] of night: (S and K in art. THm:) pl. dufaEN (Msb, K) and dufaEaAtN and dufuEaAtN and dufoEaAtN. (Msb.) You say, baqiIafiI AlUinaMCi dufoEapN There remained in the vessel as much as one pours out at once. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A part, or portion, that is given, of property. (S in art. zEb.)

difaAEu dfAE
difaAEu, determinate, as a proper name, The ewe: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) so called because she pushes her thigh this way and that by reason of bulkiness. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

dafuwEN dfwE
dafuwEN and midofaEN↓ [That impels, pushes, thrusts, drives, propels, or repels, much, or vehemently:] both signify the same. (S, K.) Hence the saying of a woman, (S,) an immodest woman, (O,) namely, Sejáhi [the false prophetess, to her husband the false prophet Museylimeh, describing the kind of cakar which she most approved], (L,) laA balo qaSiyrN midofaEN↓. (S, O, L.) You say also, rajulN dafRaAEN↓ A man who impels, propels, repels, or defends, vehemently. (TA.) And naAqapN dafuwEN A she-camel that hicks (tadofaEu) with her hind leg on being milked. (TA.)

dafRaAEN dfAE
dafRaAEN: see dafuwEN. ― -b2- Also One who, when a
bone happens to be in the part that is next to him, of a bowl, puts it away, or aside, in order that a piece of flesh-meat may become in its place. (El-Jáhidh, K.)

dufRaAEN dfAE
dufRaAEN The main portion, that pours down at once, or vehemently, of waves, and of a torrent, (K, TA,) and of a sea: (TA:) or a great torrent: (S:) or abundance and vehemence of water: (L:) or a great quantity of water of a torrent: and a great number of people. (AA.) You say, jaMCa dufRaAEN mina AlrRijaAli waAlnRisaMCi There came a great number of men and women crowding one upon another. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A great thing by which a similar great thing is impelled, propelled, or repelled. (K, * TA.)

daAfiEN dAfE
daAfiEN [act. part. n. of 1]. It is said in the Kur [lii. 8], maA lahu mino daAfiEK There shall not be any repeller thereof. (Bd.) And in the same [lxx. 2], layosa lahu daAfiEN There shall not be for it any repeller: (Bd:) or any defender. (B.) ― -b2- Applied to a ewe or she-goat, (S,) or to a she-camel, (S, K,) as also daAfiEapN and midofaAEN↓, (K,) (tropical:) That infuses (tadofaEu) the first milk into her udder [i. e. secretes it therein] a little before bringing forth; (S, K;) that infuses the milk into her udder when about to produce her young, by reason of its abundance: AO says that some make mufokihN and daAfiEN to signify the same, [i. e., to signify as explained above, or nearly so,] saying, hiIa daAfiEN biwaladK; and if you will, you say, hiIa daAfiEN, alone. (TA.)

daAfiEapN dAfE dAfEh dAfEp
daAfiEapN [fem. of daAfiEN, q. v.: and, used as a subst.,] The lower, or lowest, part of any [water-course such as is called] mayovaMC: pl. dawaAfiEu: this latter signifying the lower, or lowest, parts of the miyv, [pl. of myvAC,] (ISh, K,) where they pour into the valleys, (ISh,) or where the valleys pour thereinto: (K:) or the pl. signifies the parts in which the water pours to the myv; while the myv pour into the main valley: (As:) or the dAfEp is a [water-course such as is called] taloEap which pours into another tlEp, when it runs down a descending ground, or declivity, from elevated, or rugged and elevated, ground, and you see it going to and fro in places, having spread somewhat, and become round; then it pours into another, lower than it: every one such is thus called; and the pl. is as above. (Lth.)

madofaEN mdfE
madofaEN [A channel of water;] one of the madaAfiE of waters, in which the waters run: (S, K:) [madaAfiEu being its pl.:] the lower, or lowest, part of a valley, where the torrent pours forth, and its water disperses: (ISh:) and the [water-course, or channel, such as is called] miconab of a daAfiEap [q. v.]; because this latter pours forth therein to another dAfEp; (K, TA;) the mcnb being the channel between the daAfiEataAni. (TA.)

midofaEN mdfE
midofaEN: see dafuwEN, in two places. ― -b2- [Its primary signification is An instrument for impelling, propelling, or repelling: and hence it is applied in modern Arabic to a cannon: and to an instrument used by midwives for protruding the fœtus. ― -b3- Hence, also, it is used as an intensive epithet: and hence,] rukonN midofaEN A strong corner. (TA.)

mudafRaEN mdfE
mudafRaEN, applied to a camel, (tropical:) Held in high estimation by his owner; (A, K, * TA;) so that when he comes near to the load, he is sent back: (A, TA:) one that is reserved for covering, and not ridden nor laden; of which, when he is brought to be laden, one says, AidofaEo hecaA, i. e. Leave thou this, sparing him. (As.) ― -b2- Also, (applied to a camel, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Held in mean estimation by his owner; (K, * TA;) so that when he comes near to the load, he is sent back as despised. (TA.) Thus it bears two contr. meanings. (K.) ― -b3- Applied to a man, (A, TA,) (tropical:) Poor, (S, A, TA,) and abject, (S,) whom every one repels from himself, (A, TA,) or because every one repels him from himself; (S;) used conjointly with mudaqRaEN; i. e., you say, fulaAnN mudafRaEN mudaqRaEN: (A, TA:) a man (assumed tropical:) despised, or held in contempt, (Lth, K,) as also mutadaAfaEN↓; (Lth;) who does not show hospitality if he make one his guest, nor give if he be asked to give: (Lth:) and one (assumed tropical:) who is repelled, or repulsed, from his relations (AlRaciI dufiEa Eano nasabihi: [nasabihi being used for cawiI nasabihi, like as nasabFA is used in the Kur xxv. 56, for cawiI nasabK, as explained by Bd:]) (IDrd, K:) and a guest (assumed tropical:) whom the tribe repel, or repulse, every one of them from himself, every one turning him away to another. (IDrd, K.) ― -b4- OanaA mudafRaEN UilaI Oamori kacaA (tropical:) I am driven, compelled, or necessitated, to do, or to have recourse to, such a thing. (TA.)

midofaAEN mdfAE
midofaAEN: see daAfiEN.

huwa sayRidu qawomihi gayoru mudaAfaEK hw syd qwmh gyr mdAfE
huwa sayRidu qawomihi gayoru mudaAfaEK (assumed tropical:) He is the lord, or chief, of his people, or party, not straitened in his authority, nor thrust from it; (TA;) i. q. gayoru muzaAHamK. (K.)

AlmudaAfiEu AlmdAfE mdAfE mdfE
AlmudaAfiEu (assumed tropical:) The lion. (Sgh.)

mutadAfiEu mtdAfE
mutadAfiEu: see mudafRaEN.

qawolN mutadaAfiEN qwl mtdAfE
qawolN mutadaAfiEN (tropical:) [A saying of which one part opposes, or contradicts, another; a self-contradictory saying]. (TA.)

1 dafaqahu dfq dfqh dfqp
1. dafaqahu, aor.
dafuqa
(S, Msb, K, &c.) and
dafiqa
, (Jm, K,) inf. n. dafoqN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and by poetic license dafaqN, (TA,) He poured it forth, or out: (S, K:) or he poured it forth, or out, with vehemence: (Mgh, Msb:) namely, water [&c.]. (S, Mgh, Msb.) And dufiqa AlmaMCu The water poured out, or forth: one should not say dafaqa AlmaMCu: (S:) or this last, aor.
dafuqa
, inf. n. dafoqN, signifies the water poured forth, or out, with vehemence: but As disallowed its being used in an intrans. sense: (Msb:) [the forms of the verb commonly used intransitively are 7 and 5:] accord. to Lth, alone, (K,) i. e. in the 'Eyn, (TA,) dafaqa AlmMCu, (K, TA,) and AldRamoEu, aor.
dafuqa
, (TA,) inf. n. dafoqN and dufuwqN, signify the water, (K, TA,) and the tears, (TA,) poured forth, or out, at once: (K. TA:) but Az disallows this. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] dafaqa QllRehu ruwHahu (assumed tropical:) [God poured forth his spirit; i. e.] God caused him to die: (K:) or it means may he die. (S.) As says, I alighted at the abode of an Arab woman of the desert, and she said to a daughter of hers, Bring to him the drinking-bowl (AlEusR): and she brought me a drinking-bowl in which was milk, and spilled it; whereupon she said to her dafaqato muhojatuki [May thy blood, or heart's blood, be poured forth: or, as appears from a statement above, the right reading is probably dufiqato]. (TA. [See also muhojapN.]) ― -b3- One says also, of a river, or rivulet, and of a valley, dafaqa, [app. for dafaqa AlmaMCa,] meaning, It became full so that the water poured forth, or overflowed, or so that it poured forth the water, from its sides. (TA.) ― -b4- And dafaqa Alkuwza He poured forth, (JK,) or scattered, (K,) the contents of the mug at once; (JK, K;) as also Adfqhu↓. (K.) ― -b5- The verb is also used transitively and intransitively in relation to a beast: you say, dafaqotu AldRaAbRapa (assumed tropical:) I made the beast to hasten, or go quickly: ― -b6- and dafaqati AldRaAbRapu (assumed tropical:) The beast hastened, or went quickly: (Msb:) and [in like manner] one says of a quick camel, fiI miXoyihi yatadafRaqu↓ (assumed tropical:) [He hastens, speeds, or presses forward, in his pace, or going]: and AlOutunu tadafRaqati↓ The wild she-asses hastened, or went quickly. (TA.) ＝ -A2- dafiqa, [aor.
dafaqa
,] (TA,) inf. n. dafaqN, (JK, S, TA,) He (a camel) had his teeth standing outwards: (S, TA:) or had his elbows far apart from his sides. (JK. [See also rafiqa.])

2: [dfRqhu He poured it forth, or out, copiously, or abundantly; namely, water &c. See an ex. of the inf. n. used as a pass. part. n. voce daHiyqN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] dafRaqato kafRaAhu AlnRadaI, (S, K,) inf. n. tadofiyqN, (K,) His two hands poured forth largess (S, K) [copiously, or abundantly, for] it is with teshdeed to denote muchness. (S.)

4 Oadofaqa
4: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

5. tdfRq i. q. taSabRaba (S, K) [meaning (as the former is explained in the KL) It poured forth or out, or became poured forth or out, copiously, or abundantly; for it is quasi-pass. of dafRaqahu; though taSabRaba is said to be quasi-pass. of SabRahu like AinoSabRa, and though it is said in the TA that tdfRq is quasi-pass. of dafaqahu like Andfq]. ― -b2- See also 1, latter part, in two places. ― -b3- [Hence,] huwa yatadafRaqu fiI AlbaATili (tropical:) He hastens to do that which is false, vain, or unprofitable. (TA.) ― -b4- And tdfRq Hilomuhu (tropical:) His forbearance, or clemency, departed. (TA.)

7. Andfq i. q. AnSbR [It poured forth or out, or became poured forth or out: see also dafaqa, which, if allowable, is less usual]. (S, K.)

10 Astdfq Alkuwzu Astdfq Alkwz
10. Astdfq Alkuwzu The mug had its contents poured forth or out (AinoSabRa) at once. (TA.)

dafoqapN dfq dfqh dfqp
dafoqapN A single act of pouring forth or out [in
any manner, or at once, (see 1,) or] with vehemence: pl. dafaqaAtN. (Msb.)

dufoqapN A quantity poured forth or out (Msb) at once, like dufoEapN, (S and K in art. dfE, q. v.,) [or] with vehemence; (Msb;) of rain, [i. e. a shower, fall, or storm, as meaning the quantity that falls without intermission,] (S and Msb and K in art. dfE,) and [a gush] of blood, (Msb in that art.,) &c.: (S and Msb in that art.:) pl. dufaqN and dufaqaAtN and dufuqaAtN and dufoqaAtN. difolaI dflI dfly
difolaI, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) accord. to those who make the alif to be a sign of the fem. gender; and difolFI, accord. to those who make that letter to be one of quasi-coordination; used alike as a sing. and a pl.; (S;) and difolN↓; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) [the first of these appellations applied in the present day to The rose-bay, or laurel-bay; oleander, nerium oleander, rhododendron, or rhododaphne: and also to the common laurel:] a certain tree, (T, M,) or plant, (S, K,) bitter, (T, S, M, K,) very bitter, (TA,) and poisonous, (T,) green, and beautiful in appearance, the blossom of which is beautifully tinged, (M,) called in Persian xarozahoraho: (K:) there is a river-kind, and a land-kind: the leaves are like those of the HamoqaMC [or gardenpurslane], but more slender; and the branches, or twigs, are long, spreading over the ground; at the leaves are thorns; and it grows in waste places: the river-kind grows upon the banks of rivers; its thorns are unconspicuous, or unapparent; its leaves are like those of the xilaAf [or salix Aegyptia] and of the almond, broad; and the upper part of its stem is thicker than the lower part thereof: (TA:) it is very deadly: its blossom is like the red rose, (K,) very rough (xXn jdRA [but this I think is a mistranscription for HasanN jidRFA very beautiful], and upon it is a kind of tuft like hair: (TA:) its fruit is like the xuronuwb [q. v.]; (K;) having an aperient, or a deobstruent, property; and stuffed with a substance like wool: (TA:) it is good for the mange, or scab, and the itch (HikRap), used in the manner of a liniment, (K,) and especially the expressed juice of its leaves; (TA;) and for pain of the knee and the back, (K,) of long duration, (TA,) applied in the manner of a poultice, or plaster; and for expelling fleas and the [insect called] OaraD, by the sprinkling of a decoction thereof; and the rubbing over with the heart thereof twelve times, after cleansing, is good for removing the [malignant leprosy termed] baraS; (K;) and its leaves put upon hard tumours are very beneficial: but it is a poison: [yet] sometimes it is mixed with wine and rue, and given to be drunk, and saves from the poisons of venomous reptiles: the Ra-ees [Ibn-Seenà, or Avicenna,] says that it is perilous by itself, and its blossom, to men, and to horses and the like, and to dogs, but is beneficial when made into a decoction with rue, and drunk: (TA:) IAar says that the [trees termed] MC and OalaMC and Hbr [app. a mistranscription for xabor, a species of lote-tree,] are all called difolaI. (T.) AHn says that the zanod made from the difolaI is excellent for producing fire: and hence the prov., AiqodaHo bidifolaI fiI maroxi vumRa XudRa baEodu Oawo Oaroxi [Endeavour thou to produce fire with wood of the dflI upon wood of the mrx: then tighten afterwards or loosen]: (M:) said when one incites a bad man against another bad man: (M, Meyd:) or, accord. to IAar, said in relation to a man whom one needs not to press, or importune. (Meyd.)

, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. dafonN, (M, Msb, TA,) He buried it; interred it; i. e. hid it, concealed it, or covered it, (M, Msb, K, TA,) in the earth, or dust, (TA,) or beneath layers, or strata, of earth, or dust; (Msb;) namely, a thing; (S, Msb;) primarily having for its object a dead body: (M:) and

6. AltRadaAfunu signifies AlmawotaI mudaAfanapu↓ [i. e. The cooperating in the burying of the dead]. (TA.) laA yakaAdu AlnRaAsu yatadaAfanuwna [The people can hardly, or cannot nearly, bury one another] is said in the case of a quick and spreading death. (TA voce cariygN.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tadaAfanuwA (tropical:) They practised concealment, one with another; syn. takaAtamuwA. (S, K, TA.) It is said in a trad., lawo takaAXafotumo lamaA tadaAfanotumo (tropical:) [If ye revealed, one to another his faults, or his secrets, ye would not practise concealment, one with another, in any case]; meaning, if the fault, (Eayob, as in my copies of the S and in the TA in the present art.,) or secret or secrets, (gayob, as in one of my copies of the S in art. kXf,) of each one of you were open, or revealed, to each other of you: (S, TA:) or, accord. to IAth, [if ye revealed, one to another his secrets, ye would not bury one another; for he says that] the meaning is, if each one of you knew what is concealed in the mind of each other of you, the conducting of his funeral, and his burial, would be deemed onerous. (TA in art. kXf.)

OadofaI, applied to a man, (T, S, M, K,) Humpbacked: (T, S:) or who walks with an inclining on one side: or, as some say, i. q. OajonaOu [q. v.]: or having contracted shoulders: (M:) or bending, or curving. (K.) [See also OadofaOu.] Its fem., in all its senses, is dafowaMCu. (M.) ― -b2- Applied to a camel, Long in the neck, and protuberant in the back, whose head nearly touches his hump: (M:) and the fem., applied to a she-camel, (K,) or to an excellent she-camel, (Lth, T, S,) long in the neck; (Lth, T, S, K;) that, when she goes along, almost puts her head upon the back of her hump, and is long in the back. (T.) ― -b4- Applied to a bird, Long in the wing: (S:) or long in the wings and tail: (M:) or long in the wings, having the ends of the primary feathers even with the end of the tail. ('Eyn.) And the fem., applied to an eagle (EuqaAb), Crook-billed: (K:) or so applied because that bird is crook-billed. (S.) ― -b5- And the fem., applied to an ear [of a beast], Approaching the other ear so that the extremities of the two almost touch each other, bending down towards the forehead, not standing erect, but strong: as some say, applied to the ear of a horse only: or, as Th says, only meaning inclining. (M.) ― -b6- Also, the fem., accord. to A'Obeyd, Having wide bones. (M.) ― -b7- XajarapN dafowaMCu A great tree: (S:) or a great, shady tree; and it may be, inclining: (T:) or a shady tree, having many branches: (IAth, TA:) or, as some say, an inclining tree: (TA:) occurring in a trad., describing a certain tree that was worshipped. (T, S.)

UibilN mudofaApN Abl mdfAh Abl mdfAp
UibilN mudofaApN: see mudofaOapN, in art. dfO.

1 daqRa dq
1. daqRa, aor. yadiqRu, inf. n. difRapN, (S, Msb, K,) It (a thing, S) was, or became, daqiyq, which means the contr. of galiyZ; as also AstdqR↓: (S, K:) [i. e. it was, or became, thin as meaning slender, or small in diameter or circumference as compared with length: also small in all dimensions; small in size; minute, or fine, either as a whole, or in its component particles: and sometimes, as said of a garment or the like, thin, or fine, as opposed to thick or coarse; like raqRa:] contr. of galuZa: (Msb:) AstdqR↓ is said of the hilaAl [or moon a little after or before the change], and of other things. (TA.) [See also riqRapN.] ― -b2- And [hence], aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He, or it, was, or became, little in estimation, paltry, inconsiderable, mean, vile, or contemptible. (TA.) One says to him who refuses to confer a benefit, daqRa bika xuluquka (assumed tropical:) [Thy nature, or natural disposition, hath rendered thee mean, &c.; the verb being made trans. by bi, agreeably with a common usage mentioned in p. 141]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, said of a thing, an affair, or a case, [and of speech, or language,] (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, subtile, nice, abstruse, recondite, or obscure. (Msb.) And you say, daqRa fiI kalaAmihi (tropical:) [He was, or became, subtile, nice, abstruse, &c., in his speech, or language]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- daqRahu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
daquqa
, inf. n. daqRN, (M, Msb,) He broke it, (M, K, TA,) or crushed it, (M,) in any manner: (M, TA:) or he bruised, brayed, or pounded, it; i. e., he beat it with a thing so that he broke it, or crushed it: (M, K: *) namely, a thing, (S, M, TA,) such as medicine, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, He beat it; namely, a garment or the like; in washing and whitening it. And daqRa AlbaAba He knocked at the door for admission.] ― -b3- And [hence also, (in the CK, erroneously, “ or, ”) as appears from what follows,] (assumed tropical:) He made it apparent; showed, exhibited, manifested, or revealed, it: (K:) so says IAar, citing the following verse of Zuheyr:
tadaArakotumaA EabosFA wacuboyaAna baEodamaA
tafaAnawoA wadaqRuwA bayonahumo EiTora manoXimi
(TA:) i. e. Ye two repaired the condition of the tribes of 'Abs and Dhubyán by peace, (talaAfayotumaA OamorahumaA biAlSRuloHi,) after they had shared, one with another, in destruction, and had brayed [among themselves] the perfume of Menshim as a sign of their having leagued together against their enemy; i. e., after slaughter had come upon the last of their men, as upon the last of those who perfumed themselves with the perfume of Menshim: for [it is said that] mnXm is the name of a woman who sold perfume in Mekkeh, and a party bought of her some perfume, and leagued together to fight their enemy, making the dipping of their hands in that perfume to be a sign of their league; and they fought until they were slain to the last of them: whence the prov., OaXoOamu mino EiTori manoXima: (EM p. 117:) [so that, accord. to this explanation, which is one of many, mnXm is made perfectly decl. for the sake of the rhyme:] or the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) after they had manifested enmities and faults. (TA.) One says also, in cases of enmity, laOaduqRanRa XuEuwraka, meaning (assumed tropical:) I will assuredly manifest thy circumstances. (TA.) ＝ -A3- duqRa, inf. n. daqRN and diqRN, He was seized with the malady termed diqR [i. e. hectic fever]. (MA.)

2 dqRq dqp dqq
2. dqRq, (K,) inf. n. tadoqiyqN, (S,) He bruised, brayed, or pounded, finely; he comminuted, or pulverized; syn. OanoEama AldRaqRa. (S, K.) This is the primary signification. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (assumed tropical:) [He made a minute examination. ― -b3- And He spoke, or expressed himself, and] he proved a question, or a problem, in a subtile, nice, abstruse, recondite, or obscure, manner. (El-Munáwee, TA.) ― -b4- See also 4.

3 dAqR SaAHibahu AlHisaAba dAq SAHbh AlHsAb
3. dAqR SaAHibahu AlHisaAba, inf. n. mudaAqRapN, (tropical:) [He was minute, observant of small things, nice, or scrupulous, with his companion in the reckoning; and so dAqRhu fiI AlHisaAbi;] (JK, K, TA;) he reckoned with his companion with minuteness:
(TK:) it signifies an act between two. (TA.) [And dAqRhu fiI AlOamori (assumed tropical:) He was minute, &c., with him in the affair, or case.] AlmudaAqRapu fiI AlOamori signifies AltRadaAqRu↓; (S;) which is an instance of tafaAEulN from AldRiqRapu: (Sgh, K:) you say, tadaAqRaA↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) They were minute, &c., each with the other. (TK.) You say also, dAqR AlnRaZara fiI muEaAmalaAtihi wanafaqaAtihi [He examined minutely into his dealings and his expenses]. (TA in art. dnq.) ― -b2- And [hence] mudaAqRapN, metonymically, signifies (tropical:) The being niggardly, stingy, or avaricious. (Az, TA in art. dnq.)

4 AdqRhu Odq Odqh Odqp Adqh Adqp dq dqyq
4. AdqRhu He made, or rendered, it (a thing, S, M) daqiyq [i. e. thin, or slender, &c.]; (S, M, K;) as also dqRqhu↓. (S, M.) ― -b2- And He gave him a small thing: (S, TA:) or he gave him little: (S in art. jl:) or (tropical:) he gave him a sheep, or goat; (M;) or sheep, or goats. (K, TA.) You say, Oatayotuhu famaA OadaqRaniI walaA OajalRaniI (S, M) I came to him, and he gave me not a small thing, nor gave he me a great thing: (S in the present art.:) or he gave me not little, nor gave he me much: (S in art. jl:) or he gave me not a sheep, or goat, nor gave he me a camel. (M.) ― -b3- And AdqRt, said of the eye, It shed few tears; opposed to AjlRt; as in the saying of El-Fak'asee cited in art. jl. (S * and TA voce OajalRa, q. y.) ＝ -A2- And AdqR (assumed tropical:) He pursued little, paltry, or mean, things. (TA.)

6 tadaAoqaqa
6: see 3, in two places.

7. AndqR It (a thing, S, M, TA, such as medicine, &c., TA) was, or became, broken, (M, K, TA,) or crushed, (M,) in any manner: (M, TA:) or bruised, brayed, or pounded; i. e. beaten with a thing so that it was broken, or crushed: (M, K: *) quasi-pass. of daqRahu. (S, M, K.)

diqRN dq
diqRN: see daqiyqN, in nine places. ― -b2- Hence, HumRaI AldRiqRi [Hectic fever; so termed in the present day]; that is, from diqRN as signifying the contr. of galiyZN. (S.) ＝ -A2- diqRN in measuring, relating to the thing measured, is The being broken, crushed, or bruised, in the measure, so as to become close, or compact. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also (tropical:) Niggardliness, stinginess, or avarice; the condition of him in whom is little, or no good. (M, TA.)

duqRapN dq dqh dqp
duqRapN Soft dust swept by the wind (S, K) from the ground: pl. duqaqN: (S:) or dust swept from the ground; as also duqaAqapN↓: (TA:) or duqaqu AltRuraAbi signifies fine dust; and duqRapN is its sing.: (M:) or, accord. to IB, the sing. of duqaqN is duqRaI↓, like as the sing. of julalN is julRaI. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food, (IDrd, M, K,) bruised, or brayed, (M,) and what are mixed therewith; (IDrd;) such as are termed qazoH, and the like: all such seeds of the cooking-pot are called duqRap by the people of Mekkeh: (IDrd, Sgh:) and salt with such seeds mixed therewith: (M, K:) this is the application now commonly obtaining: (TA:) or salt alone: (M:) or salt bruised, or brayed: (Lth, K:) whence the saying, maA lahu duqRapN He has not salt. (Lth, M, K. *) ― -b3- And [hence,] (tropical:) Beauty, or prettiness: (M, K, TA:) whence the phrase AimoraOapN laA duqRapa lahaA, (M,) or qaliylapu AldRuqRapi, (K,) or maA lahaA duqRapN, (TA,) (tropical:) A woman who is not beautiful, or pretty; (M, K; *) who has not beauty, or prettiness. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A certain ornament (HaloIN) of the people of Mekkeh. (K.) ― -b5- And The small, or young, (HaXow,) of camels. (TA.)

diqRapN dq dqh dqp
diqRapN inf. n. of the intrans. verb daqRa [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) [As a simple subst.,] The state, or condition, or quality, of that which is termed diqRN [and daqiyqN; properly and tropically: i. e., it signifies slenderness, &c.]: and smallness, littleness, or the like; [properly and tropically;] contr. of EiZamN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Littleness in estimation, paltriness, inconsiderableness, meanness, vileness, or contemptibleness. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [And (assumed tropical:) Subtileness, niceness, abstruseness, reconditeness, or obscureness.]

daqaqapN [pl. of daAqRN↓, agreeably with analogy,] Persons who manifest, or reveal, the faults, or vices, of the Muslims. (IAar, K.)

duqaAqN What is broken, or crushed; or bruised, brayed, or pounded; of a thing; as also duqaAqapN↓: (M:) broken particles of anything: (JK, K:) and [particularly] fragments, or broken pieces, of branches; as also diqaAqN↓. (K.) ― -b2- See also madoquwqN [with which it is sometimes syn.]: ― -b3- and see daqiyqN.

diqaAqN dqAq dqyq
diqaAqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

daquwqN dqwq
daquwqN A certain medicine (JK, M, K) for the eye, (JK, K,) bruised, brayed, or pounded, (JK, M, K,) and then sprinkled (JK, M) therein. (JK.)

daqiyqN dqyq
daqiyqN contr. of galiyZN (JK, * S, M, * Msb, K) and jaliylN; (Msb;) as also duqaAqN↓ and diqRN↓; (S, K;) the last contr. of jilRN: (JK, S, M:) [i. e. Slender, or small in diameter or circumference as compared with length: also small in all dimensions; small in size; minute, or fine, either as a whole, or in its component particles: and sometimes, as applied to a garment or the like, thin, or fine, as opposed to thick or coarse; like raqiyqN: but properly,] daqiyqN differs from raqiyqN; the former signifying the contr. of galiyZN [as stated above], and the latter, the contr. of vaxiynN: therefore one says HasFA raqiyqN and HasFA vaxiynN [“ thin soup ” and “ thick soup ”], but not HasFA daqiyqN; and one says sayofN daqiyqu AlmaDoribi [a sword thin in the edge, or in the part next the point]; and rumoHN daqiyqN [a slender spear]; and guSonN daqiyqN [a slender branch]; and HabolN daqiyqN [a slender rope]: (IB, TA:) pl. [of mult. diqaAqN and of pauc.] OadiqRapN. (Msb.) One says, walaA jilRN maA lahu diqRN↓ [He has neither slender, or small, or fine, nor thick, or great, or coarse]; i. e. daqiyqN walaA jaliylN. (S in art. jl.) And Oaxacotu wajilRahu diqRahu↓ [I took the slender, &c., thereof, and the thick, &c., thereof]; like as one says, Axct qaliylahu wa kaviyrahu. (S in the present art.) And it is said in a trad., wajilRahu AallRehumRa QgofiroliI canobiI kulRahu diqRahu↓ [O God, forgive me all my sin, the small thereof and the great thereof]. (TA.) XajarN diqRN↓ means Shrubs, bushes, or small trees: (M:) opposed to XajarN jilRN. (Lth in art. jl, and Mgh in art. bql.) Accord. to AHn, diqRN↓ signifies Plants that are slender and soft to the camels, so that the weak of the camels, and the young, and such as has its teeth worn down to the sockets, and the sick, eat them: or, as some say, their small leaves: (M:) or slender and long leaves of the OaraAk: and grain trodden out but not winnowed: pl. OadoqaAqN. (JK.) And Hulalu diqRK↓ means Thin, or fine, [garments, or dresses, of the kind called] Hulal; opposed to Hulalu jilRK: (Mgh:) or diqRN↓ signifies the contr. of jilRN as applied to carpets, and to the garments called Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMC] and the like, and to the [cloth called] Hilos, and to the mat and the like. (TA in art. jal.) ― -b2- [Hence,] daqiyqN is also applied to a thing, an affair, or a case, as meaning (assumed tropical:) Little in estimation, paltry, inconsiderable, mean, vile, or contemptible; in this case, contr. of jaliylN: (IB, TA:) and means also (tropical:) niggardly, stingy, or avaricious; (M, TA;) in whom is little, or no, good; (M, K, TA;) applied to a man: (M:) pl. [of pauc.] OadiqRapN and [of mult.] diqaAqN and OadiqRaMCu. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a thing, an affair, or a case, (assumed tropical:) Subtile, nice, abstruse, recondite, or obscure: (M, K, TA:) [applied likewise to speech; and so diqRN↓:] you say, jaMCa bikalaAmK diqRK and daqiyqK (tropical:) [He uttered subtile, nice, abstruse, recondite, or obscure, speech]. (TA.) ― -b4- [The fem.] dqyqp↓ [used as a subst.] signifies (tropical:) Small cattle; i. e. sheep or goats; opposed to jaliylapN (JK, K, TA) which signifies camels: (JK, TA:) pl. daqaAYiqu. (TA.) You say, maA lahu daqiyqapN walaA jaliylapN (tropical:) He has neither sheep, or goats, nor camels: (TA:) or neither a sheep, or goat, nor a she-camel. (M.) And kamo daqiyqatuka (tropical:) How many are thy sheep, or goats? (TA.) And huwa raAEiI AldRaqaAYiqi (tropical:) He is the pastor of sheep, or goats. (TA.) And OaEoTaAhu mino daqaAYiqi AlmaAli (tropical:) [He gave him of the small cattle]. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, [i. e. daqiyqapN↓,] as a conventional term of the astronomer, (assumed tropical:) [A minute of a circle;] the sixtieth [in the O, and in some copies, app. most, of the K, erroneously, “ thirtieth, ” as remarked by MF and SM and others,] part of a darajap [or degree of a circle: pl. daqaAYiqu, as above]. (K, TA.) ― -b6- ↓ [And (assumed tropical:) A minute of time; the fourth part of a darajap (or degree) of time: pl. as above. ― -b7- daqiyqapN↓ is also sing. of daqaAYiqu as syn. with madaAqRN, q. v.] ＝ -A2- daqiyqN signifies also Flour, or meal, (S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) of wheat &c.; (Msb;)
[thus used as a subst.; as though] in the sense of madoquwqN. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, Farina,] You say, jaraI AldRaqiyqu fiI AlsRunobuli [The farina pervaded the ears of wheat]. (L in art. qmH.) And Hamala AldRaqiyqa [It bore farina] is said of seed-produce [or corn]. (TA in art. Hnq. [See 4 in that art.])

daAqRN: see daqaqapN.

OadaqRu [More, and most, daqiyq, i. e. slender, &c. See an ex. in a prov. cited voce xayoTN].

madaqRu mdq
madaqRu [A place of breaking or crushing, or of bruising, braying, or pounding]. [Hence,] madaqRu AlHawaAfiri The place of falling of the hoofs of horses or the like [upon the ground]. (Ham p. 679.)

midaqRN mdq
midaqRN and midaqRapN↓ and muduqRN↓, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) the last extr. (Msb, K) with respect to rule, (Msb,) one of the instances of an instrumental noun of the measure mufoEulN, (S, TA,) like munoxulN, (Az, TA,) said by Sb to be of this form because it is a subst. like julomuwdN, (M,) A thing with which one breaks (S, * M, Mgh, * K) or crushes in any manner, (M,) or with which one bruises, brays, or pounds, i. e. beats so as to break or crush, (S, * M, Mgh, * K,) a thing, (M,) in a general sense: (Mgh:) [signifying also] the thing with which qumaAX [or cloth of any kind] &c. are beaten: (Msb:) [also, the first, the wooden implement called minodaf, by means of which, and a bow, cotton is separated and loosened: and the second, the implement with which corn is thrashed; as mentioned by Golius on the authority of ElMeydánee:] but the particular terms for the thing used by the qaSRaAr [or whitener of cloth, for beating it, in washing,] are kuciynaqN and bayozarN and miyjanapN: (Mgh:) Az says that muduqRN↓, with damm to the m [and d], signifies a stone with which perfume is bruised: [and in like manner it is said in the S, in one place, to mean the midowak of the seller of perfumes:] but when it is made an epithet, it is restored to the measure mifoEalN [so that you say midaqRN]: (TA:) the pl. is madaAqRu: and the dim. is mudiyuqRN↓. madoquwqN mdqwq

(Msb.) ＝ -A2- Also Seized with the malady termed diqR [i. e. hectic fever]. (MA.)

madaAqRu mdAq mdqp
madaAqRu [a pl. of which the sing is not mentioned and app. is not used]. You say, yatatabRaEuwna madaAqRa AlOumuwri [and AlOumuwri daqaAYiqa↓ (assumed tropical:) They pursue, or investigate, or they seek successively, time after time, or repeatedly, or in a leisurely manner, gradually, step by step, or one thing after another, to obtain a knowledge of,] the subtilties, niceties, abstrusities, or obscurities, of things, affairs, or cases. (TA.) [And (assumed tropical:) They pursue, &c., the minutiæ of things, affairs, or cases: or small, or little, things &c.; for in the phrase tatabRaEa madaAqRa AlOumuwri (in the S in art. sf), mdAqR AlAmwr signifies, accord. to the PS, small, or little, things &c.] And you say, OasafRa UilaI madaAqRi Alkasobi (assumed tropical:) [He pursued small means of gain]. (TA in art. dqE.) And OasafRa UilaI madaAqRi AlOumuwri waOalaAYimihaA [lit. (assumed tropical:) He pursued small, or little, things, and the meanest, or most ignoble, thereof]; meaning he became mean, or ignoble. (M in art. sf.)

mudayoqN mdyq
mudayoqN: see mdaqRN, near the end of the paragraph.

musotadaqRN mstdq
musotadaqRN The slender, or thin, part of anything. (M, TA.) And [hence,] The fore part of the saAEid [or fore arm], next the wrist. (M, K.) [And The lower part of the saAq, or shank, next the ankle.]

duqoruwrN dqrwr

(S, K.) ― -b2- And An alominable lie: (TA:) foul language: calumny; slander: (K:) forgery of tales. (TA.) You say fulaAnN yafotariI AldRaqaAriyra Such a one forges lies, (S,) or abominable lies, (TA,) and foul language. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Also Contrariety; opposition; and so duqoruwrapN↓: and contention, or altercation, (K, TA,) that wearies one: (TA:) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b4- And An evil, or a bad, habit: pl. as above. (K.) It is related in a trad. of 'Omar, that he said to his freedman Aslam, who was a Bejáwee slave, Oaxacatoka diqoraArapN Oaholika The evil habit of thy family, or people, which was deviation from the truth, and acting falsely, hath come upon thee. (TA.) ― -b5- Also A calumniator; a slanderer: (S, K:) as though meaning cuw diqoraArapi, i. e., cuw namiymapK: (TA:) pl. as above. (K.)

1 daqiEa dqE
1. daqiEa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
daqaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. daqaEN, (Msb,) He (a man, S) clave to the dust, or earth, (S, Msb, K,) by reason of abasement, or abjectness; (S, Msb;) or, as some say, by reason of poverty: or he clave to the dust, or earth, and became poor; as also AdqE↓: or he clave to the dust, or earth, or some other thing, by reason of anything whatever: (TA:) and he became lowly, humble, or submissive, and clave to the dust, or earth. (S, TA.) It is said in a trad. [cited voce xajila], UicaA juEotunRa daqiEotunRa When ye [women] are hungry, ye become lowly, humble, or submissive, and cleave to the dust, or earth; (S, TA;) or ye bear poverty ill. (TA in art. xjl.) ― -b2- He was, or became, grieved, unhappy, or disquieted in mind; as also daqaEa, inf. n. daqoEN and duquwEN; and lowly, humble, submissive, or abased. (TA.) ― -b3- He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, in seeking, or requesting, an object of want, and desired it vehemently. (TA.) ― -b4- He was, or became, content with mean sustenance. (K; but only the inf. n., namely daqaEa, of the verb in this sense, is there mentioned.) ― -b5- [And, as shown above,] He bore poverty ill. (S, K; but only the inf. n., as above, is mentioned in them.) [Thus the verb bears two contr. meanings.] El-Kumeyt says,
walamo yadoqaEuwA Einoda maA naAbahumo
liSarofi zamaAnK walamo yaxojaluwA
i. e. They did not bear poverty ill [on the occasion of what befell them by reason of a changing of fortune], nor did they bear richness ill: or, as some say, they did not cleave to the ground in consequence of poverty and hunger, &c., nor did they become lazy, or indolent, and remiss, in seeking subsistence. (TA.) ― -b6- He (a young camel) turned away with disgust from the milk; was averse from it; loathed, or nauseated, it; syn. baXima Eani AllRabani. (K.) ― -b7- daqaEa, inf. n. daqoEN, [mentioned
above,] also signifies He pursued small means of gain; as also AdqE↓. (TA.)

1. dakRa, aor.
dakuka
, (S,) inf. n. dakRN, (S, K,) He broke, or crushed, in any manner; or bruised, brayed, or pounded; i. e., beat with a thing so as to break or crush; i. q. daqRa. (S, K.) He threw down, pulled to pieces, or demolished. (K.) He broke a wall, and a mountain. (Lth, TA.) He beat a thing and broke it so as to lay it even with the ground. (S.) Hence the saying in the Kur [lxix. 14], fadukRataA dakRapF waAHidapF, (S,) i. e. And they shall be beaten together with one beating, and the whole shall become fine dust: or they shall both be spread with one spreading, so as to become an even ground. (Bd.) [For] dakRa AlOaroDa, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) means He made even the elevations and depressions of the earth, or ground. (K, TA.) OacaA dukRati AlOaroDu dakRFA, in the Kur [lxxxix. 22], means When the earth shall be made level, without hills, (Ibn-'Arafeh, Bd,) and without mountains: or it means, shall become fine dust scattered: (Bd:) or shall be shaken so that every building thereon shall be demolished and non-existent. (Jel.) See also dakRN below. ― -b2- dakRN also signifies The spreading (kabos [for which kanos is erroneously put in the CK]) of earth, and making it even. (K.) When a roof, or flat house-top, has been spread with earth (kubiasa biAltRuraAbi), one says, dukRa AltRuraAbu Ealayohi [Earth was spread upon it]: and dakRa AltRuraAba EalaI AlmayRiti, inf. n. dakRN, means He poured earth upon the corpse. (AZ, AHn.) ― -b3- Also The filling up a well (K, TA) with earth; and so dakodakapN↓. (TA.) You say, dakakotu AlrRakiIRa I filled up the wells with earth: (S:) and AlrRakiIRa dakodaka↓ He filled up the wells with earth. (TA.) ― -b4- And dakRahu signifies also He pushed him, or thrust him; like SakRahu and lakRahu. (As, TA.) ― -b5- [Hence,] dakRa jaAriyatahu (tropical:) He (a man) distressed his young woman, or female slave, by throwing his weight upon her when
desiring to compress her. (AA, TA. [See also rakRa.]) And dakRa AldRaAbRapa biAlsRayori (tropical:) He distressed, or jaded, or fatigued, the beast by journeying. (TA.) And dukRa AlrRajulu, (S, K,) i. e. dakRatohu AlHumRaI, (AZ, S,) or dakRahu AlmaraDu, (K,) meaning (tropical:) Fever, or disease, weakened the man: (TA:) or he became sick, or ill. (K.) ― -b6- And dakRN also signifies The sending forth camels all together. (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA.)

In the following verse, Lebeed applies it as meaning A wine-skin that has become in good condition in respect of its colour and odour by reason of its oldness; (S;) or a blackish, or black, wine-skin: (EM p. 169:)

Oawo jawonapK qudiHato wafuDRa xitaAmuhaA
