I buy wine at a high price, together with every blackish, or black, old, wineskin, or wine-jar smeared with pitch, from which one has ladled out, the sealed clay upon its mouth having been broken. (EM.) ― -b2- variydapN dakonaMCu [A mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth] having a large quantity of seeds with which it is seasoned: (K:) [app. because of its colour: but SM says,] as though the said seeds were put one upon another on it. 1 dalRa dl
1. dalRa, aor. yadulRu, He, or it, directed; directed aright; guided; or caused to take, or follow, a right way or course or direction. (IAar, T.) And dulRa He (a man) was directed, directed aright, guided, &c. (IAar, T.) You say, dalRahu Ealayohi, (S, M, K,) aor. as above, (S, M,) inf. n. dalRN, (M,) or duluwlapN, (S, K,) and dilaAlapN, (S, M, K,) [but this is afterwards said in the M to be a simple subst., as it is also in the Msb, and so is duluwlapN in the M,] and dalaAlapN, (S, K,) which is of higher authority than dilaAlapN, (S,) and dulaAlapN, (K,) and [perhaps] dalRiylaI, [which see below, voce dilaAlapN,] (K,) or this is a simple subst., (M,) He directed him, or rightly directed him, or guided him, to it; (S, * M, K;) namely, the way, (S,) or a thing: (M:) or he showed him it; namely, the way. (TA.) And dalRahu AlTRariyqa [He directed him to the way; or showed him the way]. (TA.) And dalRa AlXRaIoCa, and Uilayohi [or Ealayohi], aor. as above, inf. n. duluwlapN, [He indicated the thing, by a word &c.,] said of a man; as also AdlR↓ [i. e. AdlR AlXRaIoCa, &c.]. (Msb.) You say also, of a word, yadulRu EalaI kacaA [It denotes, or signifies, such a thing]. (The lexicons passim.) ＝ -A2- Accord. to Sh, you say, dalilotu bihecaA AlTRariyqi, [aor. OadalRu,] inf. n. dalaAlapN, i. e. I knew this way; and dalalotu bihi, aor. OadilRu, inf. n. dalaAlapN: accord. to AZ, you say, biAlTRariyqi AidRalalotu↓, inf. n. AidRilaAlN, [I was, or became, directed, or rightly directed, or guided, in the way:] and [Az says,] I heard an Arab of the desert say to another, EalaI OamaA tanodalRu↓ AlTRariyqi [meaning Wilt thou not be directed, or rightly directed, to the way?]: (T:) [for] AndlR↓ signifies he was, or became, directed, or rightly directed, (M, K, TA,) to the way: (TA:) and IAar cites as an ex., (T,)
maA laka yaA OaHomaqu laAtanodalRu
wakayofa yanodalRu QmoruWN EivowalRu
[What aileth thee, O stupid, that thou wilt not be rightly directed? but how shall the dull and slack be rightly directed?]. (T, M, TA: but in the M, yA fulaAnu; and in the TA, yA OaEowaru.) And sometimes AstdlR↓ is quasi-pass. of dalRahu AlTRariyqa [explained above: see 10 below]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- dalRato, [sec. pers. dalaloti,] aor. tadilRu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. dalRN; (S, * M, * Msb, K; *) and dalRato of the class of taEiba, [sec. pers. daliloti, aor. tadalRu,] (Msb, MF, TA,) inf. n. dalalN; (Msb;) and tdlRlt↓; (S, M, Msb, K;) She (a woman) behaved in an amorous manner, or used amorous gesture or behaviour, with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition; (S;) she behaved with boldness (M, Msb, K) towards her husband, (M, K,) and with amorous gesture or behaviour, and coquettishness, feigning opposition: (M, Msb, K:) [and dalRato also signifies she talked and jested in a pleasing manner, displaying a pleasant mien or guise: and in like manner dalRa is said of a man with his wife: see dalRN, below. See also 4.] ― -b2- dalRa also signifies He gloried in, or boasted of, certain properties, or peculiar qualities. (IAar, T.) ― -b3- Also, aor. yadilRu, He favoured with, or conferred, a gift. (IAar, T.) ＝ -A4- And dalRa, [aor., accord. to rule, yadulRu,] He emboldened: so in the phrase, maA dalRaka EalaIRa [What emboldened thee, or hath emboldened thee, against me?]: and in the saying of Keys Ibn-Zoheyr,
OaZunRu AlHiloma dalRa EalaIRa qawomiI
waqado yusotajohalu AlrRajulu AlHaliymu
[I think that forbearance hath emboldened against me my people: for sometimes the forbearing man is reckoned ignorant]: (T:) and dlRl↓ signifies the same. (T and TA in art. dlw.)

10. AstdlR He desired, or sought, an indication, an evidence, a proof, or an argument: [this is the primary signification: and hence,] he adduced an indication, &c.: and he drew an inference, or a deduction: (KL:) or he established an indication for the purpose of obtaining a certain knowledge of a thing indicated, or for the purpose of affirming a thing indicated: and sometimes it is quasi-pass. of dalRahu AlTRariyqa [explained above, so that it signifies he was, or became, directed, or rightly directed, to the way]. (TA. See 1.) [You say, AstdlR biXaIoCKEalaI XaIoCK Mxara He desired, or sought, to be directed, or guided, by a thing, to another thing: he adduced, or took, or regarded, a thing as an indication, an evidence, or a proof, of another thing, or as an argument in favour of another thing: he inferred, from a thing, another thing: he sought, or found, or perceived, or saw, in a thing, an indication, an evidence, or a proof, of another thing, or an argument in favour of another thing: he was, or became, directed, or guided, or he directed or guided himself, by a thing, to another thing, or to the knowledge of another thing. AldRaliylu maA yusotadalRa bihi, occurring in the S, means The dlyl is that whereby one is directed, or guided.]

Andlq It (a sword) came forth (S, Msb, K) from its scabbard (Msb) without being drawn: (S, Msb, K:) or became loose, and so came forth, and came forth quickly: (TA:) and in like manner, its scabbard became slit, (S,) or it slit its scabbard, (K,) so that it came forth from it: (S, K:) or it fell from its scabbard, and came forth, without being drawn; (Har p. 386;) and so dalaqa↓, inf. n. duluwqN (TA, and Har ubi suprà) and daloqN: (TA:) which also signifies it (a thing) came forth, or issued, from its place of egress quickly: (TA:) and [in like manner] the former verb signifies it (a thing) came forth, or issued, from its place: (A 'Obeyd, K:) it (anything) came forth, or issued, or fell out. (S.) You say, TaEanahu faQnodalaqato OaqotaAbu baTonihi He pierced him, and the intestines of his belly came forth. (S.) And Andlqt Alxayolu (S, TA) The horses, or horsemen, came forth, or issued, and hastened: (TA:) and Alxayolu dalaqati↓ The horses, or horsemen, came forth, or issued, consecutively, or uninterruptedly. (JK.) ― -b3- He preceded: (S:) or went before and away. (TA.) You say, Ainodalaqa mino bayoni OaSoHaAbihi He went before and away from among his companions. (TA.) ― -b4- It was, or became, flabby and prominent; said of a belly; (TA in the present art.;) or, accord. to Naseer, said of the belly of a woman, like AndlE, meaning it became large and flabby. (TA in art. dlE.) ― -b5- It (a door) shut again (AinoSafaqa) when opened; would not remain open. (TA.)

dalaqN dlq
dalaqN, a Persian word (S, Msb) arabicized, (S, Msb, K,) originally dalahN; (Msb, K;) [A species of weasel; accord. to some, app., the common weasel;] a certain small beast (duwayobRapN, S, Msb, K) like the samRuwr [or sable], (K,) or like the cat, having a long back, [of the coat] of which are made fur garments: some say that it is the [animal called] Aibon miqoraD [q. v.; and this is agreeable with the description of Kzw, who says that it is “ a certain wild animal, an enemy to pigeons, likened to the cat, which, when it enters a pigeonhouse, leaves not in it anything, and abundant in Egypt; ” a description altogether applicable to the common weasel, now generally called Aibon nimos]: some say that it resembles the Eiros [or ichneumon]: some, that it is the Greek ichneumon (nimos ruwmiIR): (Msb in the present art.:) accord. to IF, the [common] nimos. (Msb in art. nms.) ― -b2- [Also, from the same Persian original, in post-classical times, but variously pronounced by moderns, dalaqN and daliqN↓ and daloqN and (now generally by the vulgar) diloqN; the third being perhaps a contraction of the first, like as XaEorN is of XaEarN, or, as also the fourth, of the second, like as katofN and kitofN are contractions of katifN; A certain kind of garment; first probably applied to one made of the fur of the animal so called: then applied to a kind of garment formerly worn by the kádees and other 'ulamà and the khateebs of mosques, (see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., vol. ii. pp. 267-269,) and by other persons of religious orders: and lastly, to a kind of patched garment worn by many devotees, reputed saints, and darweeshes; also called muraqRaEapN (q. v.) and xiroqapN. It occurs in a piece of post-classical poetry, quoted in p. 45 of the Arabic text of the vol. of the Chrest. above referred to, necessarily with the l quiescent; probably by poetic license, or in conformity with the common vulgar pronunciation.]

(TA.) [For the pl., see what follows.] ― -b2- gaArapN daluwqN (S, K) and duluqN, (TA,) and xayolN duluqN and munodaliqapN↓, (S,) [Horsemen making a sudden attack and engaging in conflict, or horsemen urging their horses, and simply horsemen, or horses,] rushing vehemently: (S, K, TA:) duluqN is pl. of daluwqN and of daAliqN↓ having the same signification. laA sinRa lahaA XaArifN daloqaMCu↓
taHomilu AlOaEobaMCa mino Eahodi Uiramo

trad. as meaning having the teeth broken so that water falls from her mouth when she drinks: (TA:) [but] AZ says that one applies to the she-camel, after what is termed buzuwlN, the epithet XaArifN; then, Eawozamo; then, liToliTN then, jaHomariXN; then, jaEomaMCu; and then, diloqimN↓, when having her teeth (OaDoraAs) fallen out by reason of extreme old age. daluka
, inf. n. dalokN, (S, Msb,) He rubbed it, or rubbed it and pressed it, (M, Msb, K,) with his hand: (S, M, Msb, K:) [or he did so well: or he pressed it, or squeezed it, and rubbed it: for] dalokN signifies the act of rubbing, or rubbing and pressing, well: (KL:) or the act of pressing, or squeezing, and rubbing: (Ham p. 798:) [and in like manner, dlRkhu↓, inf. n. tadoliykN, signifies in the present day he rubbed it, or rubbed it and pressed it; and particularly, a person's body and limbs, in the bath: its proper meaning, however, is, he rubbed it, or rubbed it and pressed it, much or well: Golius explains it as signifying he rubbed it much or well on the anthority of the KL; but it is not in my copy of that work.] You say, dalaka AlvRawoba He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, the garment, or piece of cloth, to wash it. (TA.) And dalakotu AlsRunobula HatRaI Qnofaraka qiXoruhu Eano HabRihi [I rubbed the ears of corn until their husks rubbed off from their grain]; (TA;) and AidRalakahu↓ [signifies the same]. (K in art. rhw, &c.) And dalaka Eayonayohi [He rubbed his eyes]; i. e., a man looking at the setting sun. (Z, TA.) And dalakati AlmaroOapu AlEajiyna [The woman kneaded the dough]. (TA.) And dalakotu AlnRaEola biAlOaroDi I wiped the sandal with [meaning upon] the ground. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] dalakahu AldRahoru (tropical:) Time, or fortune, disciplined him well, tried, or proved, him, rendered him expert, or experienced, or firm or sound in judgment, and taught him. (K,* TA.) And dalakatohu AlOasofaAru (tropical:) Journeyings inured him to them; namely, a camel. (TA.) And dulika biAlOasofaAri, said of a camel, (A, O, L, K,) (tropical:) He was inured by journeyings, and habituated thereto: (A, L:) or he was fatigued, or jaded, by journeyings; like [dukRa and] kudRa. (O, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] dulikati AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) [The produce, or herbage, of] the land was eaten, or consumed. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- See also 3. ＝ -A2- dalakati AlXRamosu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
daluka
, (Msb,) inf. n. duluwkN, (S, Mgh, &c.,) (tropical:) The sun set; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.;) accord. to Z, because he who looks at it rubs (yadoluku) his eyes, so that it is as though it were the rubber; (TA;) and in like manner, AlnRujuwmu the stars: (Msb:) or became yellow, (K, TA,) and inclined to setting: (TA:) or declined (K, * TA) so that the beholder almost required, when looking at it, to contract the rays from his eyes with the palm of his hand: (TA:) or declined after midday: (Ibn-'Omar, TA:) or it signifies (or signifies also, Msb) the sun declined from the meridian, or midheaven, (I'Ab, Fr, Zj, Az, S, * Mgh, * Msb, K, &c.,) at noon; (I'Ab, Fr, Zj, Az;) and in like manner, AlnRujuwmu the stars. (Msb.) Az says that, in his opinion, the words of the Kur [xvii. 80] Oaqima QlSRalaApa liduluwki AlXRamosi (TA) mean Perform thou prayer from the declining of the sun at noon: so that the command expressed by these words with what follows them includes the five prayers: (Mgh, * TA:) for by the dlwk are included the first prayer [of noon] and that of the EaSor; and by the gasaq of night, the two prayers [of sunset and nightfall] of which each is called EiXaMC; and by the quroMn of the fajor, the prayer of daybreak: if you make the dlwk to be the setting, the command is restricted to three prayers: in the language of the Arabs, duluwkN is said to be syn. with zawaAlN; and therefore the sun is said to be daAlikapN when it is declining at noon and when it is setting. (TA.) [Respecting the phrase dalakato baraAHi or biraAHi, accord. to different readings, occurring at the end of a verse, see baraAHi, and see also raAHapN in art. rwH.] It is said in [one of the works entitled] the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb, ” that dalakati AlXRamosu signifies The sun became high; like damakat and Ealat and AiEotalat. (TA.)

3. dAlkhu, (S, K,) inf. n. mudaAlakapN, (TA,) He delayed, or deferred, with him, or put him off, (namely, his creditor, S, TA,) promising him payment time after time; (S, K, TA;) as also daAEakahu. El-Hasan (El-Basree, TA) was asked, OayudaAliku AlrRajulu QmoraOatahu [May the man delay, or defer, with his wife?], meaning, in the matter of the dowry; and he answered, “ Yes, if he be in a state of bankruptcy, ” or “ poor. ” (A 'Obeyd, S, TA.) And you say likewise, AlrRajula HaqRahu dalaka↓ He deferred, or put off, by repeated promises, giving the man his right, or due. (TA.) ― -b2- The inf. n. also signifies The vying in patience: or, as some say, the importuning, pressing hard, or urging, in demanding the giving, or payment, of a due or debt. (TA.)

(TA.) ＝ -A3- A certain plant: (K:) n. un. with p. (TA.) ― -b2- And The [hip, or] fruit of the [wild] red rose, that comes after it, [i. e. after the flower,] (K, TA,) becoming red, like wheat, and ripening, (TA,) and becoming sweet, like the fresh ripe date; called in Syria Suromu AldRiyoki: (K, TA:) n. un. with p: (TA:) or [the fruit of] the mountainrose Alwarod AljabaliIR [a name now given to the wild rose, or sweet brier], like wheat burR [in the CK busor]) in size and redness, and like the fresh ripe date in sweetness: in El-Yemen it is sent from one to another as a present: (K, TA:) Az says, so I have heard from an Arab of the desert, of the people of El-Yemen; and it grows with us [app. meaning in El-'Irák] so as to form thickets. sawodaMCa HaAlikapK kalawoni AlOadolami
[And verily I purposed a hostile incursion in a night intensely black, like the colour of black leather]. (TA.) ― -b5- AldRalomaMCu [fem. of AlOadolamu] (assumed tropical:) The thirtieth night (K, TA) of the [lunar] month: because of its blackness. (TA.)

, (TK,) inf. n. dalahN (JK, K, TK) and duluwhN, (K, TK,) He (a man, TK) became bereft of his heart, or mind, or reason, in consequence of anxiety and the like; (JK, K, * TK;) as when a man's mind is confounded, or perplexed, so that he cannot see his right course, (ydlh, [app. for yudalRahu↓,]) in consequence of excessive love of a woman, or from some other cause; (TA;) or like as is the woman for her child (kamaA tudalRahu↓ AlmaroOapu EalaI waladihaA) when she has lost it: (JK:) and dulRiha↓, also, (JK,) inf. n. tadoliyhN; (JK, S;) and
tdlRh↓; (K;) signify he became bereft of his heart, or mind, or reason, (JK, S, * K,) in consequence of anxiety, (JK,) or love, or desire, (S,) or excessive love of a woman: (K:) [or] daliha aor.
dalaha
, (S, K,) inf. n. dalahN; (TA;) and tdlRh↓; (TA;) he became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, (S, K, TA,) in consequence of love, (S,) or excessive love of a woman, and anxiety: (TA:) or the former of these two verbs signifies he became insane, or bereft of reason, in consequence of excessive love of a woman, or from grief: (K:) and dulRiha↓, he (a man) was caused to become confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (TA.) ― -b2- dalaha, aor.
dalaha
, (M, K,) inf. n. duluwhN, (M, TA,) or dalohN, (TK,) He became free from care, or thought; or became diverted [Eano XaIoCK from a thing] so as to be free from care [respecting it]. (M, K.) And dalihato Eano UilofihaA, and Eano waladihaA, (so in three copies of the S,) or dalahato, (thus in one of my copies of the S,) aor.
dalaha
, inf. n. duluwhN, She (a camel) scarcely ever, or never, yearned towards her mate, or fellow, and her young one. (AZ, S.)

daAlihN dAl dAlh dAlp
daAlihN and daAlihapN, (K,) each applied to a man, (TA,) [but the latter is of a form denoting intensiveness of signification,] Weak-minded. (K.)

mudalRahN Bereft of his heart, or mind, or reason, in consequence of anxiety [&c.]: (JK:) or heedless in heart, bereft of reason, in consequence of excessive love of a woman, and the like: or one who will not keep, or retain, in his mind, or memory, (laA yaHofaZu,) what he does or what is done to him: (K:) and one going to and fro in confusion, or perplexity, not knowing his right course. (TA.)

Q. 4 AidolahamRa OdAl Odl OdlI Odlhm Adlhm dAl dl dlI Qdlhm
Q. 4. AidolahamRa It (the night) was, or became, black; (TA;) or intensely dark: (Mgh:) and AidolaOamRa signifies the same; (K and TA in art. dlm;) the C being a substitute for h. (TA in that art.) And It (darkness) was, or became, dense, or thick. (K.) See the next paragraph. ― -b2- Also He (a man) was, or became, aged; and so AidolahanRa. (K in art. dlhn.)

dalohamN dl dlhm
dalohamN Dark. (K.) You say layolN dalohamN Dark night: (TA:) and layolapN mudolahimRapN↓ A dark night. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And Deprived of his reason by love: (K:) a signification which shows the m to be augmentative; for it is from AldRalahu: or, accord. to IKtt and others, the l in AdlhmR↓ is augmentative; for, they say, it is from AldRuhomapu: either opinion is allowable. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The wolf. (K.) ― -b4- And The male of [the bird called] the qaTaA [like dayolamN]. (K.)

dilohaAmN dlhAm
dilohaAmN A man who is penetrating, sharp, vigorous, and effective. (K.) ― -b2- And A lion. (K.)

mudolahimN Densely black. (TA.) And Oasowadu mudolahimN Intensely black. (Lh, K.) See also dalohamN. ― -b2- falaApN mudolahimRapN [A desert, or waterless desert,] in which are no signs of the way. (TA.)

1 dalaA AldRalowa dlA Aldlw
1. dalaA AldRalowa, (Mgh, K, [in the CK, dalRAhA is erroneously put for dalaAhaA,]) [and dalaA biAldRalowi,] first pers. dalawotu AldRalowa, (T, S, Msb,) and dalawotu biAldRalowi, (Msb,) aor., first pers., Oadoluw, inf. n. dalowN; (T;) and AldRalowa AdlI↓; (Mgh; [the only authority that I find for the latter verb in the sense here explained;]) He pulled the dalow [or bucket] up, or out, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) from the well, (T, Mgh,) full: (T, Mgh:) or he pulled the dlw to make it come forth. (K.) Hence, i. e. from AdlI Aldlw as explained above, the saying, in a trad., if it be correct, Eani AlmaMCa waraduwA maMCK fasaOaluwA Oaholahu Oano yudoluwhumo↓ [They came to water, and they asked its owners to draw for them from the water]; for yudoluwA lahumo, or yudoluwA dalowahumo. (Mgh.) And Oadoluw HaAjatiI, from dalawotu AldRalowa explained above, means (assumed tropical:) I seek, or demand, the accomplishment of my want: (Ham p. 500:) or dalaA HaAjatahu means (assumed tropical:) He sought, or demanded, the object of his want. (TA.) And dalawotu bifulaAnK Uilayoka, (S, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) I begged, or beg, such a one to make intercession for me to thee. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] dalaA (assumed tropical:) He drove, or urged on: (IAar, T:) or did so gently; for dalowN [the inf. n.] means the driving, or urging on, gently. (M.) You say, dalawotu AlnRaAqapa, (S, K,) aor. Oadoluw, (TA,) inf. n. dalowN, (S, TA,) (tropical:) I made the she-camel to go gently, or leisurely. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- And dalawotuhu and daAlayotuhu↓ (tropical:) I was gentle with him; namely, a man; (S, K, TA;) treated him with gentleness or blandishment, soothed him, coaxed him, or wheedled him; (S, TA; and K in art. dlI [in which, as is said in the TK, daAwayotuhu is erroneously put, in some copies, for daArayotuhu];) endeavoured to conciliate him. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 4, in three places.

2 tadoliyapN OdlI dl dlI tdlyh tdlyp
2. tadoliyapN [inf. n. of dlRI] signifies The lowering a thing; like UidolaMCN↓ [inf. n. of 4]. (Bd in vii. 21.) You say, dlRI AlXRaIoCa fiI mahowaApK He let down the thing, made it to hang down, or let it fall, into a pit or the like. (T, * M, TA.) And dalRaAhu mino saToHK biHabolK He let him, or it, down from a house-top by means of a rope. (Mgh.) And dlRI rijolayohi mina AlsRariyri [He hung down his legs from the couch]; and AdlI↓ occurs in the same sense. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., dulRiIa EalaIRa jiraAbN mino XaHomK mino baEoDi HuSuwni xayobara, meaning [A bag, or provision-bag, of fat] was let down, or let fall, upon me [from one of the forts of Kheyber]. (Mgh.) See also 4. ― -b2- And dlRI AlXRaIoCa He made, or brought, or drew, the thing near to another thing (mino gayorihi); like AldRalowi UidolaMCu↓. (Har p. 173.) ― -b3- dalRaAhu biguruwrK (assumed tropical:) He caused him to fall into that which he desired [to bring about] by exposing him to perdition, or destruction, or loss, without his knowledge; from AldRalowi UidolaMCu↓. (S.) [In the Kur vii. 21,] fadalRaAhumaA biguruwrK means (assumed tropical:) And he caused them to fall (fdlRAhmA) into disobedience by deceiving, or beguiling, them: so says Aboo-Is-hák [Zj]: or (assumed tropical:) he excited their cupidity [with deceit, or guile]; originating from the case of a thirsty man's being let down (yudalRaI) into a well in order that he may satisfy his thirst from its water, and his not finding water in it, so that he is let down into it with deceit, or guile: or it means he emboldened them to eat of the tree with deceit, or guile; originally dalRalahumaA. (T.)

3 daAlayotuhu dAlyp dAlyth dAlytp
3. daAlayotuhu: see 1.

4 Oadolayotu c
4. Oadolayotu, [in the CK, erroneously, dalayotu,] and dalawotu↓ (K;) or Oadolayotu AldRalowa, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UidolaMCN; (T, Msb;) and AldRalowa dalawotu↓, [and app. biAldRalowi,] aor. Oadoluw, [inf. n. dalowN;] (T, * Msb;) I let down the dalow [or bucket] (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) into the well, (T, S, Mgh, K,) to fill it, (T,) or to draw water with it. (M, Msb.) Oadoli dalowaka fiI AldRilaMCi [Let down thy bucket with the other buckets] is a prov. used in urging [a person] to strive, or labour, for gain; (TA;) originating from a company's assembling at a well, and letting down their buckets in order that every one of them may take his share of the water, or what is easily procurable by him thereof: meaning, use means to acquire, like as do others. (Har p. 167.) See also 2, in four places. ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) AdlI biHujRatihi (tropical:) He adduced his plea, or the like, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) correctly, or validly; (T;) or he defended himself by adducing it or urging it: (S:) or he established his plea, or the like, and so obtained his claim or demand or suit. (Msb.) And in like manner you say, AdlI biHaqRihi (tropical:) [He urged, or established, his right or due]. (TA.) ― -b3- And AdlI bimaAlihi (tropical:) He gave, (dafaEa, M, K, TA,) or presented, or offered, (rafaEa, S, TA,) his property, (S, M, K, TA,) Uilayohi [to him], (M,) or AlI AlHaAkima [to the judge]. (S.) Hence, in the Kur [ii. 184], watudoluwA bihaA UilaI, AlHukRaAmi, (S, K,) i. e. (tropical:) And [do not] give it, or offer it, as a bribe to the judges: (S, * TA:) or and do not endeavour to conciliate with it the judges in order that they may cut off for you what is the right of others: (T:) or and do not throw it to the judges to be decided by them, (Mgh, Bd, Jel,) or as a bribe. (Jel.) And in a letter of 'Omar, faQfohamo UicaA OudoliIa Uilayoka And understand thou
when an application is made to thee by litigants for the decision of a cause. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And AdlI biraHimihi (tropical:) He sought to bring himself near, to approach, or to gain access, [UilaI gayorihi to another,] by means of his relationship: (S, K, TA:) and he pleaded, or made intercession, thereby. (TA.) bihi Uilayoka waqado dalawonaA↓, in a prayer for rain, of 'Omar, referring to El-' Abbás, i. e., accord. to the “ Ghareebeyn, ” (assumed tropical:) And we have sought to approach, or to gain access, to Thee by him, app. means that they sought to obtain the mercy and aid of God [by means of his intercession], like as one seeks to get at, or obtain, the water by means of the dalow [or bucket]. (M.) One says also, OadolaI UilaI AlmayRati biAlbunuwRapi wanaHowihaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) He was united to the dead by sonship, and the like; from UidolaMCu AldRalowi. (Msb.) And fulaAnN yudoliI UilaI AlmayRiti bicakirK (assumed tropical:) Such a one is united with the dead by a male. (Mgh.) ― -b5- AdlI fiyhi means (tropical:) He said of him what was evil, or foul. (M, K.) ― -b6- And AdlI said of a horse &c., He put forth his yard, for the purpose of staling or covering; (M, K;) as also dlRI↓ said of an ass, as is also the former verb. (M.) ― -b7- See also 1, first and second sentences.

5 tdlRI Odl OdlI dl dlI tdlI tdly
5. tdlRI It was let down or lowered; it hung down, or dangled; it was let down; (T, * M, Mgh;) into, and over, a pit or the like; (M;) it hung (K) from (mino) a tree; (S, K) it hung down as a fruit [from a tree]. (Bd in liii. 8.) [Hence,] tdlRI EalayonaA mino OaroDi kacaA [He, or it, came down, or descended, upon us from such a land]. (TA.) And tdlRI biAlXRarRi He descended upon one with evil, or mischief. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He drew near, or approached: (K in art. dlI:) or he drew near, or approached, [from above, or] after being high. (IAar, T.) Accord. to Fr, vumRa danaA fatadalRaI [in the Kur liii. 8] means vamRa tadalRaI fadanaA, (T,) i. e. Then he (Gabriel) hung down from the highest region of the sky, and so drew near to the Apostle: showing that he took him up without becoming separated from his place: or the meaning of the phrase, as it stands, is, then he drew near to the Prophet, and he clung to him: (Bd:) but accord. to Zj, it means then he drew near, and drew nearer; and is like the phrase danaA fulaAnN minRiI waqaruba. (T. [See also another explanation in what follows.]) ― -b3- And He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; or he lowered, humbled, or abased, himself. (IAar, T; and K in art. dlI.) ― -b4- In the saying of a poet,
kaOana raAkibahaA guSonN bimarowaHapK
UicaA tadalRato bihi Oawo XaAribN vamilN
tdlRt may be quasi-pass. of dalaA, inf. n. dalowN, signifying “ he drove, or urged on, gently: ” or it may be for tadalRalato: [so that the meaning may be, As though her rider were a branch of a tree in a place over which the wind was blowing, when she became urged on gently with him, or an intoxicated drinker: or, when she emboldened herself with him, &c.:] (M:) [for] tadalRaI is also syn. with tadalRala: (S, K:) and [J says that] this is its meaning in the saying in the Kur [otherwise explained above] vumRa danaA fatadalRaI: being like yatamaTRaI in the Kur [lxxv. 33], i. e. yatamaTRaTu. (S.)

12 AidolawolaI AdlwlI Adlwly
12. AidolawolaI, of the measure AifoEawoEala, He hastened, made haste, sped, or went quickly; (S;) [like AclwlI.]

dalFA dl dlA
dalFA: see what next follows.

dalowN dlw
dalowN [A bucket, generally of leather;] a certain thing with which one draws water; (S, TA;) a vessel with which one draws water from a well; (KL;) well known; (T, K;) in Pers. dwl [i. e. duwlo, pronounced “ dól ”]: (MA:) masc. and fem.; (M;) sometimes masc.; (K;) mostly fem., (M, Msb,) and thus accord. to the more approved usage: (M:) pl. (of pauc., T, S, Msb) OadolK, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) of the measure OafoEulN, [originally OadoluwN,] (S,) and (of mult., T, * S, Msb) dilaMCN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and duliIRN, (S, M, Msb, K,) which is of the measure fuEuwlN (S, Msb) originally, (Msb,) and diliIRN (T, M, K, omitted in the CK) and duliyRapN, omitted here by the author of the K but mentioned by him in art. nHw, (TA,) and dalaA↓; (K; [there said to be like EalaI; but correctly dalFA;]) or dalFA is syn. with dilaMCN, and its sing. [or n. un.] is dalaApN↓; (S, M;) like as that of falFA is falaApN; (M;) [for] dalaApN is syn. with dalowN: (T:) or dalaApN signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (M,) a small dalow. (M, K. [But in the M, in one place, it seems to be stated that, accord. to some, dalaApN and dalFA signify the same, in a pl. sense: for, after the pls. of dalowN, it is added, wahiIa AldRalaApu waAldRalaA. I think, however, that he who first said this meant thereby that AldRalaApu and AldRalaA signify, respectively, the same as AldRalowu and AldRilaMCu &c.]) [Hence the saying, OatobiEi AldRalowa riXaMCahaA: see 4 in art. tbE.] As masc., it has for its dim. dulRaIRN↓: as fem., dulayRapN↓. (Msb.) See also daAliyapN. ― -b2- And hence, (M,) AldRalowu (tropical:) [The sign of Aquarius;] one of the signs of the Zodiac. (S, M, K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) The hopper of a mill. (Golius on the authority of Meyd.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A certain mark made with a hot iron upon camels; (S, K;) app. in the form of a dalow [properly so called]. (TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Calamity, misfortune, or mischief. (S, K.) So in the saying, jaMCa fulaAnN biAldRalowi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one brought calamity, &c.]. (S.)

dalaApN dl dlAh dlAp dlI
dalaApN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A share, or portion: so in the saying of a rájiz,
Mlayotu laA OuEoTiIa gulaAmFA OabadaA
dalaAtahu UinRiI OuHibRu AlOasowadaA
meaning [I have sworn, or, emphatically, I swear, I will not give a boy, ever,] his share, or portion, of love, or affection: [verily I love ElAswad:] El-Aswad was the name of his son. (S, TA.)

dulaIRN dl dlI dly
dulaIRN: see dalowN, of which they are dims.

dulayRapN dlyh dlyp
dulayRapN: see dalowN, of which they are dims.

daAlK dAl
daAlK Pulling up, or out, a dalow [or bucket] from a well: (T:) and occurring in poetry in the sense of mudolK [meaning letting down a dalow into a well]: (S:) pl. dulaApN. (TA.)

daAliyapN dAl dAlyh dAlyp
daAliyapN A [water-wheel, or machine for irrigating land, such as is called] manojanuwn, (S, M, K,) that is turned by an ox or a cow: (S:) and [such as is called] a naAEuwrap: (K:) or the nAEwrp is turned by water: (S:) and a thing made of palm-leaves (M, K) and pieces of wood, with which water is drawn [for irrigating land] by means of ropes, or cords, (M,) [app. held and drawn at one end by a man, and at the other end] tied to a tall palm-trunk: (M, K:) it is a bucket (dalow), and the like, with pieces of wood made in the form of a cross, [i. e. with two pieces of wood placed across and so tied together,] the two arms of which are bound to the top [or rim] of the bucket; them one end of a rope is tied to it, and the other end to a palm-trunk standing at the head of the well; and one irrigates [land] with it [app. by drawing and swinging it up by means of another, or of the same, rope]: the word is of the measure faAEilapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN [because it is pulled up]: the pl. is dawaAlK: El-Fárábee deviates from others, by explaining it as meaning a manojanuwn; and J follows him: (Msb:) [a similar apparatus for irrigating land is used in the northern parts of Egypt, called qaTowap and dalow↓: it consists of a bowl-shaped bucket, with four cords attached to its rim: two men, each holding two of the cords, throw up the water by means of it into a trough or trench: accord. to Mtr,] the daAliyap is a tall palm-trunk set in the manner of the machine with which rice is beaten [to remove the husks], having at its head a large bowl, with which water is drawn [for irrigating land]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also Land that is irrigated by means of the dalow [or bucket] or the [machine called] manojanuwn [mentioned above]. (M, K.) ― -b3- And the pl., dawaAlK, Unripe dates hung, and eaten when they become ripe. (T, K.) Hung fruit. (Bd in liii. 8. [But perhaps Alvmr is there a mistranscription for AltRmoru.]) ― -b4- Also (i. e. the pl.) Black grapes, but not intensely black, (AHn, M, K,) the bunches of which are the largest of all bunches, appearing like goats hung [upon the vines]: the berries thereof are coarse, breaking in the mouth, and round; and are dried. (AHn, M.) [See also dawaAliIRu, in art. dwAl.) ― -b5- [The sing. also signifies A grape-vine itself: and a shoot of a grape-vine: pl. as above.]

1. daliIa, (IAar, T, K,) aor.
dalaIa
, inf. n. dalFA, (TK,) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (IAar, T, K.)

3: and 5, mentioned in this art. in the K: see art. dlw.

1 damRa dm
1. damRa, (S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
damuma
, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. damRN, (T, M, Msb,) He smeared, or
did over, (S, M, Msb, K,) a thing, (S, M, K, *) or the face, (Msb,) with any kind of dye [or the like]: (S, Msb:) and a house, or chamber, with [plaster of] gypsum, (T, M, K,) or with mud or clay, (T,) and with [a wash of] quick lime: (TA:) and a ship with tar: (M, K:) and an eye, externally, (Lth, T, K,) or a pained eye, externally, (M,) with a dimaAm, (Lth, T, M, K,) i. e. any medicinal liniment, (Lth, T,) such as aloes, and saffron; (TA;) as also dmRm↓: (Kr, M, K:) [or this latter, probably, has an intensive signification: see also R. Q. 1:] and damRato, aor. and inf. n. as above, said of a woman, she smeared the parts around her eye with aloes or saffron: (M:) or damRati AlEayona she applied a collyrium to the eye; or smeared it with a dimaAm. (Msb.) You say also, damRa Alqidori, aor. and inf. n. as above, He smeared, or did over, the [stone] cooking-pot with blood or spleen, [or with liver, (see damiymN,]) after repairing it: (Lh, M:) and dumRat it (the [stone] cooking-pot) was smeared, or done over, with blood or spleen [or liver], after it had been repaired: (T:) or was plastered with mud or clay, and with gypsum. (TA.) And damRa AlSRadoEi, aor. and inf. n. as above, He smeared over the crack with blood and burnt hair mixed together; as also damRamahu↓. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] dumRa biAlXRaHomi, said of a camel &c., (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, loaded [or overspread] with fat; syn. Oawoqara or Ouwoqira. (So accord. to different copies of the S.) And dumRa [alone], inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He (a camel) had much fat and flesh, so that one could not feel in him the prominence of a bone. (T, TA.) And dumRa wajohuhu HusonFA (assumed tropical:) His face was [flushed,] as though it were overspread, with beauty. (M.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] bima damRato EayonaAhaA, [so I find it written, but I think it should be dumRato,] meaning (tropical:) What did she bring forth? or what has she brought forth? a male or a female? and dmRt fulaAnapu bigulaAmK [the verb (here written without any vowel-sign) being app. dumRato, meaning dumRato EayonaAhaA, because offspring, and especially boys, are among the things by which the eye is said to be refreshed, as it is by the application of a dimaAm,] (tropical:) Such a woman brought forth a boy. (TA.) ― -b4- damRa AlOaroDa, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He made the earth, or ground, even, (M, K,) as is done after turning it over for sowing. (M.) And damRa juHorahu, said of the Jerboa, (T, S, M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (T,) It stopped up the mouth of its hole with its nabiyXap [or earth which it had extracted]: (T:) or it filled up its hole with earth: (S:) or it covered over its hole and made it even. (M, K.) And damRa AlkamoOapa He made the earth, or dust, even over the truffles. (K.) And damamotu EalaI AlXRaIoCi I covered over the thing; (T, TA;) as also damamotu AlXRaIoCa: (Ham p. 461: [see also R. Q. 1:]) and in like manner, damamotu Ealayohi Alqabora [I covered up the grave over him]: and damodamotu↓ EalaI AlXRaIoCi I buried the thing, making the ground even over it. (T, TA. *) ― -b5- damRahu, (K,) or damRa raOosahu, (T, M,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) (assumed tropical:) He broke his head: (M, K:) or he struck, or beat, and broke, his head: (T:) or it signifies, accord. to Lh, (M,) or signifies also, (K,) he struck, or beat, his head, (M, K,) whether he broke it or not. (M.) And damRa Zahorahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He struck, or beat, his back with a brick, (M, TA,) and with a staff or stick, or with a stone: a tropical meaning, as is said in the A. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A2- dmRr, (TK,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He (a sportsman) fumigated his qutorap [or lurking-place] with fur, or soft hair, [of camels,] in order that the wild animals might not perceive his smell. utter perdition] befell them. (A.) And maAraOayota wadabaAratihi mino xasaAratihi wadamaAratihi↓ [What sawest thou of his error and his perdition and his state of destruction?]. (T.)

And rajulN xaAsirN daAmirN (Yaakoob, T, M, A) and xasirN wadamirN↓ (Lh, T, M) [A man erring and perishing]: Lh says that damirN↓ in the latter phrase is an imitative sequent to xasirN: but [ISd says,] I think that xasirN is a verbal epithet, and damirN a possessive epithet. daAmiriIRN: see tadomuriIRN.

(K.) ＝ -A2- Any one: so in the saying, maA fiI AldRaAri tadomuriIRN (Fr, T, K *) and tudomiriIRN (K) and daAmiriIRN↓ (A, TA) [There is not in the house any one]; like taOomuriIRN &c. (TA.) One says also of a beautiful woman, maA raOayotu tadomuriyRFA OaHosana minohaA, (K, TA,) i. e. [I have not seen] any one [more beautiful than she]. , (Msb, K,) inf. n. damaEN; (AO, S, Msb, TA; [in one copy of the S, damoEN, which is a mistake;]) or only damaEat, with fet-h to the m; (AZ, Ks;) The eye shed tears. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- damaEa AljuroHu (tropical:) The wound flowed [with blood]. (TA.) And damaEati AlXRajRapu (assumed tropical:) The wound on the head flowed with blood; its blood ran. (Msb.) ― -b3- damaEati Aljafonapu (tropical:) The bowl flowed [or overflowed] with its grease, or gravy. (TA.) And damoEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The flowing from the strainer of the dyer. waAlXRamosu tadomaEu EayonaAhaA wamanoxiruhaA
wahunRa yaxorujona mino biydK UilaI biydi
[app. meaning (assumed tropical:) And the sun was shedding its fierce rays and its gossamer when they were going forth from deserts to deserts]: and he said, I think [that the poet means] it was the Zahiyrap [or midday of summer when the heat was vehement], when what is called luEaAbu AlXRamosi [and muxaATu AlXRamosi, which latter is here the more appropriate term,] was flowing [in the air]: and El-Ghanawee says, when the beasts thirst, their eyes shed tears, and their nostrils flow. [of mult.] is dumuwEN (K) and [of pauc.] OadomuEN: (TA:) and damoEpN↓ [is the n. un., signifying] a single drop thereof; [i. e. a tear:] (S, K:) if from joy, it is cool; or if from grief, hot. (TA.) ― -b2- damoEu daAwuwda [David's tears;] a certain well known medicine: (Sgh, K:) [perhaps the fruits of a species of coix, namely coix lachryma, now called damoEu OayRuwba, or Job's tears, which are hard and stony, and are said to be strengthening and diuretic.] ― -b3- bakati AlsRamaACu wadamoEu AlsRaHaAbi saAli (tropical:) [The sky wept, and the tears of the clouds flowed]. (TA.) ― -b4- Xaribi damoEapN↓ Alkaromi (tropical:) [He drank the tear of the vine]; i. e., wine. (A, TA.) ― -b5- dumuwEi Aljafonapi (tropical:) [The tears, meaning] the grease, or gravy, of the bowl. (TA.)

[damiEN masc. of] damiEapN A woman quick to shed tears: (S, K:) or quick to weep, abounding with tears; (L;) as also damiyEN↓, without p; (Lh, L;) of which latter, which is applied also to a man, the pl. is dumaEaMCu, applied to men, and damoEaI, applied to men and to women, and damaAYiEu, applied to women. dumRaAEN: see dumaAEN.

the tears run: (TA:) or the place where the tears collect in the sides of the eye: pl. madaAmiEu, which comprises the inner and the outer angles of the eyes: (Az, TA:) or the pl. signifies the inner angles, (AlmaMqiI,) which are the extremities of the eye [or eyes]. (S.) ― -b2- The pl. also signifies (assumed tropical:) Waters which drop, or drip, from the side of a mountain. (Aboo-'Adnán.) And it may also signify Flowings of tears. (Ham p. 551.)

madomuwEN mdmwE

damaga
(IDrd, Msb, K) and
damuga
, (IDrd, K,) inf. n. damogN, (S, Msb,) He broke his head so that the wound reached the dimaAg [or brain]: (S, K:) or he broke the bone of his dimaAg: (Msb:) or he struck it, namely, a person's head, so that the stroke reached to the dimaAg: (Mgh:) and he struck his dimaAg, (K, TA,) and broke the interior of the skull, next the dimaAg. (TA.) And damagatohu AlXRamosu The sun pained his dimaAg. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He overcame, or subdued, and abased, him, or it: like as the truth does falsehood: and hence fayadomagahu in the Kur [xxi. 18], meaning (tropical:) so that it may overcome it, or prevail over it, and abolish it: or, accord. to Az, so that it may do away with it, in such a manner as to render it despicable, or ignominious. (TA.) And dmRghu↓ signifies (tropical:) He overcame him, or prevailed over him, much, so as to subdue him, or abase him. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] dumigati AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) [The produce of] the land was eaten. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- And damagahumo bimuTofaYapi AlrRaDofi (tropical:) He slaughtered for them a lean sheep or goat: (K:) so says Lh, except that he does not explain the verb, which is thus explained by Ibn-'Abbád and Z: (TA:) or, as some say, a fat sheep or goat. (K.) ＝ -A2- dmgt HawiyRatahaA, [the verb written in the L and TA without teshdeed, so that it is app. damagato, but it may be damRagato↓,] She (a woman) made, or put, a daAmigap [q. v.] to her HwyRp [or stuffed thing whereon she rode upon her camel]. (ISh, L, TA.)

2. dmRg, inf. n. tadomiygN, (tropical:) He made a variydap [or mess of crumbled, or broken, bread,] soft with grease, or gravy. (Ibn-'Abbád, A, K.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places.

AldRimaAgu a word of which the signification is well known; (S, Msb;) [The brain;] the marrow of the head; (K;) or the stuffing of the head: (TA:) or [app. a mistake for “and” (what is termed)] OumRu AlhaAmi or OumRu AlrRaOosi or [in one copy of the K “and”] OumRu AldRimaAgi is a thin skin, like a pouch, in which it is contained: (K:) [these three terms, AmR AlhAm and AmR AlrOs and AmR AldmAg, appear all to signify the meninx; (see OumRN;) but the first and second of them seem to have been mistaken by the author or transcribers of the K for different explanations of AldRamaAgu:] the pl. [of pauc.] is OadomigapN (S, Msb, K) and [of mult.] dumugN. (TA.)

damiygN and madomuwgN↓ Having his head broken so that the wound reaches the dimaAg [or brain]: (IDrd, K:) the former is likewise applied to a woman: and the pl., applied to men and to women, is damogaI. (TA.)

daAmigapN A wound in the head, reaching the dimaAg [or brain]; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) with which there is no living: (Msb:) it is the last [in degree] of [the wounds termed] XijaAj [pl. of XajRapN]; these being ten, as follows: [1] qaAXirapN, also called HaAriSapN (S, K, TA) and HaroSapN, or, as some think, the HArSp or HrSp is different from the qAXrp: (TA:) [2] baADiEapN: [3] daAmiyapN: [4] mutalaAHimapN: [5] simoHaAqN: [6] muwDiHapN: [7] haAXimapN: [8] munaqRalapN: [9] MmRapN, (S, K, TA,) also termed maOomuwmapN: (TA:) [10] daAmigapN: (S, K, TA:) and A'Obeyd adds daAmiEapN, with the unpointed E, after daAmiyapN; (S;) or, accord. to F, who pronounces J to have erred in saying thus, before dAmyp: but J is right in this case. (TA.) [See XajRapN daAmiEapN, voce daAmiEN. Several other terms are mentioned in the TA; but these, which will be found in their proper arts., appear to be all syn. with some that are mentioned above. See also XajRapN.] ― -b2- Also A spadix (TaloEapN) that comes forth from amid the broken portions of the qulob [or heart of the palm-tree], long and hard, and, if left, mars the palm-tree; (S, K, * TA;) wherefore, when its existence is known, it is detached. (TA.) ― -b3- And An iron above the muWaxRarap [or hinder part] of the [camel's saddle called] raHol; (As, K;) also called gaAXiyapN: (TA:) or an iron with which the back of the rHol is fastened: (JK:) the pl. is dawaAmigu: ISh says that the dwAmg are above the middle of the heads, or upper extremities, of the [curved pieces of wood called] OaHonaMC [pl. of HinowN]; and sometimes they are of wood, firmly bound; and i. q. xacaAriyfu, pl. of xucoruwfN [q. v.]: [but] Az says that when the dAmgp is of iron, it is placed across, or athwart, above the two extremities of the HinowaAni, and nailed with two nails, the xcAryf being fastened upon the heads of the cross-pieces, in order that it, or they, may not become disconnected. (TA.) [What it is, I am unable further to explain. It is perhaps thus called because so placed that a person is liable to have his head wounded by it.] ― -b4- And A piece of wood placed across between two poles, upon which is hung the skin for water or milk. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

, (T, M, Msb,) inf. n. damolu and damalaAnN, (M, K,) He put the land into a right, or proper, state: (M, K:) or he did so with damaAl, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, * K, *) i. e., [he manured it with] sirojiyn (S) or siroqiyn, (M, Msb, K,) or samaAd; (Mgh;) or OadomalahaA↓ has this latter signification; (M;) and so dabalahaA. , inf. n. damolN, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) He put the thing into a right, or proper, state; prepared it, or improved it; (S in art. dbl, and Msb;) as also dabalahu. (S in that art.) And damala bayona Alqawomi, (S, M, K, *) aor.

, (M,) inf. n. damolN, (TA,) (tropical:) He made peace, effected a reconciliation, or adjusted a difference, between the people; (S, M, K, TA;) as also dawomala↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- damala AljuroHa, (T, M, K, *) aor.

, (M,) (assumed tropical:) It (a remedy) healed the wound: (T, * M, K: *) [and Admlhu↓ has a similar meaning; for] UidomaAlN signifies the healing a wound; and causing it to skin over. (KL.) ＝ -A2- damila: see 7.

[(assumed tropical:) I hated, of the brethren, him whom I was not ceasing to treat gently, with the gentle treatment of the water-skin, or milk-skin, having in it many holes, or rents]: (T, M:) thus using an inf. n. with a verb to which it does not properly belong. [I made him to bleed;] I struck him, or smote him, so that blood issued from him: (S:) [and I made him bloody; for] damRaAhu signifies [also] he smeared him, or defiled him, or made him to be smeared or defiled, with blood. Hence the prov., wuloduki mano damRaI Eaqabayoki, (M, TA,) Thy son is he who made thy two heels to be smeared with blood; (TA in art. wld;) i. e., whom thou thyself broughtest forth; (K and TA in that art.;) he is thy son really; not he whom thou hast taken from another, and adopted. damN [Blood;] one of the [four] OaxolaAT [or humours], (M,) well known: (T, M, K:) accord. to some, (Msb,) it is originally damawN: (S, Msb:) or it is originally damFI; (Zj, Mbr, S, M, Msb, K;) thus in the correct copies of the K; (TA; [in some copies damoIN, and in the CK damaIN;]) though deviating from other words of the same form in respect of its pl. [which see below]; (Mbr, S;) as is shown by its dual, (Zj, M,) which is damayaAni, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) whereby [also] the letter gone from it is shown to be I; (Mbr, S;) but it has also for its dual damaAni; (T, M, Msb, K;) and some of the Arabs say damawaAni; (S, M;) in which last, however, [accord. to ISd,] the w is substituted for I, though generally w is changed into I: (M:) and this original form is used by a poet, [namely, Hoseyn Ibn-El-Homám, accord. to one of my copies of the S,] in his saying,
falasonaA EalaI AlOaEoqaAbi tadomaI kuluwmunaA
walekino EalaI OaqodaAminaA yaqoTuru AldRamaI↓
[And we have not our wounds bleeding upon the heels; but upon our feet the blood drops]: (S:) or it is originally damoIN; (Sb, T, S, M, Msb;) as is shown by its pls., (Sb, S,) which are dimaMCu (Sb, T, S, M, K) and dumiIRN, (Sb, S, M, K,) also pronounced dimiIRN; (TA;) like as ZaboIN and dalowN have for their pls. ZibaMCu and ZubiIRN and dilaMCN and duliIRN; for if it were like qafFA and EaSFA, it would not have such pls. (Sb, S.) damRN is ignored by Ks; but is used by poetic license; (M;) or it is a dial. var. of damN. (K in art. dm.) damapN↓ has a more special signification than damN, the two words being like bayaADapN and bayaADN; (S;) [i. e.] it signifies A portion of blood: (T, M, K:) or it is a dial. var. of damN, (M, K,) accord. to IJ. (M.) The dim. of damN is dumaIRN↓. (S.) [Hence,] rajulN cuw damK A man seeking to obtain, or prosecuting for, [the revenge of] blood. (TA.) damu fulaAnK fiI vawobi fulaAnK is a saying of the Arabs, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one is the slayer of such a one. (Ham p. 632.) AldRamu AldRamu waAlhadomu Alhadomu, or waAlhadama Alhadama, is a saying of the Arabs, meaning If thy blood be sought, my blood shall be sought; and if thy blood go for nought, my blood shall go for nought: or, accord. to the latter reading, as is said in the Nh, and where thou shalt be buried, I will be buried: or thine abode shall be mine abode. (JM in art. hdm, q. v.) See also an ex. voce dumoyapN. ― -b2- damu AlOaxawayoni [The red, resinous, inspissated juice called dragon's blood;] what is called AlEanodamu; (S;) i. q. damu AlgazaAli; (K voce maZRN;) now called AlqaATiru AlamikRIRu; or a species thereof; (TA;) [vulgarly qaTor makRap; and also called damu AlvRuEobaAni;] what is called in Pers. xuwn siyaAwuXaAn (K.) ― -b3- damu AlgizolaAni A certain herb, or leguminous plant, having a beautiful blossom: (M, K:) accord. to Lth, AlgizolaAni dumoyapu↓ is the name of a certain herb, or leguminous plant, having a blossom. R. Q. 1. danodana It buzzed, or made a buzzing sound; syn. SawRata, and TanRa, (K,) and TanoTana; (Sh, T, TA;) as also danRa↓, and dnRn↓; said of the fly, (K,) [and of the bee, and of the hornet, and the like; for] danodanapN [inf. n. of danodana] (Lth, T, M, K) and daniynN [inf. n. of danRa↓] (Lth, T, M) and dinodinN↓ [a simple subst.] (M) signify
the buzzing (Sawot, Lth, T, M, K) of the fly, (M, K,) or the bee, (Lth, T,) and the hornet, (Lth, T, M, K,) and the like. (M.) ― -b2- And [hence,] He (a man) spoke in a low, gentle, or soft, tone, so that his speech was not understood; (A'Obeyd, K, TA;) [as also danRa↓; for] danodanapN [inf. n. of the former] (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) and daniynN [inf. n. of danRa↓] and dinodinN↓ (M, K) signify the speaking in a low, gentle, or soft, tone, (A'Obeyd, T, S,) or in the manner termed hayonamapN, (M, K,) so that the speech is not understood: (A'Obeyd, T, S, M:) or danodanapN signifies [merely] the speaking in a low, or faint, tone: (M:) accord. to IAth, it is a little above what is termed hayonamapN. (TA.) A poet says,
nudanodinu mavola danodanapi AlcRubaAbi
[We buzz in our speech like the buzzing of the fly]. (Sh, T.) And it is said in a trad., HawolahaA nudanodinu, (S,) or HawolahumaA, (M, JM, TA,) which is thus explained: the Prophet asked an Arab of the desert, “ What dost thou say in the taXahRud? ” [see this word, which means the repetition of a form of words at the close of the ordinary prayers:] and he answered, “ I ask of God Paradise, and seek protection of Him from the fire [of Hell]: but as to thy danodanap and the danodanap of Mo'ádh, I do not approve it: ” and the Prophet said, HawolahumaA nudanodinu; (M, JM; *) i. e. [We speak with a low, or faint, voice] about those two things, namely, the seeking Paradise and the praying for protection from the fire [of Hell]; and on account of them: (JM:) accord. to some, it is from danodana Hawola AlmaMCi He went round about the water: [hence it may mean we utter our prayer respecting them with a low, or faint, sound, as though we were buzzing round about them like flies; seeking to enter the one, and to keep outside the other:] As says that it may be from the signification of the sound [of buzzing], or from that of going round about: (TA:) or, accord. to one relation, the Prophet said, EanohumaA nudanodinu [From a consideration of them we utter our prayer with a low, or faint, voice;] i. e. our danodanapu arises from them; and is because of them: and hence, (JM,) danodana means also He (a man, JM) went to and fro in one place. (JM, TA.)

(JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.) ― -b3- Emaciated and falling down, or emaciated and tottering; expl. by mahozuwlN saAqiTN: (AA, S, K:) or falling down, or tottering, (saAqiTN,) by reason of emaciation: (JK:) applied to a man (AA, K) and to a she-camel. (AA, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, and daAnaqa↓, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) the former, accord. to some, the more chaste, arabicized [from the Pers. daAnok or daAnak], (Msb,) and daAnaAqN↓, (JK, S, K,) like as they said dirohamN and dirohaAmN, (S,) [but daAnaAqN seems to have been disallowed by Sb, either as unused or as post-classical,] The sixth part of a dirhem (or drachm); (S, Msb, K;) [i. e.] two carats; (Mgh;) [i. e.] two grains of the xuronuwb [or carob], with the ancient Greeks, for the dirhem with them was twelve grains of the xrnwb; but the dAnq of the Muslims is two grains of the xrnwb and two thirds of a grain of the xrnwb, for the dirhem of the Muslims is sixteen grains of the xrnwb: (Msb:) and the sixth part of the deenár: (TA: [but this I find nowhere else: see diynaArN: and see also riTolN:]) the pl. of dAnq is dawaAniqu and dawaAniyqu; (Mgh, TA;) the former is said by Az to be pl. of daAniqN; and the latter, of daAnaqN; and it is said that every pl. of the measure fawaAEilu or mafaAEilu may be lengthened with I so that one may say fawaAEiylu and mafaAEiylu: (Msb:) or, accord. to Sb, dawaAniyqu is pl. of daAnaAqN↓, though this be not in their speech. (TA.) [Also A small silver coin, the sixth part of the coin called diroham.] The dim. is duwayoniyqN↓. (TA.)

daAnaAqN dAnAq
daAnaAqN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

dawaAniqiIRN dAnq dwAnqI dwAnqy
dawaAniqiIRN [rel. n. from dawaAniqu pl. of daAniqN], (ElMekeen, “ Hist. Sarac. ” p. 104,) or dawaAniyqiIRN [rel. n. from dawaAniyqu pl. of daAnaAqN], (TA,) [Of, or belonging or relating to, dániks: and hence,] a surname of the 'Abbásee Khaleefeh Aboo-Jaáfar El-Mansoor; (El-Mekeen, TA;) because of his extreme niggardliness. (El-Mekeen.)

duwayniyoqN dwynyq
duwayniyoqN: see daAniqN, last sentence.

mudanRiqN mdnq
mudanRiqN One who examines minutely into his dealings and expenses: used in this sense by the people of El-'Irák. (TA.) ― -b2- EayonN mudanRiqapN An eye of which the ball, or globe, is prominent, and apparent: so accord. to AZ; and Az holds this to be the correct explanation, rather than an eye sunk, or depressed, in the head. (TA.)

1 danaA dAn dnA dnnA
1. danaA, (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) first pers. danawotu, (T, S,) aor. yadonuw, (T, Msb,) inf. n. dunuwRN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and danaAwapN, (M, K,) He, or it, was, or became, near; drew near, or approached; (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also AdnI↓; (IAar, T, K;) and dnRI↓, inf. n. tadoniyapN; (IAar, T;) and dAnI↓, inf. n. mudaAnaApN; (KL, but only the inf. n. is there mentioned;) and AidRanaI↓, inf. n. AidRinaMCN: (TA:) it is either in person, or substance, or in respect of predicament, and in place, and in time: (El-Harállee, TA:) you say, danaA minohu, (M, Mgh, Msb,) and danawotu minohu, (T, S,) and Uilayohi, (M, Msb,) and lahu, (TA,) and Ealayohi occurs in a verse of Sá'ideh as meaning minohu, (M,) He, or it, and I, was, or became, near, &c., to him, or it: (T, M, Mgh, Msb:) [and in like manner you use the other verbs mentioned above, except dAnI↓, which is immediately trans.: or danaA minohu with danaAwapN for its inf. n. means, or means also, He was near to him in respect of kindred; was related to him: for] danaAwapN is syn. with qaraAbapN (S, M, K) and qurobaI: (M, K:) you say, bayonahumaA danaAwapN meaning qaraAbapN [i. e. Between them two is relationship]; (S;) and maA tazodaAdu minRaA UilRaA qurobFA wadanaAwapK [Thou increasest not save in nearness and relationship to us]. (ISk, T, S.) A rájiz says,
maA liI OaraAhu daAlifFA qadodunoIa lahu
meaning duniIa lahu [i. e. What hath happened to me that I see him walking gently or with short steps, or rendered lowly by age, having been approached by death?]: it is from danawotu, but the w is changed into I because of the kesreh before it, and then the n is made quiescent: and there are similar instances of contraction of verbs: but [ISd says,] I know not dunoIa except in this instance; and As used to say of the poem in which this occurs, This rejez is not ancient: it is app. of Khalaf ElAhmar or some other of the Muwelleds. (M.) One says also, danati AlXRamosu lilomaguruwbi and Oadonat↓ [The sun was, or became, near to setting]. (M.) ＝ -A2- daniIa, (T, M, K, TA, [in the CK, mA kAna danoyaA wlqd danA is erroneously put for maA kaAna daniyFA walaqado daniIa,]) like raDiIa, (TA,) aor. yadonaI, (T,) inf. n. danFA (T, M, K) and danaAyapN, (T, K, TA,) or dinaAyapN; (M, accord. to the TT; and so in the CK; [app. a mistranscription occasioned by a misunderstanding of what here follows;]) the I [in daniIa] being substituted for w because of the nearness of the kesreh; all on the authority of Lh; (M;) and danuwa, aor. yadonuw, without C, inf. n. danaMCapN, with C, (ISk, T,) and dunuwRN; (T;) or danaA, aor. yadonuw, inf. n. danaAwapN; i. q. danaOa and danuWa; (Msb;) [i. e.] He (a man, T, M) was, or became, such as is termed daniIRN↓; (T, M, Msb, K;) and daniIoCN; (Msb;) meaning weak; contemptible (xasiysN); not profitable to any one; who falls short in everything upon which he enters: (T: [like mudanRK:]) or low, ignoble, or mean; (saAqiTN;) weak; (M, K;) such as, when night affords him covert, will not quit his place, by reason of weakness: (M:) or low, ignoble, or mean, (laYiymN,) in his actions, or conduct; bad, evil, or foul; accord. to the explanation of danaA by Es-Sarakustee: but some distinguish between daniIoCN and daniIRN; making the former to signify “ low, ignoble, or mean; ” (laYiymN;) and the latter, xasiysN [app. as meaning contemptible]. (Msb, and so the latter is explained in the Mgh.)

2 danRawa
2: see 1: ＝ -A2- and 4. ― -b2- It is said in a trad., samRuwA wa samRituwAwa danRuwA, i.e. [Pronounce ye the name of God, (i. e. say, In the name of God,) and invoke a blessing upon him at whose abode or table ye eat, (see art. smt,) and] make your words to be near together in praising God. (M.) And in another trad., UicaA Oakalotumo fasamRuwA QllReha wadanRuwA, i. e. [When ye eat, pronounce the name of God, and] eat of that which is near you: (M:) or UicaA Oakalotumo fadanRuwA, i. e. [When ye eat,] eat of that which is next you. (S.) ― -b3- danRaI, (T, M,) inf. n. tadoniyapN, (T,) also signifies He (a man) sought after mean, paltry, or contemptible, things. (Lh, T, M.) And dnRI fiI AlOumuwri, (inf. n. as above, S, K,) He pursued small matters, and mean, paltry, or contemptible: (T, S, TA:) in the K, erroneously, and great. (TA.) ― -b4- Also He was, or became, weak; syn. DaEufa. (S and TA in art. dwn.)

3 dAnI dAnI dAny dAnyy
3. dAnI, inf. n. mudaAnaApN: see 1, in two places. You say also, daAnayotu AlOamora I was, or became, near to [doing, or experiencing,] the affair, or event. (M.) ― -b2- daAnayotu Alqayoda lilobaEiyri I made the shackles, or hobbles, strait, or contracted, to the camel. (M, K.) And daAnaI Alqayodu qayonaIi AlbaEiyri (M, TA) The shackles, or hobbles, straitened, or contracted, [the two parts of the camel that were the places thereof.] (TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
daAnaI lahu Alqayodu fiI dayomuwmapK qacafK
qayonayohi waQnoHasarato Eanohu AlOanaAEiymu
[The shackles, or hobbles, straitened to him, in a far-extending, wide desert, the two parts of him that were the places thereof, and enjoyments became removed from him]. (M.) And you say also, daAnayotu bayona AlOamorayoni I made the two affairs, or events, to be nearly uninterrupted; syn. qaArabotu: (T, S, Msb:) or I made the two affairs, or events, to be connected; syn. jamaEotu. (M.)

4 AdnAhu OdAn OdnAh OdnI OdnnAh AdnAh AdnAp QdnAh QdnI Md
4. AdnAhu He made him, or it, to be, or become, near; to draw near, or to approach; he drew near, or brought near, him, or it; (S, M, Mgh, K;) as also dnRAhu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. tadoniyapN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oadonato vawobahaA EalayohaA She (a woman) let down her garment upon her, and covered, or veiled, herself with it. (Mgh.) And Oadonayotu AlsRitora I let down the veil, or curtain, [for the purpose of concealment.] (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xxxiii. 59], yudoniyna EalayohinR mino jalaAbiybihinRa [They shall let down upon them a portion of their outer wrapping-garments]; (Mgh;) meaning they shall let down a portion of their outer wrapping-garments over their faces, when they go forth for their needful purposes, except one eye. (Jel.) ＝ -A2- AdnI is also intrans.: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] Oadonato, said of a she-camel, (S, TA,) and of a woman, (TA,) She was, or became, near to bringing forth. (S, TA.) And Oadonato EalaI raOosi Alwaladi [a phrase similar to OaDoraEato EalaI raOosi Alwaladi, q. v.]. (Occurring in a verse cited in the TA in art. fkh.) ― -b3- And AdnI He lived a strait life, (IAar, T, K,) after easiness and plenty. (IAar, T.)

5 tdnRI OdAn OdnI dnA dnI dny tdnI tdnny tdny wdI QdnI
5. tdnRI He (a man, S) drew near, or approached, by little and little. (S, K.)

6 tadaAnawoA OdAn dAnI tdAnI tdAnwA
6. tadaAnawoA They drew near, or approached, one to another. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tdAnI It (a thing) drew together, or contracted; or became drawn together or contracted. (M* and L in art. qlS.) ― -b3- And tadaAnato Uibilu AlrRajula The camels of the man became few and weak. (M.)

8 AidRanaI Od OdAn OdnI Odnny Odny AdnI Adny dnA dnI dny wdI QdnI Md Mdny
8. AidRanaI, inf. n. AidRinaMCN: see 1.

10 AstdnAhu AstdnAh AstdnAp QstdAn QstdnAh QstdnI QstdnnAh
10. AstdnAhu He sought, desired, or demanded, of him, nearness, or approach; (M, K, TA;) he sought, or desired, to make him draw near, or approach: and he drew him near, or caused him to approach. (MA. [See also 4.])

danFA dnA
danFA inf. n. of daniIa, q. v. (T, M, K.) ＝ -A2- OadonaI danFA: see AdnI.

huwa Qbonu EamR dinoIK c
huwa Qbonu EamR dinoIK and dinoyFA and dinoyaA and dunoyaA↓ mean [He is a son of a paternal uncle] closely related; syn. laHRFA [q. v.]: when you pronounce the d with damm, you do not make the word perfectly decl.: when you pronounce it with kesr, you make it either perfectly or imperfectly decl.: but when you prefix EamR to a determinate noun, dinoI may not be in the gen. case: for instance, you say, huwa Qbonu EamRihi dinoyFA, i. e. [He is the son of his paternal uncle] closely related; as also dinoyapN↓; because dinoI, being indeterminate, cannot be an epithet applied to that which is determinate: (S:) and [in like manner] you say, huwa Qbonu EamRiI, or Abn xaAliI, or Abn EamRatiI, or Abn xaAlatiI, or Abn OaxiI, or Abn OuxotiI, (M, K,) all mentioned by Lh, the last two as on the authority of Aboo- Safwán, but all except the first and second as unknown to Ks and to As, (M,) followed by dinoyapN↓ and dinoyFA and dinoyaA and dunoyaA↓, (M, K, TA,) the last two without tenween, (TA; [and so written in the M; but in the CK and my MS. copy of the K, in the place of these two is put dunoyFA, which is disallowed by J;]) meaning [He is the son of my paternal uncle, and the son of my maternal uncle, &c.,] closely related: (M, K:) and huwa EamRuhu dunNyaA↓ and dinoyapF↓ and dinoyFA and dinoyaA [He is his paternal uncle closely related]: (Ks, T:) Lh says that the w is changed into I in dinoyapF↓ and dinNyFA because of the nearness of the kesreh and the weakness of the intervening letter, as is the case in fitoyapN and EiloyapN: but it seems that these words are originally dunoyaA↓, i. e., by a relationship, or uterine relationship, nearer to me than others; and that the change of the letter is made only to show that the I is that of the fem. of OadonaI. (M.) You say also, humo rahoTuhu dinoyapF↓ They are his people, and his tribe, closely related. (S and TA in art. rhT.)

dinoyapN dny dnyh dnyp
dinoyapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.

dunoyaA dnI dny dnyA
dunoyaA fem. of OadonaI [q. v.].

dunoyiIRN dny dnyI dnyy dnyyy
dunoyiIRN: see what next follows.

dunoyawiIRN dnywI dnywy
dunoyawiIRN: see what next follows.

dunoyaAwiIRN dnyAwI dnyAwy dnywy
dunoyaAwiIRN [Of, or relating to, the present world, or state of existence; worldly:] a rel. n. from AldRunoyaA; (T, S;) as also dunNyawiIRN↓ and dunoyiIRN↓. (S.)

daniIRN OdnI dnI dny
daniIRN i. q. qariybN [as meaning Near, in person, or substance, or in respect of predicament, and in place, and in time: (see 1, first sentence: and see also daAnK:) and a relation]: (T, S:) and a friend; or a sincere, or secret, or particular, friend; syn. xuloSaAnN. (T.) It has these significations (of qryb and xlSAn) in the prov. kulRu daniIRK duwanhu daniIRN [app. meaning There is a relation, or a friend, nearer than every other relation, or friend; like another prov., namely, duwna kulRi qurayobaI qurobaI, for the meaning and application of which see art. qrb: Freytag renders it, “ Quod attinet ad quemlibet propinquum (amicum), præter eum est propinquus:” (Arab. Prov. ii. 357:) and he adds, “ Proverbii sensus esse videtur: Quilibet propinquus seu amicus unicus non est; sed præter eum est alius ”]: (T, Meyd:) so says AZ. (Meyd.) ― -b2- See also OadonaI. ＝ -A2- As an epithet applied to a man, signifying Weak; contemptible; &c.: see 1, near the end of the paragraph: [but J says that] as meaning duwnN, it is [daniIoCN,] with C: (S:) the pl. is OadoniyaMCu. (T, M.) [In the CK, by a mistranscription mentioned above (voce daniIa), danoIN is made to signify the same.]

daniyRahN dny dnyh dnyp
daniyRahN A low, or base, quality, property, natural disposition, habit, practice, or action; syn. naqiySapN; (Mgh;) or such as is blamed; originally daniyoYapN: (TA:) pl. danaAyaA. (Har p. 327.) Hence the saying of Ibn-Háritheh, AlmaniyRapa laA AldRaniyRapa, meaning I choose death rather than, or not, disgrace. (Har ubi suprà.)

daAnK dAn dAny
daAnK [Being, or becoming, near; drawing near, or approaching: and hence, near; like daniIRN:] act. part. n. of danaA minohu. (Msb.)

OadonaI c
OadonaI Nearer, and nearest; opposed to OaqoSaI: (TA:) fem. dunoyaA; (M, TA;) in which the [radical] w is changed into I, as in EuloyaA and quSoyaA: (ISd, TA voce buqowaI:) [the pl. of the masc. is OadaAnK and Oadonawona; the latter in the accus. and gen. Oadonayoni: and] the pl. of the fem., dunFI, (S, K, TA,) like kubarN pl. of kuboraI, and SugarN pl. of SugoraI; (S, TA;) said by some to be extr. and strange [in respect of usage]; and El-Mutanebbee has been blamed for using it; (MF, TA;) but in the case referred to he has used AldRunaI for AldRunoyaA, [not as a pl.,] suppressing the I by poetic license. (TA.) [Hence,] gulibati AlrRuwmu fiI OadonaI AlOaroDi, in the Kur xxx. 1 and 2, The Greeks have been overcome in the nearer, or nearest, part of the land. (Bd, Jel.) And Aljamorapu AldRunoyaA [The nearest heap of pebbles;] the heap of pebbles nearest to Minè. (TA. [See art. jmr.]) And
AlsRamaMCu AldRunoyaA [The nearest heaven; i. e. the lowest;] the heaven that is the nearest to us: (T, TA:) also called samaMCu AldRunoyaA [which means the heaven of the present world; as will be seen from what follows]. (TA.) See also exs. of the fem. in the paragraph commencing with the words huwa Qbonu EamRK dinoIK, in four places. ― -b2- Also Former, and first; and fore, and foremost; opposed to MxirN. (TA.) [Hence,] laqiytuhu OadonaI daniIRK↓ (S, K, TA) and OadonaI danFA↓, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AdnI danRIe and AdnI daniIRK,]) i. e. I met him the first thing. (S, K.) [And OadonaI Alfami The fore, or foremost, part of the mouth.] And AldRunoyaA [for AldRaAru AldRunoyaA, and AlHayaApu AldRunoyaA, The former dwelling, or abode, and life; i. e. the present world, and life, or state of existence]; contr. of AlMxirapu: (M, K:) [or] it is so called because of its nearness: (T, S:) [and may be rendered the sublunary abode, &c.: and the inferior abode, &c. It also signifies The enjoyments, blessings, or good, of the present world, or life; worldly blessings or prosperity, &c.] And sometimes it is with tenween, (K, TA,) when used indeterminately: (TA:) [thus,] IAar mentions the saying maA lahu dunoyFA wa laA MxirapN [as meaning He has none of the enjoyments, or blessings, of the present world, nor in prospect any enjoyments, or blessings, of the world to come]; with tenween. (M, TA.) And you say, baAEa dunoyaAhu biMxiratihi [He purchased his enjoyments of the present world at the expense of his enjoyments of the world to come]. (Z, TA in art. byE.) And Aabonu AldRunoyaA means The rich man. (Msb in art. bnI.) ― -b3- Also More, and most, apt, fit, or proper: thus in the Kur [xxxiii. 59], in the phrase celika OadonaI Oano yuEarafona [That will be more, or most, apt, fit, or proper, that they may be known]; (Ksh, Mgh;) i. e., that they may be known to be free women, as distinguished from female slaves, who did not cover their faces. (Jel.) ― -b4- Also Less [in number or quantity &c.], and least [therein]; opposed to Oakovaru. (TA.) walaA OadonaI mino celika walaAOakovara, in the Kur [lviii. 8], means Nor less in number than that, nor more in number. (Bd.) And walanuciyqanRahumo mina QloEacaAbi QloOadonaI duwna QloEacaAbi QloOakobari, in the Kur [xxxii. 21, lit. And we will assuredly make them to taste of the smaller punishment besides the greater punishment], means, accord. to Zj, whatever punishment is inflicted in the present world and the punishment of the world to come. (M.) ― -b5- Also Worse, [or inferior in quality,] and worst; or more, and most, low, ignoble, base, vile, mean, or weak; opposed to xayorN. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 58], Oatasotabodiluwna QlRaciI huwa OadonaI biQlRaciI huwa xayorN [Will ye take in exchange that which is worse, or inferior, for that which is better? or], accord. to Zj, meaning that which is less in value [for that which is better]? AdnI being thus, without C: Fr says that it is here from AldRanaMCapN: and Zuheyr El-Kurkubee [or (accord. to some) El-Furkubee] read OadonaOu. (T.)

mudonK mAd mdn mdnn mdynp
mudonK and mudoniyapN, applied to a she-camel, (M, K,) and to a woman, (M,) Near to bringing forth. (M, K.)

mudanRK mAd mdn mdnn mdynp
mudanRK, applied to a man, Weak; (S, TA;) contemptible (xasiysN); not profitable to any one; who falls short in everything upon which he enters; [like daniIRN;] (TA;) or falling short of accomplishing that which it behooves him to do: (AHeyth, T:) also, for the sake of rhyme, [by poetic license,] written mudano. (T.)

R. Q. 1 dahodaha dhdh dhdp
R. Q. 1. dahodaha, (JK, S, K,) inf. n. dahodahapN, (JK,) He rolled a stone down; (S,* K,* TA;) as also dahodaI, (S, K,) inf. n. dahodaApN and dihodaMCN: (S:) or he cast stones, or a thing, from a higher to a lower place. (JK.) ― -b2- And He turned over a thing, one part upon another; (K;) as also dahodaI. (TA.) ― -b3- And He collected together camels to drive them. (JK.)

R. Q. 2 tadahodaha tdhdh tdhdp
R. Q. 2. tadahodaha, said of a stone, (S, K,) &c., (S,) It rolled down; (S,* K,* TA;) as also tadahodaI. (S, K.) ― -b2- And hence, He, or it, was quick. (Har p. 108.)

UilRaA daho falaA daho AlA dh flA dh AlA dh flA dp
UilRaA daho falaA daho, (JK, and so in some copies of the K,) or UilRaA dahK falaA dahK, (As, IAar, S, TA, and so in copies of the K,) a saying of the Arabs, meaning If this thing be not now, it will not be after the present time: (As, S, K:) As says, I know not its origin, but I think it to be Pers., and to mean, if thou strike not him, or it, now, thou wilt not strike him, or it, ever: (S:) accord. to IAar, it is said to a man when he is at the point of accomplishing his want in respect of a creditor of his, or in respect of his blood-revenge, or in respect of paying honour to a friend of his; (TA;) and means if thou seize not the opportunity now, thou wilt never meet with it: (K, TA:) accord. to Lth, (TA,) it means, if thou avenge not his blood, or if thou slay him not in blood-revenge, now, thou wilt never do so. (JK, TA.) Accord. to As, one says also, laA dahK falaA dahK, meaning I will not accept either of the two actions proposed. (TA.) Az says that this saying shows dh to be Pers., and to mean The act of striking: you say to a man, diho↓, meaning Strike thou: and he says, I have seen it written with kesr in the book of AZ. (TA.) diho↓ in Pers. means Give thou: and metonymically, the act of striking. (TA.)

duho duho dh dh dh dp
duho duho A cry by which camels are chidden; (IAar, TA;) a cry by which camels are called to their young ones. (K in art. dwh.) ＝ -A2- duho durRayoni, or duho durRayono: see art. dhdr.

diho dh dp
diho: see daho, last two sentences.

dahodahapN dhdhh dhdhp
dahodahapN A hundred camels, and more; (JK, K;) as also dahodahaAnN↓ and duhayodihaAnN↓: (K:) or ↓the second of these three words signifies many camels. (JK, S.)

dahodahaAnN dhdhAn
dahodahaAnN: see what next precedes, in two places: and what next follows.

dahodaACN dhdAC
dahodaACN Small, or young, camels: (JK, S, K:) pl. dahaAdihu. (S, * K.) A rájiz says,
qulayRiSaAtK waOubayokiriynaA
qado rawiyato UilRaA duhayodihiynaA↓
[They had satisfied their thirst, except some small, or young, camels; little young she-camels and little young he-camels]: as though he formed from dahodaAhN the pl. dahaAdihu; and from this, the dim. duhayodihN; and from this, the pl. duhayodihiyna [in the nom. case duhayodihwuna]: (S, TA:*) and in like manner, Oubayokiriyna as pl. of OubayokirN, dim. of OabokurN, pl. of bakorN. (S.) [Accord. to a passage imperfectly written in the TA, it seems to signify also Many small, or young, camels; and so, as there written, dhdAn, app. for dahodahaAnN↓.] ― -b2- One says also, maA OadoriI OaIRN AldRahodaAhi huwa, (TA,) or AldRahodaOi and AldRahodaMCi, the last on the authority of Ks, meaning I know not what one of men he is. duhodurRN dhdr
duhodurRN a noun signifying What is false, or vain; a lie; syn. baATilN and kacibN: as also duhodurRayoni, (K,) its dual, (TA,) or duho durRayoni, or duho durRayono: (as in different copies of the S:) whence duhodurRayoni and duhodurRiyRapN↓ are epithets applied to a liar; or a great or habitual liar: and accord. to AZ, the Arabs used to say, duhodurRaAni laA yugoniyAani Eanoka XayoYFA [Lies will not avail thee aught]: and duhodunRN signifies the same as duhodurRN. (TA.) ― -b2- duhodurRayoni is also a noun, (K,) i. e. a verbal noun, (TA,) signifying He was, or has become, unoccupied, or without work; syn. baTala; (K;) like saroEaAna for saruEa, and hayohaAti for baEuda. (TA.) Hence the prov., (TA,) duhodurRayoni saEodu Alqayoni, (As, K,) without the conjunction wa [after the first word], and dhdrRyn being written as one word, (TA,) meaning Saad the blacksmith became, or has become, unoccupied, or without work; not being employed because of the people's being diverted from other things by drought (As, K) and distress. (TA.) Some say saAEdu Alqayoni: and Aboo-'Obeydeh Maamar Ibn-El-Muthennà relates it thus: dhdrRyn saEoda Alqayon, with sEd in the accus. case, and says that dhdrRyn is governed in the accus. case by a verb understood; apparently meaning that it is a noun signifying AlbaATilu, dual of duhodurRN, not a verbal noun, as though the prov. meant Cast ye away what is false, or vain, and Saad the blacksmith: but what he says is not correct. (TA.) Or a certain blacksmith asserted his name to be Saad
for some time, and then his lying became manifest; so this was said to him; meaning, Thou hast added falsehood to falsehood, O Saad the blacksmith. (K.) It is also related separately; (K;) and so J and others relate it; saying dh drRyn: (TA:) [in one copy of the S, I find it written duho durRayono: in another, duho durRayoni:] duho being an imperative from AldRahaMCu; its final radical letter being transposed to the place of the medial, so that it becomes duwoho, and the w being then rejected because of the two quiescent letters, (K,) so that it becomes duho, like as is done in the case of qulo: (TA:) and durRayoni being from darRa, “ it was consecutive; ” (K;) by the dual form being meant repetition, as in the case of labRayoka &c.: (TA:) so that the meaning is Be thou very lying (K) and cunning, (TA,) O Saad (K) the blacksmith: (TA:) and this explanation, says IB, is good, except inasmuch as that the d in drRyn thus derived should be with fet-h; or, he adds, it may be with damm to assimilate it to the d in duho [like as Alqayoni is terminated with kesr to assimilate it to durRayoni]. (TA.) Or the origin of the saying was this: Saad the blacksmith was a Persian, who went about the districts of ElYemen, working for the people; and when he became without work in a district, he used to say, in Persian, diho badoruwdo: [so in a copy of the S; and this, or diho bidoruwdo, is the correct reading: in another copy of the S, daho baduwrudo: and in the copies of the K, diho badoruwdo:] (S, K:*) meaning, [O town, or village,] farewell: to acquaint them that he was going forth on the morrow: (K:) or meaning I am going forth to-morrow: (S:) in order that he might be employed: and they arabicized the expression, and made him the subject of a prov. with respect to lying; and said, When ye hear of the blacksmith's departure at night, he is assuredly coming in the morning. (S, K.) Some say that the prov. is elliptical, for baTala qawolu saEodK Alx [False is the saying of Saad &c.]. (TA.) [This is mentioned in the S in art. dr.]
