dahorN dhr
dahorN (T, S, M, K, &c.) and daharN↓, (M, K,) the latter either a dial. var., agreeably with the opinion of the Basrees in cases of this kind, and therefore such cases are limited by the authority of hearsay, or it is so written and pronounced because of the guttural letter, and so is accordant to a universal rule, agreeably with the opinion of the Koofees, (ISd,) Time, from the beginning of the world to its end; (Esh-Sháfi'ee, Az, Msb, Er-Rághib;) as also HiynN: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, Az:) this is the primary signification: (Er-Rághib:) and any long period of time; (Z, Mgh, K, Er-Rághib;) thus differing from zamaAnN, which will be explained below: (Er-Rághib:) and a portion of the longest period of time: (Az:) or dahorN signifies, (S, A,) or signifies also, (Az, Msb,) time; or a time; or a space, or period, of time; syn. zamaAnN, (Sh, Az, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) whether long or short: (Msb:) or this is the proper signification of zamaAnN, but not of dahorN: (Er-Rághib:) and (tropical:) a division of the year: and (tropical:) a less period: (Az, Msb:) Az says, I have heard more than one of the Arabs say, OaqamonaA EalaI maMCi kacaA dahorFA [We stayed at such a water a long time, or a time]; and hecaA AlmaroEaI yakofiynaA dahorFA [This pasture-land will suffice us a long time, or a time]; but one does not say that AldRahoru is four times, or four seasons, because its application to (tropical:) a short period of time is tropical, and an extension of its proper signification: (Msb:) or it signifies i. q. OabadN [meaning a long unlimited time; or an extended indivisible space of time; or duration without end; time without end]; (S, Msb;) it differs from zamaAnN in having no end: (Khálid Ibn-Yezeed:) or a prolonged, or lengthened, term; syn. OabadN mamoduwdN: (K, in some copies of which, in the place of Abd, we find Oamad:) and (tropical:) the period, or duration, of life; an age: (Kull p. 183:) the present state of existence: (Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) a thousand years: (K:) pl. [of pauc.] OadohurN (K) and [of mult.] duhuwrN: (S, A, K:) both said to be pls. of dahorN, and no other pls. are known as those of daharN; the form OadohaArN not having been heard. (TA.) ― -b2- You say maDaI Ealayohi dahorN and duhuwrN [A long time and long times, or an age and ages, &c., passed over him, or it]. (A.) ― -b3- And kaAna celika dahora AlnRajomi That was in the time of God's creation of the stars; meaning, in the beginning of time; in ancient time. (A.) ― -b4- [And fiI OawRali AldRahori In the beginning of time. (A.) ― -b5- [And yaboqaI AldRahora It remains for ever. ― -b6- And laA Mtiyhi AldRahora I will not come to him, ever. See also daAhirN.] ― -b7- And SaAma AldRahora [He fasted ever, or always]. (TA in art. Awl, &c. [See a trad. cited voce Mla, in that art.]) ― -b8- [Hence, because, in one sense, time brings to pass events, good and evil,] AldRahoru was applied by the Arabs to Fortune; or fate: and they used to blame and revile it: and as the doing so was virtually blaming and reviling God, since events are really brought to pass by Him, Mohammad forbade their doing thus. (Az, Mgh, TA, &c.) It is said in a trad., laA tasubRuwA QldRahora faUinRa QldRahora huwa QllRehu, (S, Mgh, TA, &c.,) or, accord. to one reading, faUinRa QllRehu huwa QldRahoru, (Az, Mgh, TA, &c.,) in which some explain Aldhr in the first proposition as having a different meaning from that which it has in the second, whereas others assign to it the same meaning in both cases: (TA:) the meaning of the trad. is, Revile ye not [fortune, or] the Efficient of fortune; for the Efficient of fortune is God: (Az, S, TA, &c.:) or, accord. to the second reading, for God is the Efficient of fortune. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) some reckon AldRahoru as one of the names of God: (K, &c.:) but some disallow this: and some say that it is allowable if meant to signify, as rendered above, the Efficient of fortune. (TA, &c.) ― -b9- zawoju dahorK A husband prepared for the accidents or calamities of fortune. (S in art. bhr. [See bahorN.]) ― -b10- dahorN also signifies An evil event or accident; a misfortune; a calamity. (K.) See also dahaAriyru. [And see 1.] ― -b11- Also A purpose; an intention: (S, K:) a desire: (TA:) the scope, or end that one has in view. (K, TA.) You say, maA dahoriI bikacaA, (S, TA,) and maA dahoriI kacaA, (TA,) My purpose, or intention, (S, TA,) and my desire, and my scope, or the end that I have in view, (TA,) is not such a thing. (S, TA.) ― -b12- Also (tropical:) A custom, or habit, (S, K,) that is constant, or permanent, (Kull p. 183,) or that lasts throughout life. (TA.) You say, maA caAka bidahoriI (tropical:) That is not my custom, or habit, (S,) that lasts throughout my life: (TA:) and maA dahoriI bikacaA (tropical:) My habit throughout life is not so. (TA.)

[and written dihoqaAnu &c.], because of the measure fElAnu; (S;) [but this statement relates especially to the measure faEolaAn, with fet-h to the f; except in the case of a proper name; and an epithet of this measure, moreover, that forms its fem. by the addition of p, as dhqAn does, is perfectly decl.; and it should be observed also, that,] accord. to IJ, dhqAn is of the measure fElAl, from tadahoqana, and there is no instance, in the language, of the measure tafaEolana; (Har p. 102;) it signifies The headman, or chief, of a village or town: (Es-Sem'ánee, Msb, TA: [agreeably with the Pers. original:]) or the proprietor thereof, in Khurásán and El-' Irák: (Es-Sem'ánee, TA:) or, as used by the Arabs, a great man of the unbelievers of the ' Ajam [or Persians]: but they disdained this appellation: (Mgh:) Lth says that it is a nickname, or name of reproach: (TA:) it became predominantly applied to such of them as was of the people of the districts of cultivated land and of villages or towns: and then to anyone possessing much land or other immoveable property: (Mgh:) [it signifies generally a dweller, or one having a fixed abode, in a district of cultivated land, or in a village or town of such a district; a rustic; a husbandman:] or it signifies a chief, headman, or person in authority, over the husbandmen, or peasants, of the 'Ajam [or Persians]: and the headman of a province: (K:) and a possessor of land or other immoveable property: (Msb:) and a merchant: (Msb, K:) and one who manages affairs firmly, or strongly, with sharpness: (K:) the fem. is with p: (JK, Mgh, K:) and the pl. is dahaAqiynu (Msb, K) and dahaAqinapN. Oadohamu c
Oadohamu Black; (JK, S, * Mgh, Msb, * K;) as also duhaAmN↓: (K:) the former is applied in this sense to a horse, (S, * Mgh, Msb, * TA,) and to a camel, &c.: (TA:) or, applied to a camel, of a deep ashcolour without any tinge of white; (As, S, Msb, K;) when of a deeper hue, so as to be very black, he is termed jawonN: (S:) or, as some say, applied to a camel, like OaSofaru, [in this case meaning black with some intermixture of yellow,] but less black: (TA:) fem. dahomaMCu; which, when applied to a sheep (S, M, Msb, K) or goat, (S, Msb,) means of a pure or an unmixed brown colour (xaAliSapu AlHumorapi): (S, M, Msb, K:) pl. duhomN. (TA.) The Arabs say, muluwku Alxayoli duhomuhaA [The kings of horses are the black thereof]. (TA.) And farasN Oadohamu bahiymN A black horse in which is no intermixture of colours. (TA.) And laA Mtiyka maA HanRati AldRahomaMCu [I will not come to thee as long as she (among the camels) that is of a deep ash-colour without any tinge of white reiterates her yearning cry after her young one; meaning, ever]. (Lh, TA.) And ramaAdN Oadohamu Black ashes. (TA.) ― -b2- HadiyqapN dahomaMCu and mudohaAmRapN↓ (tropical:) [A walled garden] green inclining to black. (K.) Hence, (K,) mudohaAmRataAni↓, (S, K,) in the Kur [lv. 64], (S, TA,) [Two gardens (janRataAni)] of which the greenness inclines to blackness; for every green plant, when its abundance and its moisture, or irrigation, are complete, inclines to blackness: (Zj, TA:) or black by reason of intense greenness arising from abundant moisture, or irrigation; and everything that is green (OaxoDar) the Arabs term Oasowadu. (S, TA.) ― -b3- raboEN Oadohamu [A place of alighting or abode] recently occupied by the tribe; [because blackened by their fires &c.:] pl. OarobuEN duhomN. (TA.) And OavarN Oadohamu A new, or recent, mark, trace, or vestige: (As, K:) and Oagoyaru means one that is “old, becoming effaced:” (As, TA:) and the former means also old, becoming effaced; (K;) as some explain it; (TA;) thus having two contr. significations. (K.) And waToOapN dahomaMCu A new, or recent, footstep, or footprint: and gaboraMCu means “becoming effaced:” or the former means one that is becoming effaced, because it has become obscure to him who seeks it; (JK;) or an old footstep, or footprint: and HamoraMCu means one that is “new, or recent.” (S.) [See also Oagobaru.] ― -b4- AldRahomaMCu also signifies (tropical:) The cooking-pot: (JK, S, A, K:) or the black cooking-pot: (ISh, TA:) and the old cooking-pot. (K. [But it is implied in the TA that this last meaning is a mistake, occasioned by an omission; and that, instead of Alqidoru waAlqadiymapu, (in the CK Alqidoru Alqadiymapu,) we should read, Alqidoru waAlwaToOapu AldRahomaMCu Alqadiymapu, explained above. Accord. to Golius, on the authority of a gloss in the KL, Oabuw AlOadohami signifies The great cooking-pot in which a whole sheep is cooked at once.]) ― -b5- And The twenty-ninth night of the [lunar] month: (JK, K:) because of its blackness. (TA.) And
[the pl.] AldRuhomu Three nights of the [lunar] month [during which is the change of the moon]: (K:) because they are black. (TA.) ― -b6- See also AldRuhayomu. ― -b7- [Used as a subst.,] Oadohamu signifies also A shackle or fetter, or a pair of shackles or fetters; syn. qayodN: (S, K:) because of the blackness thereof: accord. to AA, of wood: (TA:) or a heavy shackle or fetter or a pair of shackles or fetters: syn. OadaAhimu: (S, K:) because of the blackform of pl., which is proper to substs., because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it. (TA.) ― -b8- And [the fem.] dahomaMCu signifies (assumed tropical:) A multitude, or large number: (K:) and (assumed tropical:) a company of men; (Ks, S, K; *) and multitude thereof: (Ks, TA:) or (tropical:) the generality, the common mass, or the main part [thereof]: (Z, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the commonalty, or common people. (Mbr, Har p. 671.) [See also dahomN.] ＝ -A2- Also, dahomaMCu, The aspect, appearance, mien, guise, or garb, of a man. (JK, S, * K.) ＝ -A3- And AldRahomaMCu A certain herb, or tree, green, and broad in the leaves; (JK;) or a certain broad herb, (K,) having leaves and twigs, resembling the qaronuwap; (TA;) with which one tans. (JK, K.)

3 mudaAhanahN mdAhn mdAhnh mdAhnp
3. mudaAhanahN and UidohaAnN↓ signify the same; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. (tropical:) The endeavouring to conciliate; syn. muSaAnaEapN: (S, TA:) or the making peace with another; or becoming reconciled with another: (Msb:) or the pretending the contrary of, or what is different from, that which one conceals in his mind: (K:) and the former signifies also the acting with dishonesty, or dissimulation: or ↓the latter has this signification; and the former signifies the striving to outwit, deceive, beguile, or circumvent; syn. muwaArabapN: (TA:) or daAhanotu signifies I hid, concealed, or covered; syn. waArayotu [accord. to four copies of the S; but probably this is a mistranscription for waArabotu, meaning I strove to outwit, deceive, beguile, or circumvent, as is indicated in the TA]; and Oadohanotu↓ signifies I acted with dishonesty, or dissimulation: (S:) or UidohaAnN↓ is [originally] like tadohiynN [as has been stated above]: but is used as denoting the act of treating with gentleness or blandishment, soothing, coaxing, wheedling, beguiling, or deluding; and abstaining from restraint or prohibition: (AHeyth, TA:) or it originally signified the anointing such a thing as a hide with some oil or the like: and as such a thing is rendered soft to the sense [of feeling], it was used tropically, or metaphorically, to denote ideal softness, absolutely: hence, the treating with gentleness or blandishment, soothing, coaxing, wheedling, beguiling, or deluding, was termed mudaAhanapN: then this tropical signification became commonly known, and conventionally regarded as proper: and then the word [mdAhnp or AdhAn↓, or rather each of these words,] was tropically used as signifying the holding a thing in light, or little, or mean, estimation, or in contempt: so in the 'Ináyeh. (MF, TA.) It is said in the Kur [lxviii. 9], wadRuwAlawo tudohinu fayudohinuwna↓ (tropical:) They wish that thou wouldst endeavour to conciliate [them], and in that case they will endeavour to conciliate [thee]: (S, TA: *) or that thou wouldst be soft, pliant, or gentle, in thy religion, and in that case they will be soft, pliant, or gentle: (TA:) or that thou wouldst be soft, pliant, or gentle, to them, and in that case they will be so to thee: (Jel:) or, accord. to Fr, that thou wouldst be an unbeliever, and they will be unbelievers. (TA.)

[What vice is] more grievous, (Mgh,) or worse, (TA,) [than niggardliness?] occurring in a trad.: and the saying of a woman, kulRu daMCK lahu daMCN, meaning Every vice that is in men is in him: (Lth, T, TA:) and mayRitu AldRaMCi One whose evilness is dead, (K and TA in art. blh,) so that he is not cognizant of it; (TA in that art.;) said of a person when he does not bear malice towards him who does evil to him. (AM, TA.) daMCu AlZRaboIi, (S, TA,) or daMCu ZaboIK, (M, TA,) [The disease of the gazelle, or of a gazelle,] accord. to AA, (M, TA,) means (assumed tropical:) health, or soundness, and briskness, or sprightliness; (TA;) or no disease; like as [it is said that] there is no disease in the gazelle: (S, M:) or, accord. to ElUmawee, binaA daMCu ZaboIK means that when he desires to leap, he pauses a little and then leaps: but A'Obeyd prefers the former explanation. (M.) daMCu Almuluwki [The disease of kings] means (assumed tropical:) the enjoyment of plenty and pleasure and softness or delicacy. (TA.) daMCu AlkiraAmi [The disease of the generous], (assumed tropical:) debt and poverty. (TA.) daMCu AlDRaraAYiri [The disease of fellow-wives], (assumed tropical:) constant evil. (TA.) daMCu AlbaToni. [The disease of the belly], (assumed tropical:) trial, or dissension, or the like, (Alfitonapu,) in which one cannot find the right way to act. daAYidN and mudiydN↓ and mudawRidN↓ (Msb) and maduwdN↓ (L) [the last from diyda, confirming my opinion that dayRada in some copies of the K is a mistranscription,] Corn, or food, (TaEaAmN,) having in it duwd [or worms, &c.]; (L, Msb;) and becoming eaten thereby. (L.)

maduwdN md mdwd
maduwdN: see what next precedes.

mudiydN mdyd
mudiydN: see what next precedes.

mudawRidN md mdwd
mudawRidN: see what next precedes.

1 daAra dAr dAry
1. daAra, aor. yaduwru, inf. n. daworN and dawaraAnN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and duWuwrN (M) and madaArN; (Lth, T;) and AstdAr↓; (M, A, Msb, K;) and AdAr↓; (M;) He, or it, went, moved, or turned, round; circled; revolved; returned to the place from which he, or it, began to move. (TA.) ― -b2- You say, daAruwA Hawolahu and AstdArwA↓ They went round it: (A:) and dAr Hawola Albayoti and AstdAr↓ He went round the house [or Kaabeh]. (Msb.) Z and others dislike the phrase dArbiAlbayoti, [which seems to have been used in the same sense as dAr Hawolahu,] preferring the phrase TaAfa biAlbayoti, because of the phrase dAr baAldRuwaAri, signifying He went round about in the circuit called AldRuwaAr, round the idol called by the same name. (TA.) [bihi AstdAr↓ mostly signifies It encircled, or surrounded, or encompassed, it.] ― -b3- [You say also, dAr bayonahumo It (a thing, as, for instance, a wine-cup) went round, or circulated, among them. And] dAr Alfalaku fiI madaArihi [The firmament, or celestial orb or sphere, revolved upon its axis]: (A:) dawaraAnu Alfalaki signifies the consecutive incessant motions of the several parts of the firmament. (Msb.) ― -b4- Hence the saying daArati AlmasoOalapu, [inf. n. daworN,] The question formed a circle; one of its propositions depending for proof upon another following it, and perhaps this upon another, and so on, and the latter or last depending upon the admission of the first. (Msb.) [And in like manner, dAr, inf. n. daworN, signifies He reasoned in a circle.] ― -b5- It is said in a trad., UinRa AlzRamaAna qadi QsotadaAra↓ kahayoYatihi yawoma xaloqi QllRehi AlsRamewaAti wa AlOaroDa [Verily time hath come round to the like of the state in which it was on the day of God's creating the heavens and the earth: this was said by Mohammad after he had forbidden the practice of intercalating a lunar month, by which the Arabs had long imperfectly adjusted their lunar year to the solar.] (TA.) And one says, daArati AlOayRaAmu [The days came round in their turns]. (S and Msb and K in art. dwl.) And yawomN laA yaduwru fiI Xahorihi [A day of the week that does not come round again in its month: as the last Wednesday, &c.]. (Mujáhid, TA voce dubaArN [q. v.].) [And dAr is said of an event, as meaning It came about. See an ex. in a verse cited in art. Ac.] ― -b6- dArbihi It went round with him; as the ground and the sea do [apparently] with a person sick by reason of vertigo, or giddiness in the head. (L in art. myd. [See also 4.]) ― -b7- One says also, bimaA fiI AstdAr↓ qalobiI (tropical:) He comprehended [as though he encircled] what was in my heart. (A.) ― -b8- And fulaAnN yaduwru EalaI OarobaEi nisowapK (tropical:) Such a one has within the circuit of his rule and care four wives, or women. (A.) And fulaAnN yaduwru Hawola fulaAnapa wayujamRiXuhaA (tropical:) [Such a man has within his power and care such a female, and toys, dallies, wantons, or holds amorous converse, with her]. (A and TA in art. HwD.) And OanaA Oaduwru Hawola celika AlOamori (tropical:) [I have within my compass, or power, and care, that thing or affair]. (S and A in art HwD.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in four places.

2 dwRrhu dAr dwr dwrh dwrp
2. dwRrhu, (K,) inf. n. tadowiyrN, (S,) He made it mudawRar [i. e. round, meaning both circular and spherical]; (S, K;) as also AdArhu↓. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4, in two places. ― -b3- [One says also, dwRr AlMraMCa fiI OamorK and AdArhA↓ (assumed tropical:) He turned about, or revolved, thoughts, or ideas, or opinions, in his mind, respecting an affair: like as one says, qalRaba Alfikara faI OamorK.]

3 dAwrhu dAwr dAwrh dAwrp
3. dAwrhu, inf. n. mudaAwarapN and diwaArN, He went round about with him; syn. daAra maEahu. (M, K.) ― -b2- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) He circumvented him.] Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
HatRaI OutiyHa lahu yawomFA bimaroqabapK
cuw mirRapK bidiwaAri AlSRayodu wajRaAsu
[Until there was prepared for him, one day, in a watching-place, an intelligent person, acquainted with the circumvention of game]: wjRAs is here made trans. by means of b because it means the same as EaAlimN in the phrase EaAlimN bihi. (M.) [Or the meaning of the latter hemistich is, a person possessing skill in circumventing game, attentive to their motions and sounds.] ― -b3- dAwrhu also signifies (assumed tropical:) He endeavoured to induce him to turn, or incline, or decline; or he endeavoured to turn him by deceit, or guile; Eani AlOamori from the thing; and Ealayohi to it; syn. laAwaSahu. (M, K.) It is said in the trad. respecting the night-journey [of Mo- hammad to Jerusalem, and his ascension thence into Heaven], that Moses said to Mohammad, laqado daAwarotu baniI UisoraAYiyla EalaI OadonaI mino hecaA faDaEufuwA [(assumed tropical:) Verily I endeavoured to induce the children of Israel to incline to less than this, and they were unable]: or, accord. to one relation, he said raAwadotu. (TA.) See also 4. ― -b4- daAwara AlOumuwra (tropical:) He sought to find the modes, or manners, of doing, or performing, affairs, or the affairs: (A:) AlmudaAwarapN is like AlmuEaAlajapN [signifying the labouring, taking pains, applying one's self vigorously, exerting one's self, striving, or struggling, to do, execute, or perform, or to effect, or accomplish, or to manage, or treat, a thing; &c.]. (S, K.) Suheym Ibn-Wetheel says,
Oaxuw xamosiyna mujotamiEN OaXudRiI
wanajRadaniI mudaAwarapu AlXRuWuwni
[Fifty years of age, my manly vigour full, and vigorous application to the management of affairs has tried and strengthened me]. (S.)

4 AdArhu OdAr OdArh UdArp AdArh AdArp dArI
4. AdArhu, (S, M, A, K,) and dwRrhu↓, (M, A, K,) and bihi daAra↓, (M, TA,) and bihi dwRr↓, (S, K,) and AadaAra bihi, and AstdAr↓, (M, K,) He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to go, move, or turn, round; to circle; to revolve; to return to the place from which he, or it, began to move. (TA.) You say, OadaAra AlEimaAmapa EalaI raOosihi [He wound the turban round upon his head]. (A.) And AdAr AlzRaEofaraAna fiI AlmaMCi [He stirred round the saffron in the water, in dissolving it]. (A and TA in art. dwm.) And
bihi dawaAYiru AlzRamaAni daArato↓
[The revolutions of fortune, or time, made him to turn round from one state, or condition, to another]. (A.) And bihi diyra↓, and Oudiyra bihi, (S, A, K,) and Ealayohi diyra↓ (K,) [the first and second lit. signifying He was made to turn round; by which, as by the third also, is meant] he became affected by a vertigo, or giddiness in the head. (S, * A, * K. [See also 1.]) ― -b2- AdArhu EalaI AlOamori He endeavoured [to turn him to the thing, i. e.] to induce him to do the thing: and AdArhu Eanohu he endeavoured [to turn him from it, i. e.] to induce him to leave, or relinquish, it; (T, A;) or i. q. laAwaSahu; as also daAwarahu↓, q. v. (M, K.) ― -b3- UidaArapN [the inf. n.] also signifies The giving and taking, from hand to hand, without delay: and agreeably with this explanation is rendered the phrase in the Kur [ii. 282], lijaArapN HaADirapN tudiyruwnahaA bayonakumo Ready merchandise, which ye give and take among yourselves, from hand to hand, without delay; i. e., not on credit]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 1: ― -b5- and 2, in two places.

5 tdyRr AlmakaAna tdyr AlmkAn
5. tdyRr AlmakaAna He took the place as a house, or an abode. (A.) [The I in this verb takes the place of w, as in dayorN and AayobapN &c.]

10 AstdAr AstdAr QstdAr
10. AstdAr [It had, or assumed, a round, or circular, form; it coiled itself, or became coiled; it wound, or wound round;] it was, or became, round. (KL.) You say, AstdAr Alqamaru [The moon became round, or full: see also the act. part. n., below]. (A.) And lafRato vawobFA kaQloEiSaAbapi EalaI QsotidaArapi raOosihaA [She wound a piece of cloth like the fillet upon the round of her head, leaving the crown uncovered]. (Mgh and L and Msb voce miEojarN.) ― -b2- See also 1, in six places. ― -b3- And see 4.

daArN dAr dAry
daArN, [originally dawarN, as will be seen below, A house; a mansion; and especially a house of a large size, comprising a court; or a house comprising several sets of apartments and a court; (see bayotN;)] a place of abode which comprises a building, or buildings, and a court, or space in which is no building: (T, M, K:) as also daArapN↓: (M, K:) or the latter is a more special term; (S;) meaning any particular house; the former being a generic term: (MF:) accord. to IJ, it is from daAra, aor. yaduwru; because of the many movements of the people in it: (M:) it is of the fem. gender: (S, Msb:) and sometimes masc.; (S, K;) as in the Kur xvi. 32, as meaning mavowaI, or mawoDiE, (S,) or as being a gen. n.: (MF:) pl. (of pauc., S) OadoWurN and OadowurN (S, Msb, K) and MdurN, (Abu-l- Hasan, AAF, Msb, K,) formed by transposition, (Msb,) [for OawodurN,] and OadowaArN (T, K) and OadoyaArN (T) and OadowirapN, (T, K,) and (of mult., S) diyaArN, (S, Msb, K,) like as jibaAlN is pl. of jabalN, (S,) and diwaArN (T) and diyaArapN (M, K) and duwrN, (T, S, M, Msb,) like as OusodN is pl. of OasadN, (S,) and diyraAnN (T, M, K) and duwraAnN (T, K) and diyarN and diyarapN, (T,) and [quasi-pl. n.] daArapN↓, and [pl. pl.] diyaAraAtN [pl. of diyaArN] and duwraAtN [pl. of duwrN], (M, K,) and [pl. of daArapN] daAraAtN. (T.) The dim. is duwayorapN↓. (Har p. 161.) [Hence, daAru AlDarobi The mint: &c.] ― -b2- Also Any place in which a people have alighted and taken up their abode; an abode; a dwelling. (T, Mgh.) Hence the present world is called daAru AlfanaMCi [The abode of perishableness; or the perishable abode]: and the world to come, daAru AlbaqaMCi [The abode of everlastingness; or the everlasting abode]; and daAru AlqaraAri [The abode of stability; or the stable abode]; and daAru AlsRalaAmi [The abode of peace, or of freedom evil]. (T.) [And hence, daAru AlHarobi: see HarobN.] [Hence, also,] daArN is applied to A burial-ground. (Nh from a trad.) ― -b3- [And hence,] AisotaOocino EalaI rabRiI fiI daArihi [Ask thou permission for me to go in to my Lord] in his Paradise. (TA from a trad. respecting intercession.) ― -b4- And saOuriykumo daAra AlfaAsiqiyna, in the Kur [vii. 142, I will show you the abode of the transgressors], meaning Egypt: or, accord. to Mujáhid, the abode to which the transgressors shall go in the world to come. (TA.) ― -b5- [Hence, also,] daArN signifies i. q. baladN [A country, or district: or a city, town, or village]. (Mgh, K.) ― -b6- And, with the art. Al, [El-Medeeneh;] the City of the Prophet. (K.) ― -b7- And hence, (TA,) daArN also signifies (tropical:) A tribe; syn. qabiylapN: (A, K:) for Oaholu daArK: (TA:) as also daArapN↓: (K:) pl. of the former, duwrN. (A, Msb.) You say, marRato binaA daAru baniI fulaAnK (tropical:) The tribe of the sons of such a one passed by us. (A.) And in the same sense dAr is used in a trad. in which it is said that there remained no dAr among which (fiyhaA) a mosque had not been built. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Mtr states that it is said to signify also A year; syn. HawolN; and if this be correct, which he does no hold to be the case, it is from AldRawaraAnu, like as HawolN is from AlHawalaAnu: or, as some say, i. q. dahorN [as meaning a long time, or the like]. (Har p. 350.) ＝ -A3- And AldRaAru is the name of A certain idol. (Msb, K.) ＝ -A4- [dAr and dyr explained by Freytag as meaning “ Medulla liquida in ossibus ” are mistakes for raArN and rayorN.]

daworN dAr dwr
daworN an inf. n. of daAra. (S, M, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence, The circumference of a circle: see takosiyrN.] ― -b3- And A turn, or twist, of a turban, (T, A,) and of a rope, or any other thing: (T:) pl. OadowaArN. (A.)

dayorN dyr
dayorN, originally with w; (T, S;) or originally thus, with I, (M, [and so accord. to the place in which it is mentioned in the A and Msb and K,]) as appears from the occurrence of the I in its pl. and in the derivative dayRaArN, for if the I were in this case interchangeable with w it would occur in other derivatives; (M;) [or this is not a valid reason, for dayRaArN is held by J to be originally dayowaArN, i. e. of the measure fayoEaAlN; and ISd himself seems in one place to express the same opinion; in like manner as dayRuwrN is held by the latter to be originally dayowuwrN; and tadayRara is evidently altered from tadawRara;] A convent, or monastery, (xAn,) of Christians: (M, K:) and also the SawomaEap [i. e. cloister, or cell,] of a monk: (A:) the pl. is OadoyaArN (S, M, K) and duyuwrapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rOosu AldRayori [lit. The head of the convent or monastery] is an appellation given to (tropical:) Any one who has become the head, or chief, of his companions. (IAar, S, A, K.)

daArapN dAr dArh dArp
daArapN: see daAYirapN, in two places. [Hence,] daArapN Alqamari The halo (haAalp) of the moon; (S, A, Msb, * K;) as also dawRaArap↓: (K * and TA in art. Hlq:) pl. daAraAtN. (Msb.) Dim. duwayorapN↓. (Har p. 609.) One says, fulaAnN wajohuhu mivolu daArapi Alqamari [Such a one's face is like the halo of the moon]. (TA.) And AlUisolaAmi HatRaI yaxoruja Alqamaru mino laA taxorujo Eano daAYirapi↓ daAratihi [Go not thou forth from the circle of ElIslám until the moon go forth from its halo]. (A.) ― -b2- Also A round space of sand; (K;) as also dayRrapN↓, incorrectly written in the K diyrap↓ (TA) [and in some copies dayorap]; and tadowirapN↓: pl. of the first daAraAtN and duwrN: (K:) and pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of the second dayRirN↓: (TA:) or daArapN signifies, accord. to As, a round tract of sand with a vacancy in the middle; as also duwrapN↓, or, as others say, daworapN↓, and dawRaArapN↓ and dayRirapN↓; and sometimes people sit and drink there. (T.) ― -b3- And Any wide space of land among mountains: (K:) it is reckoned among productive low lands: (AHn:) or a plain, or soft, tract of land encompassed by mountains: (A:) or a wide and plain space of land so encompassed: (As:) or i. q. buhorapN, except that this is always plain, or soft, whereas a dArp may be rugged and plain, or soft: (Aboo-Fak'as, Kr:) or any clear and open space among sands. (TA.) ― -b4- And Any place that is surrounded and confined by a thing. (T, A.) ― -b5- See also daArN, in three places. ＝ -A2- daArapu, determinate, (M, K,) and imperfectly decl., (M,) Calamity, or misfortune. (Kr, M, K.)

daworapN dAr dwr dwrh dwrp
daworapN: see daArapN: ＝ -A2- and see also daAYirapN.

duwrapN dAr dwr dwrh dwrp
duwrapN: see daArapN.

diyrapN dAr dyr dyrh dyrp
diyrapN: see daArapN.

daAriIRN dAr dArI dAry dAryy
daAriIRN A man (A) who keeps to his house; (M, K;) who does not quit it, (M, A,) nor seek sustenance; (M;) as also daAriyRapN↓. (K.) ― -b2- And hence, (S,) (assumed tropical:) A possessor of the blessings, comforts, or conveniences, of life: (S, K:) pl. daAriyRuwna. (S.) ― -b3- Also A camel, or sheep or goat, that remains at the house, not going to pasture: fem. with p: (A:) or a camel that remains behind in the place where the others lie down; (M, K;) and so a sheep or goat. (M.) ― -b4- See also dayRaArN. ＝ -A2- A sailor that has the charge of the sail. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- A seller of perfumes: so called in relation to Dáreen, (S, A, K,) a port of ElBahreyn, in which was a market whereto musk used to be brought from India. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., mavalu Aljaliysi AlSRaAliHi mavalu AldRaAriIRi Uino lamo yuHocika mino EiTorihi Ealiqaka mino riyHihi [The similitude of the righteous companion who sits and converses with one is that of the seller of perfumes: if he give not to thee of his perfume, somewhat of his sweet odour clings to thee]. (S.)

duwriIRN dAr dwr dwrI dwry dwryy
duwriIRN: see dayRaArN.

daAriyRapN dAr dAry dAryh dAryp
daAriyRapN: see daAriIRN.

dayoraAniIRN dyrAnI dyrAny
dayoraAniIRN (anomalous [as a rel. n. from dayorN], M) and dayRaArN↓ The master, (SaAHib, S, M, K,) or an inhabitant, (T, A,) of a dayor [i. e. convent, or monastery]. (T, S, M, A, K.)

dawaArN dwAr
dawaArN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

duwaArN dwAr
duwaArN A vertigo, or giddiness in the head; (S, * A, * K;) as also dawaArN↓. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- Also, and dawaArN↓, (S,) or AldRuwaAru and AldRawaAru↓, (T, M, K,) and (but less commonly, TA) AldRuwRaAru↓ and AldRawRaAru↓, (M, K,) A certain idol, (T, S, M, K,) which the Arabs set up, and around it they made a space, (T,) round which they turned, or circled: (T, M:) and the same name they applied to the space above mentioned: (T, M:) it is said that they thus compassed it certain weeks, like as people compass the Kaabeh: (MF:) or certain stones around which they circled, in imitation of people compassing the Kaabeh. (IAmb.) Imra-el- Keys says,
EacaAraI duwaArK fiI mulaMCK mucayRali
[Virgins making the circuit of Duwár, in
long-skirted garments of the kind called mulaMC]: (S:) likening a herd of [wild] cows to damsels thus occupied and attired, alluding to the length of their tails. (TA.) AldRuwRaAru↓ and AldRawRaAru↓ also signify The Kaabeh. (Kr, M, K.) And duwRaArN↓ (Th, M, [not duwRaArapN, as is implied in the K,]) A circling tract (musotadaAr↓) of sand, around which go the wild animals: (Th, M, K:) a poet says,
bidRuwaAri nihoI ciI EaraArK waHulRabi
[In the sandy tract around a pool of water left by a torrent, containing plants of the kinds called 'arár and hullab]. (Th, M.)

duwayorapN dwyrh dwyrp
duwayorapN: see daArN and daArapN, of each of which it is the dim.

dayRirN dyr
dayRirN: see daAarpN.

dayRirapN dAr dyr dyrh dyrp
dayRirapN: see daAarpN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also daAYirapN.

dawRaArN dwAr
dawRaArN [Turning round, circling, or revolving,] applied to the firmament, or celestial orb. (A.) ― -b2- Applied likewise to time, or fortune; (M, K;) as also dawRaAriIRN↓, (S, M, A, K,) which is said to be a rel. n., but is not so accord. to AAF, though having the form thereof, like kurosiIRN, (M,) the I being a corroborative: (Msb voce waHoXiIRN:) thus in the saying,
waAldRahoru biQloUinosaAni dawRaAriIRu↓
(S, M, * A, * K, *) occurring in a poem of El-'Ajjáj, (S,) and dawRaArN, (M, K,) i. e. And time, or fortune, turns man about from one state, or condition, to another: (S, M, * A, K: *) or turns him about much. (Msb in art. wHX.) ＝ -A2- See also duwaArN, in two places.

duwRaArN dwAr
duwRaArN: see duwaArN, in three places.

maA biAldRaAri dayRaArN mA bAldAr dyAr
maA biAldRaAri dayRaArN, (S, M, A, K,) originally dayowaArN, of the measure fayoEaAlN, (S,) and duwriIRN↓, (S, M, K,) and dayRiwrN↓, (M, K,) in which a w is changed into I, (M,) [dyRwr being originally dayowuwrN,] and daAriIRN↓, There is not in the house any one: (S, M, K:) the broken pl. of dayRaArN and dayRuwrN is dawaAwiyru; the w being unchanged because of its distance from the end of the word. (M.) ISd says, in the EawiyS, that Yaakoob has erred in asserting dyRAr to be used only in negative phrases; for Dhu-r-Rummeh uses it in an affirmative phrase. (MF.) ― -b2- See also dayoraAniIRN.

dayRuwrN dywr
dayRuwrN: see the next preceding paragraph.

dawRaArapN dwAr dwArh dwArp
dawRaArapN: see daArapN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also duwRaArapN, in two places: ― -b3- and daAYirapN. ― -b4- Also [or perhaps duwRaArapN↓] The pieces of wood which the water turns so as to make the mill turn with their turning. (Mgh.) ― -b5- And A pair of compasses. (T, K, * TA.)

duwRaArapN dwAr dwArh dwArp
duwRaArapN and dawRaArapN↓, of the head, A round part or portion. (M, K.) ― -b2- And of the belly, What winds, or what has, or assumes, a coiled, or circular, form, (maA taHawRaI, [so in the M and L, in the K mAyaHowiI, which is evidently a mistake,]) of the guts, or intestines, of a sheep or goat. (M, L, K. *) ― -b3- Accord. to IAar, (T,) dawRaArapN↓ and fawRaArapN are applied to Anything [round] that does not move nor turn round: and duwRaArapN and fuwRaArapN to a thing that moves and turns round. (T, K, TA.) ― -b4- See also dawRaArapN.

dawRaAriIRN dwAr dwArI dwAry dwAryy
dawRaAriIRN: see dawRaArN, in two places.

daAYirapN c
daAYirapN, in which the p is added for the purpose of transferring the word from the category of epithets to that of substs, and as a sign of the fem. gender, ('Ináyeh,) The circuit, compass, ambit, or circumference, of a thing; (T, K, TA;) as in the phrases daAYirapu AlHaAfiri the circuit of, or what surrounds, the solid hoof, (TA,) or the circuit of hair around the solid hoof, (T,) and daAYirapu Alwajohi the circuit of the face, or the parts around the face; (TA;) and daArapN↓ signifies the same: (K:) pl. of the former dawaAYiru; and of the latter daAraAtN. (TA.) [Hence one says, hecaA OawosaEu daAYirapF mino caAka, meaning (assumed tropical:) This is wider in compass, or more comprehensive, than that. See also 10, third sentence.] ― -b2- A ring: (M, K:) or the like thereof; a circle: and a round thing: as also daArapN↓; pl. as above. (T.) See an ex. voce daArapN. ― -b3- The circular, or spiral, curl of hair upon the crown of a man's head: (T, M, K:) or the place of the duWaAbap. (IAar, M, K.) Hence the prov., maA QqoXaEarRato lahu daAYiratiI [The circular, or spiral, curl of hair upon the crown of my head did not stand erect on account of him]: said of him who threatens thee with a thing but does not harm thee. (M.) ― -b4- [What is called, in a horse, A feather; or portion of the hair naturally curled or frizzled, in a spiral manner or otherwise]: pl. dawaAYiru. (T, S, Msb.) In a horse are eighteen dwAYr, (AO, T, S,) which are distinguished by different names, as AlqahoEapu and AlqaAliEu and AlnRaAxisu and AllRaTaApu [&c.]. And Alxayolu taduwsu AlqatolaI biAlHawaAfiri [The horses trample upon the slain with the hoofs]. (A.) ― -b2- daAsa AlTRaEaAma, (S, A,) or AlHinoTapa, (Msb,) or AlHabRa, (M,) aor. yaduwsu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. dyaAsapN, (S, A, Mgh,) or dawosN and diyaAsN, but some say that diyaAsN is not of the language of the Arabs, and some say that it is tropical, as though from daAsa in the
sense explained above, (Msb,) or the professors of practical religion use it in the place of diyaAsapN by a kind of license, relying upon the understanding of the hearer or reader, or do so erroneously, (Mgh,) He trod, or thrashed, (M, Mgh, Msb,) the wheat, (Mgh, Msb,) or grain, (M,) either by the feet of beasts, or by repeatedly drawing over it the midowas [q. v. infrà] until it became tibon [or cut straw]; (Mgh;) as also OadaAsahu↓. (M.) You say, daAsuwhu dawosa AlHaSiydi [They trod, or trampled, upon him, or it, with the treading of reaped corn]. (A.) ― -b3- daAsahu, (IAar, TA,) inf. n. dawosN, (IAar, A, K,) He abased him. (IAar, A, K.) ― -b4- nazala AlEaduwRu bibaniI fulaAnK fajaAsahumo waHaAsahumo wadaAsahumo The enemy [came upon and] slew the sons of such a one, and went through the midst of their dwellings, and made havoc among them. (TA.) ― -b5- daAsahaA, (A, TA,) inf. n. dawosN, (A, K,) (tropical:) Inivit eam; scil., feminam: (A:) vehementer inivit eam: (A, K: [in the former, this signification is given as proper, though that immediately preceding is said to be tropical: in the TA, the latter is said to be tropical:]) conscendit et vehementer inivit eam. (TA.) ― -b6- daAsahu, (S, M, A, Msb,) inf. n. dawosN, (Msb, K,) or diyaAsN, (As, A, Mgh,) (tropical:) He polished it; namely, a sword, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the like, (K,) or some other thing. (Msb.) ― -b7- Hence, dawosN also signifies (tropical:) The framing, and dressing up, of deceit, guile, or circumvention: (As, A, TA:) [agreeably with which explanation the verb, daAsa, is probably used, though not mentioned in the A nor in the TA:] or simply, the act of deceiving, beguiling, circumventing, and practising artifice. (TA.) You say, OaxaconaA fiI AldRawosi (tropical:) We set about the framing, and dressing up, of deceit, guile, or circumvention: (A:) or we set about deceiving, &c. (TA.)

(IDrd, TA.) ― -b3- And dAkhu, (IDrd, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. dawokN, (IDrd,) He plunged him (a man) in water or dust. (IDrd, K.) ― -b4- And i. q. OasarRahu [He made him captive; &c.]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- dAk Alqawomu The people, or party, fell into a state of confusion (K, TA) in respect of their case, or affair, and went round about [in perplexity]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The people, or party, became diseased, or sick. (Abu-r-Rabeea El-Bekráwee, Aboo-Turáb, K.)

1. daAla i. q. daAra. (TA.) You say, dAlti AlOayRaAmu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. taduwlu, (Msb,) inf. n. dawolN, (KL,) meaning daArat; (S, Msb, K;) [i. e.] The days came round [in their turns]. (KL.) ― -b2- dawolN also signifies The changing of time, or fortune, from one state, or condition, to another; (K;) and so dawolapN. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, dAlt lahu AldRawolapu [The turn of fortune was, or became, in his favour; or] good fortune came to him: and dAlt Ealayohi AldRawolapu [The turn of fortune was, or became, against him; or] good fortune departed from him. (MA.) ― -b3- [Golius assigns to dAl, with dawolapN for its inf. n., as on the authority of the S and KL, two significations app. from two meanings of dawolapN, one of which he seems to have misunderstood, and to neither of which do I find any corresponding verb: they are “ Obivit alter alterum in bello: ” and “ superior evasit. ” There are many inf. ns. that have no corresponding verbs.] ― -b4- dAl, aor. yaduwilu, (T, K,) inf. n. dawolN and daAlapN, (K,) or dawolapN, (T,) He became notorious [either in a bad or in a good sense]; expl. by SaAra XuhorapF, (IAar, T, K,) i. e. maXohuwrFA. (TK.) ― -b5- dAl AlvRawobu, aor. yaduwlu, The garment, or piece of cloth, was, or became, old, and worn out. (AZ, S.) [Hence,] jaEala wudRuhu yaduwlu (tropical:) His love, or affection, was beginning to become, or at the point of becoming, worn out. (AZ, S, TA.) ― -b6- See also 7.

3 dAwl dAwl
3. dAwl, [inf. n. mudaAwalapN,] He made to come round [by turns, or to be by turns]: hence the saying in the Kur [iii. 134], w tiloka AloOayRaAmu nudaAwiluhaA bayona AlnRaAsi And those days, we make them to come round [by turns] to men: (S, * K, * TA:) or this means, we dispense them by turns to men; (Bd, Jel;) to these one time, and to these another; (Bd;) or one day to one party, and one day to another. (Jel.) You say, daAwalotu AlXRaIoCa bayonahumo fatadaAwaluwhu↓ [I dispensed the thing among them by turns, and they had, or received, or took, it by turns]. (Bd on the passage of the Kur quoted above.) mudaAwalapN also signifies The giving a turn of fortune, or good fortune. (KL. [See what next follows.])

4 AdAlhu OdAl OdAlh AdAlh AdAlp
4. AdAlhu, (M, K,) inf. n. UidaAlapN, (T, TA,) [signifying He gave him a turn of good fortune, or a turn to prevail over another in war, &c.,] is from AldRawolapu. (T, M, K, TA. [See what next precedes.]) Hence, [in the CK from AldRuwlap,] the saying, OadaAlanaA QllRehu mino EaduwRinaA [God gave us, or may God give us, a turn to prevail over our enemy]. (S, K.) And OadaAlaka QllRehu mino EaduwRika and EalaI EaduwRika, i. e. jaEala laka Ealayohi dawolapF [May God appoint thee, or give thee, a turn to prevail over thine enemy]. (Ham p. 547.) And AdAl QllRehu zayodFA mino EamorKw [God gave to Zeyd a turn to have the superiority over 'Amr;] i. e. God took away the turn of good fortune, or the good fortune, (Aldwlp,) from 'Amr, and gave it to Zeyd. (Har p. 118.) Hence, also, (TA,) El-Hajjáj said, UinRa AlOaroDa satudaAlu minRaA kamaA OudilonaA minohaA [Verily the earth will be given (?) turn to prevail over us, like as we have been given a turn to prevail over it]; (Lth, T, TA;) meaning that it will consume us, like as we have consumed [of] it. (T, TA.) And [hence] UidaAlapN signifies galabapN [or Victory]: (S, K:) or [rather], as some say, it signifies nuSorapN [i. e. aid against an enemy]: (Har ubi suprà:) you say, AallRehuma OadiloniI EalaI fulaAnN O God, aid me against such a one. (S, and Har ubi suprà. [In the former, waQnoSuroniIEalayohi, as an explicative adjunct: in the latter, AI nSRirnI Elyh, for QnoSuroniI.])

And tadaAwalonaA AlEamala wa AlOamorabayonanaA We did the work, and the thing, or affair, by turns, among us. (T.) And tadaAwaluwA AlbaATila They took it by turns to say, or to do, that which was false, wrong, vain, futile, or the like; syn. tabaTRaluwA bayonahumo. (Az and K in art. bTl.) And tadaAwalatohu AlOayodiI The hands took it by turns. (S.) And tadaAwalati AlrRiyaAHu rasoma AldRaAra The winds blew by turns upon, or over, the remains that marked the site of the house [so as to efface them]; one time from the south, and another time from the north, and another time from the east, and another time from the west. (Az, TA in art. Ewr.) And, of a thing, you say, yutadaAwalu (T) or yutadaAwalu bihi (S) [meaning It is taken, or done, by turns]. And tuduwowilati AlOaroDu biAlrRaEoIi [The land was pastured on by turns]. (S and K in art. wZb.) [tadaAwaluwhu also signifies They made frequent use of it; i. e., used it time after time, or turn after turn; namely, a word or phrase: but perhaps in this sense it is postclassical: see an ex. in De Sacy's “ Chrest. Arabe, ” sec. ed., p. 141 of the Arabic text.] And tadaAwalati AlOaXoyaMCu The things alternated; or succeeded one another by turns, one taking the place of another: (L in art. nsx:) and [in like manner] AlOazomanapu [the times]. (Msb and K in that art.) [See also 6 in art dfw.]
