dawolapN dwlh dwlp
dawolapN A turn, mutation, change, or vicissitude, of time, or fortune, (K, TA,) from an unfortunate and evil, to a good and happy, state or condition; (TA;) [i. e.,] relating to good; as daborapN, on the contrary, relates to evil: (As, T and M in art. dbr:) [therefore meaning a turn of good fortune; a favourable turn of fortune: or] good fortune [absolutely]: (KL:) a happy state or condition, that betides a man: (MF:) [also] a turn which comes to one or which one takes [in an absolute sense]; syn. nawobapN: (K in art. nwb:) and [particularly] (K) a turn (EuqobapN) [to share] in wealth, and [to prevail] in war; as also duwlapN↓: ('Eesà Ibn-'Omar, * T, * S, * M, K: *) or each is a subst. [in an absolute sense, app. as meaning a turn of taking, or having, a thing,] from tadaAwaluwA AlXRaIoCa signifying “ they took, or had, the thing by turns: ” (Msb:) or duwlapN↓ is in wealth; and dawolapN is in war; (Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, T, S, M, Msb, K;) this latter being when one of two armies defeats the other and then is defeated; (Fr, T;) or when one party is given a turn to prevail (tudaAl) over the other: one says, kaAnato lanaA Ealayohimu AldRawolapu fiI AlHarobi [The turn to prevail over them in war was ours]: (S:) and qado rajaEati AldRawolapu EalaI heWulaMCi [The turn to prevail against these returned]; as though meaning AlmarRapu: so says Fr: but duwlapN↓, he says, is in religions and institutions that are altered and changed with time: (T:) accord. to Zj, (T,) or A'Obeyd, (so in two copies of the S,) duwlapN↓ signifies a thing that is taken by turns; and dawolapN, the act [of taking by turns]; (T, S;) and a transition from one state, or condition, to another: (T: [in this last sense, app. an inf. n.: see 1, third sentence:]) you say, bayonahumo SaAra AlfaIoCu duwlapF↓, meaning [The fIC
(or spoil, &c.,) became] a thing taken by turns among them: (S:) and the saying, in the Kur [lix. 7], bayona AlOagoniyaMCi minokumo kaIo laA yakuwna duwlapF↓ means That it may not be a thing taken by turns [among the rich of you]: (T:) or dawolapN relates to the present life or world; and duwlapN↓, to that which is to come: (M, K:) and it is said that the former of these two words signifies prevalence, predominance, mastery, or victory; and ↓the latter, the transition of wealth, blessing, or good, from one people, or party, to another: (TA:) the pl. (of dawolapN, S, Msb) is dawilN, (S, M, Msb, K,) like as qiSaEN is pl. of qaSoEapN, (Msb,) and (of duwlapN↓, T, S, Msb), duwalN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and duwlaAtN, (S, TA,) and dawalN↓ (M, K) is [a quasi-pl. n.] of both, because, as IJ says, dawolapN is regarded as though it were originally duwlapN. (M.) ― -b2- [In post-classical works, it signifies also A dynasty: and a state, an empire, or a monarchy.] ＝ -A2- Also The HawoSalap [or stomach of a bird; its triple stomach: or only its first stomach; the crop, or craw]: because of its AinodiyaAl [or flaccidity]. (Ibn-'Abbaád, K.) And The qaAniSap [which may here mean the same as the HwSlp, for this is one of the meanings assigned to it, and this explanation of dwlp is not given by Ibn- 'Abbád: or it may here mean the intestines, of a bird, into which the food passes from the stomach: or the gizzard]. (K.) ― -b2- And The XiqoXiqap [or faucial bag of the he-camel]. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- And A thing like a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] with a narrow mouth. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b4- And The side of the belly. (K.) [But] accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, maA OaEoZama dawolapa baTonihi means How large is his navel! (TA.)

dwulapN dwlh dwlp
dwulapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in nine places: ― -b2- and see also what next follows, in two places.

duwalapN dwlh dwlp
duwalapN (T, S, K) and diwalapN↓ (Ibn-'Abbád, TA) [and duwlapN↓, as appears from what follows]; as also tuwalapN (T, S) [and tiwalapN and tuwalpN]; A calamity, or misfortune: (T, Ibn-'Abbád, S, K:) pl. duwalaAtN (S) and diwalaAtN and duwalaAtN. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) You say, jaMCa biduwalaAtihi (S) [and bidiwalaAtihi↓] and biduwlaAtihi↓ (Ibn-'Abbad, TA) and biduwlaAhu↓, as also bituwlaAhu, (Aboo-Málik, K,) He, or it, came with, or brought, or brought to pass, his, or its, calamities, or misfortunes: (Ibn-'Abbád, S, K. *)

diwalapN dwlh dwlp
diwalapN: and jaMCabidawalaAtihi: see duwalapN.

jaMCa biduwlaAhu jMC bdwlAh jMC bdwlAp
jaMCa biduwlaAhu: see duwalapN.

dawiylN dwyl
dawiylN A plant that is a year old, (S, M, K,) and dry: (M, K:) or two years old, (AZ, K,) and worthless: (AZ, TA:) or especially what is dry of the [plants called] naSiIR and sabaT: (M, K, * TA:) or any plant broken and black. (TA.)

dawaAliIRu dAlyp dwAlI dwAly
dawaAliIRu A sort of grapes of Et-Táïf, (M, K,) black inclining to redness. (M.) [See also dawaAlK, in art. dlw.]

dawaAlayoka dAlyp dwAlyk
dawaAlayoka i. q. mudaAwalapF, [in the CK, erroneously, mutadAwalapF,] used in an imperative sense [with its verb and the objective complement thereof understood before it, and thus meaning daAwili AlfiEola mudaAwalapF Make thou the action to come round, or to be, by turns]: (M, K:) or it may be rendered as meaning that the thing happened in this manner [i. e. the action being made to come round, or to be, by turns]: (Sb, M:) or it means tadaAwulN baEoda tadaAwul [i. e. a taking, or doing, (a thing) by turn after (another's) doing so, and may be rendered virtually in the same manner as above, i. e. let the action be done by turns: or the action being done by turns]: (S, O, K: [in the PS, tadaAwulFA baEoda tadaAwulK, which better explains the two manners in which it is said to be used:]) IAar says that it is an invariable expression, like HajaAzayoka and hacaAcayoka; and is from the phrase tadaAwaluwA AlOamora bayonahumo, said of persons when this takes a turn and this a turn. (T, TA.) 'Abd-Beni-l- Has-hás says,
Uica XuqRa burodN XuqRa biAlburodi mivoluhu
dawaAlayoka HatRaI layosa liloburodi laAbisu
[When a burd (a kind of garment) is rent, the like thereof is rent with the burd, the action being done by turns, so that there is no wearer of the burd; it having been rent so as to fall off]: (S:) the poet is speaking of a man's rending the clothing of a woman to see her person, and her rending his also. (T, TA. [This verse is related with several variations: see another reading of it voce hacaAcayoka, in art. hc; with another explanation of it.]) ― -b2- Ibn-Buzurj says, (T,) sometimes the article Al is prefixed to it, so that one says AldRawaAlayoka, (T,) meaning One's walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side, (T,) or one's urging, or pressing forward, and striving, (Oano yataHafRaza, [in the CK, erroneously, An yataHafRaza,]) in his gait, or pace, (K,) when he moves about his shoulder-joints, and parts his legs widely, in walking. (T, K,* TA. In the copies of the K, jAl [or jACk] is erroneously put for HaAka, the reading in the T, TA. [The author of the TK follows the reading jAl; and has fallen into several other evident mistakes in explaining this expression; which is itself, in my opinion, when with the article Al, a mistake for AldRawaAliyoku, mentioned in art. dlk.]) A poet uses the phrase yamoXiI AldRawaAlayoka as meaning Walking, or going, in the manner explained above: (Ibn-Buzurj, T and TA in the present art.:) or yamoXiI AldRawaAliyka. (TA in art. dlk.)

munodaAlN mndAl
munodaAlN as meaning Dangling, or moving to and fro; and hanging; is said by Seer to be of the measure munofaEilN from AltRadalRaI, and formed by transposition; and if so, it has no inf. n.; for the word that is formed by transposition has no inf. n. (M. [But for this assertion I see no satisfactory reason.])

mutadawaAlN mtdwAl
mutadawaAlN: see dawalN. ― -b2- [AlkalaAmu AlmutadaAwalu signifies, in modern Arabic, The language commonly used.]

duwlaAbN dwlAb
duwlaAbN, or dawolaAbN: see art. dlb.

1 daAma dAm dAmy
1. daAma, aor. yaduwmu and yadaAmu; (S, M, Msb, K;) the see. pers. of the pret. when the aor. is yaduwmu being dumota; and when the aor. is yadaAm, dimota; (M;) and accord. to Kr, (M,) you say also dimota, aor. taduwmu, which is extr., (M, K,) and not of valid authority, held by the lexicologists [in general] to be anomalous like mitRa having for its aor. tamuwtu, and faDila of which the aor. is yafoDulu, and HaDira of which the aor. is yaHoDuru, and said by Aboo-Bekr to be a compound of the pret. of which the aor. is tadaAmu with the aor. of which the pret. is dumota; (M;) inf. n. dawomN and dawaAmN [which is the most common form] and dayomuwmapN [originally dayowamuwmapN, like qayoduwdapN originally qayowaduwdapN, &c.]; (S, M, Msb, K;) i. q. vabata [as meaning It (a thing, S, M, Msb) continued, lasted, endured, or remained]: (Msb, TK:) and it became extended, or prolonged; syn. AimotadRa: (TK:) and [it continued, lasted, endured, or remained, long;] its time was, or became, long: (TA:) and i. q. baqiIa [as syn. with vabata (explained above) and as meaning it continued, lasted, or existed, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever; it was, or became, permanent, perpetual, or everlasting]: (Msb in art. bqI:) and AstdAm↓ signifies the same as dAm [in all of these senses]: (TA:) [but Mtr says,] AstdAm AlsRafaru [The journey continued, or continued long,] is not of established authority. (Mgh.) [Hence, daAma mulokuhu May his dominion be of long continuance.] And dAm EalaI AlOamori; (MA;) and Ealayohi dAwm↓, [and dAwmhu↓, as is shown by a usage of the act. part. n. in art. dmn in the S, &c.,] (S, * MA,) inf. n. mudaAwamapN; (S;) He kept continually, or constantly, to the thing, or affair. (S, MA.) maA daAma means Continuance; because mA is a conjunct noun to dAm; and it is not used otherwise than adverbially, like as inf. ns. are used adverbially: you say, laA Oajolisu maA dumota qaAYimFA, i. e., dawaAma qiyaAmika [I will not sit during the continuance of thy standing]; (S, TA;) [or as long as thou standest; or while thou standest; for] mA denotes time; and qumo maA daAma zayodN qaAYimFA means mudRapa qiyaAmi zayodK [i. e. Stand thou during the period of Zeyd's standing]. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) [And EalaIAldRawaAmi means Continually, or constantly; like daAYimFA.] ― -b2- Said of rain, it means It fell, or descended, consecutively, continuously, or constantly. (Msb.) Some say, (M,) daAmati AlsRamaMCu, aor. tadiymN, inf. n. dayomN, (M, K,) which, if correct, should be included in art. dym, (M,) meaning The sky rained continually; as also dawRamat↓ and dayRamat, (M, K,) in which last the w is changed into I as it is in diymapN, (M,) and AdAmt↓: (K:) or rained such rain as is termed diymap; (M in art. dym;) and so dayRamat↓, inf. n. tadoyiymN; (S in art. dym;) and AdAmt↓. (Z, TA.) [See also dawomN, below.] IAar cites the following verse, (M, TA,) by Jahm Ibn-Shibl, (TA in this art.,) or Ibn-Sebel, (TA in art. sbl, in which, also, the verse is cited,) in praise of a horse, as is said in “ the Book of Plants ” of Ed-Deenäwaree, and in
“ the Book of Horses ” of Ibn-El-Kelbee, not, as J asserts it to be, in praise of a munificent man, (TA,)
huwa AljawaAdu bonu AljawaAdi boni sabalo
jaAda wa Uino jaAduwA wabalo Uino dayRamuwA↓
[He is the fleet, the son of the fleet, the son of Sebel (a famous mare): if they are unremitting in their running, (the masc. pl. being here used, though relating to horses, in like manner as it is used in the Kur xli. 20,) he is fleet; and if they are fleet, he is vehement in his running]: or, as some relate it, Uino dawRamuwA. (M, TA. [It should be observed that the three verbs in this verse, and the word sbl, also relate to rain.]) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (a thing, T) was, or became, still, or motionless; said of water (T, S, * Msb, K, * TA) left in a pool by a torrent, and of the boiling of a cooking-pot; (Msb;;) and said, in this sense, of the sea: (M:) and it stopped, or stood still. (T, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, tired, or fatigued: (T, TA:) [app. because he who is so stops to rest.] ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) went round, revolved, or circled: (T, TA:) [app. because that which does so keeps near to one place.] dawamaAnN [an inf. n. of daAma like as HawamaAnN is of HaAma,] signifies (tropical:) The circling of a bird (K, TA) around water. (TA. [But in my MS. copy of the K, and in the CK, in the place of AldRawamaAnu I find AldRawamaMCu↓. See also 2.]) [Hence,] diyma bihi (tropical:) He was taken, or affected, with a vertigo, or giddiness in the head; as also bihi Oudiyma↓, (M, TA,) and Ausotudiyma↓ [app., in like manner, followed by bihi]. (Z, TA.) ― -b6- daAmati AldRalowi, (K,) inf. n. dawomN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The bucket became full: (K:) in this meaning, regard is had to the stagnant water [in the bucket]. (TA.)

2 dawRamati AlsRamaMCu dwmt AlsmMC
2. dawRamati AlsRamaMCu, and dayRamat: and dayRamuwA said of horses: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- dwRmt AlkilaAbu The dogs went far: (Akh, IAar, M, K:) or continued their course. (IAar, M.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, (de scribing a wild bull, T, TA,)
HatRaI UicaA dawRamato fiI AlOaroDi raAjaEahu
kiborN wa lawo XaMCa najRaI nafosahu Alharabu
[Until, when they went far in the land, pride returned to him: but, had he pleased, flight had saved his blood: J, however, assigns to the verb in this instance another signification, as will be seen below]. (M, TA.) ― -b3- dwRm said of a bird, (T, M, K,) inf. n. tadowiymN, (T, S,) (tropical:) It circled (Lth, T, S, M, K, TA) in the sky, (Lth, T, M, K,) as also tdAwm↓, (KL,) [or tadwRm↓, (see mutadawRimaAtN,)] to rise high towards the sky; (S;) as also AstdAm↓: (M, K:) or circled in the sky, (M,) or flew, (T, * K,) without moving its wings; (T, M, K;) like the kite and the aquiline vulture: (T, TA:) or put itself into a state of commotion in its flying. (TA. [See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.]) Dhu-r-Rummeh makes AltRadowiym to be on the earth, or ground, in the verse cited above in this paragraph; [as though the meaning were, (assumed tropical:) Until, when they went round &c.;] As disallows this, and asserts that one says only dawRaI fiIAlOaroDi, and dawRama fiI AlsRamaMCi; but some affirm that AltRadowiymu fiIAlOaroDi is correct; and say that hence is de rived AldRuwRaAmapu↓, meaning “ the round thing [or top] which the boy throws, and makes to revolve, or spin, upon the ground, by means of a string; ” though others say that this is so called from the phrase dawRamotu Alqidora [explained below], because, by reason of the quickness of its revolving, or spinning, it seems as though it were at rest: and tadowaAmN is like tadowiymN: some, however, say that tadowiymu Alkalobi signifies the dog's going far in flight: (S:) AHeyth says that, accord. to As, AltRadowiymu is only the act of a bird in the sky: (T, TA:) AAF says that, accord. to some, AltRadowiymu is in the sky, and AltRadowiyapu is on the earth, or ground; but accord. to others, the reverse is the case; and this, he says, is the truth in his opinion. (M, TA. [See also dawRaIa in art. dwI.]) ― -b4- You say also, dawRamati, AlXRamosu, (M, K,) or dwRmt AlXms fI AlsRamaACi, (T,) or fiIkabidi AlsRamaMCi, (S,) i. e. daArato fiI AlsRamaMCi [or dArt fI kbd AlsmAC, lit. (tropical:) The sun spun in the sky, or in the middle of the sky; meaning, was as though it were spinning]; (T, M, K;) or was as though it were motionless [&c.]: (T, S:) and hence is [said to be] derived the word duwRaAmapN↓ applied to the boy's revolving, or spinning, thing. (T.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, (describing the [insect called] junodab, [generally said to be a species of locust,] TA in art. rmD)
maEoraworiyFA ramaDa AlrRaDoraADi yarokuDuhu
waAlXRamosu HayoraI lahaA fiI AljawRi tadowiymu
(T, * S, TA) i. e. Venturing upon the [vehement] heat of the pebbles, [meaning the vehemently-hot pebbles,] striking them with its foot, for so the jndb does, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) when the sun is [apparently] stationary in the summer midday, [as though perplexed in its course,] as though having a spinning [in the region between heaven and earth]: (T, TA:) or as though it were motionless. (S.) ― -b5- And one says, dawRamato Eayonuhu (assumed tropical:) [His eye rolled; i. e.] the black of his eye revolved as though it were in the whirl of a spindle. (IAar, M, K.) ＝ -A2- [dwRm is also trans.] You say, dwRm AldRuwRaAmapa, (M, K,) inf. n. tadowiymN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He made the dwRAmp [or top] to revolve, or spin [so as to seem to be at rest, as has been shown above]: (M, K:) or he played with the dwRAmp. (TA.) ― -b2- And dwRmt Alxamoru XaAribahaA (tropical:) The wine intoxicated its drinker so as to make him turn round about. (As, S, TA.) ― -b3- And dawRamuwA AlEamaAYima (assumed tropical:) They wound the turbans around their heads. (TA.) ― -b4- And dwRm Almaraqapa (assumed tropical:) He put much grease into the broth so that it swam round upon it. (M, K.) ― -b5- AltRadowiymu [or app. tadowiymu AllRisaAni] also signifies (assumed tropical:) The mumbling the tongue, and rolling it about in the mouth, in order that the saliva may not dry up: so says Fr. (S, TA.) ― -b6- [Hence, app., as the context seems to indicate,] Dhu-r-Rummeh says, describing a camel braying in his XiqoXiqap [or faucial bag],
dawRama fiyhaA rizRahu wa OaroEadaA
[as though meaning (assumed tropical:) He made his braying to roll, or rumble, in it, and threatened]. (Fr, S, TA.) ― -b7- And dwRm signifies (tropical:) He moistened a thing. (S, M, K.) Ibn-Ahmar says,
waqado yudawRimu riyqa AlTRaAmiEi AlOamalu
(S, M;) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [And hope sometimes, or often,] moistens the saliva [of the eager]: (S:) he is praising En-Noamán Ibn-Besheer, and means that his hope moistens his saliva in his mouth by making his eulogy to continue. (IB.) ― -b8- (tropical:) He mixed, or moistened, or steeped, (daAfa,) saffron, (Lth, T, S, M, K, TA,) and stirred it round in doing so: (Lth, T, TA:) he dissolved saffron in water, and stirred it round therein. (A, TA.) ― -b9- dwRm Alqidora, and AdAmhA↓, (S, M, K,) He stilled the boiling of the cooking-pot by means of some [cold] water: (S:) or he sprinkled cold water upon [the contents of] the cooking-pot to still its boiling: (M, K:) or the former, (K,) or both, (M,) he allayed the boiling of the cooking-pot by means of something, (M, K,) and stilled it: (M:) and the latter signifies he left the cooking-pot upon the OavaAfiI [or three stones that supported it], after it had been emptied, (Lh, M, K,) not putting it down nor kindling a fire beneath it. (Lh, M.)

3 dAwm EalaI AlOamori c
3. dAwm EalaI AlOamori, and dAwm AlOamora: see 1. ＝ -A2- See also 10.

4 AdAmhu OdAm OdAmh OdAmp UdAm UdAmh UdAmp AdAmh AdAmp
4. AdAmhu, (inf. n. UidaAmapN, TA,) trans. of daAma; (S, M, * Msb, K; *) [i. e.] i. q. jaEalahu daAYimFA [He made it to continue, last, endure, or remain: to be extended, or prolonged: to continue, last, endure, or remain, long: and to continue, last, or exist, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever; to be permanent, perpetual, or everlasting]: (TK:) he did it continually, or perpetually: (MA:) he had it continually, or perpetually. (MA, KL.) [Accord. to Golius, followed in this case by Freytag, tdAwm↓ signifies Perennitate donavit; a signification app. given by Golius as on the authority of the KL; but not in my copy of that work.] ― -b2- AdAm Alqidora: see 2, last sentence. ― -b3- AdAm AldRalowa (assumed tropical:) He filled the bucket. (K, TA.) ― -b4- AlUidaAmapN also signifies tanoqiyru AlsRahomi EalaI AlUibohaAmi [i. e. The trying the sonorific quality of the arrow by turning it round upon the thumb: or, as explained in this art. in the TK, the making the arrow to produce a sharp sound upon the thumb: or rather this or the former is the meaning of UidaAmapu AlsRahomi; for, as is said in the TK, AdAm AlsRahoma signifies nqrh ElI AlAbhAm (i. e. nqRrhu)]. (T, K.) ＝ -A2- AdAmt AlsRamaMCu: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Oudiyma bihi: see 1, last sentence but one.

5 tadawRama
5: see 2: ― -b2- and see also 10.

6 tadaAowama
6: see 2: ― -b2- and see also 4.

10 AstdAm AstdAm QstdAm
10. AstdAm: see 1. ― -b2- And see also 2. ― -b3- And Ausotudiyma: see 1, last sentence but one. ＝ -A2- As a trans. v., (T,) i. q. AinotaZara, (Sb, T, TA,) as also tdwRm↓, (K, [or this may perhaps be used only without an objective complement expressed,]) and raqaba, (T,) or taraqRaba: (Sh, TA:) you say, Aisotadimo kacaA, meaning AinotaZirohu and Auroqubohu (assumed tropical:) [Look thou for, expect, await, wait for, or watch for, such a
thing.] (T.) [When no objective complement is expressed, it seems to mean (assumed tropical:) He paused, and acted with deliberation, or in a patient or leisurely manner, or he waited in expectation; app. from the same verb as syn. with dawRama; and thus, like one who hovers about a thing: see HawRama; and see also AinotaZara.] And AstdAmhu (tropical:) He acted with moderation, gently, deliberately, or leisurely, in it; (S, M, K, TA;) namely, an affair, or a case: (S:) or he sought, desired, asked, or demanded, its continuance, or long continuance, or endless continuance: and so dAwmhu↓ (M, K, TA) in both of these senses: (K, TA:) or he asked him to render a thing continual &c.: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) and also (assumed tropical:) he acted gently and deliberately in it; namely, an affair, or a case: (Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) he acted gently with him; (Fr, T in art. dym, M, Msb, Kt;) i. e., another person, (Msb,) or his creditor; as also AisotadomaAhu, (Fr, T, M, K,) which we judge to be formed from the former by transposition, because we do not find it [in this sense] to have any inf. n. (M.) A poet says, (T, S, Msb,) namely, Keys Ibn-Zuheyr, (S,)
falaA taEojalo biOamorika waQsotadimohu
famaA SalRaI EaSaAka kamusotadiymi↓
(T, S, Msb,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Therefore haste not in thine affair, but act with moderation, gently, deliberately, or leisurely, therein]; for no one has straightened thy staff by turning it round over the fire, (T,) meaning, no one has managed thine affair soundly, like one who acts with moderation, &c. (T, Msb.) And another says, (S,) namely, Mejnoon, (TA,)
waUinRaI EalaI layolaI lazaArK waUinRaniI
EalaIcaAka fiymaA bayonanaA OasotadiymuhaA
meaning (assumed tropical:) [And verily I am blaming Leylà; and verily, notwithstanding that,] I look for her aiding me by good conduct [in the matter that is between us]. (S.) You say also, Oasotadiymu QllReha niEomataka I seek, or desire, or ask, of God the continuance, or long continuance, or endless continuance, of thy favour, or the like. (Mgh, TA. *) And Oasotadiymu QllReha EizRaka I ask God to continue, or continue long, &c., thy might, or power, &c. (Msb.) The phrase AstdAm lubosa AlvRawobi, meaning [He continued long the wearing of the garment, or] he did not hasten to pull off the garment, may be from the saying Aisotadamotu EaAqibapa AlOamori, meaning I looked, or watched, or waited, for the end, or issue, or result, of the affair, or case. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- Also He (a man) stooped his head, blood dropping from it: formed by transposition from AisotadomaI (Kr, TA.)

daAmN dAm dAmy
daAmN for daAYimN: see the latter word.

dawomN dwm
dawomN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, M, Msb, K.) — [Hence,] maA zaAlati AlsRamaMCu dawomFA dawomFA The sky ceased not to rain [in the manner of the rain termed diymap]; and so dayomFA dayomFA↓; (M, K; [in the CK, erroneously, diyomFA diyomFA;]) in which the I is interchangeable with the w; (M;) mentioned by AHn, on the authority of Fr. (TA.) ― -b2- See also daAYimN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also [The cucifera Thebaïca; (Delile, “ Floræ Ægypt. Illustr., ” no. 941;) or Theban Palm; so called because abundant in the Thebaïs; a species of fan-palm; by some called gingerbread: accord. to Forskål, (under the heading of “ Flora Arabiæ Felicis, ” in his “ Flora Ægypt. Arab., ” p. cxxvi.,) Borassus flabelliformis; a name applied (after him) by Sonnini to the Theban palm; but now generally used by botanists to designate another species of fan-palm:] the tree of the muqol; (S, M, Msb, K;) a well-known kind of tree, of which the fruit is [called] the muqol: (TA:) n. un. with p: AHn says that the dawomap [is a tree that] becomes thick and tall, and has [leaves of the kind termed] xuwS, like the xwS of the date-palm, and racemes like the racemes of a date-palm. (M, TA.) Accord. to Aboo-Ziyád El-Aarábee, (AHn, M,) The nabiq [which properly signifies the fruit of the sidor, but here app. means, as it does in the present day, the tree called sidor, a species of lote-tree, called by Linn. rhamnus spina Christi, and by Forskal rhamnus nabeca,] is also thus called, (AHn, M, K,) by some of the Arabs: accord. to 'Omárah, great [trees of the kind termed] sidor: (AHn, M:) and, (M, K,) accord. to IAar, (M,) big trees of any kind. (M, K.) [See also dawomapN, below.]

dayomN dym dymp
dayomN, whence the saying maA zaAlati AlsRamaMCu dayomFA dayomFA: see dawomN.

diyomN dym dymp
diyomN: see diymapN.

dawomapN dwm dwmh dwmp
dawomapN n. un. of dawomN. (M, TA.) [Also, app., as in the present day, and as appears from what follows, A single fruit of the tree called dawom.] ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A testicle; (K;) as being likened to the fruit of the dawom. (TA.) ― -b3- [Golius also explains it, as on the authority of the K, as meaning “ Ebriosa mulier; ” and Freytag, as meaning “ mulier vinum vendens: ” both are wrong: it is mentioned in the K as the name of a woman who sold wine.]

diymapN dymh dymp
diymapN A lasting, or continuous, and still rain: (As, M, and TA voce DarobN, q. v.:) or rain in which is neither thunder nor lightning; the least of which is the third of a day or the third of a night; and the most thereof, of any period: (AZ, S in art. dym:) or rain that continues some days: (Msb:) or rain that continues long and is still, without thunder and lightning: (K, * TA:) or rain that continues five days, or six, (M, K,) or seven, (K,) or a day and a night, (T in art. dym, M, K,) or more; (T, TA;) or the least whereof is a third of a day or of a night; and the most thereof, of any period: (K, TA:) pl. diyamN, (S, M, K,) the w being changed [into I] in the pl. because it is changed in the sing., (M,) and duyuwmN, (Abu-l-'Omeythil, T, K,) and [coll. gen. n.] diyomN↓ (Sh, T, TA.) [See also mudaAmN.] ― -b2- Hence other things are thus termed by way of comparison. (S.) It is said in a trad. (S, M) of 'Áïsheh, (M,) kaAna Eamaluhu diymapF (S, M, Msb) (assumed tropical:) His work was incessant [but moderate, or not excessive]; (Msb;) referring to Mohammad; (T, S, M, Msb;) on her being asked if he preferred some days to others: (T:) she likened it to the rain termed dymp in respect of continuance and moderation. (T, M.) And it is related of Hudheyfeh that he said, mentioning fitan [i. e. trials, or probations, or conflicts and factions, &c.], UinRahaA laMtiyatukumo diymFA diymFA, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Verily they are coming to you] filling the earth, or land, [and] with continuance. (T.)

daAmaMCu dAmMC
daAmaMCu (in the CK [erroneously] daOomACu) The sea, or a great river; syn. baHorN; (M, K;) because of the continuance of its water: (M:) originally dawamaMCu, or dawomaMCu: if the latter, the change of the w into A is anomalous. (TA.)

AldRawamaMCu AldwmMC
AldRawamaMCu: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

dayomuwmN dymwm
dayomuwmN and dayomuwmapN, held by Aboo-'Alee to be from AldRawaAmu, and therefore to belong to the present art.: (TA:) see art. dm. ＝ -A2- The latter is also an inf. n. of daAma [q. v.]. (S, M, Msb, K.)

duwaAmN dwAm
duwaAmN (tropical:) A vertigo, or giddiness in the head; i. q. duwaArN (S, * M, * K, TA. [In the CK, dawACN is erroneously put for duwaArN.]) You say, Oaxacahu duwaAmN (tropical:) [A vertigo took him, or attacked him]. (S.) And bihi duwaAmN (tropical:) [He has a vertigo]. (As, TA.)

duwRaAmN dwAm
duwRaAmN: see what next follows.

duwRaAmapN dwAm dwAmh dwAmp
duwRaAmapN (assumed tropical:) The falokap [or round thing, i. e. top,] which the boy throws, and makes to revolve, or spin, upon the ground, by means of a string: (S, M, * K: *) the derivation of the word has been explained above: see 2, in two places: (T, S:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] duwRaAmN↓. (M, K.) ― -b2- duwRaAmapu AlbaHori (assumed tropical:) [The whirlpool of the sea; so in the present day;] the middle of the sea, upon which the waves circle (tdwm [i. e. tudawRim]). (TA.)

daAYimN c
daAYimN [Continuing, lasting, enduring, or remaining: being extended or prolonged: (see 1, first sentence:)] continuing, lasting, enduring, or remaining, long: (TA:) [and continuing, lasting, or existing, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever; permanent, perpetual, or everlasting: (see, again, 1, first sentence:)] and dawomN↓ signifies the same as daAYimN, (S, M, K,) applied to shade; (S, M;) being an inf. n. used as an epithet: (M:) and dayRuwmN↓, also, (M, K,) [of the measure fayoEuwlN, originally dayowuwimN,] like qayRuwmN, (M,) signifies the same as dAYmN [app. in the last of the senses explained above; being of a form proper to intensive epithets]: (M, K:) Lakeet Ibn-Zurárah says,
XatRaAna hecaA waAlEinaAqu waAlnRawomN
waAlmaXorabu AlbaAridu waAlZRilRu AldRawomo
[Different, or widely different, are this and embracing and sleeping and the cool drinkingplace and the continual shade]. (IB, TA.) And the Jews are related, in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, to have said [to the Muslims], Ealayokumo AlsRaAmu AldRaAmu↓, meaning Almawotu AldRaAYimu, [i. e. May everlasting death come upon you; saying AlsRaAmu in the place of AlsRalaAmu, and] suppressing the I [or rather the hemzeh] because of [their desire to assimilate AldAYm
to] AlsAm. (TA.) [Hence daAYimFA meaning Continually: and always, or for ever.] — Also (tropical:) Still, or motionless; said, in this sense, of water; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) and so dawomN↓. (M, TA.) — It is also said of that which is in motion, [as signifying (assumed tropical:) Going round, revolving, or circling, (see 1,)] as well as of that which is still, or motionless; thus having two contr. meanings: so says Aboo-Bekr. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] maraqapN↓ daAwimapN (assumed tropical:) [Broth into which is put much grease so that this swims round upon it]: which is extr., because the w in this instance should by rule be changed into a hemzeh. (M. [The meaning is there indicated by the mention of this phrase immediately after dawRama Almaraqapa, q. v.])

maraqapN daAwimapN mrqp dAwmh mrqp dAwmp
maraqapN daAwimapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

dayRuwmN dywm
dayRuwmN: see daAYimN, first sentence.

Oadowamu c
Oadowamu [More, and most, continual, lasting, &c.] You say, huwa Oadowamu mino kacaA [It is more continual, or lasting, &c., than such a thing]: from AldRawaAmu. (IJ, M.)

mudaAmN mdAm
mudaAmN Continual, or lasting, rain. (IJ, M, K.) [See also diymapN, above.] ― -b2- And Wine; as also mudaAmapN↓: (T, S, M, K:) so called because it is made to continue for a time (T, M) in the danR, (T,) or in its receptacle, (M,) until it becomes still after fermenting: (T:) or because, by reason of its abundance, it does not become exhausted: (Sh, T:) or because of its oldness: (AO, T:) or because it is the only beverage of which the drinking can be long continued: (M, K:) or because the drinking thereof is continued for days, to the exclusion of other beverages. (A, TA.)

mudaAmapN mdAm mdAmh mdAmp
mudaAmapN: see what next precedes.

midowamN mdwm
midowamN and midowaAmN↓ A stick, or piece of wood, (M, K,) or some other thing, (M,) with which one stills the boiling of the cooking-pot. (Lh, M, K.)

OaroDN madiymapN c
OaroDN madiymapN, (Yz, S, M, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, mudiymapN,]) and mudayRamapN↓, (M, TA,) Land upon which have fallen rains such as are termed diyimN [pl. of diymapN]. (Yz, * S, * M, K, * TA.)

mudiymN mdym
mudiymN i. q. raAEifN (S, K) [Having blood flowing from his nose: or, accord. to the PS and TK as meaning having a continual bleeding of the nose].

OaroDN mudayRamapN c
OaroDN mudayRamapN: see madiymapN.

midowaAmN mdwAm
midowaAmN: see midowamN.

mutadawRimaAtN mtdwmAt
mutadawRimaAtN, applied to birds, means Going round, or circling, over a thing: and this is meant by mutadaAwimaAt↓, which is used for the former word, in the saying [of a rájiz], describing horses,
kaAlTRayori taboqiI mutadaAwimaAtihaA
i. e. Like birds when thou lookest at, or watchest, those of them that are going round, or circling, over a thing: (S, TA: *) or mtdwRmAt signifies waiting, or watching. (TA.)

mutadaAwmaAtN mtdAwmAt
mutadaAwmaAtN: see what next precedes.

musotadiymN mstdym
musotadiymN: see 10. Accord. to Sh, (TA,) it signifies (assumed tropical:) Exceeding the usual bounds in an affair; striving, or labouring, therein; or taking pains, or extraordinary pains, therein. (T, TA.)

1 daAna dAn dAny
1. daAna, aor. yaduwnu, inf. n. dawonN; and Oudiyna↓, (S, K,) with damm, (K,) inf. n. UidaAnapN; (S;) He, or it, was, or became, such as is termed duwnN; (S, K;) [i. e.] low, base, vile, &c.: or weak: (K:) mentioned by Er-Rághib on the authority of IKt: (TA:) so say some: but accord. to others, duwnN has no verb. (S, TA.) lamo yaduno, (as in my copies of the S,) or lm yudano, (as in the TA,) at the end of a verse of 'Adee, as some relate it, [perhaps the only authority for these two verbs,] is accord. to others lm ydanRo, from danRaI meaning “ he, or it, was, or became, weak. ” (S, K.)

2 dwRn AldRaywaAna dwn AldywAn
2. dwRn AldRaywaAna, (inf. n. tadowiynN, TA,) He wrote, composed, or drew up, the register [&c.]. (S, * Msb, K, TA. *) And dwRn AldRawaAwiyna He instituted, appointed, or arranged, the registers for the prefects, or administrators, (Mgh, Msb,) and the Kádees, (Mgh,) or others: (Msb:) said of 'Omar; who is related to have been the first that did this, (Mgh, Msb,) among the Arabs. (Msb.) And dwRn Alkutuba He collected the writings. (Mgh.) [And dwRn XiEora fulaAnK He collected the poetry of such a one.] And tadowiynN signifies also The writing [a person's name &c.] in a diywaAn [or register]. (KL.) You say, dwRnhu He wrote it [in a register]. (MA.) [And He registered him.]

4 Oudiyna c
4. Oudiyna, inf. n. UidaAnapN: see 1. ＝ -A2- maA Oadowanahu [as meaning How low, base, vile, &c., is he, or it!] is [asserted to be] a phrase not used, (As, T, K, TA,) because [it is said that] duwnN has no verb. (As, T, TA.)

5 tdwRn dwn tdwn tdwnn wdI
5. tdwRn He was, or became, in a state of complete richness, wealth, or competence. (IAar, T, K.) [See also tcwRn. Perhaps both are correct, as dial. vars.]

duwnF dwn dwnn
duwnF Low, base, vile, mean, paltry, inconsiderable, or contemptible; (Fr, T, S, M, * Msb, K;) applied to a man &c.: (T, Msb:) and inferior, i. e. lower, baser, viler, &c., in grounds of pretension to respect or honour [or in any approvable quality]: (Lth, T:) and such as falls short [of a thing]; used in this sense as a prefixed noun: (Ham p. 686:) [see below what is said of its usage as a prefixed noun by Lth and by Sb: and used as an epithet, scanty, or deficient; applied to anything:] and of a middling sort; between good and bad; applied to a man and to a commodity: (M:) and also high, or eminent, in rank or condition; noble, or honourable: (T, K:) thus it bears two contr. significations (K) [and significations intermediate between those two]. A poet says,
UicaA maA EalaA AlmaroCu raAma AlEalaMC
wayaqotaEu biAldRuwni mano kaAnaA duwnaA
[When the man is high in rank, or nobility, he seeks highness: and he who is low is content with that which is low]. (S.) Accord. to the most common usage, (Msb,) or accord. to what is asserted to be the most common usage, (Lh, M,) one says rajulN mino duwnK (T, M, Msb, K) and XaIoCN mino duwnK (M, Msb) A man who is [of a kind that is] low, base, &c., and a thing that is [of a kind that is] low, base, &c.: (Msb:) but sometimes they said rajulN duwnN and XaIoCN duwnN, without mino; (M, Msb;) and vawobN duwnN a bad [or an inferior] garment, or piece of cloth: (M:) or one should not say rajulN duwnN; (T, K;) for the Arabs did not use this phrase. (T.) Accord. to Lth, one says, hecaA duwnu caAka [This is the inferior of that], when meaning to denote by it low estimation, using the nom. case: (T:) [but this is uncommon, if allowable:] Sb says that duwn is not used in the nom. case as a prefixed noun: as to the saying in the Kur [lxxii. 11, an instance similar to which occurs also in vii. 167], minRaA AlSRaAliHuwna wa minRaA duwna celika, the meaning is, wa minRaA qawomN duwna celika [i. e. Of us are the righteous, and of us are a party below that party in rank or estimation]; (M, TA;) or, as another says, dwn is here in the accus. case but in the place of a noun in the nom. case because it is generally used as an adv. n. (TA.) ― -b2- As an adv. n., duwn signifies Below, contr. of fawoq; (S, K;) as denoting a falling short of the [right or approved] limit; (S;) or denoting low, or mean, estimation or condition; (Lth, T, M;) or a condition lower, baser, viler, &c., than that of another, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour [or in any approvable quality]; (Lth, T;) [and hence, inferior to, beneath, under, or short of, another in rank, height, size, &c.;] and less than another, and more deficient than another: (Fr, T:) and also above; i. q. fawoq; (T, K;) in highness, or eminence, of rank or condition, or in nobility; (T;) [and hence, exceeding another, and more than another:] thus bearing two contr. significations. (K.) You say, zayodN duwnaka meaning Zeyd is [below thee, or] in a condition lower, baser, viler, &c., than thine, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour [&c.]: and when one says, “ Verily such a one is high, or eminent, in rank or condition, ” or “ is noble, ” another replies, wa duwna celika meaning And above that. (T.) ― -b3- Also Beneath, below in situation, or under; syn. taHot. (T, TA.) Using it in this sense, you say, duwan qadamika xadRu EaduwRika [May the cheek of thine enemy be beneath thy foot]: (T, TA:) and jalasa duwnahu [He sat below him]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Before in respect of place, or in front: and [the contr., namely,] behind, or beyond. (T, M, K.) [You may say, using it in the former sense, jalasa duwnahu He sat before him, or in front of him: (see Ham p. 86:) and, using it in the latter sense,] you say, hecaA OamiyrN EalaI maA duwna jayoHuwna This [man] is governor, or prince, over what is beyond [the river] Jeyhoon. (TA.) ― -b5- And i. q. qabol [generally signifying Before in respect of time; but as some say, in respect of place also, which may perhaps be here meant]: (T:) and [the contr., namely,] i. q. baEod [generally meaning after in respect of time; but as
some say, in respect of place also, which may perhaps be here meant]. (Fr, T, TA.) ― -b6- It signifies also Nearer than another thing: (S, Msb, K:) so in the phrase hecaA duwna celika [This is nearer than that]; (S Msb;) or hecaA duwnahu [this is nearer than he, or it]. (K.) [Hence,] one says also, Audonu duwnaka meaning Draw thou near in the space that is between me and thee: (A Heyth, T:) [or approach thou nearer to me:] or draw thou near [or nearer] to me. (IAar, T, M, K.) And yaziydu baguDRu AlTRarofa duwniI, a saying of a poet, means Yezeed lowers the eye towards a spot between me and him. (A Heyth, T.) [xaXaEato duwnahu AlOaboSaAru, also, has a similar meaning: see 1 in art. xXE. So, too, has the phrase, xaAwata Tarofahu duwniI: see 3 in art. xwt. And hence,] one says, duwna AlnRahori jamaAEapN [In the way of, or to, the river, or on this side of the river, or nearer than the river, is a company of men; or] before thy reaching the river [there is to be found, or encountered, a company of men]. (K.) And duwna qatoli AlOasadi OahowaAlN [In the way of, or to, the slaying of the lion, or] before thine attaining to the slaying of the lion, terrors [are to be encountered]. (T, TA.) [And duwnahu xaroTu AlqataAdi: see 1 in art. xrT.] And HaAla duwna AlXRaIoCi [It intervened as an obstacle in the way to the thing; or] it prevented from attaining the thing. (W p. 71.) [And layosa duwnahu XaIoCN There is nothing intervening as an obstacle in the way of, or to, him, or it.] And [hence,] qutila duwna maAlihi, and nafosihi, and Oaxiyhi, and jaArihi, He was slain in defence of his property, and of himself, and of his brother, and of his neighbour. (Occurring in a trad. commencing with the words Algariyqu XahiydN, in the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer, ” and thus explained in the margin of a copy of that work.) [And nabaHa duwnahu is a modern phrase meaning (assumed tropical:) He defended him as though by barking in the way to him.] ― -b7- [Hence,] also i. q. EalaI [as meaning Against; denoting defence by means of intervention: see an ex. in a verse cited voce XaxoSN]. (Fr, T, TA.) ― -b8- And i. q. Einoda [meaning At, near, nigh, by, or near by; with, or present with; &c.]. (Fr, T, Ibn-Es-Seed.) Accord. to Ez-Zowzanee, it has this meaning in the saying of Imra-el-Keys, [describing a horse,]
faOaloHaqanaA biAlhaAdiyaAti wa duwnahu
jawaAHiruhaA fiI SarRapK lamo tuzayRali
(TA, but only the former hemistich is there given,) i. e. And he made us to overtake the foremost of the wild animals, while near to him were those that lagged behind, in a herd, not dispersed. (EM p. 48.) ― -b9- And i. q. gayor [as meaning Other than, beside, or besides, exclusively of, or not as used before a substantive or an adjective]. (K.) Hence, in the Kur [xxi. 82], wayaEomaluwna EamalFA duwna celika [And who should do work other than, or beside, that]. (Fr, TA.) And in the same [iv. 51 and 116], wayagofiru maA duwna celika But He will forgive what is other than that: or, as some say, what is less than that. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And so, it is said, in the trad., layosa fiymaA duwna xamosi OawaAqK SadaqapN [There is no poor-rate to be exacted in the case of what is other than, or not, or, rather less than, five ounces]. (K.) So, too, it is said to mean in the trad., OajaAza AlxuloEa duwna EiqaASi raOosihaA [He allowed the divorcing a wife for a gift, or compensation, other than the EiqaAS (q. v.) of her head: in the CK, in which AlxaloEu is erroneously put for AlxuloEa, this is given as an ex. of cuwna in the sense of sawiI, which is syn. with gayor]: or the meaning is, for anything, even for the EqAS of her head. (K, TA.) ― -b10- It is also used (M, K, TA) as a subst. (M, TA) with mino prefixed to it, [very often in this case, in the Kur and elsewhere, as meaning gayor and sometimes in other senses explained above,] and likewise with bi (M, K, TA,) though rarely. (K.) One says, hecaA duwnaka and hecaA mino duwnika [This is below thee, or above thee: &c.]. (M, TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xxviii. 23], wawajada mino duwnihimu QmoraOatayoni (M, TA) And he found in a place below them two women: (Bd:) or beside them, or exclusively of them. (Jel.) One says also, hedaA liIduwna laka or mino duwnika [meaning This belongs to me exclusively of thee]; i. e. thou hast no right nor share [with me] in this. (Kull p. 186.) The phrase fiyhimo mano layosa biduwnihi [app. as meaning Among whom was such as was not below him in respect of knowledge of poetry] is used by Akh in his book on rhymes. (M, TA.) ― -b11- It also denotes a command, (T, K,) and an incitement (Fr, T, S, K) to do a thing. (S.) Using it in the former sense, you say, duwnaka AldRirohama, meaning Take thou the dirhem; (T;) or duwnaka AlXRaIoCa and duwnaka biAlXRaIoCi, meaning Take thou the thing: (M:) and using it in the latter sense, you say, duwnakahu, (S, K, TA,) meaning Keep thou, cleave thou, cling thou, or hold thou fast, to him; and take care of him: (TA:) or dunaka zayodFA Keep thou, &c., to Zeyd, taking care of him. (T.) Temeem [meaning a party of the tribe so named] said to El-Hajjáj, when he had slain, i. e. crucified, Sálih Ibn-' Abd-Er-Rahmán, “ Permit us to bury Sálih: ” and he replied, duwnakumuwhu [Take ye him]. (S, TA.) ― -b12- And it also denotes a threat. (T, K.) So in the sayings duwaka SiraAEiI [Beware thou of wrestling with me] and duwnaka fatamarRaso biI [Beware thou, and then set thyself against me to do evil if thou canst]. (T, TA.) ― -b13- It is said that no verb is derived from it: (T, S, M, Msb:) but some assert that daAna and Oudiyna [mentioned in the first paragraph of this art.] are derived from it. (S.) ― -b14- The dim. of duwna is duwayona↓: (Ham p. 404:) and duwayonapa↓ occurs as a dim. in a verse of a post-classical poet; but, [ISd says,] of what word I know not, unless they said duwnapa↓ [for duwna]. (M.)

duwnapa dwn dwnh dwnnh dwnp
duwnapa: see the next preceding sentence.

duwayona dwI dwy dwyn
duwayona: see the next preceding sentence.

duwayonapa dwI dwy dwynh dwynp
duwayonapa: see the next preceding sentence.

dayowaAnN dywAn
dayowaAnN: see the next paragraph.

diywaAnN dywAn
diywaAnN, an arabicized word, (AO, M, Msb, &c.,) from the Pers. [diywaAno]; (AO, M, &c.;) [though some hold it to be of Arabic origin:] J says, (TA,) it is originally diwRaAnN, but I is substituted for one of the w s; as is shown by its pl., (S, Msb,) which is dawaAwiynu; (S, M, Msb, K;) for if the I were radical, they would say dayaAwiynu; (S;) but accord. to IDrd and IJ, (IB, TA,) it has this latter pl. also: (M, IB, K, TA:) Sb says that the w in diywaAnN, though after I, is not changed into I, as it is in sayRidN, because the I in the former word is not inherent; that word being of the measure fiERaAlN, from dawRanota; (M;) [i. e.] it is from dawRana Alkutuba meaning “ he collected the writings; ” as is shown by their saying duwayowiynN↓, (M,) which is the dim.: (Msb:) ISk says that dywAn is with kesr only [to the d]; (M;) but one says dayowaAnN↓ also, (K,) which is mentioned by Ks, as postclassical, and by Sb; like bayoTaArN: (M:) the meaning is A dafotar [or register]: (Shifá el-Ghaleel, TA:) or a collection of written leaves or papers [forming a book, generally for registration]: (ISk, M, Mgh, * K:) or a register of accounts; an accountbook: (Msb:) and a register of soldiers and pensioners [and others]: (IAth, K:) the first who instituted, or appointed, or arranged, such a book, (Mgh, Msb, K,) among the Arabs, (Msb,) for the prefects, or administrators, (Mgh, Msb,) and the Kádees, (Mgh,) is said to have been 'Omar: (Mgh, Msb, K: *) accord. to El-Máwardee, it is a register of what concerns the rights, or dues, of the state, relating to the acts of the government, and the finances, and the military and other administrators thereof: (TA:) then any book was thus called: and especially the poetry of some particular poet: so that this meaning became [conventionally regarded as] a proper signification thereof; (Shifá el-Ghaleel, TA;) i. e. a collection of poetry [of a particular poet]. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN mino Oaholi AldRiywaAni, meaning Such a one is of those whose names are written in the register. (Mgh.) [Also Such a one is of the keepers of the register; or, is of the registrars. (And sometimes it has another meaning, which see below.) And hence the saying] AlXRiEoru diywaAnu AlEarabi (assumed tropical:) [Poetry is the register of the Arabs]: because they used to refer to it on their differing in opinion respecting genealogies and wars or fights and the appointing of stipends or allowances from the government-treasury, like as the people of the dywAn [properly so called] refer to their dywAn in a case that is doubtful to them; or because it was the depository of their sciences, and the preserver of their rules of discipline, and the mine of their histories. (Har p. 263.) ― -b2- Afterwards, also, it was applied to signify An account, or a reckoning. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And Writers [of accounts or reckonings]. (TA.) ― -b4- And A place of account or reckoning, (Msb, TA,) and of writers [of accounts or reckonings] (TA.) ― -b5- [Also A council, court, or tribunal: see dasotN. Hence Oaholu AldRiywaAni sometimes means The people of the council, court, or tribunal. ― -b6- And also, in the present day, A long seat, formed of a mattress laid against the side of a room, upon the floor or upon a raised structure or frame, with cushions to lean against; or two or more of such mattresses &c. similarly placed.]

Oadowanu is used by IJ in the phrase celika OaqalRN AlOamorayoni waOadowanuhumaA [That is the lesser of the two affairs, or cases, and the lower, baser, &c., of them]: but [ISd says that] this is strange, because [he held that], like OaHonaka, it has no verb belonging to it. (M.)

1 dawiIa dwAyp dwI dwy
1. dawiIa, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yadowaI, (Msb,) inf. n. dawFI, He was, or became, diseased, disordered, distempered, sick, or ill: (S, M, Msb, K:) and he was, or became, affected with consumption, or ulceration of the lungs. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] dawiIa Sadoruhu (assumed tropical:) His bosom was, or became, affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (S.)

2 dwRI dwAyp dwI dwy
2. dwRI, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. tadowiyapN, (T, S, K,) He, or it, made a sound; or what is termed dawiIR; (T, M;) [i. e., a confused and continued sound; such as the rustling, or murmuring, of the wind; and the rustling of a bird; and the humming, or buzzing, of bees; and the rumbling of thunder; or the distant sound of rain and of thunder;] accord. to some, particularly said of thunder [as meaning it made a rumbling sound]; (M;) or it (a cloud) thundered: (KL:) and he (a stallioncamel) brayed so as to make a [rumbling] sound such as is termed dawiIR to be heard. (T, S, K.) ＝ -A2- [Also,] said of a bird, It circled in the air without moving its wings: (Msb:) or, accord. to As, one says of a dog, dwRI fiI AlOaroDi [he went round upon the ground]; like as one says of a bird, dawRama fiIAlsRamaMCi, meaning “ it circled in its flight, rising: ” he says that AltRadowiymu is not upon the ground, nor AltRadowiyapu in the sky; and he finds fault with the first of the verses of Dhu-r-Rummeh cited in the second paragraph of art. dwm: but some say that the two verbs are dial. vars., both meaning he went round about. (S. [See also dawRama, in two places.]) ― -b2- See also 2 in art. dw. ＝ -A3- Also, (T, S, M, K,) and the like, (K,) and of broth, (T, S, M,) It was, or became, overspread with the thin skin termed dawaAyapN. (T, S, M, K.) And, said of water, It was, or became, overspread with what was raised and scattered by the wind, (M, K,) resembling what is termed duwaAyap. (M.) ― -b2- And [hence,] dawRati AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) The land became overspread with various herbage; as though it were the duwaAyap of milk. (T.) ＝ -A4- dawRayotuhu, (inf. n. as above, TA,) I gave him the duwaAyap of milk, (M, K,) or of broth, to eat it. (M.) ＝ -A5- And dwRI He sold [and app. made also (see mudawRK)] what is called dawaAp. (TA.)

3 daAwayotuhu dAwI dAwyth dAwytp
3. daAwayotuhu, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. mudaAwaApN (T, S, Msb) and diwaMCN, (T, S,) the latter allowable, (T,) I treated him medically, curatively, or therapeutically; (S, K;) I cured him [mino maraDihi of his disease]; (T;) biAldRawaMCi [with the remedy]: (M, K:) and I tended him carefully, or treated him; syn. EaAnayotuhu; (K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, EaAyanotuhu;]) namely, AlmariyDa [the sick person]. (M, * TA.) You say, huwa yudowiIwayudaAwiI: see 4. And, of a person, (T,) or thing, (S,) duwwiIa, without idghám, to distinguish between the measures fuwEila and fuERila; (T, S;) meaning [He or] it was treated medically, &c.: (S:) and duwwiIa biOadowiyapK [referring to hair] It was treated (EuwniIa) with remedies, such as oils and the like. (M.) ― -b2- And dAwI farasahu, inf. n. diwaMCN, with kesr to the d, He fattened his horse, and fed him with fodder that showed its effect upon him: (T:) or daAwayotu Alfarasa I tended the horse well; or took good care of him. (M.) [See also dawaMCN.]

You say, huwa yudowiI wayudaAwiI↓ [He renders, or finds one to be, diseased, &c., and treats medically, &c., or cures]. (S.) ＝ -A2- And (assumed tropical:) He suspected him; thought evil of him; a dial. var. of OadowaOahu. (AZ, TA.) ＝ -A3- And AdwI He became a companion to a sick person. (K.)

(Lth, T.) [Being properly an inf. n., it is app. used alike as sing. and pl. in all its senses: or it may, when signifying as explained above, have for its pl. OadowaMCN, which is pl. of daMCN.] ＝ -A2- See also dawK, below, in three places. ― -b2- Also Foolish; stupid; or unsound, dull, or deficient, in intellect; (S, M, K;) applied to a man. (S.) ― -b3- And (so applied, TA) Cleaving to his place; (M, K;) not quitting it. (M.) ＝ -A3- See also dawaApN.

dawK dw

(S, M) and dual (M) and pl., (S, M,) being originally an inf. n. (S.) A poet uses ↓the latter as meaning disordered, or ill, by reason of intense drowsiness. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, UinRahu ladawiI AlSRadori [meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily he is one whose bosom is affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: see 1, second sentence]: and a poet says,
waEayonuka tubodiI OanRa Sadoraka liI dawiIo
[(assumed tropical:) And thine eye shows that thy bosom is affected with rancour towards me]. (Lth, T.) ― -b3- OaroDN dawiyapN A land in which are diseases: (As, T, S:) a land that is unsuitable [or unhealthy]; as also dawiyRapN↓ and duwiyRapN↓. (M, K.)

dawaApN [vulgarly dawaAyap, An ink-bottle; and, more commonly, an inkhorn; i. e. a portable case with receptacles for ink and the instruments of writing, so formed as to be stuck in the girdle; the most usual king is figured in my work on the Modern Egyptians, ch. ix.;] a certain thing, (S, M, Msb, K,) well known, (M, K,) from which one [takes the ink and instruments with which he] writes: (S, Msb:) pl. dawFI↓, (S, M, K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and duwiIRN, (T, S, M, K,) which is pl. of dawFI, (S, TA,) as also diwiIRN, (M, K,) and dawayaAtN, (S, Msb,) which is applied to a number from three to ten [inclusive]. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also The rind, or skin, of the colocynth, and of the grape, and of the melon; and so cawaApN. (K.)

dawaMCN dwMC
dawaMCN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and diwaMCN↓ (S, M, K, said in the Msb to be a subst. from daAwayotuhu,) and duwaMCN↓, (M, K,) the last on the authority of El-Hejeree, and the first that which is commonly known, (TA,) A medicine; a remedy: (T, M, Msb, K:) pl. OadowiyapN. (T, S.) The following verse is related as presenting an ex. of the second of these dial. vars.:
yaquwluwna maxomuwrNwahecaA diwaAWuhu
EalaIRa Uicona maXRIN UilaI Albayoti waAjibN
[they say, “ He is affected with the remains of intoxication; ” and this is his remedy: on me, if the case be so, walking to the House of God is incumbent]: meaning that they said, “ Flogging, and chastisement, is his diwMC: ” but he says, “ On me is incumbent a pilgrimage walking if I have drunk it: ” but it is said [by some] that diwaMCN is only an inf. n. of daAwayotuhu, like mudaAwaApN. (S.) ― -b2- dawaMCN also signifies Food. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And The means by which a horse is treated, consisting in what are termed taDomiyrN and HanocN [explained in the second paragraph of art. Dmr and the first of art. Hnc]: and the means by which a young woman, or female slave, is treated in order that she may become fat: and also applied to milk; because they used to effect the tDmyr of horses by the drinking of milk, and to treat therewith the young woman, or female slave: and it is likewise called qafiyRapN; because she has it given to her in preference, like as the guest has, and the child. (S, TA.)

ears; as in the saying] xalaA baToniImina AlTRaEaAmi HatRaIsamiEotu diwayRFA limasaAmiEiI [My belly became empty of food so that I heard a ringing in my ears]. (T.) ＝ -A2- [It is also an epithet; whence] OaroDN dawRiyapN: see dawK, last sentence.

1 daAva dAv
1. daAva, aor. yadiyvu, inf. n. dayovN, It (a thing) was, or became, soft, or supple; and easy: whence the term dayRuwvN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence,] dAv, aor. as above, inf. n. diyaAvapN, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, [a wittol, or tame cuckold; or] without jealousy, and regardless of shame: so in the Nawádir of Aboo-'Alee Zekereeyà Ibn-Hároon Ibn-Zekereeyà El-Hejeree: (TA:) and tadayRuvN↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) the acting the part, or performing the office, [of a dayRuwv, or wittol; or] of a pimp to one's own wife. (T, K.)

(M.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He made it (a road) even, smooth, or easy to walk or ride upon. (M, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He smoothed it; namely, an affair. (M.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He broke, or trained, him, namely, a camel, in some measure [so as to subdue his refractoriness]. (M.) ― -b5- And in like manner, [He prepared it in some measure; namely,] a skin in the tan, or tanning-liquid: and a spear in the viqaAf [or straitening-instrument]. (M.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) He subdued him; or rendered him submissive, (S, M, K,) and gentle; namely, a man. (M.) duyRava biAlSRagaAri occurs in a trad. as meaning (assumed tropical:) culRila [i. e. He was subdued, or rendered submissive, by abasement, or by tyranny, oppression, or injury]. (TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) It (time, or fortune,) tried him, or proved him, and rendered him experienced, and submissive. (M.)

(Msb.)

1 daASa dAS
1. daASa, aor. yadiySu, (S, M, A, K,) inf. n. dayaSaAnN (S, M, K) and dayoSN, (M,) He, or it, declined; turned aside, or from the right course or direction; syn. zaAga, (M, K, TA,) in the copies of the S, [and in the CK, and in a copy of the A,] raAga, with raMCa [instead of zAI], (TA,) and HaAda: (S, A, K:) he deviated from the road. (M, TA.) ― -b2- He (a man, M) fled (M, K) from war, or battle. (K.) ― -b3- It (anything) moved about beneath one's hand. (M, K.) You say, daASati AlsRaloEapu, (S, A,) or AlgudRapu, (S, M, K,) which is the same, (S,) inf. ns. as above, (M,) The ganglion wabbled, or moved to and fro, or went and came, (S, A, K,) being put in motion by the hand, (S,) or beneath the hand of him who put it in motion, (K,) or beneath the skin: (A:) or slipped about (tazalRaqat) between the skin and the flesh. (M.) And in like manner you say, daASati AlsRamakapu fiI AlmaMCi [The fish glided about, to and fro, in the water]. (A.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) inf. n. dayoSN, (Ibn- 'Abbád,) He was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) said of a groom. (Ibn-'Abbád.) ― -b5- And He (a man, TA) was, or became, low, or vile, after highness of rank or condition. (K.)

madiySN [app. A place where a person, or thing, declines; or turns aside, or from the right course or direction: a meaning which seems to be indicated in the S and TA]. A rájiz says,
UinRa AljawaAda qado raOaI wabiySahaA
faOayonamaA daASato yadiSo madiySahaA
[Verily the courser has seen its glistening; and wheresoever it turns aside, he turns aside at its place of turning aside]. (S, TA.)

UinRahu lamunodaASN biAlXRarRi (S, K) Verily he is one who comes suddenly, or unawares, [upon others] with evil, or mischief; one who is wont to make [others] fall [so I here render waqRaAEN] thereinto. (K.)

diko diko dk dk
diko diko a cry used in chiding domestic cocks. (K.)

diykN dyk
diykN a word of well-known meaning, (S, K,) The domestic cock; i. e. the male of the dajaAj: (Msb, TA:) pl. (of mult. TA) diyakapN and duyuwkN (S, Msb, K) and (of pauc. TA) OadoyaAkN. (K.) Sometimes it is employed as meaning dajaAjapN, (K,) [which is a n. un., applied to the male and to the female,] and is therefore made [grammatically] fem., (TA,) [though still applying to the male, agreeably with a common license in the case of a masc. noun that has a fem. syn., and vice versa,] as in the saying,
dajaAjapNwazRaqati AldRayku biSawotK zaqRaA
[And the cock muted with a sound, with vehement muting]; (K;) because the dyk is also a dajaAjap: so says ISd. (TA.) ― -b2- diyku AljinRi [The cock of the jinn, or genii;] a certain little creeping thing, or insect, (duwayobRap,) found in gardens. (Kzw.) And the surname of the poet 'Abd-Es-Selám. (K.) ＝ -A2- Solicitously affectionate; compassionate: (K:) or solicitously affectionate; affectionate to off spring; applied to a man, in the dial. of ElYemen: so accord. to El-Muärrij; who says that hence the dyk [or domestic cock] is thus called. (TA.) ＝ -A3- (assumed tropical:) The [season called] rabiyE [here meaning spring]; as though so called because of the various colours of its plants, or herbage, (K, TA,) and thus likened to the dyk [or domestic cock]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- One, and all, of the three stones on which the cooking-pot is placed: used alike as sign. and pl. (El-Muärrij, K.) ＝ -A5- The protuberant bone behind the ear of the horse: (K:) IKh explains it as meaning a certain bone behind the ear; not particularizing a horse nor any other animal. (IB.)
