1 daAna dAn dAny
1. daAna, (IAar, S, K, TA,) aor. yadiynu, (IAar, M, K, TA,) [inf. n. diynN, (which see below,) in this and most of the other senses, or the inf. n. is dayonN, and diynN is a simple subst.,] He was, or became, obedient; he obeyed: (IAar, S, M, K, TA:) this is the primary signification: or, as some say, the primary signification is the following; namely, he was, or became, abased and submissive: (IAar, * K, * TA:) or he was, or became, abased and enslaved and obedient. (S.) You say, daAna lahu, (S,) and dinotu lahu and dinotuhu, (M, TA,) He, and I, was, or became, obedient to him [&c.], or obeyed him [&c.]. (S, M, TA.) And dinotuhu, (M, K,) aor. Oadiynuhu, (K,) I served him, did service for him, or ministered to him, and acted well to him. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] He became [a servant of God, or] a Muslim. (TK.) You say, daAna biQloUisolaAmi, inf. n. diynN, with kesr, [and diyaAnapN,] He became, or made himself, a servant of God by [following the religion of] El-Islám; [i. e. he followed El-Islám as his religion;] and so tdyRn↓. (Msb.) And daAna bikacA, (S,) and dinotu bihi, (M, K,) inf. n. diyaAnapN [and diynN]; and bh tdyRn↓, [and tdyRntu bh; He, and I, followed such a thing as his, and my, religion;] (S, TA;) from diynN as signifying “ obedience. ” (S.) And dAn bidiynihimo He followed them in their religion; agreed with them, or was of one mind or opinion with them, upon, or respecting, their religion; took, or adopted, their religion as his. (TA.) And the trad. of 'Alee, maHabRapu AlEulamaMCu diynN yudaAnu QllRehu bihi [The love of the learned is a kind of religion with which God is served]. (TA.) In the phrase wa laA yadiynuwna diyna AlHaqRi [Nor follow the religion of the truth, or the true religion], in the Kur ix. 29, El-Islám is meant. (Jel.) ＝ -A2- Also He was, or became, disobedient; he disobeyed: and he was, or became, mighty, potent, powerful, or strong; or high, or elevated, in rank, condition, or state; noble, honourable, glorious, or illustrious. (IAar, T, K.) Thus it bears significations contr. to those mentioned in the first part of this paragraph. (MF.) ＝ -A3- Also, (S, M, Msb, K,) first pers. dinotu, (T, M8gh,) aor. as above, (T, S, Msb,) inf. n. dayonN, (S, Msb,) from AlmudaAyanapu, (Msb, [see 3,]) i. q. Oaxaca AldRayona, (IKt, M, Msb, K,) or [rather] Oaxaca dayonFA, (T,) [He took, or received, a loan, or the like; he borrowed: or he took, or received, or bought, upon credit; which is the meaning generally obtaining: and AidRaAna↓ and OadaAna↓ and AstdAn↓ and tdyRn↓ signify [in like manner] Oaxaca dayonFA: (K:) or the first, i. e. dAn, signifies he sought, or demanded, a loan, or the like; (ISk, S, Mgh, Msb;) as also AdRAn↓ and AstdAn↓: (S, Mgh:) and he became indebted, in debt, or under the obligation of a debt: (S:) and AdRAn↓ and OadaAna↓ and AstdAn↓ signify Oaxaca bidayonK [he took, or received, by incurring a debt; i. e. he took, or received, or bought, upon credit; like Oaxaca dayonFA]; (M;) or the first and last of these three signify Oaxaca AldRayona, and AiqotaraDa [which means the same]: but OadaAna↓ signifies he gave, or granted, what is termed dayonN [meaning a loan, or
the like: or he gave, or granted, or sold, a thing upon credit]: (TA:) accord. to Esh-Sheybánee, this last verb signifies he became entitled to a debt from others [or from another]: Lth says that it (OadaAna) signifies he was, or became, such as is termed musotadiynN; [i. e. it is syn. with AstdAn, as it is said to be in the M and K;] but [Az says,] this, which has been mentioned on the authority of some one or more by Sh, is in my opinion a mistake; OadaAna means he sold upon credit; or became entitled to a debt from others [or from another]; (T, TA;) or he sold to persons upon a limited credit, or for payment at an appointed period, so that he became entitled to a debt from them: (S:) and accord. to Sh, AdRAn↓ signifies he became much in debt. (T, TA.) El-Ahmar cites the following verse of El-'Ojeyr Es-Saloolee:
nadiynu wayaqoDiI QllRehu EanRaA waqado naraI
maSaAriEa qawomN laA yadiynuwna DuyRaEi
[We incur debt, and God pays for us; and sometimes, or often, we see the places of overthrow of a people, who incur not debt, in a state of perdition]: in the S [and the T] DuyRaEaA; but correctly as above; for the whole of the qaSiydap is maxofuwDap. (IB, TA.) And it is said in a trad., muEoriDFA AidRaAna↓, (S, K,) or, as some relate it, daAna, (K,) He bought upon credit, or borrowed, or sought or demanded a loan, of whomsoever he could, addressing himself to such as came in his way: (S, TA:) or both mean he bought upon credit avoiding payment: or he contracted a debt with every one who presented himself to him: (K, TA: [see also other explanations voce muEoriDN:]) AdRAn↓ signifies he bought upon credit: (K:) or [thus and also] the contr., i. e. he sold upon credit. (T, K.) ― -b2- It is also trans.; and so is OadaAna↓. (Msb.) You say, dinotuhu, (M, Mgh, K, [in the CK diynapN is here put for dinotuhu,]) inf. n. dayonN; (TA;) and Oadanotuhu↓ (M, Mgh, K,) inf. n. UidaAnapN; (TA;) I gave him, or granted him, to a certain period, what is termed dayonN [meaning the loan, or the like; I lent to him: or I gave him, or granted him, credit; or sold to him, upon credit]: (M, K, TA:) so that he owed a debt: (TA:) and i. q. OaqoraDotuhu [I gave him, or granted him, a loan, or the like]; (M, * Mgh, K;) as also dayRanotuhu↓: (Mgh:) or dinotuhu has this last meaning: (A 'Obeyd, S, M:) and Oadanotuhu↓ signifies I sought, or demanded, of him a loan, or the like; syn. AisotaqoraDotu minohu; as also Aisotadanotuhu↓: (M:) or dinotuhu has each of the last two meanings: (A 'Obeyd, T, Msb:) and signifies also I received from him a loan, or the like. (K.) And one says, OadinRiI↓ EaXarapa daraAhima meaning Lend thou to me ten dirhems. (S, TA.) ＝ -A4- dAnhu, (S,) first pers. dinotuhu, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. diynN (S, M, K) and dayonN, (M, K,) or the latter is the inf. n. and the former is a simple subst., (M,) also signifies He repaid, requited, compensated, or recompensed, him, (S, M, Msb, K,) bifiEolihi for his deed: and so dAynhu↓, inf. n. mudaAyanapN and diyaAnN. (M.) And dinRaAhumo We did to them like as they did to us. (Ham p. 10.) One says, kamaA tadiynu tudaAnu, (T, S, M,) a prov., (M,) meaning Like as thou repayest, or requitest, &c., thou shalt be repaid, or requited, &c.; (S, M;) i. e. according to thy deed thou shalt be repaid, or requited, &c.: (S:) or, as some say, like as thou doest, it shall be done to thee: (M:) or like as thou doest thou shalt be given, and repaid, &c. (T.) And it is said in a trad., AallRehumRa dinohumo kamaA yadiynuwnanaA, meaning O God, repay them, or requite them, &c., with [the like of] that which they do to us. (TA.) ― -b2- AallRehu layadiynu mina AljamRRaMCi liloqaronaMCi, a trad. of Selmán, means God will assuredly retaliate [for her that is hornless upon her that is horned]. (TA.) ― -b3- And one says, mano daAna nafosahu rabiHa, i. e. He who reckons with himself [gains] (Ham p. 10. [Or the verb may here have the meaning next following.]) ＝ -A5- Also, dAnhu, He abased him, (T, S, K,) and enslaved him. (T, S.) Hence, (T,) it is said in a trad., AlkayRisu mano daAna nafosahu waEamila limaA baEoda Almawoti, (S, T,) i. e. [The intelligent is] he who abases, and enslaves, himself [and works for that which shall be after death]: or, as some say, who reckons with himself: (T:) or, accord. to some, who overcomes himself. (TA.) And dAnhu, (K,) first pers. dinotuhu, (T,) signifies He made him to do that which he disliked. (AZ, T, K.) And diyna He was made to do that which he disliked. (T.) ― -b2- And dinotuhu, inf. n. diynN, I ruled, governed, or managed, him, or it. (M, TA.) And I possessed it; owned it; or exercised, or had, authority over it. (Sh, S, K, TA.) ＝ -A6- dAn, (IAar, T, K,) aor. yadiynN, (K,) [inf. n., app., diynN, which see below,] signifies also He became accustomed or habituated, or he accustomed or habituated himself, to good or to evil: (IAar, T, K:) and, accord. to Lth, (T,) diyna signifies he was accustomed or habituated: (T, M:) or, as some say, diynN signifying “ custom, ” or “ habit, ” has no verb. (M.) ＝ -A7- And He (a man, IAar, T) was, or became, smitten, or affected, by a disease. (IAar, T, K.)

2 dyRnhu dyn dynh dynp
2. dyRnhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. tadoyiynN, (S, K,) He left him to his religion; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) left him and his religion, not opposing him in that which he held allowable in his belief. (Msb.) ― -b2- He believed him: so in the saying, dyRnhu fiI AlqaDaMCi [He believed him in respect of the judgment, or judicial decision], (T, M, Mgh, *) and fiymaA bayonahu wabayona QllReha [in respect of what was between him and God]: (T, M:) but this is a conventional signification used by the professors. (Mgh.) ― -b3- dayRanotu AlHaAlifa (T, TA) I confirmed the swearer (qawRayotuhu [so in the TA, but in the T barRayotuhu, app. for barRaOotuhu, I held him, or pronounced him, to be clear, or quit, if not a mistranscription for qawRayotuhu,]) in that which he swore. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A3- dayRanotuhu Alqawoma I made him ruler, governor, or manager of the affairs, of the people, or company of men. (M.) And dyRnhu AlXRaIoCa, (T, * TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made him to possess the thing: to own it; or to exercise, or have, authority over it. (T, * TA.) El-Hotei-ah says, (T, S, M,) addressing his mother, (T,)
laqado duyRinoti Oamora baniyki HatRaI
tarakotihimu OadaqRa mina AlTRaHiyni
(T, S, M,) meaning mulRikoti [i. e. Verily thou hast been made to have the ordering of the affairs of thy sons until thou hast rendered them finer than flour]. (T, S.) And hence the saying, yudayRanu AlrRajulu Oamorahu i. e. yumalRaku [The man shall be made to have the ordering of his affair, or affairs, or case]. (Sh, T.)

3 daAyanotuhu dAynth dAyntp
3. daAyanotuhu, (S, M, A, K,) inf. n. mudaAyanapN and diyaAnN, (TA,) I dealt, or bought and sold, with him upon credit; (A, TA;) I dealt, or sold and bought, with him, giving upon credit and taking upon credit: (S, TA:) or I lent to him; or I gave him, or granted him, a loan, or the like; and he did so to me: (M, K:) or I dealt with him upon credit, giving or taking. (Ksh * and Bd in ii. 282.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A3- Each of the inf. ns. mentioned above is also syn. with muHaAkamapN [The summoning another to the judge, and litigating with him: &c.]. (TA.)

4 AdAn OdAn OdnI AdAn dAnI
4. AdAn, inf. n. UidaAnapN; as an intrans. v.: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- As a trans. v.: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in four places. ― -b3- [The following significations, namely, “ Subegit, ” and “ Pensavit, ” assigned to this verb by Golius as on the authority of the KL, and “ Voluit sibi esse servum, ” and “ Servum cepit, ” followed by an accus., assigned to it by him as on the authority of the S, I do not find in either of those works.]

5 tdyRn OdAn dAn tdyn tdynn wdI
5. tdyRn: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in three places.

6 tadaAyanuwA dAyn tdAyn tdAynwA
6. tadaAyanuwA They sold and bought, one with another, upon credit; and in like manner tadaAyanaA is said of two persons: (S:) or they took, or received, or bought, upon credit [app. one of another]: and so AidRaAyanuwA [which is a variation of the former]. (M.) UicaA tadayanotumo bidayonK, in the Kur ii. 282, means When ye deal, one with another, (Ksh, Bd, Jel, Msb,) upon credit, giving or taking, (Ksh, * Bd,) or by prepayment, (Jel, Msb,) or lending or the like, (Jel,) &c. (Msb.)

8 AidRaAna OdAn OdnI AdAn dAnI
8. AidRaAna, originally AidotaAna: see 1, in six places.

10 AstdAn AstdAn QstdAn
10. AstdAn, as an intrans. v.: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- AstdAnhu He sought, or demanded, of him what is termed dayonN [meaning a debt]: and also i. q. AisotaqoraDa minohu. (M.) See 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

dayonN dAn dyn
dayonN [is an inf. n. of 1: ― -b2- and is also a simple subst., and] properly signifies [A debt; such as] the price of a thing sold [which the purchaser is under an obligation to pay]; and a dowry [which one engages to pay]: and a loan, or the like; syn. qaroD: (Msb:) or it is [a debt] such as has an appointed time of falling due: what
has not such an appointed time is [properly, but not always,] termed qaroDN: (K:) and diynapN↓ signifies the same as dayonN (T, M, K) in the sense above explained: (K:) a valid dayno (daynN SaHiyHN) is such as does not become annulled save by payment, or by one's being declared clear, or quit: compensation in the case of a contract which a slave makes with his owner to pay him a certain sum as the price of himself and on the payment thereof to be free is not a valid dayon, because it may become annulled without payment, and without his being declared clear, or quit; that is, by the slave's being unable to pay it: (KT:) in the language of the law, but not in the proper language, dayonN is also applied to (assumed tropical:) [a debt incurred by] a thing taken unjustly, injuriously, or by violence; as being likened to a dayon properly so called: (Msb:) and it signifies also anything that is not present: [app. meaning anything to be paid, or done, at a future time:] (M, K:) the pl. [of pauc.] is OadoyunN (Lh, M, K) and [of mult.] duyuwnN (S, M, K) [and in the CK is added and diynapN, with kesr; but this is a mistranscription for dinotuhu, as syn. with Oadanotuhu, which follows it, connected therewith by wa]: the pl. of diynapN↓ is diyanN. (TA.) You say, maA Oakovra dayonahu and diynatahu↓ [How great in amount. is his debt!]; both meaning the same. (AZ, T.) And jiYotu liTalabi AldRiynapi↓ i. e. AldRayoni [I came for the demanding of the debt]. (AZ, T.) And Ealayohi dayonN [On him lies a debt; i. e. he owes a debt]: and lahu dayonN [To him is due a debt; i. e. he has a debt owed to him]. (S, TA.) And AiXotaraI biAldRayoni [He bought upon credit]: (K:) and Oaxaca AldRayona (IKt, M, Msb, K) or [rather] Oaxaca dayonFA [signifies the same; or he took, or received, upon credit: or he took, or received, a loan, or the like; he borrowed]: (T, K:) and Oaxaca bidayonK [likewise signifies the same; or he took, or received, by incurring a debt]. (M.) And baAEa biAldRayoni [He sold upon credit]: (K:) and biEovuhu bidayonK (TA) or bidiynapK↓ (S) [I sold to him upon credit]: and OaEoTayotuhu AldRayona [signifies the same; or I gave him, or granted him, credit: or I gave him, or granted him, the loan, or the like]. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) Death; (K, TA;) because it is a dayon [or debt] which every one must pay when [the angel who is] the demander of its payment comes. (TA.) And hence the prov., ramaAhu QllRehu bidayonihi (tropical:) [May God smite him with his death]. (TA.) ― -b4- Thaalebeh Ibn-'Obeyd says, describing palm-trees,
taDamRanu AlHaAjaAti AlEiyaAli wa Dayofihimo
wamahomaA taDamRano mino duyuwnihimo taqoDi
[They comprise the wants of the household and of their guest; and whatever they comprise of their debts, they pay]; by the duyuwn meaning what is obtained of their fruit that is gathered. (M, TA.)

diynN dAn dyn
diynN [is an inf. n. of 1: and is also used as a simple subst., signifying] Obedience; (T, S, M, K;) as also diynapN↓: (K: [in the M it is said, without any restriction, that diynapN is like diynN:]) this is its primary meaning: and its pl. is OadoyaAnN: or, as some say, its primary meaning is that next following: (TA:) a state of abasement, (M, K, TA,) and submissiveness. (TA.) AldRiynu lilRehi means Obedience to, and the service of, God. (T, K. *) And the saying, in the Kur [iv. 124], wa mano OaHosanu diynFA mimano Oasolama wajohahu lilRehi means [And who is better] in obedience [than he who resigns himself to God?] (Er-Rághib, TA.) In like manner, also, in the same [ii. 257], laA UikoraAha fiI AldRiyni means [There shall be no compulsion] in obedience. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- A religion: (K, and in one of my copies of the S:) pl. as above: (S:) so termed as implying obedience, and submission to the law: [for ex.,] it is said in the Kur [iii. 17], UinRa AldRiyna Einoda QllRehi QloUisolaAmu [Verily the only true religion in the sight of God is El-Islám]. (TA.) AldRiynu is a name for That whereby one serves God. (S, * K.) [It is applied to Religion, in the widest sense of this term, practical and doctrinal: thus comprehending AlUiymaAnu, which means “ religious belief. ”] And it [particularly] signifies [The religion of] El-Islám. (M, K.) And The religious law of God; consisting of such ordinances as those of fasting and prayer and pilgrimage and the giving of the poor-rate, and the other acts of piety, or of obedience to God, or of duty to Him and to men; syn. AlXRariyEapu. (TA.) And The belief in the unity of God. (K.) And Piety, or pious fear, and abstinence from unlawful things; syn. AlwaraEu. (S, K.) ― -b3- Also A particular law; a statute; or an ordinance; syn. HukomN (K, and Jel in xii. 76) and qaDaMCN [which signifies the same as HukomN]. (Katádeh, T, K.) It is said in the Kur [xii. 76], maA kaAna liyaOoxuca OaxaAhu fiI diyni Qlomaliki, meaning He (Joseph) was not to take his brother as a slave for the theft according to the law of the king of Egypt; i. e., fiI Hukomi maliki miSora, (Jel,) or fIqaDaAYihi; (Katádeh, T;) for his punishment according to him was beating, and a fine of twice the value of the thing stolen; not enslavement: (Jel:) or, accord. to ElUmawee, the meaning is, in the dominion of the King. (T.) ― -b4- [A system of usages, or rites and ceremonies &c., inherited from a series of ancestors.] It is said in a trad., of the Prophet, kaAna EalaI diyni qawomihi, meaning He used to conform with the old usages obtaining among his people, inherited from Abraham and Ishmael, in respect of their pilgrimage and their marriagecustoms (IAth, K, TA) and their inheritances (IAth, TA) and their modes of buying and selling and their ways of acting, (IAth, K, TA,) and other ordinances of the faith [&c.]; (IAth, TA;) but as to the belief in the unity of God, they had altered it; and the Prophet held no other belief than it: (IAth, K, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning here is, their dispositions, in respect of generosity and courage; from diynN in the sense next following. (TA.) ― -b5- Custom, or habit; (AZ, T, S, M, K;) as also diynapN↓: (M, * TA:) and business: (S, TA:) pl., as above, OadoyaAnN. (M, TA.) This, also, has been said to be the primary signification. (TA.) One says, maA zaAla celika diyniI That has not ceased to be my custom, or habit. (T, TA.) ― -b6- A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like. (K.) ― -b7- I. q. tadobiyrN [app. as meaning Management, conduct, or regulation, of affairs]. (K.) ― -b8- State, condition, or case. (S, M, K.) ISh says, I asked an Arab of the desert respecting a thing, and he said to me, lawo laqiytaniI EalaI dinK gayori hecihi laOaxobarotuka [Hadst thou found me in a state other than this, I had informed thee]. (S, M.) ― -b9- A property, such as is an unknown cause of a known effect; syn. xaASRiyRapN. (KL. [The significations of “ Via ” and “ Signum ” and “ Opera, ” mentioned by Golius as from the KL, I do not find in my copy of that work.]) ＝ -A2- Disobedience. (S, K.) [Thus it bears a signification the contr. of that first mentioned in this paragraph.] ＝ -A3- Repayment, requital, compensation, or recompense: (S, M, K:) or, as some say, such as is proportioned to the deed of him who is its object. (TA.) Hence, maAliki yawomi AldRiyni, i. e. [The King] of the day of requital, in the Kur [i. 3]: (M, T, TA:) or the meaning in this instance is the next but one of those here following. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Retaliation, by slaying for slaying, or wounding for wounding, or mutilating for mutilating. (TA.) ― -b3- A reckoning. (T, S, M, K.) [See the sentence next but one above.] Hence, in the Kur [ix. 36], celika AldRiynu AlqayRimu [is said to mean] That is the right, correct, or true, reckoning. (T, TA.) ＝ -A4- Compulsion against the will: (K:) subdual, subjection, or subjugation; ascendency: sovereign, or ruling, power; or power of dominion: (S, K:) mastership, or ownership; or the exercise, or possession, of authority. (K, TA.) ＝ -A5- A disease: (Lh, IAar, T, S, M, K:) or, accord. to El-Mufaddal, an old disease. (IAar, T.) ＝ -A6- [It is said to signify also] A constant, or a gentle, rain; as also diynapN↓: (K:) accord. to the book of Lth, [by which is meant the 'Eyn,] (T,) rain that has been constantly, (T,) or usually, (K,) recurring in a place: (T, K:) but this is a mistake of Lth, or of some one who has added it in his book: a verse of Et- Tirimmáh, there cited as an ex., ends with wadiyni, which is in that instance syn. with mawoduwn, meaning “ moistened; ” its w being the primal radical, not the conjunction wa; and diynN as meaning any kind of rain being unknown. (T, TA.) ＝ -A7- See also daAYinN.

dayonapN dyn dynh dynp
dayonapN, (so in the TT, as from the T,) or diynapN↓, with kesr, (so in the TA,) A cause of death. (T, TA.)

diynapN dyn dynh dynp
diynapN: see dayonN, in five places: ＝ -A2- and diynN, in three places: ＝ -A3- and dayonapN.

dayRinN dAn dyn
dayRinN Religious; or one who makes himself a servant of God; (S, Msb;) as also mutadayRinN↓. (S.)

dayRaAnN dyAn
dayRaAnN A requiter, (S, M, K,) who neglects not any deed, but requites it, with good and with evil; (K, TA;) in this sense, with the article Al, applied as an epithet to God: (S, M, TA:) a subduer; (T, K;) applied to a man in this sense; (T;) and also, in the same sense, with the article
Al, to God: (TA:) a judge; a ruler, or governor; (T, K;) in these senses, likewise, applied to a man; and, with the article Al, to God: (T:) a manager, a conducter, or an orderer, (S, M, K,) of affairs of another. (S.)

daAYinN c
daAYinN A debtor; (S, M, Msb, * K;) as also madiynN↓ and madoyuwnN↓, (S, * M, Msb, * K,) this last of the dial. of Temeem, (M,) and mudaAnN↓ (M, K) and mudRaAnN↓: (K:) or all of these, (M, K,) or madoyuwnN↓, (S, TA,) one much in debt: (S, M, K, TA:) and mudRaAnN↓, constantly in debt: (Sh, T:) and daAYinN signifies one who takes, or receives, a loan, or the like; who borrows; or who takes, or receives, or buys, upon credit: (Sh, T, Msb:) and also one who repays a debt: (Sh, T, TA:) thus bearing two contr. meanings: (TA:) or also one who gives, or grants, credit; or sells upon credit: (Msb:) pl. daAYinuwna, with which diynN↓ is syn. [as a quasi-pl. n.], as in the saying of a poet,
wakaAnaAlnRaAsu UilRaA naHonu diynaA
[And the people, except us, were debtors]. (S.)

mudaAnN mdAn
mudaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

madiynN mdyn
madiynN: see daAYinN. ＝ -A2- [Also Repaid, requited, compensated, or recompensed: and reckoned with.] OaYinRaA lamadiynuwna, in the Kur [xxxvii. 51], means Shall we indeed be requited, and reckoned with? (S, TA.) [See also what follows, in two places.] ＝ -A3- Possessed; owned; had, or held, under authority: (TA:) [and hence,] a slave; fem. with p: (S, M, K:) [or] so called because abased by work. (K.) gayora madiyniyna, in the Kur [lvi. 85], accord. to Zj, means Not held under authority: but Fr says, I have also heard [it explained as meaning] not requited [for your deeds]. (T.) [And it is said that] OaYinRaA lamadiynuwnna [mentioned above] means AYnRA lamamoluwkuwna [i. e. Shall we indeed be held in possession, or under authority, as servants of God?]. (M.)

madiynapN mdyn mdynh mdynp
madiynapN A city; syn. miSorN: (S, K:) so called because had, or held, in possession, or under authority. (S, * TA.) [See also art. mdn.] ― -b2- OanaA Qbonu madiynatihaA means I am he who is acquainted with it; (IAar, T, * M, * K;) like Abn bajodatihaA [q. v.]. (IAar, T.)

mudRaAnN mdAn
mudRaAnN: see daAYinN, in two places.

midoyaAnN mdyAn
midoyaAnN, applied to a man, (S, M, K,) and also to a woman, (M, K,) without p, (M,) One who gives, or grants, loans, or the like, (Sh, T, M, K,) to men, (M,) much, or often; (Sh, T, K:) and also, (Sh, T, K,) if you will, (Sh, T,) one who seeks, or demands, loans, or the like, much, or often: (Sh, T, K:) thus bearing two contr. significations: (K:) or one whose custom it is to take, or receive, by incurring debt, or to buy upon credit; and, to seek, or demand, loans, or the like: (S:) or it is an intensive epithet, signifying one having [many] debts: (IAth, TA:) pl. madaAyiynu, (M, K,) masc. and fem. (TA.)

madoyuwnN mdywn
madoyuwnN: see daAYinN, in two places.

mutadayRinN mtdyn
mutadayRinN: see dayinN.
